age: 23. gender: M.  
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___

History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with obesity, HTN, DM2, cannabis use
and other issues who presented to the ED with nausea/vomiting. 
___ is very sleepy on my evaluation and not able to provide a
detailed history, but ___ confirms that the symptoms have been
ongoing since ___.  ___ was previously on Metformin and
Lisinopril but has not seen a PCP in ___ long time and does not
remember who his PCP ___.  ___ confirms that ___ has never been on
insulin.  Regarding cannabis use, ___ tells me ___ smokes
approximately 4x per week.  ___ has not had diarrhea, but ___ has
had worsening upper abdominal pain.  ___ has not had blood in the
stool or vomitus.  Reviewing his medication history tab in OMR,
___ was prescribed Amoxicillin and Clarithromycin, likely for H.
pylori, in ___.  In the ED, ___ also reported predominantly 
LUQ
abdominal pain that spreads across the abdomen.  ___ endorsed
daily vomiting from this.  ___ also reported frequent
constipation, but that his last BM was the morning of admission. 

Throwing up typically makes the pain and nausea better ___ does
not report that hot showers improve his sytmptoms).  In the ED 
___
also reported SOB due to pain, but now his breathing is
comfortable.  Denies weight loss, fevers but endorses occasional
chills.  

In the ED, initial VS were 98.4 73 144/77 20 100% RA.  Exam
notable for acute distress and upper abdominal tenderness to
palpation with hypoactive bowel sounds.  Labs were notable for 
WBC 7.5 with 84% PMNs, Hgb 13.5, plts 107, BUN/Cr ___, HCO3 18
but lytes otherwise WNL, LFTs and lipase WNL, Lactate 1.2, VBG
___, UA with 80 ketones, 30 protein, and few 
bacteria,
Hgb A1c 7.2.  EKG with a 1 mm ST segment elevation in V2 & V3
(troponins not sent), Abdomen XR showed normal bowel gas 
pattern,
CT abdomen/pelvis showed hepatic steatosis and borderline
splenomegaly to 13 cm but no other acute pathology.  ___ received
2L NS, Ondansetron 4 mg x2, Lorazepam 1 mg IV x2, Famotidine 20
mg, Acetaminophen 1g, Haloperidol 2.5 mg IV, and topical
Capsaicin and was admitted for ongoing oral intolerance.  In the
ED ___ remained afebrile (Tm 99.5) and BP ranged from
120-160/80-110s.  ___ was admitted for ongoing symptom control.

On arrival to the floor, the patient reports that his abdominal
pain and nausea have improved and complains only of mild
headache.

ROS: A 10-point review of systems was performed and was negative
with the exception of those systems noted in the HPI.

MENTATION: alert and cooperative. Oriented to person and place

___ Gastroenterology EGD 
Normal esophagus, duodenum. Mild erythema in antrum and moderate 
erythema and congestion in stomach body. Biopsies taken.

___
EXAMINATION:  CT abdomen and pelvis with contrast 
  
INDICATION:  ___ year old man with IDDM presenting with 
intermittent episodes 
of intense abdominal pain associated w/ nausea and vomiting// 
evaluate for 
acute intra-abdominal process such as ischemia or infection 
  
TECHNIQUE:   Single phase split bolus contrast: MDCT axial 
images were 
acquired through the abdomen and pelvis following intravenous 
contrast 
administration with split bolus technique. 
Oral contrast was not administered. 
Coronal and sagittal reformations were performed and reviewed on 
PACS. 
  
DOSE:  Acquisition sequence: 
   1) Stationary Acquisition 0.5 s, 1.0 cm; CTDIvol = 1.2 mGy 
(Body) DLP = 1.2 
mGy-cm. 
   2) Stationary Acquisition 6.5 s, 1.0 cm; CTDIvol = 15.0 mGy 
(Body) DLP = 
15.0 mGy-cm. 
   3) Spiral Acquisition 14.8 s, 51.1 cm; CTDIvol = 19.9 mGy 
(Body) DLP = 
989.8 mGy-cm. 
 Total DLP (Body) = 1,020 mGy-cm. 
  
COMPARISON:  None. 
  
FINDINGS:  
  
The study is limited due to motion artifact. 
  
LOWER CHEST: Visualized lung fields are within normal limits. 
There is no 
evidence of pleural or pericardial effusion. 
  
ABDOMEN: 
  
HEPATOBILIARY: The liver demonstrates homogenous low attenuation 
throughout, 
suggestive of hepatic steatosis.  There is no evidence of focal 
lesions.  
There is no evidence of intrahepatic or extrahepatic biliary 
dilatation.  The 
gallbladder is within normal limits. 
  
PANCREAS: The pancreas has normal attenuation throughout, 
without evidence of 
focal lesions or pancreatic ductal dilatation.  There is no 
peripancreatic 
stranding. 
  
SPLEEN: The spleen is borderline enlarged measuring up to 13 cm 
in 
craniocaudal dimension.  Spleen demonstrates attenuation 
throughout, without 
evidence of focal lesions. 
  
ADRENALS: The right and left adrenal glands are normal in size 
and shape. 
  
URINARY: The kidneys are of normal and symmetric size with 
normal nephrogram.  
There is no evidence of focal renal lesions or hydronephrosis.  
There is no 
perinephric abnormality. 
  
GASTROINTESTINAL: The stomach is unremarkable.  Small bowel 
loops demonstrate 
normal caliber, wall thickness, and enhancement throughout.  The 
colon and 
rectum are within normal limits.  The appendix is not 
visualized. 
  
PELVIS: The urinary bladder and distal ureters are unremarkable. 
 There is no 
free fluid in the pelvis. 
  
REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS: The prostate and seminal vesicles are 
normal. 
  
LYMPH NODES: There is no retroperitoneal or mesenteric 
lymphadenopathy.  There 
is no pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy. 
  
VASCULAR: There is no abdominal aortic aneurysm.  No 
atherosclerotic disease 
is noted. 
  
BONES: There is no evidence of worrisome osseous lesions or 
acute fracture. 
  
SOFT TISSUES: There is mild diffuse anasarca.  There is fatty 
atrophy of the 
bilateral gluteus maximus musculature. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. No acute intra-abdominal process to explain the patient's 
symptoms. 
2. Diffuse anasarca. 
3. Hepatic steatosis. 
4. Borderline enlarged spleen. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with obesity, HTN, NIDDM2,
cannabis use, past H pylori infection ___ who presented to 
the
ED with nausea/vomiting.  

# Nausea/Vomiting with Abdominal Pain:
# History of H pylori infection and treatment course ___
-RUQ US here unremarkable. CT A/P here without intraabdominal
pathology evidence.
-___ reports ___ had positive urease breath test in ___ with 
his
PCP ___ at ___ ___ and ___ did receive amoxicillin/clav with clarithromycin
for 2 weeks. His symptoms of nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain at
that time did improve somewhat, but has recurred since.
-Urine tox here negative. LFT unremarkable and negative lipase.
-Continue prn antiemetics, pain regimen at home
-Appreciate GI recommendations. EGD completed on ___ showing
no evidence of gastritis, or any mechanical gastric outlet
obstruction. Biopsies were taken. 
-Stool H pylori testing here was sent and pending at time of 
discharge.
-Patient will continue PPI PO BID empirically x 6 weeks pending 
these biopsies for recurrent H
pylori infection (then gastroparesis or cannabinoid hyperemesis
is to be considered if negative).  
  
# NIDDM2
- Not taking metformin at home 
- Restarted metformin at discharge

# Hepatic steatosis on CT A/P: No evidence of steatohepatitis
given normal
LFTs
- Outpatient follow-up needed
- RUQ US was unremarkable

# Hypertension with proteinuria: His young age raises concern 
for
secondary causes of hypertension, but we do not have records of
whether ___ has been adequately worked up for secondary causes.
- UTox unremarkable
- Uptitrated the lisinopril to 40 mg once daily
- Elevated urine protein/creatinine
- Should have nephrology referral as outpatient. 

#elevated BNP and anasarca on CT scan 
-Negative troponins and unremarkable EKG
-Definitely needs outpatient echocardiogram and workup for 
possible chronic heart failure. ___ does not have shortness of 
breath or chest pain or palpitations or evidence of arrhythmia 
while in the hospital. 

I left a voicemail to patient's PCP to ask them to call me back 
to relay all the above information verbally.

coordination.

Discharge Instructions:
Instructions: Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure to be a part of your ___ team at ___ 
___.

====================================
Why did you come to the hospital? 
====================================

-You had abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting

====================================
What happened at the hospital? 
====================================

-You underwent upper endoscopy (EGD) test to look at the stomach 
area inside. The area looked normal. Biopsies were taken to look 
at tissue samples under a microscope. The results will take days 
to come back. Your new GI doctor ___ inform you of the results.
-The abdominal pain explanation is still unclear at time of 
discharge. The biopsy results are key to understanding if you 
may have a recurrent H pylori infection or not, as the possible 
cause of your pain.

==================================================
What needs to happen when you leave the hospital? 
==================================================

-For the abdominal pain: You will trial an acid reducing pill 
(pantoprazole) for 6 weeks as prescribed. Eat small regular 
meals and take anti-nausea meds as needed.

-Please set up a follow up appointment with your PCP and GI 
doctor as instructed. 

-You must see your PCP to have ___ referral to a kidney specialist 
(nephrologist) because of your high blood pressure at such a 
young age and that can be damaging your kidneys slowly over 
time.

-You must see your PCP to have ___ referral to a cardiologist, as 
there was evidence of heart disease based on bloodwork and the 
CT scan you had. This is absolutely important for you to get 
this investigated further in the office.

-For your diabetes: You need to take metformin to keep your 
blood sugars controlled

It was a pleasure taking ___ of you during your stay! 

Sincerely, 

Your ___ team  

 
Followup Instructions:
___
target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 23-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain and nausea. He has a history of hypertension, diabetes type 2, and obesity. He was previously on medications such as metformin and lisinopril, but had not seen a primary care physician in a long time. He also uses cannabis regularly. 

The patient's symptoms included nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain, which improved with vomiting. He also reported constipation, but his last bowel movement was the morning of admission. 

The patient's physical examination was notable for acute distress and upper abdominal tenderness to palpation with hypoactive bowel sounds. Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 7.5 with 84% polymorphonuclear cells, hemoglobin of 13.5, and platelet count of 107. 

The patient underwent an endoscopy (EGD) which showed mild erythema in the antrum and moderate erythema and congestion in the stomach body. Biopsies were taken. 

The patient's diagnosis was not acute intra-abdominal process, but rather diffuse anasarca, hepatic steatosis, and borderline enlarged spleen. 

At discharge, the patient was prescribed medications including Famotidine, Acetaminophen, and Haloperidol. ||endoftext||

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 74-year-old female who was admitted with a chief complaint of ischemic bowel. She has a history of scleroderma, gastric dysmotility, and chronic parenteral nutrition. She was transferred from another hospital after presenting with fevers and chills, and was found to be hypotensive upon arrival. She required aggressive volume resuscitation and pressor support to maintain a systolic blood pressure above 90. Her ostomy output was bloody, and she reported not feeling well and having fevers and chills.

The patient underwent several surgeries, including an extended right colectomy, cholecystectomy, and ileostomy. She also had a right hepatic laceration treated with argon beam coagulation and packing. She was found to have extensive circumferential bowel wall thickening on CT scan, which was highly concerning for ischemic bowel.

The patient's diagnosis was ischemic bowel, and she was also diagnosed with sepsis. She was treated with antibiotics and pressor support, and her white count normalized. She was discharged to a rehabilitation facility with a tracheostomy, gastrostomy, and ileostomy, and was instructed to follow up with her doctor and to resume her regular medications.

The patient's medications at discharge included insulin, miconazole, lansoprazole, pregabalin, escitalopram, levothyroxine, metoprolol, and heparin. She was also instructed to follow up with lab work and to add fat back to her TPN when her liver enzymes trended down. ||endoftext||

night
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
 ___ will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

MEDICATION:
 Take aspirin as instructed 
 Follow your discharge medication instructions

ACTIVITIES:
 No driving until post-op visit and ___ are no longer taking 
pain medications
 Unless ___ were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

 ___ should get up every day, get dressed and walk
 ___ should gradually increase your activity
 ___ may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
 Increase your activities as ___ can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 ___ may shower (unless ___ have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless ___ have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
 Redness that extends away from your incision
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

 
Followup Instructions:
___

She also has diabetes mellitus, type 2, and hyperlipidemia. The patient's past medical history includes a left stent placement, coronary artery disease, and a hysterectomy. The patient's presenting symptoms included shortness of breath, which began at 5 a.m. that morning. She had no associated chest pain, nausea, diaphoresis, dizziness, or lightheadedness. Her vital signs upon admission were normal, and she was treated with aspirin and admitted directly to dialysis.

The patient's diagnosis was acute on chronic diastolic heart failure, ESRD on HD, hypertensive urgency, and urinary tract infection. She was treated with hemodialysis, her usual blood pressure medications, and antibiotics for her urinary tract infection. She was also prescribed a sliding scale of insulin to cover her diabetes.

The patient's medications at discharge included amiodarone, calcium acetate, clonidine, epoetin alfa, furosemide, isosorbide mononitrate, lidocaine, lisinopril, metoprolol tartrate, simvastatin, and acetaminophen. ||endoftext||

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left Frontal Brain Mass

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
WOUND CARE:
You or a family member should inspect your wound every day and 
report any of the following problems to your physician. 
Keep your incision clean and dry.
You may wash your hair with a mild shampoo 24 hours after your 
sutures are removed.
Do NOT apply any lotions, ointments or other products to your 
incision.   
DO NOT DRIVE until you are seen at the first follow up 
appointment.
Do not lift objects over 10 pounds until approved by your 
physician.

DIET
Usually no special diet is prescribed after a craniotomy. A 
normal well balanced diet is recommended for recovery, and you 
should resume any specially prescribed diet you were eating 
before your surgery.  Be sure however, to remain well hydrated, 
and increase your consumption of fiber, as pain medications may 
cause constipation. 

MEDICATIONS:
Take all of your medications as ordered.  You do not have to 
take pain medication unless it is needed.  It is important that 
you are able to cough, breathe deeply, and is comfortable enough 
to walk.   
Do not use alcohol while taking pain medication. 
Medications that may be prescribed include: 
oNarcotic pain medication such as Dilaudid (hydromorphone).  
oAn over the counter stool softener for constipation (Colace or 
Docusate). If you become constipated, try products such as 
Dulcolax, Milk of Magnesia, first, and then Magnesium Citrate or 
Fleets enema if needed). Often times, pain medication and 
anesthesia can cause constipation.
If you have been prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin) for 
anti-seizure medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with 
laboratory blood drawing in one week.  This can be drawn at your 
PCPs office, but please have the results faxed to ___. 
If you have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will 
not require blood work monitoring.
If you were on a medication such as Coumadin (Warfarin), or 
Plavix (clopidogrel), or Aspirin, prior to your surgery, you 
should not resume taking this until cleared by your doctor.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc, as this can increase your chances of bleeding. 
If you are being sent home on steroid medication, make sure 
you are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, 
Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach 
irritation.  Make sure to take your steroid medication with 
meals, or a glass of milk. 

ACTIVITY:
The first few weeks after you are discharged you may feel tired 
or fatigued. This is normal. You should become a little stronger 
every day. Activity is the most important measure you can take 
to prevent complications and to begin to feel like yourself 
again. In general:
Follow the activity instructions given to you by your doctor 
and therapist.
Increase your activity slowly; do not do too much because you 
are feeling good.
You may resume sexual activity as your tolerance allows.
If you feel light headed or fatigued after increasing 
activity, rest, decrease the amount of activity that you do, and 
begin building your tolerance to activity more slowly.
DO NOT DRIVE until you speak with your physician.
Do not lift objects over 10 pounds until approved by your 
physician.
Avoid any activity that causes you to hold your breath and 
push, for example weight lifting, lifting or moving heavy 
objects, or straining at stool.
Do your breathing exercises every two hours.  
Use your incentive spirometer 10 times every hour,  that you 
are awake.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 45-year-old male who was admitted to the neurosurgery service due to his wife's concern that he was not acting quite right. He had a history of metastatic esophageal cancer and was found to have a left frontal mass. The patient underwent a left frontal craniotomy and tumor resection. His past medical history includes stage III esophageal cancer, diverticulitis, ventral hernia, dilated aortic root, and Marfan's traits. He has allergies to pollen and hayfever. The patient's diagnosis is a left frontal brain mass. At discharge, he was prescribed medications including levetiracetam, pantoprazole, oxycodone-acetaminophen, dexamethasone, docusate sodium, and senna. He was discharged home with instructions to follow a normal diet, take his medications as ordered, and avoid lifting heavy objects or driving until cleared by his physician. ||endoftext||

His oxygen saturations were checked and he was hypoxic to 73% on 
RA.  He did not come back to normal with supplemental oxygen and 
eventually was placed on a non-rebreather with his oxygen levels 
rising to 86%.  He continued to deny fever, chest pain, 
abdominal pain, or other symptoms and had no further episodes of 
emesis.  At baseline the wife reports that he is able to 
recognize people but cannot follow a TV show plot, identify the 
date, or engage in higher level thinking.  He was sent to ___ 
for further management.
.
In our ED he was found to be hypoxic and his labs were 
significant for only mild renal insufficiency.  His CXR showed a 
? RML infiltrate vs CHF and he was given zosyn, CTX, and 
clindamycin for a presumed aspiration event.  He was initially 
DNR/DNI but his code status was changed to DNR/OK to intubate 
after discussion with the patient and his wife.  He was placed 
on BiPAP and tolerated this well with an improved ABG and was 
admitted to the ICU for further evaluation and management.  
.
On the floor, he was tachypneic and sleepy but arousable and was 
unable to be interviewed secondary to his mask.  He denied pain, 
nausea, or SOB.

IMPRESSION:
1. Bibasilar atelectasis with superimposed consolidation likely 
aspiration or pneumonia.
2. Probable tracheomalacia; for confirmation a dedicated CT 
examination of the trachea would be recommended if clinically 
warranted.
3. Incidental right adrenal gland lesion which is partially 
enhancing and should be further evaluated by another examination 
such as a dedicated adrenal MRI study or CT examination.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
#Respiratory failure - Patient was initially admitted to the 
hospital and required intubation in the setting of respiratory 
failure.  The patient had an aspiration pneumonia.  The patient 
was noted to be positive for influenza and it was likely in this 
setting that he vomited and aspirated causing the hypoxia noted 
at his nursing home.  He had a difficult course of extubation 
because of copious secretions.  A broncoscopy was performed 
which showed some significant tracheitis.  There was a concern 
for HSV infections.  He completed a course of steroids and 
acyclovir for this tracheitis.  He also completed a course of 
tamiflu and Vanc/Zosyn for his aspiration pneumonia.  All of 
these were completed by the time of discharge.  He was extubated 
and called out to the medicine floor on 3L NC.  His respiratory 
status continued to improve and his oxygen requirement decrease. 
 His oxygen will continue to be weaned at this long term care 
facility. 
.  
#Cardiovascular - Patient was briefly hypotensive in unit, 
requiring pressors in the setting of intubation.  His pressures 
stablized and at the time of call out, he was restarted on his 
midodrine.  His lasix was also resumed.  He does not appear 
volume overloaded.  
.  
#Parkinsons's Disease - Continued home dosing of meds  
.  
#Nutrition - Patient had some difficulty swallowing after his 
extubation. A NG tube was placed and he recieved tube feeds.  
Speech and swallow saw the patient and cleared the patient for a 
regular diet, now straws with 1:1 supervision and assistance as 
needed.  He can also take whole pills in some puree.  His 
nutritional status should be closely monitored at his long term 
care facility to ensure he is taking enough nutrition.
.
#Incidental Findings on CT:  Patient noted to have a right 
adrenal lesion.  The radiologists recommended a dedicated 
adrenal MRI or CT scan for further evaluation.  Probably 
tracheomalacia was also noted.  If needed, this could be further 
evaluated in the future with a dedicated CT of the trachea.  
These findings should be addressed and monitored by his primary 
care physician.
.
#GERD - continued PPI  
.

The patient's discharge diagnosis was aspiration pneumonia and Parkinson's disease. His discharge condition was stable, on oxygen but with decreased requirement, and his respiratory status had improved. He was discharged to an extended care facility and was instructed to follow up with his primary care physician. ||endoftext||

She has a history of anxiety, which causes her to experience symptoms such as cough, palpitations, and gastrointestinal complaints. She also has a history of migraine with aura, hemorrhoids, and retinal detachment. The patient has allergies to iodine and latex.

The patient underwent a left video-assisted basilar segmentectomy and tolerated the procedure well. She was given pain medication and was able to transition to oral pain medication. The patient was also given prophylactic heparin and was encouraged to ambulate and get up as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile, and tolerating a regular diet. She was prescribed several medications, including acetaminophen, losartan, hydrochlorothiazide, fluticasone, simvastatin, omeprazole, oxycodone, lorazepam, docusate sodium, magnesium hydroxide, and zolpidem.

The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with her doctor if she experiences any symptoms such as fever, shortness of breath, or chest pain. She was also advised to take acetaminophen for pain and to avoid lifting heavy objects or engaging in strenuous activities until her incision has fully healed. ||endoftext||

He has a history of cirrhosis, ascites, and portal hypertension, and has undergone several previous hospitalizations for similar symptoms. He is also a heavy drinker and has a history of chronic anemia.

On admission, the patient's vital signs were stable, and his physical examination revealed a diffusely tender abdomen, flank tenderness, and yellow stool in his urostomy and ileal conduit. Laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, as well as abnormal liver function tests.

The patient was treated with antibiotics and diuretics, and his condition improved. He was discharged with a diagnosis of pyelonephritis and was prescribed medications to manage his symptoms.

The patient's allergies include aspirin, Tylenol, and ibuprofen. He has a history of bleeding from his ileal conduit and has undergone several previous procedures, including a TIPS procedure.

The patient's social history is significant for active ethanol abuse, and his family history is significant for colon cancer, diabetes, and hypertension.

The patient's physical examination on discharge revealed a stable vital sign, a soft and diffusely tender abdomen, and a palpable liver. His laboratory results showed improvement in his liver function tests and a normal platelet count.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, and he is being discharged with a plan for further management of his symptoms. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is an ___ year old Man with a history of metastatic 
prostate cancer to the T-spine presents with one day of painless 
hematuria. 
.
# Hematuria/UTI:  The patient had a positive UA on admission. CT 
of the Pelvis demonstrated hyperdense material in the bladder. 
The patient was started on Levaquin in the ED for UTI and was 
switched to ciprofloxacin.  A three way catheter for continuous 
bladder irrigation was placed.   The hematuria resolved over 
initial 24 hours of admission however, it returned within 
several hours of discontinuing the irrigation. Hematocrit was 
stable.  Urology was consulted and recommended resumption of 
continuous irrigation and lowering of the patient's home lovenox 
to once daily.  His hematuria subsequently resolved.  Cultures 
from admission eventually grew Proteus.  The patient was 
discharged on ciprofloxacin for a completion of a 10 day course. 

.  
# Pain/Difficulty Ambulating - The patient reported bilateral 
lower extremity pain and increased difficulty with ambulation 
requiring the use of a walker.  While his neurological exam was 
mostly unremarkable, an MRI of the spine demonstrated new 
epidural disease at L4 level with high-grade thecal sac 
compression and spinal stenosis.  The patient was started on 
dexamethasone and radiation oncology was consulted.  The patient 
underwent 1 round of spinal radiation for palliation of 
symptoms.  His symptoms improved and he demonstrated improved 
symptoms and walker-free ambulation.  He was discharged on a 
post radiation steroid taper.
.
# Altered mental status: During his hospitalization, the patient 
had mild confusion and agitation.  It was felt that this was 
consistent with either infectious or drug induced delirium, 
given the patients concurrent UTI and steroid use.  His symptoms 
resolved over 24 hours and he was alert and oriented at the time 
of discharge.  He was discharged home with ___ services.
.
# Prostate cancer: The patient underwent radiation as above.  In 
addition, per his outpatient oncologist the patient was 
discharged on high-dose Casodex at 150 mg daily.  He was 
scheduled for follow up with Dr. ___ on ___.  
.  
# Hypertension: The patient was noted to be moderately 
hypertensive (SBPs in 180s) despite his home antihypertensive 
regimen.  He was started on Metoprolol with modest improvement. 
The need for this medication or further adjustments in dose 
should continue to be monitored by his outpatient providers.
.  
# DVT: The patient had a history of DVT in ___.  On admission, 
he was taking 80mg BID.  Given his hematuria, this was lowered 
to 80mg once a day and the patient was instructed to continue 
this medication at this new dose.

coronary artery disease involving the left anterior descending 
artery. Mild aortic regurgitation. No pericardial effusion.

___ CARDIAC CATHETERIZATION:
Coronary angiography: right dominant
  LMCA: normal
  LAD: subtotal occlusion after proximal stents followed by long
segment of severe diffuse disease and then total occlusion at 
the
origin of the more distal stent(s). No distal collateral 
filling.
  LCX: focal eccentric ___ instent lesion in OM 1
  RCA: 60% focal lesion after PDA; otherwise minor disease

Interventional details
  Plan was to attempt to reperfuse LAD beyond prior stents to
assess size of distal vessel to determine whether further
intervention would be feasible. Changed for ___ Fr sheath and 
XBLAD
3.5 guide. All lesions were crossed with first a Prowater and
then a Pilot 50 wire into the distal vessel. All were dilated
with sequential inflations with 2.0 balloon with improvement in
the long mid segment but without distal flow. Distal contrast
injection showed short small distal vessel with 90% apical
lesion. This was dilated with the 2.0 balloon and ic NTG given
without change in the caliber of the distal vessel, It was then
clear that there would be no significant distal runoff with
further stenting and the procedure was terminated. Final distal
injection showed small localized perforation; however injection
from the guiding catheter showed persistent total occlusion of
the distal vessel making extension of perforation unlikely.
Angioseal femoral closure.

Assessment & Recommendations
1. Unsuccessful PCI of occluded LAD
2. No further intervention possible and known large anterior 
wall
motion abnormality, making medical therapy only option.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

You came to ___ because you 
began experiencing chest pain on exertion over the past week. 
The chest pain resolved with rest. Given your extensive coronary 
artery disease history, you were admitted to the hospital for 
further evaluation of your coronary arteries. You were chest 
pain free in the hospital, and received a cardiac 
catheterization on ___ where it was found that your left 
main coronary artery was normal, your LAD had some stenosis 
after the proximal stent, then an area of severe stenosis and 
occlusion of your more distal LAD stent. Your left circumflex 
coronary artery was ___ stenotic, and your RCA had a 60% 
stenotic lesion. We were unable to stent the LAD, but were able 
to open parts of the vessel via angioplasty, which may relieve 
some of your chest discomfort. During the procedure, a small 
leak of dye was seen at the very end of your LAD, representative 
of a small perforation. You received an echocardiogram that 
showed no evidence of that perforation causing any bleeding 
around the lining of your heart.

After discharge, it will be important to follow up with your 
cardiologist to optimize your medical management. Keep a diary 
of the activities that bring on your chest pain. Changes to your 
medication regimen in the future may be able to reduce these 
periods of chest pain, and you should discuss this further with 
your cardiologist. 

As we discussed, your hospital studies are available to you via 
request to medical records.

It has been a real pleasure caring for you during this 
hospitalization, we wish you all the best in your recovery!

Kind Regards,
___ Cardiology

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient Summary for Admission:
===============================
Ms ___ is a ___ yo woman with no major PMH presenting with RT 
leg pain over the past month with significant leukocytosis 
confirmed as CML. 

#CML
BCR-ABL confirmed on FISH analysis. Will initiate treatment 
after marrow for staging. Attempted bone marrow and only 
successful in getting Spleen size 14.5 and Eutos score 67.7 
predicts low risk disease. Initial testing was sent, G6PD 
remains pending, but infectious work up with HIV, hepatitis have 
been negative. TLS labs were followed. Patient was treated with 
hydroxyurea 1500 BID, fluids, and allopurinol. She was started 
on dastatinib. At time of discharge, Hydrea was stopped. Patient 
will continue ___nd continue Dasatinib.

#RT leg pain:
Fracture and clot have been excluded by XRAY and US. Other 
options include muscle strain, IT band strain, or bony pain from 
CML. MRI consistent with marrow CML infiltration. CML very 
rarely can create bone tumors that was initially a concern. No 
evidence of lytic lesions with no destruction of the cortex. 
Ortho was consulted and agreed she could resume weight bearing 
and this was most consistent with her normal CML. Pain initially 
treated with opioids, but patient had significant pain. She used 
gabapentin PRN as needed. Lidocaine patches were effective. 
Prior to discharge, patient transitioned to Tylenol for pain 
control.

#Dry cough
PNA vs pain associated. Possibly additional ___ pain. No 
findings on CXR. Cough resolved prior to discharge.

#Abdominal pain/nausea
Likely related to opioid use and anxiety combination. Opioids 
can last in system for 72 hours, will avoid for now. She also 
stopped her omeprazole during this admission due to TKI 
inhibitor interaction to acid reducers. Stopping antacids can 
cause increase in acid secretion which may have contributed to 
initial symptoms. Patient should not be discharged on antiacids. 
Nausea was controlled with Zofran and low dose Ativan. 

#Social complexity
#Anxiety
Complicated home situation and not surprising patient has 
significant anxiety. Patient amenable to following with a 
psychiatrist as an outpatient as she would like help coping and 
also working on her mood that she reports is labile. She will be 
referred to psych as an outpatient to someone near her on the 
___. 

#Contraception
Patient is obese, a women, and has a hematologic malignancy thus 
she should be treated without estrogens to prevent clot 
formation. She was started on norethindrone 3 weeks of pills 
followed by 1 week of no pills must take at the same time daily 
to prevent infection. She should use back up birth control with 
condoms for at least one month. OBGYN was used to help in 
decision making. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
==================
[] Tums also alter the stomach acid and have a mild 
contraindication with TKIs consider if patient should be 
discharged on these medications
[] Patient will be continued on new birth control that is 
progesterone only. This will reduce her risk of clots. It should 
be continued for 3 weeks. The packs do not come with placebo 
pills, but she will take 1 week off her pills each month. 
[] Patient should continue dasatinib indefinitely. She will 
require close heme onc follow up with a physician at ___ 
and consultation with Dr. ___
[] Patient is amenable to psychiatric follow up, please ensure 
she is connected with a provider closer to home. 
[] Patient can weight bear on her leg
[] Patient states she was taking ativan 0.5 mg daily, last 
script filled in ___ per Mass reporting. Clarify script with 
outpatient PCP. Psychiatry can assist as an outpatient regarding 
management of medications. 
[]Allopurinol will continue for 2 weeks following discharge.
[]Short course of Ativan prescribed for management of 
significant nausea which can be worsened by Dasatinib. This 
medication should evaluated for ongoing use in the setting of 
significant anxiety.
[]Patient should not exceed more than 2 grams of Tylenol daily.

-Stopped Medications: Omeprazole, Loestrin

- We evaluated your blood and bone marrow and found a cancer 
called chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

consistent with the cancer. We focused on controlling your pain

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is an 88-year-old male who was admitted with bradycardia and complete heart block. He presented to his primary care physician with decreased energy and was found to have a heart rate of 39 beats per minute. He was transferred to the hospital for temporary transcutaneous pacemaker placement due to complete heart block with a wide ventricular escape at 35 beats per minute. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, dementia, coronary artery bypass grafting, cerebrovascular accident, congestive heart failure, depression, and hypothyroidism. He also has a family history of unknown heart problems in his father and mother who died of pneumonia. The patient's physical examination revealed a well-nourished male in no acute distress, with a normal mental status and no signs of chest pain, shortness of breath, or abdominal pain. Laboratory results showed elevated creatinine and potassium levels, as well as a slightly elevated white blood cell count. Imaging studies revealed chronic ischemic changes in the left occipital lobe, as well as calcifications in the carotid siphons and vertebrobasilar system. The patient underwent an echocardiogram, which showed mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved global and regional biventricular systolic function, as well as mild aortic and mitral regurgitation. The patient was discharged with a pacemaker in place and prescribed medications for his condition. ||endoftext||

age: 63. gender: M. Name:  ___         Unit No:  ___

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a ___
male with metastatic renal cell carcinoma admitted today to
begin cycle 1 week 2 high-dose IL-2 therapy.  His oncologic
history began in ___ when workup for hematuria was done.
Cysto was negative.  CT scan on ___ showed a right
kidney mass measuring 7 cm.  He underwent right laparoscopic
nephrectomy on ___ confirming clear cell renal cell
carcinoma stage T3 N0.  He had a small right lower lobe
pulmonary nodule at the time of diagnosis with stable lung
nodules on followup imaging.  In ___, there was
growth in the left upper lobe pulmonary nodule with VATS on
___ confirming metastatic renal cell carcinoma.
Followup torso CT in ___ revealed growth in a right
upper lung nodule.  Treatment options were discussed, and
high-dose IL-2 therapy was recommended.  He passed
eligibility testing and began cycle 1 week 1 high-dose IL-2
therapy on ___, receiving 9 of ___omplicated by neutropenia.  His WBC improved by treatment
day 6 allowing discharge to home.  He is now recovered, is
ready for week 2 of therapy.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  RCC as above, history of prostate
cancer for which he underwent external beam radiation and
brachytherapy, history of GI bleeding with history of Meckel
diverticulum, status post diverticulectomy, history of AV
conduction block after surgery, hypertension,
hypercholesterolemia, history of hepatitis A at age ___,
hypothyroidism, psoriasis, history of Sweet syndrome, right
knee ligament repair in ___, L5 laminectomy, status post
vasectomy.

ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY: ___
FAMILY HISTORY:  Noncontributory.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  GENERAL:  Well-appearing male, no
acute distress.  Performance status 1.  VITAL SIGNS:  97.6,
88, 20, 162/85, O2 sat 100% on room air.  HEENT:
Normocephalic, atraumatic.  Sclerae anicteric.  Moist oral
mucosa without lesions.  NECK:  Supple.  LYMPH NODES:  No
cervical, supraclavicular or bilateral axillary
lymphadenopathy.  HEART:  Regular rate and rhythm, S1, S2.
CHEST:  Clear.  ABDOMEN:  Rounded, soft, nontender.  No HSM
or masses.  EXTREMITIES:  No edema.  SKIN:  Intact, dry
papular rash over the lower extremities and face.
NEUROLOGIC:  Nonfocal.

DATABASE:  Admission labs:  WBC 8.5, hemoglobin 139,
hematocrit 42.2, platelet count 404,000, INR 0.9.  BUN 17,
creatinine 1.2, sodium 138, potassium 4.4, chloride 103, CO2
of 25, glucose 92.  ALT 23, AST 21, CK 125, total bili 0.7.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted and went to
Interventional Radiology for placement of a central line.
His admission weight was 115 kg, and he received interleukin-
2 at 600,000 international units per kilo based on adjusted
ideal body weight equalling 5.9 million units of IL-2 q.8
hours x14 potential doses.  During this week, he received 10
of 14 doses with 4 doses held to prevent side effects with
change to b.i.d. dosing early in the week.  Side effects
during this week included rigors improved with Demerol;
nausea improved with antiemetic therapy; diarrhea improved
with antidiarrheals; fatigue and development of an
erythematous pruritic skin rash.  He developed mild
hypotension on treatment day #3 and improved with a fluid
bolus with no need for vasopressor therapy.

During this week, he developed acute renal failure with a
peak creatinine of 2.2 with associated oliguria.  He was
acidotic with a minimum bicarb of 19 improved with sodium
acetate infusion intravenously.  Electrolytes were monitored
and repleted per protocol.  Strict creatinine, bicarbonate
and urine output were monitored very carefully throughout his
hospital stay.  IV fluids were maintained given acute renal
failure.  During this week, he had no transaminitis,
hyperbilirubinemia, myocarditis, coagulopathy or
thrombocytopenia noted.  He was anemic without need for
packed red blood cell transfusion.  By ___, he had
recovered from side effects to allow for discharge to home.

CONDITION ON DISCHARGE:  Alert, oriented and ambulatory.

DISCHARGE STATUS:  To home with his family.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:  Metastatic renal cell carcinoma status
post cycle 1 week 2 high-dose IL-2 therapy complicated by
acute renal failure.  No neutropenia was noted during this
admission.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
1. Amlodipine 5 mg p.o. daily.
2. Atorvastatin 40 mg p.o. daily.
3. Cephalexin 500 mg b.i.d.
4. Diphenhydramine 25 to 50 mg q.6 hours p.r.n. pruritus.
5. Lomotil 1 to 2 tabs after each loose stool.
6. Lasix 20 mg p.o. daily x5 days.
7. Gabapentin 100 to 200 mg q.8 hours p.r.n. pruritus.
8. Eucerin cream topically.
9. Levothyroxine 137 mcg daily.
10.Lisinopril 40 mg p.o. daily.
11.Lorazepam 1 mg q.8 hours p.r.n. nausea or insomnia.
12.Compazine 10 mg q.6 hours p.r.n. nausea.
13.Sarna lotion topically q.i.d. p.r.n.

FOLLOWUP PLANS:  The patient will return to clinic in 4 weeks
after CT scans to assess disease response.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis:
- Atrial Tachycardia ___ Ablation
- Acute on Chronic Systolic Heart Failure
- Acute on Chronic Kidney Disease with contrast nephropathy

Secondary Diagnosis:
- Coronary Artery Disease
- Heart failure with reduced EF

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___. You were admitted to the hospital with 
shortness of breath and a fast heart rate. You had an EKG which 
showed you had a fast heart rate called atrial tachycardia. You 
had a cardiac ablation to stop the atrial tachycardia and your 
heart rate improved.

You also had shortness of breath likely due to your fast heart 
rate causing fluid to build up in your lung. You received 
medication called lasix to remove the fluid and your breathing 
improved. You also had an ultrasound of your heart called an 
echocardiogram that showed your heart was not pumping as well 
(poor systolic function). This is likely due to your fast heart 
rate and will hopefully improve in time.

You had an injury to your kidneys from the contrast dye given to 
evaluate your lungs for blood clots in the ED. You were given 
fluids and monitored, and your kidneys recovered their function.

Because your kidneys are still getting better, we have changed 
some of your medications. When you leave the hospital, you will 
be taking Lisinopril 5mg a day (half of your old dose). We did 
not restart Lasix (a water pill), since you were already 
urinating a lot. The medicines can be changed or added back on 
by your primary care doctor, based on how you are doing at your 
follow up appointment.

Please follow-up with your PCP to get labs drawn on ___. Also 
follow up with you Cardiologist; we are working on making you an 
appointment to see an electrophysiologist. We have also made you 
an appointment with a kidney doctor to follow up how your 
kidneys are improving.

All the best,
Your ___ Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 63-year-old male who was admitted for his 16th cycle of maintenance high-dose methotrexate. He has a history of mixed Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma with central nervous system involvement, and has had a complete response to induction high-dose methotrexate. He has also had a history of acute tubular necrosis associated with methotrexate.

The patient's presenting symptoms include chronic presence of floaters in his visual field, which improved after his prior chemotherapy treatment but returned recently. He has no other neurological complaints.

The patient's past medical history includes mixed Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, gastroesophageal reflux disease, history of renal tuberculosis, hyperlipidemia, and vertigo.

The patient's physical examination revealed normal vital signs, with no rashes or bruising on his skin. His neurological examination showed normal language and short-term recall, with no drift or dysmetria.

The patient's laboratory results showed normal blood counts, with no evidence of infection or inflammation. His liver function tests were slightly elevated, but his kidney function tests were normal.

The patient's imaging studies, including MRI and CT scans, showed no evidence of new or recurrent disease in the brain or torso.

The patient's hospital course was uneventful, and he tolerated his chemotherapy cycle well. He was discharged once his methotrexate levels became less than 0.2 uM. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 34-year-old female who presented to the hospital with a left thigh infection. She initially noticed erythema on her thigh, which progressed to a "ball" of fluctuance. She was treated with ceftriaxone and Keflex at an outside hospital, but her symptoms worsened, and she was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation. On admission, she was found to have an area of erythema that had progressed 1.5 inches from the previous day, with fluctuance and a fluid collection. The area was incised and drained, and a gram stain showed 2+ polymorphonuclear leukocytes with no microorganisms. Wound cultures grew out rare coagulase-negative Staphylococcus. She was started on vancomycin and amoxicillin and remained afebrile with improved white blood cell count. She was discharged with plans to complete a course of Bactrim and Keflex, with frequent follow-up visits for wound care.

The patient has a history of obesity, hypothyroidism, and GERD. She is allergic to Ortho-Cyclen, Compazine, and honey. She has no family history of note.

The patient's diagnosis is cellulitis and abscess of the left thigh. She was treated with incision and drainage, vancomycin, and amoxicillin. She was discharged with medications including levothyroxine, Bactrim, esomeprazole, Keflex, and oxycodone-acetaminophen. ||endoftext||

to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week.

to stop by your surgeon.

drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

changes in your incision

___ were admitted to the hospital after excision of your J 
pouch, end ileostomy, and hysterectomy. ___ have recovered from 
this procedure well and ___ are now ready to return home. 
Samples were taken and this tissue has been sent to the 
pathology department for analysis. ___ will receive these 
pathology results at your follow-up appointment. If there is an 
urgent need for the surgeon to contact ___ regarding these 
results they will contact ___ before this time. ___ have 
tolerated a regular diet, passing gas and your pain is 
controlled with pain medications by mouth. ___ may return home 
to finish your recovery.

___ have a long vertical incision on your abdomen that is closed 
with staples. This incision can be left open to air or covered 
with a dry sterile gauze dressing if the staples become 
irritated from clothing. The staples will stay in place until 
your first post-operative visit at which time they can be 
removed in the clinic, most likely by the office nurse. Please 
monitor the incision for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness at the incision, opening of the 
incision, increased pain at the incision line, draining of 
white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, or if ___ develop a 
fever. Please call the office if ___ develop these symptoms or 
go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. ___ may 
shower, let the warm water run over the incision line and pat 
the area dry with a towel, do not rub. ___ have a small incision 
where the JP drain was in place. The drain has been removed and 
the incision closed with steri strips. This can be covered with 
a dry gauze dressing for 24 hours and then left without a 
dressing. the drain site may leak a small amount of light 
pink/yellow drainage, it should not drain bright red ___ 
can apply a new dressing if there is drainage on the gauze. 
After 14 hours ___ can shower without the dressing on the site. 
The teristrips will fall off on their own. ___ can apply a knee 
sized bandaide to the site.

No heavy lifting for at least 6 weeks after surgery unless 
instructed otherwise by Dr. ___ may gradually increase 
your activity as tolerated but clear heavy exercise with Dr 
___ will be prescribed a small amount of pain medication. 
Please take this medication exactly as prescribed. ___ may take 
Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take more than 
4000mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while taking 
narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive a car 
while taking narcotic pain medication.

___ have a new ileostomy. The most common complication from a 
new ileostomy placement is dehydration. The output from the 
stoma is stool from the small intestine and the water content is 
very high. The stool is no longer passing through the large 
intestine which is where the water from the stool is reabsorbed 
into the body and the stool becomes formed. ___ must measure 
your ileostomy output for the next few weeks. The output from 
the stoma should not be more than 1200cc or less than 500cc. If 
___ find that your output has become too much or too little, 
please call the office for advice. The office nurse or nurse 
practitioner can recommend medications to increase or slow the 
ileostomy output. Keep yourself well hydrated, if ___ notice 
your ileostomy output increasing, take in more electrolyte drink 
such as Gatorade. Please monitor yourself for signs and symptoms 
of dehydration including: dizziness (especially upon standing), 
weakness, dry mouth, headache, or fatigue. If ___ notice these 
symptoms please call the office or return to the emergency room 
for evaluation if these symptoms are severe. ___ may eat a 
regular diet with your new ileostomy. However it is a good idea 
to avoid fatty or spicy foods and follow diet suggestions made 
to ___ by the ostomy nurses.

___ monitor the appearance of the ostomy and stoma and care 
for it as instructed by the wound/ostomy nurses. ___ stoma 
(intestine that protrudes outside of your abdomen) should be 
beefy red or pink, it may ooze small amounts of blood at times 
when touched and this should subside with time. The skin around 
the ostomy site should be kept clean and intact. Monitor the 
skin around the stoma for bulging or signs of infection listed 
above. Please care for the ostomy as ___ have been instructed by 
the wound/ostomy nurses. ___ will be able to make an appointment 
with the ostomy nurse in the clinic 7 days after surgery. ___ 
will have a visiting nurse at home for the next few weeks 
helping to monitor your ostomy until ___ are comfortable caring 
for it on your own.

___

||startoftext|| The patient is an 83-year-old male who was admitted with chest pain. He has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and has undergone four-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) in the past. He was recently hospitalized for recurrent chest pain and was found to have a positive troponin I level. He was started on heparin and nitroglycerin drips and underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed diffuse disease in the proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery, patent LIMA to LAD, and collaterals to the left circumflex (LCx) via the obtuse marginal (OM) branch. Two of the four RCA stents showed restenosis, and three Xience stents were placed in the restenosed posterior descending (PDA) artery. The patient was continued on aspirin, Plavix, atenolol, simvastatin, and lisinopril.

The patient's allergies include penicillins. His past medical history includes CAD risk factors, hypertension, and a history of CABG. He has also had a recent hospitalization for recurrent chest pain and was transferred to another hospital for possible CABG but was deemed not to be a surgical candidate.

The patient's physical examination revealed a normal sinus rhythm, normal blood pressure, and normal oxygen saturation. His chest pain was not reproducible upon palpation. His laboratory results showed a normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, but an elevated troponin I level.

The patient's discharge medications include atenolol, aspirin, Plavix, simvastatin, lisinopril, and nitroglycerin. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE
=====================
___ year old woman with stage IV ER/PR+/HER2- breast cancer (on 
C1D12 of paclitaxel), malignant pleural effusion s/p R TPC (___), PE on rivaroxaban, dCHF, AS s/p TAVR, mitral stenosis 
presented with cough, dyspnea and diarrhea. She was found to 
have Cdiff infection and pneumonia, and was started on 
antiobiotic treatment. She was initially transferred to ICU due 
to low blood pressure and concern for sepsis. She was shortly 
kept on pressors, but upon communication with primary 
oncologist, it was found that her pressures normally run very 
low. Patient was transferred to the floor but then she quickly 
returned to the FICU due to hypoxemic respiratory failure. This 
was felt to be related to flash pulmonary edema. She was 
diuresed with IV Lasix 20mg and was started on BiPAP. She was 
weaned off BiPAP after diuresis and received further diuresis 
with improvement in respiratory status. BPs remained stable. She 
was continued on cefepime for treatment of HAP and was continued 
on po vancomycin for c. difficile colitis until ___ when she 
completed her course. On the floor she remained stable on ___ 
O2 requirements, which were weaned down to 0.5L with her 
diuresis which also were tapered to Lasix 40mg PO daily. Her 
blood pressures continued to fluctuate into low realms, however, 
improved in inverse reflection of her diuretic taper to levels 
where she able to undergo extensive in house ___ and become 
re-conditioned physically.

ACTIVE ISSUES
=============
#Sespis: Patient presented with tachypnea to 33, leukocytosis, 
and potential respiratory vs. abdominal source given symptoms. 
She was given 3L IVF in ED. She was started on treatment for HAP 
with vancomycin and cefepime. Was also found to be positive for 
C. diff, and was started on PO vancomycin in the ICU. Blood 
pressure initially required support with levophed which was 
weaned off in ICU within 1 day of admission after contact with 
primary oncologist confirmed that her baseline BPs run in the 
mid ___. Patient was subsequently transferred to medical floor, 
however returned quickly to ___ due to hypoxemic respiratory 
failure (see below).

#Hypoxemic respiratory failure
#Malignant pleural effusion: 
Causes for her acute worsening dyspnea and hypoxia on the floor 
was believed to be flash pulmonary edema. Possible triggers 
included HTN (SBP 158 - baseline 80-90s), decompensated HF (BNP 
900s from 400s), tachycardia (120s from baseline 100s), 
worsening pleural effusion (150 cc drained ___, Trop and EKG 
without evidence of ischemia. She has stabilized with 20 mg IV 
Lasix, duoneb and BiPAP, transferred back to the floor. Pleurx 
was also frequently drained which helped improved hypoxia. 
Diuresis was continued on the floor however patient continued to 
have blood pressures on low ___, prompting taper of diuresis to 
40mg Lasix PO daily which reflected improvement in her BP, 
albeit it lingers below average. Pleurx was capped with plan for 
patient to continue two to three-times-per-week drainage on 
M(W)F and remove fluid as needed for comfort.

#Orthostatic hypotension: Likely related to volume status in the 
setting of ongoing diuresis, with possible contribution from 
olanzapine medication side effect. Improved w/ further ___ 
conditioning. Continued PO Lasix 40 daily, decreased from BID 
and TID earlier this admission. Continued ___ rehabilitation 
during admission and cleared for home. Continued olanzapine at 
decreased dose of 5mg qHS.

#Nausea/Vomiting: Attempted various permutations of medications 
but ultimately succeeded with suppression via pre-meal 
medication with Reglan, increased to appropriate dose. Continued 
on Caphosol for dry mouth, olanzapine 5mg QHS, Zofran PRN 
breakthrough (avoided standing as pt has developed tachyphylaxis 
in the past), and EKG q3d for QTc monitoring which have been 
unremarkable.

#Hospital acquired pneumonia: Presented with dyspnea, cough, 
presence of effusion and ?opacity on admission which was 
concerning for pneumonia. Initiated on vanc/cefepime on ___ 
for presumed HAP given recent hospitalization. Completed 
cefepime (___). Received vancomycin briefly (___) 
until MRSA swab was found to be negative. Cough was managed with 
Sodium Chloride 3% Inhalation Soln 15 mL NEB Q6H.

#HFpEF
#Mitral stenosis: likely due to mitral annular calcification 
with intermittent pulmonary edema during chemotherapy. Last ECHO 
on ___ demonstrated LVEF >55%, severe functional mitral 
stenosis, well seated aortic valve prosthesis. Notably, her 
tumor has shown signs of progression in her liver and lungs 
despite chemotherapy with 5 agents. Per Dr ___ (___) 
the risks of TMVR given her progressive metastatic disease are 
very high. Upon discharge, the patient will follow-up with Dr 
___ scheduling of a cardiac CT to reassess her risks and 
potential TMVR intervention. Lasix was 40mg PO daily at 
discharge, with discharge weight of 43.59kg 96.1lbs 

#Metastatic Breast Cancer: Patient originally on C1 of 
Paclitaxel, after failing multiple chemo regimens. Found to have 
metastatic pulmonary nodules and lymphangitic spread likely 
contributing to her hypoxia. Patient's further chemotherapy 
regimen was determined by her outpatient oncologist and fellow 
in-house given her length-of-stay and was started on eribulin in 
house ___, and second dose ___. Her CBC w/ diff has 
been followed during this therapy. Discontinued superfluous 
medications as ASA, atorvastatin, and decreased 
hydroxychloroquine to 200mg daily given weight changes. She will 
have follow up in outpatient ___ clinic for continuation of 
treatment. 

#C. Diff colitis: Patient presented with hypotension with 
initial possible sources including PNA was later found to have 
c. diff colitis. Patient was able to be weaned off of pressors 
after discovery that her baseline blood pressures are in the 
___. Patient was initiated on PO Vancomycin which she continued 
until ___. Per oncology floor policy, remained on precautions 
following the conclusion of her treatment.

#Macrocytic anemia: Hgb ~10 from baseline ~11, possibly in 
setting of fluid resuscitation vs. recent chemotherapy. Anemia 
remained stable.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___ 
___!

WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED?
You were admitted because he were found to have weakness and 
hypotension by your ___.

WHAT HAPPENED IN THE HOSPITAL?
You were initially started on antibiotics for a presumed 
infection.  You also received fluids in order to raise your 
blood pressure.  Your infectious workup showed that you have an 
infection with C. difficile, as well as a pneumonia.  For this 
you were started on oral vancomycin which you took until ___. For your pneumonia you completed a 7 day course with 
cefepime.
You were also found to have increased oxygen requirements due in 
part to increased fluid accumulation around your lung.  This 
fluid was drained through your Pleurx and this helped improved 
your oxygen requirements. 
You had a short course in the ICU for management of your oxygen 
requirements, where you received diuresis (to remove the fluid 
from your lungs) and a BiPAP machine (to improve your 
breathing). 
After your stay in the ICU, you were transferred to a regular 
oncology floor where you remained stable on ___ Oxygen, however 
your blood pressures continued to be low. Due to this reason we 
had to stop your water pills temporarily but then we restarted 
them again since your fluid status was difficult to control.
You were weaned down to a dose of one water pill per day to 
maximize treatment of your shortness of breath while allowing 
you to hold your blood pressure and work with physical therapy. 
You continued to work with physical therapy in the hospital 
until you were re-conditioned to be able to work with your 
family at home to get stronger.

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO AT HOME?
You need to continued taking your medications as prescribed and 
follow-up with the appointments scheduled for you.
 
You should have your pleurx drained ___ times a week (M(W)F). 
You can take out as much fluid as you can until you start 
feeling uncomfortable.

Thank you for allowing us be involved in your care, we wish you 
all the best!

Your ___ Team

Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you while you were admitted to 
___.  You were hospitalized due to symptoms of left visual 
field cut resulting from a transient ischemic attack (a mini 
stroke), a condition in which a blood vessel providing oxygen 
and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is 
the part of your body that controls and directs all the other 
parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived 
of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms.

Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:
1) high cholesterol including cholesterol in your aorta (large 
vessel leaving your heart
2) high blood pressure
3) diabetes mellitus

We are changing your medications as follows:
1) START Plavix 75mg daily

you to have a complete visual field test at your 
ophthalmologists office.  You CANNOT drive until you have this 
test completed and the results are approved by your 
ophthalmologist.

||startoftext|| The patient is an 81-year-old male who presented with a syncopal episode after a baseball game. He has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) with recent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), chronic heart failure (CHF), end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, hypertension (HTN), and atrial fibrillation (Afib). He was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and treatment.

Upon admission, the patient's vital signs were notable for a temperature of 97.2°F, heart rate of 52 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 151/48 mmHg. His physical examination revealed a bradycardic rhythm, normal rhythm, and a III/VI holosystolic murmur heard throughout the precordium.

Laboratory results showed elevated levels of troponin (0.53 ng/mL) and creatinine (11.0 mg/dL), as well as mild anemia (Hgb 11.3 g/dL). Imaging studies revealed severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 1.0 cm² or less, as well as mild degenerative changes in the ankle joints.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, including Eliquis for Afib and metoprolol tartrate for hypertension. He was also advised to undergo evaluation for surgical or transcatheter intervention for severe aortic stenosis, continue hemodialysis three times a week, and consider stopping metoprolol tartrate due to bradycardia.

Overall, the patient's hospital course was marked by a syncopal episode likely due to a vagal episode in the setting of severe aortic stenosis, and he was discharged with recommendations for further evaluation and treatment. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
#MCA and ACOM aneurysms 
Patient was admitted for elective Right Craniotomy for clipping 
of R MCA and ACOM aneurysm. Case was uncomplicated and well 
tolerated. He was extubated in the OR and transferred to the 
PACU for recovery. He boarded in PACU overnight, and was 
transferred to ___ on the morning of POD1. He remained 
neurologically stable. He was transferred to the floor on ___.  
He remained stable and was discharged home on ___.

#Nausea/vomiting/ileus
Post operatively, the patient had ongoing nausea and multiple 
episodes of vomiting. This was initially treated stepwise with 
IV zofran, scopalamine patch, and PR compazine which did not 
resolve his symptoms. An abdominal XR showed dilated loops of 
small bowel and stool/gas filled large bowel, which was 
suggestive of ileus. An NG tube was placed at bedside, and prior 
to connection to wall suction, a chest XR confirmed placement in 
stomach. He was made NPO and his bowel regimen was increased. 
___ Repeat KUB was obtained. NGT was taken off suction and 
patient was monitored. ACS was consulted. His NGT was removed 
and diet was slowly advanced.  He started producing flatus and 
had BM x 3.  N/V improved and he tolerated a diet.

#Hypertension
Post-operatively, he was hypertensive, over his SBP goal of less 
than 140. This required maximum dosing of nicardipine drip, as 
well as alternation of iv labetalol/hydralazine. His pain 
medications were increased, with concern for undertreated pain 
as exacerbation of his hypertension.

#Urinary retention
Patient had a foley for the operation, which was discontinued on 
POD1. He had small void amounts, which prompted bladder 
scanning, revealing high PVRs. He was straight cathed x1.

#Methadone dependence
He was maintained on his home dose of methadone while admitted.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions

Dr. ___ & Dr. ___

___ Aneurysm ___

Call your neurosurgeons office and speak to the Nurse 
Practitioner if you experience:

-Any neurological issues, such as change in vision, speech or 
movement

-Swelling, drainage, or redness of your incision

-Any problems with medications, such as nausea vomiting or 
lethargy

-Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit

-Headaches not relieved with prescribed medications

Activity:

-Start to resume all activities as you tolerate  but start 
slowly and increase at your own pace.

-Do not operate any motorized vehicle for at least 10 days 
after your surgery  your Nurse Practitioner can give you more 
detail at the time of your suture removal.  

Incision Care:

-Keep your wound clean and dry.

-Do not use shampoo until your sutures are removed. 

-When you are allowed to shampoo your hair, let the shampoo run 
off the incision line.  Gently pad the incision with a towel to 
dry.

-Do not rub, scrub, scratch, or pick at any scabs on the 
incision line.

-You need your sutures removed 7 to 10 days after surgery

Post-Operative Experiences: Physical

-Jaw pain on the same side as your surgery; this goes away 
after about a month

-You may experience constipation.  Constipation can be 
prevented by:

oDrinking plenty of fluids
oIncreasing fiber in your diet by eating vegetables, prunes, 
fiber rich breads and cereals, or fiber supplements
oExercising
oUsing over-the-counter bowel stimulants or laxatives as 
needed, stopping usage if you experience loose bowel movements 
or diarrhea

-Fatigue which will slowly resolve over time

-Numbness or tingling in the area of the incision; this can 
take weeks or months to fully resolve

-Muffled hearing in the ear near the incision area

-Low back pain or shooting pain down the leg which can resolve 
with increased activity

Post-Operative Experiences: Emotional

-You may experience depression.  Symptoms of depression can 
include

oFeeling down or sad
oIrritability, frustration, and confusion
oDistractibility
oLower Self-Esteem/Relationship Challenges
oInsomnia
oLoneliness

-If you experience these symptoms, you can contact your Primary 
Care Provider who can make a referral to a Psychologist or 
Psychiatrist

-You can also seek out a local Brain Aneurysm Support Group in 
your area through the Brain Aneurysm Foundation

oMore information can be found at ___

 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 32-year-old male who was admitted for an elective craniotomy to clip two aneurysms in his brain. He has a history of methadone dependence, polycystic kidney disease, hepatitis C, iron deficiency anemia, and a cardiac heart murmur. He also has a family history of adult polycystic kidney disease and an aneurysm that was previously fixed.

During his hospital stay, the patient experienced nausea and vomiting, which was treated with medication and an NG tube. He also had hypertension, which was managed with medication, and urinary retention, which was treated with a foley catheter and straight catheterization.

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of right MCA and AComm aneurysm and was prescribed medications including acetaminophen, senna, albuterol, clonidine, lisinopril, methadone, and pantoprazole. He was advised to follow up with his neurosurgeon's office and to contact his nurse practitioner if he experiences any neurological issues, swelling, drainage, or redness of his incision, or any problems with medications.

The patient was also given discharge instructions to start resuming activities slowly, to avoid operating any motorized vehicles for at least 10 days after surgery, and to keep his wound clean and dry. He was also advised to follow up with his primary care provider if he experiences depression or any other emotional symptoms. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with IDDM, possible pyoderma gangrenosum of the perianal

___ found to have NSTEMI on hep gtt with troponin 0.3

with significant hilar lymphadenopathy. Upon admission, patient 
was placed on a heparin drip and received PRN nitroglycerin for 
control of chest pain. Patient was taken to the cath lab on 
___ that showed 60% stenosis of his RCA and 30% stenosis of 
LCx. No intervention was performed. He was started on ASA, 
statin a beta-blocker for his CAD. Patient continued to complain 
of chest pain, but given the cath results this was thought to be 
unlikely caused by cardiac disease. He had an incidental finding 
of a RUL lung nodule and significant hilar lymphadenopathy. 
Patient reported recent night sweats with unintentional 30-lb 
weight loss. Interventional pulmonology was consulted who 
recommended bronchoscopy with hilar lymph node biopsy as an 
outpatient. Additionally, the patient had on-going rectal pain 
due to his ___ wound. Dermatology and colorectal surgery 
were consulted and recommended wound care. Biopsies and further 
work up were deferred for the outpatient setting. Patient also 
developed loose stools with incontinence concerning for C diff 
given history. He was started and discharged with a prescription 
for PO vancomycin. 

  
 # CORONARIES: unknown
 # PUMP: unknown 
 # RHYTHM: sinus    

# NSTEMI: Patient presented with three days of chest pain, peak 
trop 0.3, EKG with <1mm STD in lateral leads. Patient EKG did 
show evidence of old inferolateral infarct. Patient was started 
on a heparin drip for NSTEMI. Chest pain required nitroglycerin 
and intermittently oxycodone/IV morphine for relief. Patient 
underwent coronary catheterization on ___ which revealed 
RCA 60% stenosis and LCx 30% stenosis. No intervention was 
performed. Patient began ASA, Atorvastatin, metoprolol for CAD 
medical management. Following cath, patient continued to have 
chest pain that was largely unchanged. Multiple EKGs pre and 
post cath did not show new changes or signs of ischemia. While 
the patient had documented CAD on cath, it is possible that some 
of his chest pain was also due to demand ischemia given give 
___ wounds. Pain ___ also be due to hilar 
lymphadenopathy found on CTA. Interventional pulmonology was 
consulted, please see explanation below for lung nodule/hilar 
lymphadenopathy.

# Pulmonary nodule: CT chest reveals discrete nodule  in LUL 
that is >2.0cm in diameter.  OSH started CTX and Doxy for CAP on 
___ but this was discontinued on ___ given no suspicion for 
PNA. Patient with reported history 30 pound weight loss, night 
sweats for ___ months. CTA was uploaded to ___ system for 
image review. Per wet read of radiology, most concerning on the 
CTA was significant hilar lymphadenopathy. History is concerning 
for possible lymphoma vs other malignancy vs infectious 
etiology. Interventional pulmonology was consulted who 
recommended bronchoscopy with biopsy as an outpatient. Patient 
is scheduled for bronchoscopy on ___. 

# Hydradinitis Suppurative Lesions: Patient with lesions in  
axilla, groin, and perianal area are consistent with the 
distribution seen in hidradinitis suppurativa. He has started to 
see improvement in his right axillary lesion but his perianal 
lesions are unchanged.  Dermatology was consulted for re-biopsy 
of anal wound given concern given differing pathology reports 
and unclear diagnosis given refractory nature of his perianal 
lesion. There was no evidence of infection on exam. Colorectal 
surgery was also consulted who discussed patient case with derm. 
___ wounds are painful and of unclear etiology. DDx 
includes verrucous carcinoma vs pyoderma gangrenosum. Since 
patient had multiple previous biopsies by his outpatient 
dermatologist, the decision was made to defer further biopsies 
and discuss with his primary dermatologist as an outpatient. 
Patient was discharged home with wound care ___ services. Humira 
was restarted on discharge, held in-house. 
 
# Coagulopathy: INR elevated on admission to 1.6.  Liver 
synthetic function wnl.  INR remined stable but elevated 
throughout admission. 

# DMII: On metformin at home. Held metformin in the setting of 
potential cath. Last HbA1C 7.2% ___. Patient was given

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 46-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of diabetes, anxiety, depression, and hidradenitis suppuritiva, and is currently taking Humira for his condition. He was transferred from another hospital with a diagnosis of NSTEMI and was started on heparin and morphine for pain management. 

The patient's past medical history includes depression, anxiety, genital warts, c. diff, fatty liver, DM2, HLD, thyroid nodule, and anal condyloma. He has also had multiple surgeries, including a L4-S1 diskectomy/fusion, hemorrhoidectomy, and excision of anal condylomata.

The patient's physical exam was notable for a large ulcerated lesion on his perianal skin, as well as lesions on his groin and axilla. His labs showed elevated troponin levels, and a cardiac catheterization showed 60% stenosis of his RCA and 30% stenosis of his LCx.

The patient was prescribed the following medications at discharge: ASA, statin, and beta blocker. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 30-year-old male who was admitted for alcohol withdrawal. He has a history of alcohol abuse and asthma. He presented with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and tremors, which are consistent with alcohol withdrawal. His vital signs were stable, and he was given valium and a banana bag to manage his symptoms. He was also started on thiamine, folic acid, and multivitamins. His diagnosis was confirmed as alcohol withdrawal, and he was discharged with a plan to follow up with a therapist or support group. He was also prescribed albuterol inhaler for his asthma and instructed to take his medications as directed. ||endoftext||

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 48-year-old male with a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) due to presumed hypertensive nephropathy, atrial fibrillation, and calciphylaxis with a left lower extremity skin lesion. He presents to the emergency department with a non-functioning left upper extremity fistula, which was placed several years ago. The patient has been asymptomatic until recently, when he developed a large ulcer on his left calf due to calciphylaxis. He was unable to undergo dialysis at his dialysis center due to the non-functioning fistula.

The patient underwent a balloon dilation and thrombectomy of the left radiocephalic fistula, which was successful in restoring flow to the arterial portion of the fistula. He was also found to have mixed bacterial flora in his wound cultures, including Corynebacterium species and a mixed bacterial flora.

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and he was noted to have shallow ulcers on his right posterior calf and a larger ulcer on his left posterior calf with granulation tissue and yellow exudate. He was prescribed medications for pain management and was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for further management of his calciphylaxis and fistula.

The patient's allergies and adverse reactions are listed as no known allergies or adverse drug reactions. ||endoftext||
