neuroma s/p resection who was transferred from ___ to 
___ with multiple PEs and a UTI. Patient initially presented 
to OSH with abdominal pain, vomiting, hypotension and AF with 
RVR. She was also hypoxic and required supplemental O2 via NC 
(~2L). She received IVF resuscitation (~2.4L) with improvement 
in SBPs and HRs. Initial labs showed a lactate of 3.6 which 
improved to 2.7 with IVF. UA was c/f UTI and received 
vancomycin/Zosyn. A CTA was performed and showed multiple large 
central PEs with evidence of R heart strain. She was given tPA 
(100 mg over 2h). Trop was 0.21. She was transferred to ___ 
for further management of PEs.  
 
In the ED, initial vitals: T 97.8, HR 82, BP 129/77, RR 20, 100% 
on 2L NC. The PE team was consulted and recommend starting a 
heparin gtt if the PTT was <2x ULN. Heparin gtt was started in 
the ED and she was admitted to the ICU for further management. 
On transfer, vitals were: T 97.6, HR 69, BP 128/72, 100% NC.
  
On arrival to the MICU, T 98.0, BP 125/84, HR 75, 97% 2LNC. 
Patient was alert and oriented to self and place but not time. 
She denied chest pain or shortness of breath. She denies having 
had blood clots in the past. Denies recent surgery or prolonged 
immobilization. She does report having had multiple falls in the 
past but none recently. She has "poor gait" and is followed by a 
neurologist.

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is an 84-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with hypoxia and pulmonary emboli. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, bladder cancer, breast cancer, recurrent urinary tract infections, and falls. She was initially treated with tPA for her pulmonary emboli and was started on a heparin drip to bridge to warfarin. She developed a large right hand hematoma that was surgically evacuated. She also had a urinary tract infection and was treated with antibiotics. The patient's diagnosis includes multiple pulmonary emboli, left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis, and a urinary tract infection. She was prescribed warfarin and a heparin drip at discharge, and will need to follow up with her doctor to discuss the duration of anticoagulation and further work-up for thrombophilia and underlying malignancy. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure.  Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the 
PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/pnemoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA.  Diet was advanced as tolerated.

back and

extremity
weakness, and the progressive loss of ability to walk.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
Without Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without moving around.

-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate. 
oLimit any kind of lifting.

-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery.  You have been given medication to 
help with this issue.

-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If it is dry 
then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once the 
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing and call the office. 

-You should resume taking your normal home medications.

-You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2.  We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
 In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.

Physical Therapy:
Ambulate as tolerated. 
Treatments Frequency:
Keep dressing clean and dry

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 55-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a rapidly progressive syndrome of back and radiating leg pain, progressive lower extremity weakness, and the progressive loss of the ability to walk. He underwent a lumbar posterior decompression procedure without complication. The patient has a history of allergies to Ibuprofen, Penicillins, Sulfa, and Latex. His past medical history is significant for spinal stenosis, and he has a family history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obstructive sleep apnea. The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including acetaminophen, docusate sodium, oxycodone, hydrochlorothiazide, finasteride, and tamsulosin. He was advised to follow a normal diet, avoid lifting heavy objects, and to ambulate as tolerated. The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his doctor and to take his medications as directed. ||endoftext||

___ Radiology ART DUP EXT UP BILAT COMP 
Patent bilateral brachial/radial and ulnar arteries with normal 
waveforms and velocities. There is no evidence of macrovascular 
arterial ischemia at this location. If there is a concern for 
embolic findings they may not be detected by this study looking 
at the distal location.
.
___ Radiology CHEST (PA & LAT) 
 Bibasal, left more than right, linear opacities consistent with 
atelectasis/scarring. No evidence of pneumonia.
  
___ Radiology BILAT LOWER EXT VEINS   
No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the bilateral lower 
extremities.
.

___ Radiology ART EXT (REST ONLY) 
 Normal lower extremity arterial hemodynamics at rest. Some 
noncompressible vasculature, consistent with age and history. 

.
___ Radiology CTA UPPER EXT W&W/O C & RECONS RIGHT  
 1. Atherosclerosis in the ulnar artery with non filling of the 
distal ulnar artery at the level of the wrist joint. On delayed 
scanning, contrast is seen in the palmar branches of the ulnar 
artery, most likely filling via collaterals.

2. Atherosclerosis is present in the radial artery at the level 
of the wrist joint, though this is patent and is seen giving off 
branches in the hand.

3. The arterial arcades of the hand could not be assessed.

4. No vascular aneurysm or evidence of vasculitis.
.
___ Pathology Tissue: SKIN LEFT INDEX FINGER TIP 
Focal fibrin thrombus in dermal arteriole and focal cryoglobulin 
deposit in superficial capillary with associated ectasia of 
small vessels (see note).
Note:  No vasculitis, interface dermatitis or other changes of 
graft versus host disease, fungi or bacteria are seen (PAS, 
Brown-Brenn stain, and multiple levels examined). 
.
___ Radiology ART DUP EXT UP UNI OR LMTD 
 Patent bilateral brachial/radial and ulnar arteries with normal 
waveforms and velocities. There is no evidence of macrovascular 
arterial ischemia at this location. If there is a concern for 
embolic findings they may not be detected by this study looking 
at the distal location.
 
.
___ Cardiology ECHO 
Technically suptimal study due to poor esophageal contact.
No spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus is seen in the body of 
the left atrium/left atrial appendage or the body of the right 
atrium/right atrial appendage. Overall left ventricular systolic 
function is normal (LVEF>55%). The ascending, transverse and 
descending thoracic aorta are normal in diameter and free of 
atherosclerotic plaque to 40 cm from the incisors. The aortic 
valve leaflets (3) are minimally thickened, with good leaflet 
excursion. No vegetations are seen. No aortic regurgitation is 
seen. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal with 
trivial mitral regurgitation. No mass or vegetation is seen on 
the mitral valve. There is no pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Minimal aortic valve sclerosis. No vegetations or 
pathologic flow identified.  
.
___ Cardiology ECHO 
The left atrium is elongated. There is mild symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and systolic 
function (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free 
wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly 
thickened. No masses or vegetations are seen on the aortic 
valve. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears structurally 
normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral 
valve prolapse. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not 
be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Minimal aortic valve sclerosis. No vegetations 
identified. Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
preserved global and regional biventricular systolic function.

CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS: 
Based on ___ AHA endocarditis prophylaxis recommendations, the 
echo findings indicate prophylaxis is NOT recommended. Clinical 
decisions regarding the need for prophylaxis should be based on 
clinical and echocardiographic data.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo man with history of AML s/p allo-BMT ___ who presents 
with tender cutaneous lesions and polycythemia.  He had 
presented to clinic with splinter hemorrhages but had negative 
blood cultures and TTE on ___.  He also had polycythemia with 
an elevated erythropoeitin level.  
His fingers became painful and he was admitted for an expedited 
workup of splinter hemorrhages.  On admission his finger (left 
index finger) was slightly discolored.  He had blood cultures 
that were negative.  He has a TTE that was negative and then a 
TEE, which he tolerated well.  Both tests showed no signs of 
vegetations on the valves or thrombi.  It was felt that 
endocarditis as a cause of his finger lesions (splinter 
hemorrhages) was unlikely in the face of this data.  He also did 
not have these lesions else where.  A differential including 
GVHD vasculitis or rheumatological vasculitidies was formulated 
and a rheumatology consult was called.  Extensive serologies 
were sent, and his ___ was positive with a titer of 1:320.  This 
was felt to be non-specific.  A hypercoagulability panel was 
sent with negative results.  He also had negative cryoglobulins. 
 Rheumatology had suggested that he be evaluated by dermatology 
for his skin changes (distal digits had started becoming 
slightly purple-blue).  Vascular surgery had also evaluated him. 
 They felt that this was not a surgical issue as he had 
dopplerable pulses to the mid-phalanx.  They also felt that an 
MRA or CTA of his arms would not be helpful as he had 
dopplerable pulses and likely did not have a thrombi occluding 
his vessels.  He had an ultrasound of his arteries in the upper 
extremities which was normal.  He was started on Solumedrol 40mg 
a day. Dermatology had suggested that there may be a 
vaso-spastic element to his finger presentation. He was started 
on Nifedipine 10mg po bid and NTG oitment to his fingertips.  
This was somewhat helpful with his finger pain.  A CT-A of his 
right arm was performed that showed atherosclerosis of his ulnar 
and radial artery, no evidence of vasculitis was seen.  
Cholesterol levels were obtained for risk stratification.   He 
had an acute worsening  of the color of his fingertips (to a 
more intense purple-blue) with maintenance of his pulses.  His 
solumedrol dose was increased to 250mg q 6 hours and his 
cellcept was increased to 500mg po tid.  Dermatology was spoken 
with and they performed a skin biopsy before the higher dose 
solumedrol and cellcept was initiated. In addition a heparin gtt 
was initiated.  One day following the 1g per day solumedrol and 
anticoagulation, his fingertips improved in pain and pallor.  
The results of the biopsy showed one arteriole with a waxy 
deposit consistent with cyroglobulins and one thrombus in an 
arteriole.  No vasculitis was seen.  
Repeat cryoglobulins were sent, and were hand delivered in a 
warm water bath to ensure that they did not precipitate en 
route.  The results were negative.  
After 3 days on anticoagulation it was stopped as it was decided 
that the risk outweighed the benefit (as he is unsteady 
secondary to his cerebral palsy)and the indication for 
anticoagulation was not present.  His fingers continued to be 
improved.  The solumedrol was gradually tapered to prednisone 
40mg a day and eventually to 30mg a day prior to discharge.  On 
___ he received Rituxan as it has been used in 
cryoglobulinemia.  He tolerated it well.  At the time of 
discharge his finger lesions were felt to be due to a 
vasculopathy with a vasospastic element. 
He had an increase in lower extremity edema that was felt to be 
secondary to the high dose steroids but a lower extremity 
ultrasound was done to assess for DVTs.  This exam was negative. 
  
His blood sugars were quite elevated after the initiation of 
high dose steroids.  He was followed by the ___ clinic.  He 
required q 6 hours NPH and a sliding scale.  As his steroids 
were tapered his insulin needs decreased.  He was discharged on 
glipizide and once daily 70/30.
His hematocrit remained high and an epo level was tested again 
to confirm the initial high reading.  The repeat epo was high.

Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
___ Diagnosis:
vasculopathy

------------
AML status post allogeneic stem cell transplant ___
cerebral palsy

 
Discharge Condition:
stable, afebrile, good po intake, ambulatory

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with lesions on your fingers called "splinter 
hemorrhages".  We looked at your heart (with an echocardiogram) 
to make sure that there were no clots that were traveling to 
your fingers and causing decreased blood flow.  You had several 
blood tests looking for processes that attack blood vessels that 
were negative.  You had a skin biopsy and a CT of your arm to 
look at your blood vessels.  Blood thinner (heparin) and high 
dose steroids were started to treat your fingers.  Your fingers 
started improving and you were taken off the blood thinner.  
Because of the high dose steroids you had high blood sugar and 
you needed insulin.  Your fingers were improved and remained 
that way.  It was decided that a vasculopathy possibly due to 
GVHD is the likely cause of this.
You should continue to take your medications as prescribed.  We 
increased your cellcept to 500mg three times a day.  You are 
also on prednisone 30mg a day now, you should continue to take 
this until instructed by Dr. ___.  You are also on a 
medication called glipizide (for diabetes), you will take 10mg 
of this in the morning before breakfast and 5mg at bedtime.  You 
will also be taking insulin (called ___ 50 units in the 
morning.  It is important to check your blood sugar before 
taking any of these diabetes medications.  If your sugar is 
below ___ you should not take the medication.  If it is 65 or 
below you should call your doctor.  If your blood sugar is over 
___ you should call your doctor.  
Please call your doctor if you have any increased pain in your 
fingers, headache, lightheadedness, abdominal pain, nausea, 
vomiting, fevers, chills or any other concerning symptoms.
It is important that you follow up as outlined below.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 52-year-old male with a chief complaint of concern for vasculitis. He has a history of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and has undergone allogenic stem cell transplant with busulfan and cytoxan for conditioning regimen. He recently developed increasing hematocrit and splinter hemorrhages in his nailbeds. The patient has a past medical history of AML, mild chronic graft-versus-host disease of eyes and mouth, cerebral palsy, psoriasis, and a history of upper extremity deep vein thrombosis. He has no known allergies to drugs.

The patient's diagnosis is erythroid hyperplasia, and he underwent a skin biopsy of the left index finger and a trans-esophageal echocardiogram. The patient's medications at discharge include phlebotomy.

The patient's laboratory results show normal hemoglobin electrophoresis, elevated erythropoietin, and normal blood cultures. His bone marrow biopsy shows erythroid hyperplasia with mildly megaloblastoid maturation. His clot section and biopsy slides show normal myeloid elements and megakaryocytes.

The patient's radiology results show patent bilateral brachial/radial and ulnar arteries with normal waveforms and velocities, and no evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the bilateral lower extremities. His echocardiogram shows minimal aortic valve sclerosis with no vegetations or pathologic flow identified. ||endoftext||

Discharge Diagnosis:
Incarcerated right inguinal hernia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the Acute Care surgery Service on ___ 
with right groin swelling and abdominal pain. You were found to 
have an inguinal hernia which is when a piece of your bowel goes 
through a hold in the abdominal wall and gets stuck there. You 
underwent surgery to have the piece of intestine put back in and 
a piece of mesh placed over the hole to prevent the problem from 
happening again. You are now doing better, tolerating a regular 
diet, and ready to be discharged from the hospital to continue 
your recovery from surgery.

Please note the following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

-___ CXR: In comparison with study of ___, the right base

atelectasis, and possibly supervening pneumonia in the

decreasing phlegmon or evolving hematoma. A small amount of air 
within this collection is likely related to recent attempted 
aspiration. No new fluid collections or extraluminal oral 
contrast is present. 2. Persistent edema and wall thickening 
involving the visualized large bowel, most pronounced in the 
region of the splenic flexure. Slight interval worsening of

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with metastatic papillary serous 
ovarian CA who was transferred from ___ with SBO. She had 
exp laparotomy on ___ where a perforated transverse colon was 
found; a R extended hemicolectomy and end ileostomy was 
performed, with L colon no longer in continuity with GI tract. 
This surgery was reported to be uneventful with minimal blood 
loss but some intra-peritoneal intra-peritoneal spillage. She 
was transferred to ICU for post-op monitoring given severity of 
comorbidities.
.
Given the concern for intraoperative spillage, she was started 
on Vancomycin, Zosyn and Fluconazole for planned five day course 
(day ___ this was broadened to Vancomycin, Meropenem, 
Ciprofloxacin and Fluconazole (day ___ when she was found to 
have developed a concomitant pneumonia. Her pain was treated 
with a Dilaudid PCA and she was kept NPO with TPN post-surgery. 
She was also continued on IV Bblocker and IV PPI post surgery.
.
The patient remained hypoxic after her surgery, with high 
supplemental oxygen need, thought to be due to splinting from 
abdominal pain as well as pneumonia; she was treated with 
antibiotics as above. She initially had acute renal failure with 
poor urine output but this improved with volume resuscitation. 
.
This patient has known metastatic ovarian cancer and was on 
weekly Avastin/Taxol prior to GI perforation. She was given one 
dose of neupagen on ___ after surgery; this was stopped after 
discussing with Gyn/Onc. Gyn/Onc will further direct her 
oncologic treatment, with social work and pastoral care 
following. 
.
Patient was transferred to the floor on ___ after oxygen 
requirement was tapered to 6L. Patient was diuresed with IV 
lasix and TPN was halved. She was advanced from clear liquids to 
regular diet over the following two days with TPN discontinued. 
Patient's ostomy showed normal outputs with appropriate gas. On 
___, the superior pole of the abdominal incision was noted 
to be erythematous with clear drainage. 3 staples were removed, 
cultures sent, and wound was packed. Gram stain showed no 
organisms. Wound was monitored and anitbiotics continued. Given 
the appearance of the wound and persistent elevated EBC count, 
CT abdomen was performed to assess for abdominal fluid 
collection which revealed a small anterior fluid collection in 
the superior abdomen. ___ was consulted but the collection was 
too small to drain. Follow up CT scans were performed to see 
progression of collection with gradual resolution noted on 
imaging. Over the next several days, superior abdominal wound 
opened further with fascial dehiscence noted in wound and 
drainage of purulent fluid. Wound was packed with aquacel and 
drainage decreased over time. 

As wound improved, persistent leukocytosis raised concern for 
cdiff colitis. Patient was started on empiric flagyl and a 
sigmoidoscopy was performed to assess remnant colon for 
pseudomembranes, with none seen. Flagyl was stopped once 3 cdiff 
cultures were negative. On ___, patient was complaining of 
significant muscle cramping, refractory to diazepam. One dose of 
tizanidine was given and patient was overly sedated. She was 
monitored closely with no change in respiratory function, though 
she was drowsy. Once tizanidine wore off, she was active with no 
mental slowing. Tizanidine was not given and diazepam was 
stopped.

On ___, patient reported severe dyspnea and tachycardia and a 
CTA chest was performed to rule out PE. Scan was negative and 
patient's dyspnea was releived with nebulizer treatments and 
supplemental oxygen. A similar episode occured on ___, and a 
repeat CTA chest was performed in light of patient's high risk 
due to cancer, and immbolization. Repeat scan was also negative. 
On ___, interventional pulmonology was consulted for 
therapeutic thoracentesis of left pleural effusion in hopes of 
improving patient's dyspnea. 400 cc of seroud fluid was drained, 
with no bacterial growth, and chemistries consistent with 
transudate. Her dyspnea improved significantly after this, 
though she occasionally had episodes of dyspnea and tachycardia, 
presumably from anxiety.

Over the next ___ days, patient's leukocytosis stabilized around 
16 and her oxygen requirement resolved. She worked with physical 
therapy and po intake was encourage. 
Calorie count revealed inadequate calories intake. Her nutrition 
was supplemented with ensure shakes. 

At discharge, pt felt well. She was discharged on hospital 
day#28/post-operative day #26 in stable condition: afebrile, 
able to eat regular food, under adequate pain control with oral 
medications, and ambulating with ___ and urinating without 
difficulty.

Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Transverse colon perforation
 
Discharge Condition:
Good
 
Discharge Instructions:
___ were admitted to the hospital after emergency surgery for 
your colon perforation from your ovarian cancer. ___ have 
recovered from this procedure well and ___ are now ready to 
finish your recovery in rehab. 

___ have a long vertical incision on your abdomen that is closed 
with staples. This incision can be left open to air or covered 
with a dry sterile gauze dressing if the staples become 
irritated from clothing. The staples will stay in place until 
your first post-operative visit at which time they can be 
removed in the clinic, most likely by the office nurse. Please 
monitor the incision for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness at the incision, opening of the 
incision, increased pain at the incision line, draining of 
white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, or if ___ develop a 
fever. Please call the office if ___ develop these symptoms or 
go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe.  ___ may 
shower and let the warm water run over the incision line and pat 
the area dry with a towel; do not rub.

No heavy lifting for at least 6 weeks after surgery unless 
instructed otherwise by Dr. ___ Dr. ___ may 
gradually increase your activity as tolerated but avoid heavy 
exercise. 

___ may take Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take 
more than 4000mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while 
taking narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive 
a car while taking narcotic pain medication.

___ have a new ileostomy. The most common complication from a 
new ileostomy placement is dehydration. The output from the 
stoma is stool from the small intestine and the water content is 
very high. The stool is no longer passing through the large 
intestine which is where the water from the stool is reabsorbed 
into the body and the stool becomes formed. ___ must measure 
your ileostomy output for the next few weeks. The output from 
the stoma should not be more than 1200cc or less than 500cc. If 
___ find that your output has become too much or too little, 
please call the office for advice. The office nurse or nurse 
practitioner can recommend medications to increase or slow the 
ileostomy output. Keep yourself well hydrated. If ___ notice 
your ileostomy output increasing, take in more electrolyte drink 
such as gatoraide. Please monitor yourself for signs and 
symptoms of dehydration including: dizziness (especially upon 
standing), weakness, dry mouth, headache, or fatigue. If ___ 
notice these symptoms please call the office or return to the 
emergency room for evaluation if these symptoms are severe. ___ 
may eat a modified regular diet with your new ileostomy.

Please monitor the appearance of the ostomy and stoma and care 
for it as instructed by the wound/ostomy nurses. ___ stoma 
(intestine that protrudes outside of your abdomen) should be 
beefy red or pink. It may ooze small amounts of blood at times 
when touched and this should subside with time. The skin around 
the ostomy site should be kept clean and intact. Monitor the 
skin around the stoma for bulging or signs of infection listed 
above. Please care for the ostomy as ___ have been instructed by 
the wound/ostomy nurses. ___ will be able to make an appointment 
with the ostomy nurse in the clinic after surgery. ___ will have 
nurses at rehab for the next few weeks helping to monitor your 
ostomy until ___ are comfortable caring for it on your own.

Thank ___ for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that ___ will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!
 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 58-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain. She had a history of recurrent metastatic ovarian cancer and had undergone multiple surgeries and chemotherapy treatments. She was initially diagnosed with stage IIC ovarian cancer and had received carboplatin and Taxol therapy until she developed a carboplatin allergy. She was then switched to Doxil and later started on Arimidex. She had been stable until she developed abdominal pain, concern for acute appendicitis, and underwent laparoscopic evaluation, which revealed several carcinoma implants along both hemidiaphragms, the right lobe of the liver, and the lower abdomen on the sigmoid colon and appendix.

The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy with extended right colectomy and end ileostomy. She was found to have small bowel pneumatosis and was placed on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to concern for sepsis. She was also found to have rising CA-125 levels and was initiated on carboplatin therapy. However, she developed a carboplatin allergy and was switched to Doxil.

The patient's past medical history is significant for recurrent metastatic ovarian cancer, osteopenia, and a family history of CAD and ovarian cancer. Her physical exam revealed abdominal tenderness, absent bowel sounds, and a Foley catheter in place draining clear urine.

The patient's discharge medications included vanc/zosyn, and her discharge labs showed elevated WBC count, AST, and ALT levels. Her imaging studies revealed a partially rim-enhancing fluid collection within the anterior midline abdomen, no findings of bowel obstruction or leak, and bibasilar atelectasis with small left pleural effusion.

In summary, the patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of recurrent metastatic ovarian cancer who underwent exploratory laparotomy with extended right colectomy and end ileostomy due to abdominal pain and concern for acute appendicitis. She was found to have small bowel pneumatosis and was placed on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to concern for sepsis. She was also found to have rising CA-125 levels and was initiated on carboplatin therapy, but developed a carboplatin allergy and was switched to Doxil. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the podiatric surgery service 
post-operatively on ___ for a L foot infection. She was 
taken to the OR for left foot incision and drainage as well as 
debridement with VAC placement. Pt was evaluated by anesthesia 
and taken to the operating room.  There were no adverse events 
in the operating room; please see the operative note for 
details. Afterwards, pt was taken to the PACU in stable 
condition, then transferred to the ward for observation. 

Post-operatively, the patient remained afebrile with stable 
vital signs; pain was well controlled oral pain medication on a 
PRN basis.  The patient remained stable from both a 
cardiovascular and pulmonary standpoint. She was placed on 
vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and flagyl while hospitalized, 
switched to oral antibiotics on POD 4 and discharged with broad 
spectrum oral antibiotics. Her intake and output were closely 
monitored and noted to be adequate. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin throughout admission; early and frequent 
ambulation were strongly encouraged while minimizing 
weightbearing to her L foot. She was evaluated by physical 
therapy who recommended working with the patient for ___ more 
sessions prior to discharge. Physical therapy deemed her safe to 
return home with her current weightbearing status. Following 
flushing her wound and skin prep with betadine, her incision 
site to her L foot was closed at bedside on ___. Upon 
discharge, she was seen at the podiatric surgery clinic where 
she was placed in a total contact cast. 

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

L foot infection

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were admitted 
to the Podiatric Surgery service after your left foot surgery. 
You were placed on IV antibiotics, and switched to oral 
antibiotics during your hospital stay. You are being discharged 
home with the following instructions: 

ACTIVITY:
There are restrictions on activity. Please remain 
nonweight-bearing to your left foot until your follow up 
appointment. You may place minimal weight to your left foot in 
the total contact cast with transfers. You should keep this site 
elevated when ever possible (above the level of the heart!) 

No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.
PLEASE CALL US IMMEDIATELY FOR ANY OF THE FOLLOWING PROBLEMS:
Redness in or drainage from your leg wound(s).
New pain, numbness or discoloration of your foot or toes.
Watch for signs and symptoms of infection. These are: a fever 
greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus 
draining from the incision site. If you experience any of these 
or bleeding at the incision site, CALL THE DOCTOR.

Exercise:
Limit strenuous activity for 6 weeks.
No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next ___ days.
Try to keep leg elevated when able.

BATHING/SHOWERING:
You may shower immediately upon coming home, but you must keep 
your dressing CLEAN, DRY and INTACT. You can use a shower bag 
taped around your ankle/leg or hang your foot/leg outside of the 
bathtub. 

Avoid taking a tub bath, swimming, or soaking in a hot tub for 4 
weeks after surgery or until cleared by your physician.

MEDICATIONS:
Unless told otherwise you should resume taking all of the 
medications you were taking before surgery. 
Remember that narcotic pain meds can be constipating and you 
should increase the fluid and bulk foods in your diet. (Check 
with your physician if you have fluid restrictions.) If you feel 
that you are constipated, do not strain at the toilet. You may 
use over the counter Metamucil or Milk of Magnesia. Appetite 
suppression may occur; this will improve with time. Eat small 
balanced meals throughout the day. 

DIET:
There are no special restrictions on your diet postoperatively. 
Poor appetite is not unusual for several weeks and small, 
frequent meals may be preferred.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENT:
Be sure to keep your medical appointments. 
If a follow up appointment was not made prior to your discharge, 
please call the office on the first working day after your 
discharge from the hospital to schedule a follow-up visit. This 
should be scheduled on the calendar for seven to fourteen days 
after discharge. Normal office hours are ___ 
through ___.
PLEASE FEEL FREE TO CALL THE OFFICE WITH ANY OTHER CONCERNS OR 
QUESTIONS THAT MIGHT ARISE.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 77-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital due to mental status changes, failure to thrive, and a history of agitation and aggression. He has a past medical history of diabetes, coronary artery disease, hypertension, asthma, and chronic kidney disease. He was previously admitted to a skilled nursing facility (SNF) for similar symptoms and was discharged with a diagnosis of mild cognitive delay and confusion over his disposition. He was readmitted to the hospital after being transferred from the SNF, where he was found to have an excoriated red rash and a stage I coccygeal ulcer. He was given miconazole powder and haldol 1 mg IV in the emergency department.

The patient's physical examination revealed an elderly obese male who was alert and hypervigilant, but clearly delirious. His mental status was impaired, and he was unable to give a coherent history. His neurological examination was normal, except for increased tone and jerks in his left upper extremity.

The patient's laboratory results showed a normal complete blood count, electrolyte panel, and renal function tests. His urine analysis showed a specific gravity of 1.020, and his blood glucose level was 159 mg/dL. His electroencephalogram (EEG) was mildly abnormal, showing occasional bursts of generalized theta slowing.

The patient underwent a lumbar puncture, which showed a clear and colorless cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) with no white blood cells, red blood cells, or protein. His magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head and neck showed stable mild chronic small vessel ischemic changes and moderate diffuse parenchymal volume loss.

The patient was diagnosed with dementia, likely due to his rapid progression of cognitive decline. He was treated with haldol and reassurance, and his agitation and aggression improved. He was discharged from the hospital with a plan for further management and follow-up. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 63-year-old female who was admitted for a scheduled exploratory laparotomy with total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and sigmoid colectomy with reanastomosis due to grade 2 endometrial cancer. She has a history of hypertension, osteoarthritis, and diverticulitis. She has no known allergies or adverse reactions. The patient's diagnosis is endometrial cancer and diverticular disease. During her hospital stay, she underwent an exploratory laparotomy, lysis of adhesions, total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, total pelvic lymphadenectomy, and para-aortic lymph node sampling. She also had a rectosigmoid resection with reanastomosis. Post-operatively, she experienced an oxygen desaturation episode, but her oxygen saturation improved with supplemental oxygen and discontinuation of Dilaudid PCA. She was discharged home on post-operative day 4 with medications including docusate sodium, hydrochlorothiazide, atenolol, paroxetine, ibuprofen, oxycodone, and acetaminophen. Her discharge instructions included no heavy lifting for six weeks, no driving while taking narcotics, and taking pain medication as needed. She was also advised to avoid heavy lifting, intercourse, and tampons for 12 weeks. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on 
___ for evaluation and treatment of abdominal pain.  An 
abdominal ultra-sound revealed cute cholecystitis. The patient 
underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which went well without 
complication (reader referred to the Operative Note for 
details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the 
patient arrived on the floor tolerating CLD, on IV fluids, and 
Oxycodone and Tylenol for pain control.  The patient was 
hemodynamically stable.

Pain was well controlled. Diet was progressively advanced as 
tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. The patient 
voided without problem. During this hospitalization, the patient 
ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory 
toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively participated in 
the plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

acute cholecystitis

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___, 

___ were admitted to ___ and 
underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. ___ are recovering well 
and are now ready for discharge. Please follow the instructions 
below to continue your recovery:

___ were admitted to the hospital with acute cholecystitis. ___ 
were taken to the operating room and had your gallbladder 
removed laparoscopically. ___ tolerated the procedure well and 
are now being discharged home to continue your recovery with the 
following instructions.
 
Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the 
appointment listed below.
 
ACTIVITY:
 
o Do not drive until ___ have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel ___ could respond in an emergency.
o ___ may climb stairs. 
o  ___ may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
___ see your surgeon at your next visit.
o  Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o ___ may start some light exercise when ___ feel comfortable.
o ___ will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when ___ 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW ___ MAY FEEL: 
o  ___ may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. ___ 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust ___.
o  ___ may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
o  ___ might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
___ might feel somewhat depressed.
o  ___ could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow ___ may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressing ___ have small plastic bandages 
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
is normal.
o ___ may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless ___ were told 
otherwise.
o ___ may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
o ___ may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when ___ may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, ___ may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. ___ can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
o If ___ go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
o Your pain should get better day by day. If ___ find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o ___ will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if ___ take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long ___ will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
o If ___ are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when ___ 
cough or when ___ are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If ___ experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines ___ were on before the operation just as 
___ did before, unless ___ have been told differently.
If ___ have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

which showed WBC 47K and calcium pyrophosphate crystals. 
According to rheumatology, calcium pyrophosphate chrystals can 
be seen in both pseudo gout and in septic arthritis. Given 
concurrent immunosupresant therapy, and rising peripheral 
leukocytosis in the setting of positive blood cultures, concern 
was raised for septic arthritis. Culture of the fluid was 
negative though he was on vancomycin at the time which may have 
sterilized the culture.  He was taken to the operating room with 
orthopedics and underwent washout of his left knee and ankle.

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 57-year-old male who was admitted with fever and gram-positive cocci isolated from blood cultures. He has a history of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, secondary acute myeloid leukemia, and chronic kidney disease. He was recently treated with allogenic stem cell transplant from his brother and is currently enrolled in a clinical trial for CMV infection prevention. The patient's allergies include iodine, hydrochlorothiazide, lactose, and cefepime. He has a history of past medical conditions, including Mantel zone Stage 1A lymphoma, large cell B cell lymphoma, and secondary AML. The patient's physical examination revealed no significant abnormalities, except for erythema at the catheter site and hyperpigmentation over the axillae. His laboratory results showed normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, but elevated creatinine and liver enzymes. The patient was diagnosed with gram-positive cocci sepsis and was treated with antibiotics. He underwent removal of his catheter, arthrocentesis of his left knee, and operative washout of his left knee and ankle. At discharge, the patient was prescribed medications including vancomycin, magnesium sulfate, and phenazopyridine. ||endoftext||

She was also prescribed medications for anemia, electrolyte replacement, and pain management.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 66-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of toe pain. He has a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, foot ulcers, peripheral vascular disease (PVD), pulmonary hypertension, and chronic kidney disease (CKD). He was previously treated with ASA/Plavix for PVD. The patient's symptoms started two weeks ago and have not changed much over that time. He has been experiencing pain in his left toe, which has made it difficult for him to get up and ambulate. He has also been experiencing increased agitation and confusion, as well as urinary incontinence.

The patient underwent a left lower extremity angiogram with angioplasty of the proximal left posterior tibial artery, mid left posterior tibial artery, and left anterior tibial artery. He was found to have dry gangrene of his left toe, which was thought to be secondary to his extensive PVD and an aortic thrombus.

The patient was started on vancomycin, but it was discontinued upon admission to the medicine floor given low concern for infection or wet gangrene. He was continued on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with ASA and Plavix. Podiatry was consulted and is planning for outpatient surgical intervention. The patient's home lovastatin was switched to high-dose atorvastatin due to his extensive PVD and other medical history.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated blood glucose, urea nitrogen, and creatinine levels, as well as decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit levels. His imaging studies showed atherosclerotic changes in the neck vessels and aortic arch, as well as a short segment stenosis and occlusion in the left posterior tibial artery.

The patient's hospital course was complicated by dry gangrene of his left toe, PVD, and an aortic thrombus. He underwent successful balloon angioplasty of the proximal left posterior tibial artery and distal left anterior tibial artery. He was continued on DAPT and was discharged with plans for outpatient surgical intervention and continued management of his medical conditions. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F who initially presented from assisted 
living to ___ with chest pain. Cardiac work up was 
unremarkable. CT scan showed evicence of cholecystitis and she 
was given IV zosyn. The following morning she had an elevated

Surgery was discussed with the patient, husband, and health care

the operating room urgently for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. 
Intra-operative cholangiogram was preformed and negative for 
obstruction. Post operatively she remained intubated and was 
transferred to the ICU. 

ICU Course:
On POD0 she remained intubated and hemodynamically stable. On 
POD2 she was extubed without difficulty to nasal canula and then 
weaned to room air. Foley catheter was removed and she voided 
spontaneously adequate urine. Liver function and total bilirubin 
continued to trend down. Required 250 ml albumin for low urine 
output. On POD4 she was transferred to the floor. 

Floor Course:

to the surgical floor for further management. She tolerated a 
regular diet and converted or oral pain medication with 
continued good effect. The patient continued to void without 
problem. Intake and output were monitored. She was given 
laxative for constipation. Physical therapy evaluated her 
mobility and recommended discharge to acute rehab. Respiratory 
toilet and incentive spirometry were encouraged and the patient 
and family actively participated in the plan of care. The 
patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were 
used during this stay.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating with assistance, voiding adequate urine, and 
pain was well controlled. The patient was discharged to acute 
rehab. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan. Follow up appointments were scheduled.

Please note the following discharge instructions:
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. 
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

She has a history of mild dementia, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding while taking Coumadin. She was given zosyn and admitted to surgery after a CT scan revealed evidence of cholecystitis. The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was diagnosed with emphysematous cholecystitis. She had an elevated heart rate and increased pain after the procedure, but her vital signs remained stable. The patient was intubated and transferred to the ICU, where she was extubated and weaned to room air. She was then transferred to the surgical floor, where she tolerated a regular diet and was able to void without problem. The patient was discharged to acute rehab, where she will continue to receive physical therapy and respiratory care.

The patient has the following allergies: codeine. She has a history of mild dementia, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding while taking Coumadin. She also has a history of osteoarthritis and has undergone a left total hip replacement.

The patient's medications on admission included simvastatin, fibercon, acetaminophen, ASA, clobestasol, mirtazepine, and pantoprazole. Her discharge medications include acetaminophen, cepacol, docusate sodium, heparin, metoprolol tartrate, and polyethylene glycol.

The patient's physical exam revealed a soft and distended abdomen with increased tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Her vital signs were stable, and she was able to move all extremities equally and strongly. Her speech was clear and fluent, and she was able to follow commands. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure to take care of you at ___. You were 
admitted for a urinary tract infection affecting your surgical 
bladder. The bacteria causing the infection are strong and 
resistant to most antibiotics, so you required strong 
antibiotics through the IV. You completed a full 10 day course 
of Linezolid and Cefipime.

While you were here, you developed a problem with bleeding. 
First you were bleeding from your gut. We think this is because 
your platelets (a part of your blood that stops bleeding) were 
very low, and because of your liver disease. Later, you 
developed bleeding from your stoma. You needed several 
transfusions, because your blood counts were low. You were 
transferred to the intensive care unit, where they made a new 
path for blood to flow from your gut back to your heart without 
passing through your liver, lowering the pressure in your 
vessels, and a procedure to scar down the bleeding vessels 
themselves. After this your bleeding resolved.

You also developed some confusion while you were here. We think 
this is because you liver is not able to clear toxins from your 
blood as effectively anymore. For this confusion, it is very 
important that you continue to take lactulose and rifaximin.

Unfortunately, you left the hospital premises before you could 
be safely discharged and given any of this information. We 
called you and asked you to come back to the hospital but you 
refused. We re-inforced the need for you to seek medical care. 
You then hung-up the phone on us. 

We wish you all the best going forward. 

Sincerely,

Your medical team at ___

___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the ___ on ___ for rsurgical 
management of his coronary artery disease. He was taken  to the 
Operating Room where he underwent coronary artery bypass 
grafting to three vessels. Please see operative note for detail. 
 Overall the patient tolerated the procedure well and 
post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable 
condition for recovery and invasive monitoring.  
 POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable.  Beta blocker was initiated and the 
patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  The 
patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further 
recovery.  Foley re-placed for urinary retention and Flomax 
initiated.   Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued 
without complication.  He had a brief burst of AFib which 
converted to SR with Lopressor.  The patient was evaluated by 
the Physical Therapy service for assistance with strength and 
mobility.  He became orthostatic following simultaneous dosing 
of Lopressor, Lasix and Imdur. Doses staggered the following day 
and the patient tolerated well. AFib returned.  Xarelto 
initiated for anti-coagulation.   By the time of discharge on 
POD 5 the patient was ambulating freely, the wound was healing 
and pain was controlled with oral analgesics.  The patient was 
discharged home in good condition with appropriate follow up 
instructions.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 69-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for surgical management of his coronary artery disease. He presented with chest pain and was referred to Dr. ___ after a stress test. The patient has a history of diabetes type II, dyslipidemia, and GERD. He also has a bullet wound in his left leg from his military service, but there is no retained metal in his body.

The patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting to three vessels, and the procedure was successful. He was extubated on the first post-operative day and was able to ambulate freely by the time of discharge. The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including acetaminophen, furosemide, isosorbide mononitrate, metoprolol tartrate, potassium chloride, rivaroxaban, tamsulosin, tramadol, metformin XR, ascorbic acid, aspirin, fenofibrate nanocrystallized, and glimepiride.

The patient's allergies and adverse reactions include no known allergies or adverse drug reactions. His diagnosis is coronary artery disease, and he underwent cardiac catheterization and TEE (transesophageal echocardiogram) as part of his evaluation. ||endoftext||

HTN, BPH, CAD, s/p ICD for CMP (EF now normalized) who presented 
to the emergency room s/p fall in his home with a small 
laceration over his right eyelid however with significant 
periorbital hematoma.  

He is somewhat confused on interview on the floor and there is 
no family at the bedside. He states, through an interpreter, 
that he tried to get up from the chair that he was sleeping in 
and after a few steps fell and hit his head. He states that he 
can normally take a few steps on his own. He otherwise states 
that he did not notice any blood in his urine at home but that 
he wears diapers for incontinence. He denies any pain, SOB, CP, 
diarrhea, or constipation. He notes that he has not had any 
fevers or chills at home but does have a dry cough that seems to 
have gotten worse over the last few days (?, unclear duration).  

 
 In the ED, initial vitals were: 100, 67, 138/80, 15, 97% RA  
 - Exam notable for: signficiant ecchymosis over the right eye, 
unable to open the eye due to significant swelling. 2cm 
laceration over the right eyelid, hemostatic.    
 Ophthalmology was consulted and did not find any need for acute 
ophthalmic intervention after exam but recommended erythromycin 
eye drops for 48 H post-eye exam.  
 A foley was placed and patient developed new hematuria possibly 
from pulling at foley catheter therefore CBI was started to 
prevent clotting but urology was not consulted. He was admitted 
to medicine for fever and hematuria with UTI and falls.  
 Vitals on transfer were: 101.8, 66, 156/57, 20, 94% RA

prevent rejection of corneal implant.

IMAGING
==============================
CT C-spine ___ IMPRESSION: 
1. Limited examination due to motion artifact.  Exam is non 
diagnostic at the C2-3 and C4-5 through C5-6 levels.  Apparent 
anterolisthesis of C5 on C6 is likely due to motion artifact.  
No visualized fracture. 
2. Extensive degenerative changes most severe at C3-4 and C4-5. 

CT sinus/mandible ___
IMPRESSION:  Right periorbital hematoma without underlying 
fracture.  Possible tiny component of hemorrhage the postseptal 
region abutting the lacrimal gland without mass effect. 

CT-pelvis ___  
IMPRESSION: 
1. No evidence of acute fracture.  Apparent cortical step-off of 
the left 
proximal femoral diaphysis on sagittal images is thought to be 
motion artifact rather than true fracture.  No evidence of soft 
tissue hematoma. 
2. No free fluid or fluid collections in the pelvis. 
3. Underdistended urinary bladder, limits evaluation.  Several  
unchanged 
urinary bladder diverticula. 
4. Severe enlargement of the prostate gland. 

CXR ___ IMPRESSION:    
In comparison with the study of ___, there is increased 
opacification at the left base with silhouetting hemidiaphragm, 
consistent with pleural effusion and volume loss the left lower 
lobe.  In the appropriate clinical setting, it would be 
impossible to exclude the possibility of superimposed pneumonia 
left great. 
No evidence of vascular congestion.  The remainder of the lungs 
is clear.  
Dual channel pacer device remains in place with leads extending 
to the right atrium and apex of the right ventricle. 

CXR ___ IMPRESSION:   
Left lower lobe consolidation is improving.  There is no 
significant pleural effusion. 

Renal US ___ IMPRESSION:  
No evidence of hydronephrosis bilaterally.  Bilateral renal 
cysts.  Note is made that the known small solid mass arising 
from the lower pole of the left kidney could not be visualized 
on today's portable bedside exam. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo man who presented w/ R periorbital hematoma after a fall 
at home, found to have a UTI and likely CAP, with hospital 
course complicated by ___ ___ obstruction, hematuria.

#Leukocytosis: Peaked to 13.1 on ___ on last day of treatment 
for CAP and UTI. Unclear source as respiratory symptoms were 
improving, ___ resolving, follow-up blood cultures were 
negative, and patient remained afebrile. Downtrended to 10.1 on 
day of discharge.

___ retention: Cr spike to 2.8 on ___ after removal of 
foley ___. Immediate 1L urine output with foley replacement. 
Renal u/s showed no hydronephrosis. ___ FeUrea (34.5%)and FeNa 
(0.84%) were equivocal, suggesting that ___ may have been 
attributable to both post-renal obstruction and prerenal 
azotemia. Cr improved steadily with catheterization, and was 1.1 
on DC. Tamsulosin and finasteride were started. Foley will be 
continued on discharge as patient was unable to void 
spontaneously and straight cathing was complicated by blood at 
the urethral meatus. Patient should follow-up with urology for 
foley maintenance. 

#Atrial Fibrillation w/ h/o CVA x2: Rate-controlled, on 
warfarin, sub-therapeutic throughout admission. Given high 
Chads2 score, patient was bridged with enoxaparin, which should 
be continued until INR >2. Warfarin dose increased to 3 mg 
daily. INR 1.7 on discharge.

#S/p Fall at Home: Unclear precipitant of fall. No known LOC per 
hx from pt and wife. Possible mechanical fall i/s/o 
deconditioning. Orthostasis also possible factor given suspicion 
for active PNA at time of admission. Pt does have 
known afib with ICD, though ICD found to be functioning well 
without arrhythmia on EP evaluation during admission. ___ 
evaluated patient and determined him to be suitable for rehab.  

#GPR & GPC Bacteremia: Corynebacterium and coag-neg staph 
isolated from 1 bottle (___) over 5d,thought to be contaminant. 
Follow-up blood cultures negative. Patient hemodynamically 
stable throughout admission; fever to 100.5 on ___ likely 
attributable to CAP.

___ Hematoma: After fall at home, with periorbital 
laceration sutured in ED. Evaluated by ophtho in the ED, who 
determined no need for surgical intervention. Hematoma improved 
throughout admission, and patient did not experience visual 
changes. Sutures removed on ___. Patient should have 
ophthalmology follow-up as outpatient.

#Hypoactive Delirium: Stuttering mental status declines noted in 
OMR over past year. Prior CT head imaging notable for diffuse 
microvascular ischemia. Pt remained somewhat somnolent on exams, 
but as alert and oriented x2-3 when roused. 
Deliriogenic medications including ipratropium and cetirizine 
were d/c'd on ___. Per his daughter, patient often becomes 
altered during past hospitalizations. Daughter reported patient 
was at his mental status baseline on day of discharge.

#CAP vs. Aspiration Pneumonitis: Noted on ___ CXR after patient 
spiked fever to 100.5. Patient also had diffuse upper and lower 
airway wheezing, with intermittent dyspnea. Patient was treated 
with IV vancomycin (___), IV cefepime (___), IV unasyn 
(___), PO ampicillin (___) for a total of 7 days of 
antibiotics. Infiltrate noted to be improved without effusion on 
repeat ___ CXR. Blood cultures negative except for ___ blood 
culture growing GPR and coag-negative staph, thought to be a 
contaminant. 

#UTI: Urine cx (___) showed pan-sensitive proteus. As prior 
UA/Ucx prior to foley insertion was clean, may be ___ to foley 
insertion. Patient was treated with 7 days of antibiotics as 
above. Patient should have urology follow-up for indwelling 
foley. 

#Hematuria: Noted on admission after foley insertion, resolved 
initially 
with bladder irrigation. Mild hematuria without clots recurred 
after foley re-insertion prior to discharge, likely in the 
setting of traumatic foley and anticoagulation. Patient should 
follow-up with urology as above.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
===============
#Dysphagia: Initial concern for aspiration based on nursing 
observation. Cleared by speech and swallow for thin liquid and 
pureed diet. Meds crushed and given in applesauce.

#Presumed RCC: Left lower pole renal mass modestly increased in 
size on last admission. Last seen by urology ___, 
recommended repeat CT in ___. Patient should follow-up 
with urology sooner than scheduled ___ appointment for 
maintenance of indwelling foley catheter.

#Hypertension:  Intermittently with HTN up to SBP 160s during 
admission. Home losartan held while patient had obstructive ___, 
but restarted prior to DC as ___ improved. Patient also started 
on amlodipine 5 mg daily - his daughter reported 
amlodipine not a home med, but refill history indicates 
prescription for amlodipine 10 mg daily.

#Coronary Artery Disease: Aspirin and statin continued. 
 
#Chronic diastolic heart failure (ECHO w/ LVEF >55% in ___, 
s/p ICD: Home Lasix was held during admission in the setting of 
active infection. Was euvolemic on exam on discharge, and 
patient maintained even fluid status according to I/Os. Lasix 
will be held on discharge, and daily weights and volume status 
should be monitored. 

#BPH: Finasteride and tamsulosin started during admission for 
urinary retention.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
====================================
[] Home furosemide held during admission, and patient remained 
euvolemic. Please obtain daily weights and consider restarting 
furosemide if patient's weight increases >3 lbs or if he 
appears volume-overloaded. 
[] DC weight = 80 kg (bed weight)
[] Patient should follow-up with ophthalmology for his 
___ hematoma. 
[] Amlodipine 5 mg started during admission (unclear if was 
taking at home). Consider increasing if hypertensive.
[] Foley inserted during admission for obstructive ___ and 
subsequent inability to void. Consider trial of void to 
decrease risk of recurrent UTI. Patient should have urology 
follow-up.
[] Tamsulosin and finasteride started during admission for 
BPH/urinary retention.
[] Warfarin increased to 3 mg daily in the setting of 
subtherapeutic INRs. 
[] Bridging with enoxaparin ongoing at ___. DC INR = 1.7.  
Continue enoxaparin bridge until is 2.0 or above. Repeat INR on 
___.
[] Cetirizine stopped for deliriogenic effect.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 67-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for further care due to a nonhealing ulceration on his right heel. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease, venous stasis, and skin changes, and has been followed by a podiatrist and wound care services. He was recently started on home Ceftriaxone and was evaluated by a doctor after experiencing increasing right foot pain.

The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type 2 with neuropathy, coronary artery disease with a previous myocardial infarction, chronic systolic congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and polyarthritis rheumatica. He is anticoagulated and has a history of allergies to drugs.

The patient's physical examination revealed bilateral edema, pitting with hyperpigmentation changes to his lower extremities, and a right lower extremity with blanching erythema and a punched-out heel ulceration. His pulses were palpable, but his right pedal pulse was absent.

Laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell counts, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine levels, as well as abnormal liver function tests. The patient's blood glucose levels were also elevated.

The patient underwent a right heel incision and drainage, as well as a right below-knee amputation. He was prescribed medications including Vancomycin, Digoxin, and Ceftriaxone.

The patient's wound culture showed growth of Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus anginosus, and Bacteroides fragilis group. The patient's antibiotic sensitivities were reported as follows: Staphylococcus aureus was sensitive to Clindamycin, Erythromycin, Gentamicin, Levofloxacin, Oxacillin, and Trimethoprim/Sulfa. ||endoftext||

cover it when outside. 
 Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
 We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
 You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
 No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
 If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
 No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
 Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
 You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication as indicated on your discharge instructions. It is 
important that you take this medication consistently and on 
time. 
 You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
 You may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
 You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
 You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
 Feeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
 Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
 Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
 Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
 Nausea and/or vomiting
 Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
 Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
 Seizures
 Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
 Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
 Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
 Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
 Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
 Sudden severe headaches with no known reason
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the 
gynecology service after undergoing and IV guided drainage of a 
tuboovarian abscess noted on her left adnexa. Please see the 
operative report for full details.

Her immediate post op course was complicated by low grade fevers 
on post-operative day 1 and 2 and IV antibiotics were broadened 
to include gentamycin, clindamycin, and ampicillin. On post-op 
day 2, patient had an elevated WBC with increasing left shift 
and repeat pelvic ultrasound and CT pelvis with contrast was 
performed. Imaging was notable for a decreased left adnexal 
fluid collection of 3cm (decreased from 6cm on admission) and a 
new right rim-enhancing 1.3cm and 0.9 collection on the right 
adnexa. Interventional radiology was re-consulted but given 
improvement of WBC count and clinical improvement, additional 
drainage deferred. On post-op day 3, she was transitioned to PO 
levofloxacin and metronidazole. Patient remained afebrile and 
felt subjectively improved. 

During her stay she was noted to have negative gonorrhea, 
chlamydia, trichomoniasis, and HIV tested. Tumor markers were 
noted to be within normal limits. The fluid drained from her 
left adnexal mass grew no microorganisms and urine cultures were 
negative. 

On post-operative day 3, she was voiding spontaneously, her diet 
was advanced without difficulty, and she was transitioned to 
oral pain medications and oral antibiotocs.She was then 
discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up 
scheduled.

day Disp #*27 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  Atenolol 100 mg PO DAILY  
5.  Losartan Potassium 50 mg PO DAILY  
6.  MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 500 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home

Tubo-ovarian abscess

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service for treatment of 
tubo-ovarian abscess. You were started on antibiotics and also 
underwent an ___ guided drainage of a fluid collection in your 
abdomen. We feel that it is now safe to discharge 

Please follow these instructions:
- General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

Constipation:
* Drink ___ liters of water every day.
* Incorporate 20 to 35 grams of fiber into your daily diet to 
maintain normal bowel function. Examples of high fiber foods 
include:
Whole grain breads, Bran cereal, Prune juice, Fresh fruits and 
vegetables, Dried fruits such as dried apricots and prunes, 
Legumes, Nuts/seeds. 
* Take Colace stool softener ___ times daily.
* Use Dulcolax suppository daily as needed.
* Take Miralax laxative powder daily as needed. 
* Stop constipation medications if you are having loose stools 
or diarrhea.
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), recurrent pneumonias, and bronchiectasis. He was previously treated with levofloxacin for a pneumonia, but his symptoms persisted, and he was admitted to the hospital for further care. 

The patient's past medical history includes coronary artery disease, benign prostatic hypertrophy, hypertension, and mild congestive heart failure. He also has a history of polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) and was recently restarted on prednisone. 

The patient's physical examination revealed inspiratory crackles in the left upper lobe and expiratory wheezes bilaterally. His laboratory results showed leukocytosis, and his chest imaging revealed bilateral upper lobe pneumonias. 

The patient was diagnosed with bronchial lavage, which was negative for malignant cells. He was treated with antibiotics and mucolytics and was discharged on cefpodoxime to complete a 14-day course of antibiotics. He will follow up with his primary care physician and an ear, nose, and throat specialist. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 27-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with hemoptysis, a severe thrombocytopenia, and a history of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). She has a history of multiple admissions for bleeding, including menorrhagia, and has undergone treatments including steroids, rituxan, IVIG, and splenectomy. The patient's past medical history includes H. pylori, iron-deficiency anemia, menorrhagia and fibroids, shingles, and ovarian cyst. She has also had a bone infarct in the past, likely due to high-dose steroids.

The patient's physical examination revealed a petechial rash on her chest and arms, as well as scattered petechiae on her skin. Her laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 8.7, a hematocrit of 32.3, and platelets of 7. She was treated with high-dose dexamethasone and IVIG, which improved her platelet counts and resolved her clinical signs of bleeding.

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and her physical examination revealed a normal affect, warm and dry skin, and full range of motion of her bilateral hips and knees. Her laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 21.8, a hematocrit of 24.0, and platelets of 86.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, including high-dose prednisone taper, IVIG, and plasmapheresis. She was also advised to follow up with hematology oncology for further treatment and monitoring. ||endoftext||
