||startoftext|| The patient is an 84-year-old female who was admitted with a chief complaint of gastrointestinal bleed. She has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, ischemic cardiomyopathy, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. She also has a history of mitral regurgitation and squamous cell carcinoma of the right lung. 

The patient's presenting symptoms included hematemesis, diarrhea, constipation, and fatigue. Her physical examination revealed conjunctival pallor, dark stool, and coffee-ground emesis. Laboratory results showed anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. 

The patient underwent an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (EGD) which revealed erosions in the gastroesophageal junction, stomach, and duodenum, as well as granularity and erythema in the stomach and duodenum compatible with gastritis and duodenitis. 

The patient was diagnosed with moderate to severe regional systolic dysfunction and moderate to severe mitral regurgitation. She was prescribed high-dose proton pump inhibitors twice a day and was recommended to undergo a repeat EGD in 8 weeks for evaluation of the esophageal erosion. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old right handed ___ driver with an unknown medical 
history was found in his truck confused by the police on the 
morning of admission. According to the patient, he has nausea 
last night, which continued until this morning. He also had a 
bifrontal throbbing headache, which continues to be present. He 
is not sure whether the headache came on suddenly. He does not 
know why he was found in his truck with a laceration above his 
right eye, and a dislocated right middle finger.  It was 
hypothesized he may have had a seizure resulting in mild trauma 
and possible contra-coup injury (right frontal trauma with left 
posterior temporal contusion).  Other possibilities included 
arteriovenous malformation or underlying mass.  The patient was 
admitted to the neurology ICU for further management.
.

.

continued at 1000 mg bid.  He was monitored initially with q1h 
neurochecks.  His systolic blood pressure was maintained between

intraparenchymal and small subdural hematoma.  MRI brain showed 
no evidence of underlying mass.  A CTA showed no sign of 
vascular malformation.  The patient will undergo repeat MRI 
brain with and without contrast in ___ weeks for further 
evaluation of his hemorrhage.  He will continue on keppra at 
1000 mg bid for at least six months.  The patient was 
transferred to the neurology floor on HD#2.  There he was 
evaluated by ___ who found that he was stable and able to 
ambulate without assistance. A repeat head CT on ___ showed no 
change in the intraparenchymal or subdural bleeds. He did not 
have any seizure activity while in house.
.

middle finger which was subsequently reduced. This was splinted 
and did not cause him significant pain
.
CV/Pulm/Renal/GI: the patient was stable from a cardiac, 
pulmonary, renal and GI standpoint. He tolerated a regular diet 
without issues, he made adequate urine and did not have any 
desaturations.

On HD 5 the patient felt well and a repeat head CT showed no 
evolving process. He was anxious to return home to ___ 
as his family had finally arrived in ___. He will take all 
hospital documents with him and tranfer his care down to PA near 
his family. At the time of discharge he was ambulating without 
assistance, tolerating a regular diet but did have some 
persistent confusion. However, he and his family understood the 
gravity of his problem and certified that he would arrange 
follow up care with neurology and neurosurgery upon his return 
to ___.

#Hyperkalemia: K 7.7 in setting of missed PD sessions and 
suspected dietary non compliance. treated with insulin, D50 and 
Ca gluconate, Kayexalate in ED and 2 cycles of PD, per renal 
team, increasing bowel regimen to facilitate K excretion. 
Patient had improvement of K in first few PD sessions, and 
continued to have normal K throughout the rest of the

adjusts the regular in the morning based on the prelunch BG and 
adjusts the regular before supper based BG at bed time. His 
nighttime coverage was also supplemented by 40 units of insulin 
being placed in his diasylate. 

#Leukocytosis - Chest xray without consolidation. PD fluid 
without signs of infection.  LFTs WNL and no ABD pain making 
abdominal sourses (pancreatitis, cholangitis, cholecystitis) 
less likely. CXR negative and patient makes no urine. No 
evidence of diarrhea. Covered with CTX as intra-abdominal 
infection was possible and if so, would want to prevent fibrosis 
of peritoneum. This was d/c'ed as patient was afebrile and 
cultures negative. We observed him with leukocytosis for several 
days and extensive evaluation and work up remained negative. 

#Hyponatremia - Likely in the setting of missing PD leading to 
hypervolemic hyponatremia. Pseudohyponatremia also due to 
elevated glucose levels. Improved with treatment.
 
#Previous pancreas and kidney transplants: Continued prednisone 
5mg daily. Per D/C summary on ___, Tacro was stopped per 
renal team instructions; thus bactrim was stopped given no need 
for PCP ___.

#Coffee Ground Emesis - Pt vomited coffee ground emesis on 
arrival to the CCU. Pt states he had nausea and vomiting day 
prior but without blood. He continued to vomit on the ward but 
no blood or coffee grounds were observed. His LFTs were normal, 
thus less likely esophageal varices. In the setting of diabetes, 
gastroparesis was likely resulting in frequent N&V and thus MW 
tear was possible. Important to keep in mind Uremia can cause 
platelet dysfucntion. Given IV PPI BID, IV Zofran. Crit trend 
was stable.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It has been a pleasure taking part in your care. You were 
admitted to ___ for a dangerously high 
potassium level after missing dialysis twice. You were admitted 
to the intensive care unit where you were treated and observed, 
and subsequently transferred to the floor. Your potassium 
improved to normal. You were also seen by the foot doctors, who 
would like to follow up with you as noted below. 

You had hard-to-control blood sugars, and you were seen by the 
___ diabetes team, who provided recommendations for how to 
better control your blood sugars. Please follow these as 
described below. 

It was recommended that you stay in the hospital to try and fix 
your blood sugars, but you desired to leave against medical 
advice. You expressed an understanding of the risks involved 
with leaving prior to becoming more stable, which include 
diabetic ketoacidosis which can cause serious injury and death, 
and electrolyte abnormalities which can cause an irregular heart 
rhythm and death. Please follow up with health care providers as 
listed below.

Continue to perform dialysis on your normal schedule and 
maintain a low potassium diet. Please also take your insulin as 
prescribed and check your blood sugars regularly. This is 
crucial for you to maintain your health. Please follow up with 
all your appointments, and continue to take your medications as 
prescribed.

Again, it has been a pleasure taking part in your care, and we 
wish you the best. If you develop any fevers, chills, 
uncontrolled blood sugars, or develop any concerning signs or 
symptoms, please call your doctor or present to the ED. 

We wish you the best,

- Your ___ care team

||startoftext|| The patient is a 43-year-old male with a chief complaint of hyperkalemia. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus (DMI) complicated by end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is currently on peritoneal dialysis (PD) and insulin. He was admitted to the hospital after presenting with hypoglycemia, syncopal episodes, fatigue, and a potassium level of 7.7. He reported missing two days of PD and eating many bananas, which may have contributed to his hyperkalemia. The patient was treated with insulin, D50, calcium gluconate, and kayexalate in the emergency department and underwent two cycles of PD. His potassium level improved, and he was discharged with a plan to increase his bowel regimen to facilitate potassium excretion.

The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), chronic kidney disease, tonsil hypertrophy, anemia, depression, secondary hyperparathyroidism, vitamin D deficiency, peripheral vascular disease, and a history of tobacco abuse. He also has a family history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and kidney cancer.

The patient's physical examination was normal, with no acute distress, and his laboratory results showed a leukocytosis of 19.3, anemia, and lactate of 0.7. His imaging studies, including a chest x-ray and kidney, ureter, and bladder (KUB) x-ray, were normal. His blood cultures were negative, and his fluid culture showed no growth.

The patient was discharged with a plan to start on NPH insulin and regular insulin by carb counting, and to check his blood glucose levels before meals and adjust his insulin doses accordingly. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is an 89-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital after falling down five stairs and becoming unresponsive. She was intubated at the scene and transported to the hospital, where a head CT scan revealed an acute on chronic subdural hematoma, traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage, and intraventricular hemorrhage. The patient was not deemed a surgical candidate and remained intubated and ventilated for several days. Despite showing no neurologic improvement, the patient was extubated and transferred to the floor, where she eventually passed away. The patient had a history of high cholesterol, knee replacement, and no known allergies or adverse reactions. She was prescribed several medications during her hospital stay, including statin and aspirin, but was not discharged with any medications. The patient's diagnosis was subdural hematoma and intraparenchymal hemorrhage. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted  and was taken to the operating room 
for a total knee arthroplasty. Please see operative report for 
details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated 
the procedure well. Pain was initially controlled with a PCA 
followed by a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The 
patient was placed in a CPM machine with range of motion that 
started at ___ degrees of flexion before being increased to 90 
degrees as tolerated. The patient received IV antibiotics for 24 
hours postoperatively, as well as lovenox for DVT prophylaxis 
starting on the morning of POD#1. The drain was removed without 
incident on POD#1. The Foley catheter was removed on POD#2 and 
the patient was subsequently voiding independently. The surgical 
dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was 
found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal 
drainage. 
 
On the morning of POD1 the pt went into rapid afib RVR.  15mg 
dilt pushed, med consult called.  His rate was then controlled.  
 His EKG did not show ischemic changes and cardiac enzymes were 
negative.  Because of continued intermittent rapid ventricular 
response, his toprol was changed to lopressor 37.5mg TID and 
given 1pRBC with good response.  

He had a positive urine analysis, so he was empirically started 
on ciprofloxacin 500mg BID for planned 6 doses.  

While in the hospital, the patient was seen daily by physical 
therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and 
repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was 
tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The patient was 
afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was 
acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral 
regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and 
the wound was benign. The patient progressed well with physical 
therapy. Post-operative Xrays demonstrated hardware in good 
position. The patient was discharged in stable condition.  The 
patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as tolerated 
on the operative extremity.

Mental Status: Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane)

 
Discharge Instructions:
Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills.
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool
softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent this side effect.
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon or your primary physician.
6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five 
days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at least 
four weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues to be 
non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be removed 
will be taken out by the visiting nurse or rehab facility two 
weeks after your surgery.
7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in four weeks.
8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).
9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for three weeks 
to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  After 
completing the lovenox, please take Aspirin 325mg daily for an 
additional three weeks.
10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four week 
checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each 
day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check 
wound regularly for
signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. 
Staples will be removed by the visiting nurse or rehab facility 
in two weeks.
11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after 
surgery.
12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow 
up appointment.
Physical Therapy:
ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity.  No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow 
up appointment.
Treatments Frequency:

||startoftext|| The patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for a total knee replacement due to right knee pain caused by osteoarthritis and significant flexion contracture. He has a history of obesity, atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure, COPD/RAD, gastric sleeve surgery, incarcerated ventral hernia repair with mesh, obstructive sleep apnea, chronic venous stasis disease, hypothyroidism, left hip replacement, and right knee repair and replacement. He has allergies to propafenone and warfarin.

The patient underwent a total knee arthroplasty and tolerated the procedure well. He was started on pain medications and was placed in a CPM machine to improve range of motion. He received IV antibiotics and lovenox for DVT prophylaxis.

At discharge, the patient was taking several medications, including aspirin, simvastatin, gabapentin, acetaminophen, ursodiol, levothyroxine, citalopram, trazodone, multivitamin, folic acid, ferrous sulfate, hydromorphone, metoprolol, and diltiazem. He was also prescribed mupirocin calcium ointment and lovenox injections.

The patient was discharged in stable condition, with instructions to follow up with his primary physician and to weigh himself daily. He was advised to return to the emergency department or notify his physician if he experiences any severe pain, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers, shaking chills, or other concerns. ||endoftext||

Mr. ___ was admitted to the Orthopaedic Trauma service for

calcaneus.  He tolerated the procedure well, and there were no 
complications.  He was placed in a splint.  Please see Operative 
Report for full details.  Post-operatively, the patient was 
taken to the recovery room and then transferred to the floor in 
the usual fashion.  Pain was controlled with a Dilaudid PCA.

The patient worked with the Physical Therapy service during his 
hospitalization and made steady progress.  On POD#1, the PCA was 
discontinued and the patient was transitioned to an oral pain 
regimen.  

On the day of discharge, the patient was deemed ready for 
discharge home.  He was able to tolerate a regular diet, void 
spontaneously, ambulate with crutches, and his pain was 
controlled with oral pain medications.  He was given detailed 
precautionary instructions as well as instructions regarding

The patient is a 44-year-old male who was admitted to the Orthopaedic Trauma service for repair of a right calcaneus fracture sustained in a fall. He underwent open reduction and internal fixation of the fracture and tolerated the procedure well. The patient was placed in a splint and made steady progress with physical therapy during his hospitalization. At discharge, he was able to tolerate a regular diet, void spontaneously, ambulate with crutches, and had controlled pain with oral pain medications. The patient was discharged home with instructions to remain non-weightbearing on his right lower extremity, elevate his right leg to reduce swelling and pain, and not remove his splint. He was also prescribed medications for pain, blood thinning, and bowel regularity. The patient's discharge diagnosis was a right calcaneus fracture, and he was advised to follow up with his doctor in two weeks for removal of stitches or staples. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) that has relapsed to the central nervous system (CNS). He was admitted for high-dose methotrexate treatment. The patient has a history of CAD, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, vasectomy, OSA, tonsillectomy, and bilateral lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVTs). He is allergic to erythromycin base.

The patient's chief complaint is a cycle #7 high-dose methotrexate. He has received six cycles of R-EPOCH and four doses of intrathecal methotrexate for CNS prophylaxis. He has also received Rituxan and ICE salvage chemotherapy.

The patient's diagnosis is relapsed DLBCL with CNS involvement. He has undergone several cycles of chemotherapy, including R-EPOCH and ICE, and has received Rituxan and methotrexate.

The patient's medications at discharge include sodium bicarbonate tablets, IV fluids with bicarbonate for alkalinization, leucovorin rescue every six hours until methotrexate levels are less than 0.10, and dexamethasone 4mg every 12 hours. He will also start Neupogen daily after clearance of methotrexate.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia secondary to chemotherapy. He has been transfused with two units of packed red blood cells prior to discharge. His electrolyte levels are normal, and his calcium, phosphorus, and magnesium levels are within normal range.

The patient's plan is to continue his current medications and to follow up with his doctor for further treatment and monitoring. He is advised to seek immediate medical attention if he feels ill or has a temperature above 101°F. ||endoftext||

HOSPITAL COURSE: ___ year old male with a history of type one 
diabetes and failed kidney and pancreas transplant on peritoneal 
dialysis admitted for right foot cellulitis and volume overload. 
While he was at ___ his blood sugars were very labile and 
___ team was involved to help stabilize his blood 
sugar on a insulin regimen. Given his need for dialysis dosing 
his vancomycin was difficult and infections disease and renal 
were involved in managing his infection and peritoneal dialysis 
respectively. The lower extremity edema markedly improved with 
diuresis and peritoneal dialysis and his infection responded 
well to antibiosis. The renal team decreased his tacrolimus dose 
while in the hospital and discontinued his mycophenolate 
mofetil. 

ACTIVE ISSUES:
 
# Lower extremity swelling/mild erythema: Likely due to to 
volume overload from inadequate volume extraction during 
initiation of peritoneal dialysis. His presentation and exam are 
consistent with cellulitis as well as volume overload. Initially 
antibiotics were stopped beacuse the thought was that his 
symptoms were more consistant with volume overload. However 
after the resolution of edema secondary to overload there was a 
clear demarcation of erythema and warmth on the right ankle and 
foot consistant with cellilutus. Vancomycin was restarted and 
vancomycin levels followed given kidney disease. 

# Kidney Failure. Currently on peritoneal dialysis. Given poor 
graft function renal was consulted and the patient was diuresed 
and peritoneal dialysis optimized. The patients mycophenolate 
mofetil was discontinued and tacrolimus dose was decreased to 
2mg per day. His prednisone dose remains the same. During his 
stay he made some urine. He will need close renal follow up as 
an outpatient.

blood sugars were very labile. ___ was consulted to help 
stabalize his blood sugar on a insulin regimen while in the 
hospital and after discharge.

during his hospitilzation. His home metoprolol and amlodipine 
were continued. More aggressive control was avoided given 
diuresis and concern for hypotension. The patient's blood 
pressure when markedly elevated was treated with hydralazine. At 
the time of discharge losartan was added. This will need to be 
follow as at outpatient.

his home citalopram dose.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 43-year-old male with a history of type 1 diabetes, retinopathy, vitrectomy, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. He was admitted to the hospital with increasing bilateral lower extremity swelling, which had led to difficulty putting on his left prosthetic leg. He had been started on keflex for possible right lower extremity cellulitis as an outpatient, but his symptoms had not improved. On admission, his initial vitals were normal, and labs showed no signs of deep vein thrombosis. He was given IV vancomycin for cellulitis and admitted to medicine for further management.

The patient's past medical history includes a failed kidney and pancreas transplant, peritoneal dialysis, and a history of anxiety. He has no known allergies or adverse reactions.

The patient's diagnosis was cellulitis and volume overload. He underwent treatment with antibiotics and diuresis, and his infection responded well. He was also managed for kidney failure, type 1 diabetes, and hypertension.

At discharge, the patient's medications included vancomycin, insulin, amlodipine, metoprolol, calcium acetate, fenofibrate, levamir, and citalopram. He was advised to follow up with his primary care physician, renal specialist, and endocrinologist after discharge. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 45-year-old female with a history of EtOH abuse, cirrhosis, and ascites. She presented with abdominal pain and was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation. Her chief complaint was abdominal pain, which was likely secondary to increased ascites. She had a diagnostic paracentesis, which was negative for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). She was given zofran and morphine and admitted to medicine for further evaluation.

The patient has a past medical history of EtOH abuse, cirrhosis, and ascites. She has allergies to epinephrine. She was prescribed several medications, including lasix, spironolactone, azithromycin, and levofloxacin, but was unsure why she was prescribed these medications.

The patient's physical exam revealed a firm, distended abdomen with a positive fluid wave and diffusely tender to palpation. She had no organomegaly appreciable. Her discharge physical exam revealed a firm, nondistended abdomen with a slight bulge of her umbilical hernia.

The patient's laboratory results showed mildly elevated alkaline phosphatase and normal liver function tests. Her urine analysis showed a trace of protein and a few white blood cells. Her ascites fluid analysis showed a high white blood cell count and a high protein level.

The patient's imaging studies showed low lung volumes with bibasilar atelectasis and a small right pleural effusion on chest X-ray. Her RUQ ultrasound showed a nodular liver with coarsened echotexture and large volume ascites, compatible with hepatic cirrhosis. Her CT abdomen showed a nodular liver with large volume simple ascites and no signs of loculated fluid collection or bowel perforation.

The patient's hospital course was marked by an acute issue of abdominal pain, which was likely secondary to increased ascites. She had a therapeutic paracentesis of 6.5L and had a persisting fluid leak, which was successfully stopped with a suture. She was discharged with improved pain and was advised to follow up with her PCP in a couple of days to repeat her blood pressure and restart diuretics. ||endoftext||

He has a history of diabetes mellitus, type 1, and has undergone a renal transplant. He also has a history of peripheral vascular disease, gastroparesis, osteoporosis, and chronic immunosuppression. The patient's past medical history is significant for chronic rejection versus medication effect, and he has been experiencing labile blood sugars and hypoglycemic unawareness.

The patient's presenting symptoms included a new right heel ulcer, which was diagnosed as a chronic wound with chronic changes on X-ray. He was treated with IV vancomycin and zosyn, and was admitted to the hospital for further management.

The patient's physical examination revealed a chronically ill-appearing individual with a 2cm ulcer on the lateral aspect of his right heel, which was mildly painful on examination. He was also found to have a history of chronic rejection versus medication effect, and was taking immunosuppressive medications.

The patient's laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 7.0, hemoglobin of 11.5, and hematocrit of 36.2. His blood glucose level was 232, and his urea nitrogen level was 30. His creatinine level was 2.2, and his sodium level was 137.

The patient's diagnosis was a chronic wound with chronic changes on X-ray, and he was treated with IV vancomycin and zosyn. He was also prescribed medications at discharge, including IV pip-tazo and IV vancomycin.

The patient's social history is significant for a sedentary lifestyle, which has led to his current wheelchair-bound state. He has also had a history of hypertension, but is not currently taking medications for it. ||endoftext||

.

.

.

.
-___ CT Angiogram: 1. Pulmonary embolism of a right

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o M with HCV cirrhosis c/b ascites, refractory to 
increasing medical diuresis, requiring admission for 
paracentesis, in setting of increased dyspnea. Found to have 
pulmonary emboli.

# HCV Cirrhosis/Abdominal distension: The patient initially 
underwent an attempted bedside paracentesis, which only yielded 
small amounts of hemorrhagic ascites. He then underwent 
ultrasound-guided diagnostic/therapeutic paracenteses x 2, each 
of which was negative for infection or malignancy. He received 
IV albumin with the procedures. He reported somewhat improved 
respiratory status after the paracenteses, often alluding to his 
new ability to finish a sentence without having to take a 
breath. MRI showed stable solitary liver lesion. LFTs were 
generally stable. His furosemide and spironolactone were 
initally held, then restarted. He was discharged on his home 
dose of spironolactone, which has caused him side effects 
(breast tenderness) on higher doses. He was also discharged on 
an increased dose of furosemide, with instructions to have his 
electrolytes and renal function checked at his primary care 
follow-up visit on ___. Of note, the patient's paracentesis 
site on his RLQ continued to leak ascites for several days. 
Ostomy bag was placed to collect the ascites, and the patient 
ultimately had multiple stitches placed over the paracentesis 
site, to prevent further leakage. The stitch was non-absorbable, 
and will have to be removed at a follow-up visit.

# Pulmonary Emboli: The patient was persistently tachycardic and 
remained short of breath after his large-volume paracentesis. 
ABG revealed hypoxia, and the patient desaturated to the 
mid-high 80's when ambulatory. Lower extremity ultrasound was 
negative for deep venous thrombosis. He had CTA performed, which 
revealed bilateral segmental/sub-segmental pulmonary emboli, and 
was immediately initiated on a heparin drip, without a bolus (no 
bolus ___ concern over hemorrhagic ascites). He was initiated on 
warfarin as well, and took several nights of ___ mg warfarin, 
to reach a therapeutic INR of 2.7, on day of discharge. He was 
discharged on warfarin 5 mg PO QHS. Discussions took place 
between the patient's primary care physician and the admitting 
team, and the patient was scheduled to see the PCP on ___ 
___, where the PCP would assume responsibility for checking 
INR's and managing the patient's warfarin regimen.

No clear cause for PE was identified, as the patient reported up 
to date cancer screening (no malignancy on colonoscopy/biopsy, 
normal PSA), and did not have any clear risk factors for blood 
clots.

Discharge Instructions:
Mr ___,
You were admitted to the hospital to undergo a paracentesis for 
your increasing abdominal distension. Bedside paracentesis 
yielded small amounts of bloody fluid, and the attempt was 
aborted. The following day you underwent paracentesis with 
radiologic guidance, which yielded 5 liters of fluid, which was 
sent for analysis. You had a repeat paracentesis done several 
days later. Each time, your abdominal fluid was negative for 
infection.
.
You had low oxygen levels when walking, so you had a CT scan of 
your chest, which showed pulmonary emboli (blood clots) in both 
lungs. You were started on blood thinning medication, initially 
through the IV and later in pill form. Your coumadin levels were 
at the appropriate levels on the day of discharge, but you will 
need to have this rechecked by your primary care physician. You 
should also have your electrolytes and kidney function tests 
checked by your PCP, as we have changed your diuretic 
medications.
.
The puncture sites from your paracenteses continued to leak 
fluid for several days. We placed a surgical stitch to try to 
stop the leakage. This leak will stop as your skin and soft 
tissue heal. In the meantime, you should place tight gauze 
dressings with paper tape over your skin. If the leakage 
persists or worsens, you can place ostomy bags over the leak to 
collect the fluid.
.
The following changes were made to your medications:
-Added WARFARIN (Coumadin) 5 mg tabs, one tab by mouth at 
bedtime. This medication will require close monitoring with 
blood tests and potential dose adjustments, which will be 
coordinated by your primary care physician.
-Increased FUROSEMIDE (Lasix) to 80 mg tabs, TWO TABS (total of 
160 mg) by mouth, once daily.
.
Please call your physician or return to the hospital if you 
experience any severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, back 
pain, chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, or any 
other concerning symptoms.

___

||startoftext|| 
The patient is a 54-year-old male with a chief complaint of abdominal distension. He has a history of decompensated HCV cirrhosis, ascites, and portal hypertensive gastropathy. He has been experiencing increasing abdominal distension, lower extremity edema, and dyspnea, which has worsened over time. He has a history of hypertension, depression, anxiety, migraines, and cellulitis. He is also obese and has a family history of alcoholism.

The patient's physical examination revealed an obese male with a distended abdomen, bilateral 2+ pitting edema, and ecchymosis over the proximal right thigh. His laboratory results showed abnormal liver function tests, including elevated ALT and AST levels, as well as abnormal coagulation studies. His renal function was also impaired, with elevated BUN and creatinine levels.

The patient underwent diagnostic and therapeutic paracentesis, and his medications at discharge included furosemide, spironolactone, and lactulose. He was also prescribed bupropion, which he had recently started taking. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 72-year-old male who was admitted with abdominal pain and night sweats. He has a past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type 2, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and a spontaneous pneumothorax. He has undergone a distal pancreatectomy, splenectomy, and cholecystectomy in the past.

The patient's presenting symptoms included abdominal pain, night sweats, and a CT scan revealed an increased size of peripancreatic fluid collection. He was treated with CT-guided drainage and pigtail drain placement into the peripancreatic fluid collection. The patient's white blood cell count returned to normal after drainage, and his abdominal pain improved.

The patient was diagnosed with an infected peripancreatic fluid collection and was treated with antibiotics. He was also prescribed medications for pain, nausea, and blood thinning. The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his surgeon and primary care provider.

The patient's medications at discharge included verapamil, oxycodone, docusate sodium, acetaminophen, pantoprazole, warfarin, senna, lisinopril, metformin, and daptomycin. He was also instructed to follow a regular diet, ambulate several times a day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. ||endoftext||

Pancreas, allograft, needle core biopsy (___):
Changes consistent with severe acute cell-mediated rejection, 
with:
1.  Fibrinoid necrotizing arteritis.
2.  Septal vasculitis.
3.  Septal ductal inflammation.
4.  Neural inflammation.
5.  Multifocal inflammatory acinar involvement and acinar 
damage.
6.  CMV immunohistochemical stain is negative.
7.  Trichrome stain shows minimally increased fibrous tissue (no 
significant loss of acinar parenchyma).

ADDENDUM  #1: 
Immunostain for C4d demonstrates focal staining (defined as 
between 5 and 50%) of interacinar capillaries and diffuse 
staining of venous and arteriolar endothelium within septae. 
Staining evaluated and reported per the criteria as set forth by 
___, ___ Journal of Transplantation, ___ (10):1669-76. 
 
ADDENDUM #2:
A C4D immunostain reveals staining of intra-acinar capillaries 
approximately 30%.  The significance of this finding has to be 
correlated with DSA testing.  The biopsy findings here 
(prominent eosinophilic infiltrates, prominent septal 
inflammation, venulitis and ductal inflammation) favor AMCR.  
Given the c4d staining, a combined ACMR and antibody-mediated 
rejection occurring simultaneously is a consideration..

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with history of type 1 diabetes mellitus 
status post deceased donor pancreas transplant in ___ referred 
to the ED for elevated pancreatic enzymes and found to have cell 
mediated/humoral rejection on the basis of pancreatic biopsy and 
treated with plasmapheresis, IVIG, antithymocyte globulin, 
steroid taper, and rituximab.

Active Issues:
(1)Pancreatic rejection: Despite pancreatic ultrasound and CT 
abdomen/pelvis on admission with radiographic features 
unconcerning for rejection, initial suspicion for rejection on 
the basis of elevated amylase and lipase was confirmed on CT 
guided pancreatic biopsy with histologic evidence of humoral and 
cell mediated rejection. He was treated with a steroid taper 
(methylprednisolone 500mg IV daily x3 days, followed by 
prednisone 60mg PO daily x2 days, 40mg PO daily x2 days, and 
20mg PO daily indefinitely), antithymocycte globulin x7, 
plasmapheresis x5, weight based IVIG, and a single dose of 
rituximab. Response to therapy was monitored via daily T 
lymphocyte subsets and periodic donor specific antibody screens. 
Tacrolimus was increased from 2mg bid to 5mg bid to maintain 
therapeutic levels and home dose mycophenolate 500mg bid was 
continued. Pantoprazole, valgancyclovir, 
trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, and nystatin were given 
prophylactically in the setting of high dose 
steroids/immunosuppression. Amylase and lipase downtrended over 
the course of admission from 164 to 101 and 334 to 139, 
respectively. He was advised to have weekly labs checked and 
sent to Dr. ___ has followup with him ___.

(2)Type 1 diabetes mellitus: He is no longer diabetic/insulin 
dependent following pancreatic transplant. Fingersticks were 
found to be elevated to 200s in the setting of pancreatic 
rejection with high dose steroid administration, prompting 
initiation of gentle Humalog insulin sliding scale to maintain 
euglycemia. He was advised to check his fingersticks at home and 
if your fasting blood sugars persistently greater than 150, to 
call Dr. ___. He was provided testing supplies

(3)Fever: He experienced isolated low-grade fever to 100.7 on 
___, without localizing signs/symptoms of infection and 
unrevealing infectious work up, including negative 
urinalysis/urine culture and blood culture with no growth. Fever 
did not recur throughout the remainder of admission.

(4)Visual symptoms: He developed right sided floater on ___, 
with no gross visual field or extraocular movement deficits. He 
was evaluated by ophthalmology who determined he had Inferior 
vitreous hemorrhage and Posterior vitreous detachment OD. They 
advised no urgent interventions, but that pt needs to follow up 
with his Ophthalmologist as outpatient.

(5)Acute on chronic loose stools: In the setting of report on 
acute on chronic loose stools on admission, CMV viral load was 
undetectable and C. difficile assay negative. CT abdomen/pelvis 
on admission was without evidence of colitis. Loose stools did 
not occur throughout admission, but perhaps reflected some 
element of exocrine dysfunction.

(6)Cytopenia: He experienced period cytopenias, including white 
blood cell count nadiring at 3, hematocrit as low as 30.3 (from 
baseline of 39 to 40), and platelets to 110s (from baseline of 
210s) in the setting of high dose immunosuppression. There were 
no signs of bleeding or infection.

Inactive Issues:
(1)Hypertension: He remained normotensive on home metoprolol 
succinate.

(2)Hypothyroidism: Home levothyroxine was continued. 

(3)Hyperlipidemia: Home atorvastatin was continued.  

(4)Depression: His mood remained stable on home sertraline.

1) Weekly safety labs

fasting blood glucose persistently elevated >150.

to ___. As you know, you were 
admitted after routine bloodwork raised concern for rejection of

pancreas was obtained, and there was some evidence of injury to 
your new pancreas by your body's immune system, i.e. rejection. 
You were treated with plasmapheresis and multiple intravenous 
medications, including ATG, IVIG, and rituximab. There was 
improvement in your bloodwork over the course of admission, 
suggesting response to treatment.

We had you assessed for your eye floaters by our opthomalogists. 
There were no immediate concerns, but you should follow up with 
your outpatient ophthalmologist.

Please check your fingersticks daily to check your blood sugars. 
If your fasting (morning) blood sugars are persistently greater 
than 150, please call Dr. ___. Please bring your meter 
with you to your visit.

Please have you labs checked and sent to Dr. ___ a 
week.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 38-year-old male with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and a deceased donor pancreas transplant. He was admitted to the hospital with elevated pancreatic enzymes and was found to have cell-mediated and humoral rejection on pancreatic biopsy. He was treated with plasmapheresis, IVIG, antithymocyte globulin, steroid taper, and rituximab. The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, history of nephrolithiasis, and depression. He has no known allergies or adverse drug reactions. The patient's diagnosis is severe acute cell-mediated rejection of the pancreas transplant. He underwent insertion of a plasmapheresis catheter and plasmapheresis. At discharge, the patient was prescribed tacrolimus 5mg bid, mycophenolate 500mg bid, pantoprazole, valgancyclovir, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, and nystatin. ||endoftext||

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p craniotomy/Left MCA aneurysm clipping

 
Discharge Condition:
neurologically intact

 
Discharge Instructions:
General Instructions

Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
You may shower ___ and wash your hair - DO NOT SCRUB THE 
INCISION ITSELF/ you may get it wet and pat it dry.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
If you have been prescribed an anti-seizure medicine, take it 
as prescribed and follow up with laboratory blood drawing as 
ordered.
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

New onset of tremors or seizures.
Any confusion or change in mental status. 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, or drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 48-year-old female who was admitted to the Neurosurgery Service with a left middle cerebral artery aneurysm. She has a history of right subarachnoid hemorrhage and falls, and was anxious about the aneurysm rupturing due to her family history of two maternal uncles dying from ruptured aneurysms. She complained of intermittent headaches, malaise, and nausea. 

The patient underwent a left pterional craniotomy and clipping of the left middle cerebral artery with temporary occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery. She was prescribed medications including Dilantin, Oxycodone, Phenytoin, Fentanyl, Hydromorphone, and Gabapentin. 

At discharge, the patient was neurologically intact and was discharged home with instructions to take her pain medicine as prescribed, exercise limited to walking, and to increase her intake of fluids and fiber. ||endoftext||

Imaging
=======

___ EKG
Sinus rhythm. Possible old septal myocardial infarction. Low QRS 
voltage in the precordial leads. Non-specific ST-T wave 
abnormalities. No previous
tracing available for comparison.

___ CXR
FINDINGS:  The patient is status post endotracheal intubation.  
The
endotracheal tube terminates about 5.5 cm above the carina.  An 
orogastric
tube courses into the stomach and terminates in the fundus.  
Surgical clips project over the left axillary region.
The cardiac, mediastinal and hilar contours appear within normal 
limits. 
There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  The lungs appear 
clear.  
IMPRESSION:  Status post endotracheal intubation.  No evidence 
of acute
cardiopulmonary disease.

___ TTE
The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. The 
estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. Left ventricular 
wall thickness, cavity size, and global systolic function are 
normal (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly 
thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears structurally 
normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral 
valve prolapse. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not 
be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: 
Normal biventricular cavity sizes with preserved regional and 
global biventricular systolic function.

___ RUQ US
IMPRESSION: 
1.  Normal hepatic echotexture. No focal hepatic lesions.
2.  Trace ascites.
3.  Prominent fluid-filled loops of bowel, which is nonspecific.

___ KUB
IMPRESSION: Nonspecific bowel gas pattern.  No evidence of 
pneumoperitoneum.

___ CT abd/pelvis
IMPRESSION: 
1. Findings consistent with a small bowel obstruction.
2. Diffuse anasarca, diffuse small amount of ascites, small 
right pleural
effusion.
3. Chronic findings including atherosclerotic disease, with 
surgical clips and probable partial colectomy.
4. Despite a history of hepatitis and cirrhosis, there is no 
evidence to
suggest portal hypertension, liver appearance is unremarkable.

___ CT head w/o contrast
IMPRESSION: Limiited study secondary to motion artifact. 
Unremarkable unenhanced head CT.

___ KUB
FINDINGS:  There is an enteric tube whose side port is at the GE 
junction. This could be advanced several centimeters for more 
optimal placement.  Thereis a relative paucity of bowel gas.  
There is air seen within the rectum.  No definite dilated loops 
of bowel are seen. However, Please note that the dilated small 
bowel loops were fluid filled on the CT, thus it is difficult to 
assess for change in the degree of obstruction. There is no free 
intra-abdominal gas.

___ CXR
FINDINGS:  Comparison is made to previous study from ___. 
Endotracheal tube, feeding tube, and right-sided central venous 
line are 
unchanged in position.  Heart size is within normal limits.  
There is some coarsening of the bronchovascular markings without 
signs for overt pulmonary edema or focal consolidation.  No 
pneumothoraces are seen. 

___ CT abd/pelvis
IMPRESSION:  
1. Interval decompression of small bowel loops. Oral contrast is 
seen to the level of the rectum. There is small bowel and 
colonic wall thickening with may represent edema related to 
recent small bowel obstruction or liver dysfunction. However, 
underlying infection or malignancy cannot be excluded. 
2. There is loculated abdominal ascites and hepatic cirrhosis. 
3. There is a focal hypodensity in the right kidney which was 
not definitely present on the prior exam. This finding is 
suspicious for focal pyelonephritis. Recommend correlation with 
urinalysis. 
4. There is enterocolic intussusception without obstruction at 
the level of the enterocolic anastomosis. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo woman with a PMH of HepC cirrhosis 
who was found down at home, intubated at ___ and 
placed on pressors, and transferred to ___ for further 
management.

ACUTE ISSUES
============

#Septic shock: Patient with bandemia to 19 and tachycardia as 
well as hypotension. Could potentially have an infectious 
source, potentially intra-abdominal given her history of 
abdominal surgery. Received a dose of vanc/zosyn at ___. 
She was maintained on vanc/cefepime at ___. Cardiogenic shock 
ruled out with a normal TTE. CT torso and serial CXR showed 
nothing localizing. C. diff negative on ___. Her blood and urine 
cultures remained negative. Initially, it was unclear if her 
hypotension was due to septic shock, toxic injection, 
hypovolemia, or cardiogenic shock, but as her hospital course 
progressed, septic shock was most likely. She was given fluid 
boluses and was initially maintained on levophed/vasopressin. 
Pressors were weaned by ___ and vancomycin/cefepime was 
maintained until ___. She was also given flagyl empirically 
for concern for C. difficile infection as her stool output 
increased (started on IV flagyl on ___, switched to po on ___ 
as patient able to take po's). After antiobiotics were 
discontinued, the patient demonstrated no further signs of 
sepsis or infection (no hypotension, no fevers, no white count).

#Toxic metabolic encephalopathy:  Likely from septic shock. 
Patient had slightly elevated levels of tylenol and ASA but 
unclear if a true ingestion. She also has a significant acidosis 
that may be contributing as well as electrolyte abnormalities. 
Finally, there was initially concern that she has a hx cirrhosis 
and may be experiencing hepatic encephalopathy; this was later 
disproven after discussion with her PCP. A final etiology may be 
seizure activity. Upon arrival, she was started on NAC for 
possibly tylenol ingestion. Her electrolyte abnormalities were 
corrected. She was initially given lactulose out of concern for 
possible hepatic encephalopathy but this was later held. She was 
treated for septic shock per above. In addition, a 20-minute EEG 
showed numerous discharges and a 24-hour EEG was performed, 
which showed no evidence of seizure. After she was transferred 
to the floor, her mental status improved markedly. She became 
alert, oriented x 3, attentive, and conversive.

# Diarrhea: While in the ICU, the patient developed profuse, 
watery diarrhea. C. diff was ruled out. A rectal tube was 
placed, and remained as the patient was transferred to the 
floor. When arriving to the hospital floor, the patient noted 
abdominal pain. A CT was obtained that showed enterocolic 
intussusception without obstruction at the level of the 
enterocolic anastomosis. It was also learned, from the patient's 
stepdaughter, that the patient was previously found down with 
opioid intoxication, hypotension, and ischemic colitis for which 
she had colostomy and reversal. Since this event, the patient 
had been having diarrhea since, requiring Imodium ___ times per 
day and still having loose stools. Because of no obstruction and 
history of diarrhea, follow-up colonoscopy with GI was 
recommended as an outpatient. With negative stool cultures and 
WBC count downtrending to 8.1, an infection was not suspected. 
The rectal tube was removed and loperamide with pancreatic 
enzymes (for possible pancreatic insufficiency) was initiated. 
The patient began to make formed stools at the time of 
discharge.

#Shock liver: LFT's greater than 1000 may be from causes such as 
hepatitis, portal thrombosis, drug intoxication, shock liver, 
___ disease. most likely shock liver given hypovolemia. In 
this instance, likely from shock liver. Septic shock treated per 
above and her LFT's trended down.

#Hypernatremia: Patient was found to have hypernatremia to 156 
on the am of ___. Likely from free water deficit given NG 
tube on suction. She was repleted with LR boluses and D5W and 
her Na trended down. Her fluid balance was carefully monitored 
given her history of psychogenic polydipsia. She was placed on a 
2L fluid restriction while on the hospital floor, but she did 
not even consume that much fluid. She remained normonatremic 
during the remainder of her hospitalization.

#Thrombocytopenia: Unclear cause but concern for possible HIT. 
Heparin dc'd on ___ and HIT ab was sent, but it was negative. 
Through the rest of her course in the hospital, her platelets 
trended upward 87->128->140->188->184.

#Respiratory failure with respiratory acidosis: Patient was 
somnolent and likely failing to protect her airway; in addition, 
a possible toxic ingestion may have played a role. Per ___ 
reports, satting in mid to high 90's on nasal cannula prior to 
intubation. By ___, the patient was beginning to follow 
commands and was weaned to pressure support. She had difficulty 
with autoPEEP, likely from air trapping given history of COPD. 
She was extubated on ___ and was weaned to room air on 
___.

#Ileus: CT scan on ___ showed concern for an SBO, which the 
patient is at risk for given prior partial colectomy/adhesions. 
Surgery was consulted but felt it was more likely to be an 
ileus. Her NG tube was placed to suction and tube feeds were 
temporarily held. By ___, she was extubated and eating a 
normal diet.

#Rhabdomyolysis: patient with significantly elevated CK upon 
admission. Unclear whether resulting from patient lying on the 
ground for a long period of time vs MI vs other acute muscle 
injury. She underwent aggressive fluid repletion and her CK 
trended down. She did not experience further kidney injury.

#A-fib with RVR: Patient experienced AFib with RVR on ___ and 
initially responded to IV silt boluses but ultimately required 
an amiodarone drip. ___ have been precipitated by septic shock. 
She was transitioned to po amiodarone on ___, which was stopped 
on ___. On ___, her HR transiently spiked to the 110's and 
she was started on metoprolol 12.5 mg qid given concern for 
recurrent A-fib. At discharge, she was continued on this 
treatment for rate control because of intermittent tachycardia.

#Elevated troponins: Patient with a troponin >1 ___; 
trending down at ___. Last set of 3 down to 0.06. Likely 
demand ischemia given acute illness.

#Hyperkalemia: Patient hyperkalemic >6; likely from a 
combination of respiratory acidosis and impared kidney function. 
Resolved during hospital stay.

#Acute kidney injury: Unclear baseline but cr 1.5 and at risk 
for further injury given shock and rhabdomyolysis. With 
aggressive fluid repletion, Cr trended down.

#Hep C/B positivity: unclear history of 
varices/encephalopathy/SBP/transplant candidacy. No ascites to 
tap.  Per PCP, no clear cirrhosis diagnosis and no biopsies have 
been taken. She has a diagnosis of Hep C, genotype 1 but has 
refused treatment. She also was found to be positive for Hep B. 
Viral loads were sent and 
demonstrated HepB VL not detected; HepC viral load: 7,420,000 
IU/mL.

#Anemia: Patient with a normocytic anemia. She was noted to have 
melanotic stools and underwent an EGD that was negative for an 
UGIB bleed. Her Hct remained stable during her hospital course. 
She will need a colonoscopy as an outpatient.
  
# Communication: Patient, step-daughter ___ ___  
# Code: Full

___

Dear ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay at ___. 
You were admitted because you were found nearly unconscious at 
home with a low blood pressure. You were intubated to protect 
your ability to bereathe. You were admitted to an ICU because of 
your near-unconcsious state and low blood pressure and there was 
also concern for infection and started on antibiotics. Your low 
blood pressure and possible infection likely resulted in 
temporary decreased blood flow to the liver and bowel. Your 
liver became inflamed, but this resolved. You continued to have 
diarrhea, but this responded to Imodium and pancreatic enzymes. 
Because of multiple transfers, you also became confused. After a

Your ___ care team

left knee arthritis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills.

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.

6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.

7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).

8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking this medication.  
___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.

9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your Silverlon dressing clean and 
dry. REMOVE on ___. It is okay to shower five days after 
surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision 
until after your four (4) week checkup. You may place a dry 
sterile dressing on the wound after the Silverlon dressing is 
removed, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly 
for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. 
Staples will be removed by at your follow-up visit in 3 weeks.

10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.

11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise or 
heavy lifting until follow up appointment.

Physical Therapy:
Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity. 
Mobilize. ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise or heavy 
lifting until follow up appointment.

Treatments Frequency:
Underlying Silverlon dressing to be removed ___
Overlying ABD pad / paper tape / ACE may be changed daily
Staples will be removed at post op appointment in 3 weeks. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

PREDNISONE - prednisone 20 mg tablet. 2 (Two) tablet(s) by mouth 
 
as directed 13 hours prior to procedure 7 hours prior to  
procedure 1 hour prior to procedure  
SIMVASTATIN - simvastatin 80 mg tablet. 1 (One) tablet(s) by  
mouth at bedtime - (Prescribed by Other Provider)  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen-Caff-Butalbital ___ TAB PO Q6H:PRN headaches 
RX *butalbital-acetaminophen-caff 50 mg-325 mg-40 mg ___ 
tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours Disp #*60 Tablet 
Refills:*0
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
3. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 
4. Simvastatin 80 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cerebral aneurysm

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Elective Aneurysm Clipping

Call your neurosurgeons office and speak to the Nurse 
Practitioner if you experience:

Any neurological issues, such as change in vision, speech or 
movement

Swelling, drainage, or redness of your incision

Any problems with medications, such as nausea vomiting or 
lethargy

Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit

Headaches not relieved with prescribed medications

Activity:

Start to resume all activities as you tolerate  but start 
slowly and increase at your own pace.

Do not operate any motorized vehicle for at least 10 days after 
your surgery  your Nurse Practitioner can give you more detail 
at the time of your suture removal.  

Incision Care:

Keep your wound clean and dry.

Do not use shampoo until your sutures are removed. 

When you are allowed to shampoo your hair, let the shampoo run 
off the incision line.  Gently pad the incision with a towel to 
dry.

Do not rub, scrub, scratch, or pick at any scabs on the incision 
line.

You need your sutures removed 7 to 10 days after surgery

Post-Operative Experiences: Physical

Jaw pain on the same side as your surgery; this goes away after 
about a month

You may experience constipation.  Constipation can be prevented 
by:

oDrinking plenty of fluids
oIncreasing fiber in your diet by eating vegetables, prunes, 
fiber rich breads and cereals, or fiber supplements
oExercising
oUsing over-the-counter bowel stimulants or laxatives as 
needed, stopping usage if you experience loose bowel movements 
or diarrhea

Fatigue which will slowly resolve over time

Numbness or tingling in the area of the incision; this can take 
weeks or months to fully resolve

Muffled hearing in the ear near the incision area

Low back pain or shooting pain down the leg which can resolve 
with increased activity

Post-Operative Experiences: Emotional

You may experience depression.  Symptoms of depression can 
include

oFeeling down or sad
oIrritability, frustration, and confusion
oDistractibility
oLower Self-Esteem/Relationship Challenges
oInsomnia
oLoneliness

If you experience these symptoms, you can contact your Primary 
Care Provider who can make a referral to a Psychologist or 
Psychiatrist

You can also seek out a local Brain Aneurysm Support Group in 
your area through the Brain Aneurysm Foundation

oMore information can be found at ___

 
Followup Instructions:
___

The patient's chief complaint was elective aneurysm clipping, and he underwent a successful surgery. He was monitored in the ICU for 24 hours before being transferred to the general floors. On discharge, the patient was noted to have L nasolabial flattening, but was otherwise intact. He was prescribed medications including acetaminophen-caff-butalbital, docusate sodium, lisinopril, and simvastatin. The patient was discharged in stable condition and instructed to follow up with his neurosurgeon's office and to resume activities slowly. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 57-year-old female who was admitted with burning chest pain and shortness of breath. She has a history of coronary artery disease, including a previous myocardial infarction and stenting, as well as scleroderma, hypertension, and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis. She was previously a renal transplant recipient, but her current transplant is failing. She was admitted to the hospital with pulmonary edema and dyspnea, and was intubated for respiratory distress. She was started on dialysis and was treated with lasix, which provided relief from her symptoms. She was also prescribed furosemide and omeprazole.

The patient's diagnosis is not explicitly stated in the report, but it appears that she has chronic kidney disease, pulmonary edema, and possibly gastrointestinal issues contributing to her chest pain. She underwent a removal of a tunneled dialysis catheter and was started on CPAP in the emergency department.

At discharge, the patient's medications included furosemide, omeprazole, and possibly other medications not specified in the report. Her physical exam was notable for mild respiratory distress, but she was otherwise stable and comfortable while sitting upright with oxygen. ||endoftext||

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care:
1. You may keep your incisions open to air or covered with a 
clean, sterile gauze that you change daily. If any areas develop 
blistering, you will need to apply Bactroban cream twice a day. 
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with soap and water. 
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day. 
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount. 
5. DO NOT wear a normal bra for 3 weeks. You may wear a soft, 
loose camisole for comfort.  
6. You may shower daily with assistance as needed. Be sure to 
secure your upper drains to a lanyard that hangs down from your 
neck so they don't hang down and pull out. You may secure your 
lower drains to a fabric belt tied around your waist.
7. The Dermabond skin glue will begin to flake off in about ___ 
days. 
8. No pressure on your chest or abdomen 
9. Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your 
doctor. 
. 
Activity: 
1. You may resume your regular diet.  
2. Keep hips flexed at all times, and then gradually stand 
upright as tolerated. 
3. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity for 6 weeks following surgery. 
. 
Medications: 
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered . 
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. 
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol. 
4. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 
5. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber. 
. 
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 
. 
Return to the ER if:  
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.  
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
. 
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS 
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 46-year-old female who was admitted for elective delayed reconstruction with bilateral deep inferior epigastric perforator flaps after a history of right breast cancer and bilateral mastectomies. She has a past medical history of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and a family history of breast cancer. She has no known allergies or adverse drug reactions. The patient underwent bilateral breast reconstruction with deep inferior epigastric perforator flaps and tolerated the procedure well. She was monitored on the surgical floor postoperatively and remained hemodynamically stable. At discharge, she was prescribed medications including acetaminophen, aspirin, cefadroxil, cyclobenzaprine, docusate sodium, oxycodone, escitalopram, and metformin. She was also advised to follow specific discharge instructions, including wound care, drain care, and activity restrictions. ||endoftext||

Admission laboratories:

 
Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: ___ is a ___ woman on 
day +174 after an allogeneic cord blood transplant for 
lymphoblastic crisis of CML, h/o breast cancer, h/o of BK and 
HHV-6 viremia presenting with altered mental status and 
seizures.  
.  
# Seizure: The patient had two seizures before being admitting 
to the floor, one at home and another at the ___ ER. Both were 
witnessed. The patient had a lumbar puncture in the ER and 
bacterial cultures, cryptococcal antigen, ___ virus, VZV and CMV 
viruses were sent. Other viruses and cultures would have been 
sent, though there was not enough CSF sample and since the 
patient improved clinically, the team felt the risks of a lumbar 
puncture outweighed the benefits. The patient had a MRI with 
contrast and EEG which were both normal. ___ virus, CMV and 
cryptococcal antigen were normal. Her CSF fluid analysis was not 
concerning for infection or malignancy and the preliminary 
bacterial culture data showed no growth to date. Neurology 
consulted on the patient and recommended starting the patient on 
Keppra.
.
The patient was empirically started on vancomycin, levaquin and 
continued her home posaconazole. The patient remained afebrile 
without any signs of infection. She was observed off of 
antibiotics for 24 hours and remained hemodynamically stable and 
afebrile.
.
On the first day after admission, the patient endorsed 
difficulty walking with leaning over to the right side. She also 
had headaches in the morning which resolved with oxycodone. On 
her second hospital day, the patient returned to baseline 
without difficulty walking. There was suspicion that the seizure 
could have been related to her recent sinus surgery, though 
neurology felt that it was unlikely given her benign CSF and 
normal MRI. The headaches resolved. She will continue on Keppra 
1000 mg BID and followup with neurology within one month.
.  
#Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia with blast crisis s/p allogeneic 
SCT in ___ (Day +174): The patient is currently in 
remission. She continued her bactrim, acyclovir, ursodiol, 
posaconazole, cellcept and prednisone during this admission. 
.  
#Acute renal failure: The patient presented with a Cr=1.4 which 
improved with a normal saline bolus. Likely pre-renal in 
etiology.

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 54-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of seizures. She has a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) that converted to acute myeloid leukemia (AML) after a cord blood transplant. She has also had a history of breast cancer and has undergone several surgeries, including sinus surgery. The patient has allergies to cefepime and ragweed. She was started on immunosuppressive therapy and has been experiencing recurrent pulmonary exacerbations.

The patient's past medical history includes GVHD, BOOP, chronic sinusitis, chronic renal failure, breast cancer, glaucoma, depression, and oophorectomy. She has also had a history of BK viremia and HHV-6 viremia.

The patient's physical examination revealed that she was alert and well-appearing, with no acute distress. Her vital signs were normal, and her neurological examination was normal except for an unsteady gait and need for support while walking.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, hyponatremia, and mild acute renal failure. She was started on vancomycin, levaquin, and posaconazole, and was observed off of antibiotics for 24 hours without any signs of infection.

The patient's diagnosis was acute lymphoblastic crisis of CML, and she was started on Keppra 1000 mg BID for seizure prophylaxis. She will follow up with neurology within one week. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with a complicated past 
medical history including Klippel-Trenaunay-Weber and CLOVES 
syndrome, COPD on home 2L O2, insulin dep. T2DM, dCHF, c diff 
colitis, CKD, MDR UTIs, Asthma, OSA (does not tolerate CPAP), 
complex renal/urologic history notable for bladder obstruction 
from lymphatic malformations, and PE s/p IVC filter removal and 
on home xarelto, with recent admission for sepsis due to 
cholecystitis s/p percutaneous cholecystostomy, who presented 
with altered mental status, sepsis, and hypercarbic respiratory 
failure.

ACTIVE ISSUES: 
==============

#Septic Shock 
Patient presented in septic shock, with altered mental status 
and hypercarbic respiratory failure requiring pressors and 
intubation. Blood cultures grew coag negative staph (staph 
hominis) and group C strep. Skin source of infection was 
suspected, with multiple skin lesions on exam. Other sources 
considered included biliary given recent cholecystitis, urinary, 
pulmonary. He received vanc (___), zosyn (___), 
daptomycin (___), before ultimately transitioning to 
only vancomycin (___) based on blood culture sensitivities. 
TTE was done showing no vegetations. The patient had a PICC line 
placed prior to discharge. He is planned to finish vancomycin on 
___. Vancomycin dosing was adjusted on day of discharge 
for supratherapeutic trough of 24.9 (1500 mg Q8H to 1250 mg 
Q8H). Please recheck vancomycin level before morning dose 
___.

#GI bleed
#Anemia
On arrival in the ED, the patient had large maroon colored bowel 
movement, with an apparent acute drop in hemoglobin to 7.6, from 
9.1 on ___. He was transfused a total 3U pRBC. CTA abdomen 
pelvis showed no evidence of active bleeding. GI was consulted 
and deferred scoping, as his GI bleed stabilized, and he has 
known vascular malformations throughout the colon due to his 
underlying CLOVES with a history of prior GI bleeding. By 
discharge, H/H was stable and he had not had further blood BMs. 
Should have CBC rechecked ___. Discharge 
Hemoglobin 9.0. Sister/HCP expressed concerns that patient 
should have CBC monitored on a weekly basis given that he has 
required blood transfusions on recent hospitalizations. 
 
#Hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure
The patient was intubated and sedated for hypercarbic 
respiratory failure in the ED with VBG showing pCO2 71. The 
cause of his respiratory failure was thought to be 
multifactorial and secondary to hypoventilation from toxic 
metabolic encephalopathy, with contribution from pulmonary 
edema.  He was extubated shortly afterward, and was returned to 
his home 2L NC. 

#PE 
CT chest ___ showed suggestion of RLL PE, with CTA chest ___ 
showing segmental RLL PE that appeared new, or potentially acute 
on chronic. He was started on a heparin gtt. His home 
rivaroxaban had been held upon admission ___, given his GI 
bleeding. Heme/onc was consulted for guidance regarding 
anticoagulation, and per recs he was transitioned to heparin gtt 
back to rivaroxaban, at therapeutic dosing 20 mg daily for 1 
month before returning to his pre-hospital dose of 10 mg daily. 
Records indicated that he had an IVC filter for previous DVT/PE 
but per review of imaging and patient history he did not have an 
IVC filter in place. He should have heme/onc followup, scheduled 
for ___.

# C. diff infection 
The patient had C. diff colitis during his last admission 
___. He was c diff PCR positive this admission and continued 
on PO vancomycin, with planned course to end on ___. 

# Hematuria 
Patient reports intermittent hematuria at baseline, in the 
setting of CLOVES. He has known lymphatic and vascular 
malformations in the bladder, leading to bladder outlet 
obstructions and hematuria. He had hematuria this admission 
without clots that had resolved by discharge. He had a foley 
catheter that was discontinued and had acute urinary retention 
but refused straight cath and bladder scans despite discussion 
at length regarding the risks of urinary retention. He was 
voiding spontaneously by discharge. Continued home tamsulosin.

He was maintained on standing and sliding scale insulin, 
decreased from pre-admission regimen to Glargine 23u BID plus

# COPD on 2L NC: continued Tiotropium bromide cap, held

standing, restart gabapentin 2 days after discharge if not

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure to care for you at ___ 
___. 

WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED? 
- You had confusion and difficulty breathing. 
- You had a bloody stool. 

WHAT HAPPENED TO YOU IN THE HOSPITAL? 
- You initially required care in the ICU because you were 
intubated to help your breathing, and you needed IV medication 
to keep your blood pressure up. 
- You improved quickly and were able to be extubated and 
transferred out of the ICU. 
- You had an infection in the blood, that likely came originally 
from a skin source. You were treated with IV antibiotics. 
- You received blood transfusions because you were anemic, 
likely because of bleeding from the gut. 
- You received imaging that showed you had a blood clot in the 
lung (PE). 
- You were started on an IV blood thinner medication (heparin) 
to treat your PE, then transitioned back to your xarelto, which 
you should take at a higher dose for one month.

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO ON DISCHARGE? 
- Please continue to take all your medications as prescribed. 
- You will need to complete a total 2-week course of IV 
antibiotics.

We wish you the best, 
Your ___ team

___
target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 54-year-old male with a complicated past medical history, including Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome, CLOVES syndrome, COPD, type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and morbid obesity. He was recently admitted for sepsis and respiratory failure, and was treated with antibiotics and underwent a percutaneous cholecystostomy. He was also diagnosed with cholecystitis and C. difficile colitis. The patient was intubated and sedated due to hypercarbic respiratory failure, and was treated with vasopressors and oxygen therapy. He was also diagnosed with a MDR pseudomonas UTI, but was presumed to be a colonizer.

The patient's allergies include ciprofloxacin, meperidine, penicillins, aspirin, and Bactrim. His medications at discharge include Zosyn and vancomycin.

The patient's physical exam revealed an obese male with LUE and RLE deformities, and he had a port wine stain on his left hand and left back. He also had gangrenous necrosis of his right lower extremity toes and an erythematous rash on his left shin.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and troponin levels, as well as abnormal liver function tests and electrolyte levels. His blood glucose level was 226 mg/dL, and his pro-BNP level was 665 pg/mL.

The patient's diagnosis was sepsis, respiratory failure, and cholecystitis, and he was treated with antibiotics, oxygen therapy, and vasopressors. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with PMH significant for ESRD on HD, DM2 who presents with

ACTIVE ISSUES:
#Left ___ toe cellulitis: Superimposed on ___ left metatarsal 
laceration sustained 2 weeks prior to admission. Was seen in

did not heal properly and stitches fell out per patient. Wound
