Discharge Instructions:
Craniotomy for Tumor Excision
Dr. ___

Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
Your wound was closed with staples, you must wait until after 
they are removed to wash your hair. You may shower before this 
time using a shower cap to cover your head.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) & 
Senna while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc.  
If you are being sent home on steroid medication, make sure 
you are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, 
Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach 
irritation.  Make sure to take your steroid medication with 
meals, or a glass of milk. 
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

New onset of tremors or seizures.
Any confusion or change in mental status. 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: increasing redness, 
increased swelling, increased tenderness, or drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 101.5° F.

Dexamethasone Taper:

Dexamethasone 3mg by mouth every 8hrs for 9 doses then
Dexamethasone 2mg by mouth every 8hrs for 6 doses then
Dexamethasone 2mg by mouth every 12hrs until follow-up

Please complete the one day of oral antiobiotics.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 55-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for resection of a recurrent cerebellar brain mass. He has a history of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, large midline cerebral hemorrhage, hypertension, and gout. He underwent a bilateral suboccipital craniotomy for cerebellar tumor excision and was found to have necrotic tissue, possibly from radiation. His post-operative course was uneventful, and he was discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up.

The patient's medications at discharge include acetaminophen, citalopram, docusate sodium, famotidine, lisinopril, memantine, oxycodone, and dexamethasone. He was also prescribed physical therapy and instructed to follow up with his surgeon.

The patient's discharge diagnosis includes metastatic carcinoma, posterior fossa brain mass, and cerebral edema. His discharge condition is stable, with a clear and coherent mental status, alert and interactive level of consciousness, and ambulatory independence. ||endoftext||

Laryngeal cancer

Total laryngectomy, left selective neck dissection, right 
radical neck dissection, primary closure

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ male who presents today with a 
history of a cT3 N2 cM0 (stage ___ SCC of the supraglottic 
larynx with concurrent left true vocal cord T1 N0 M0 SCC treated 
with chemoradiation, now with question of recurrence. His 
symptomatology began in ___ when he noted hoarseness of 
his voice and a sore throat.

___- Seen by Dr. ___,  ___ videostroboscopy revealed 
a supraglottic mass and left vocal fold leukoplakia.  There was 
an extensive supraglottic mass from the epiglottis extending 
into the right AE fold and full length exophytic leukoplakia of 
the left vocal cord.
___- CT Neck showed diffuse mucosal abnormality along the 
supraglottic larynx towards the right periglottic space.  The 
epiglottis was thickened and the right thyroarytenoid muscle
appeared to be involved consistent with transglottic spread.  
The bilateral ventricles were effaced and the subglottic area 
was preserved. There were multiple small lymph nodes in the left 
and right neck, measuring up to 12 mm in short axis dimension.
___- Panendoscopy with Dr. ___ inflammation at the 
gastroesophageal junction, which was biopsied and found to be 
inflammation.  There was a white plaque on the left true vocal 
cord that was dissected.  There was also a mass centered on the
laryngeal surface of the epiglottis involving the bilateral 
pharyngeal epiglottic folds and right arytenoid cartilage.  This 
was biopsied, returning invasive squamous cell carcinoma.  The 
dissected left vocal cord revealed dysplasia with foci 
concerning for invasion.
___- PET/CT showed intense FDG avidity within the known 
right supraglottic mass, with an SUV max of 13.7.  There was a 
left level 2 lymph node measuring 1.4 x 1.3 cm with an SUV max 
of 6.1. Also noted were 2 right level 2 lymph nodes, with an SUV 
of ___, concerning for metastasis. 
___- Received concurrent chemoradiotherapy under 
the care of Dr. ___  ___ Dr. ___. He was treated with a 
total dose of 7000 cGy delivered with weekly carboplatinum.
___- Seen by Dr. ___. On laryngoscopy there was evidence 
of fungal laryngitis, involving the supraglottis.  There is also 
mucosal irregularity, concerning for disease
persistence/recurrence. Biopsy was deferred, as his restaging 
PET/CT was pending.
___- restaging PET/CT- Demonstrated a prominent FDG avid 
supraglottic mass, not significantly changed since the 
comparison study, and demonstrating an SUV max of up to 11.1.  
In addition, there has been interval enlargement of bilateral 
Level II 2 lymph nodes. Other cervical lymph nodes have also 
increased in size and FDG avidity.
___- Biopsy of larynx, ___ lesion showed 
extensively necrotic tissue with a small focus of highly 
atypical squamous cells suspicious for squamous cell carcinoma, 
multiple
levels examined. 
___- Panendoscopy with biopsy by Dr. ___- invasive ___.

Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Laryngeal cancer

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
*Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.
*Continue stoma care
*Do not take anything by mouth until you have been cleared by 
your surgeon after a leak test. Continue tube feeds via ___.
*The ___ fastener buttons (3) will fall off on their own in 
few weeks time; do not try to remove them.
*Take insulin as instructed by diabetes educator.

___ Instructions: Laryngectomy

ACTIVITY
Go home and rest today.
If you have received general anesthesia, you may feel tired 
and drowsy for a few hours. You should not drink alcoholic 
beverages, drive a car, operate any machinery, or make legal 
decision for 24 hours.
You need to avoid strenuous activity for 2 weeks
Do NOT lift any weight greater than 10 Lbs for 2 weeks.
Make sure you exercise your shoulders and arms gently to keep 
them from getting stiff
You should not take in anything by mouth until cleared at your 
___ appointment 

MEDICATIONS
Take pain medication as prescribed.
Resume other medications as prescribed except any aspirin or 
aspirin containing products unless cleared by your surgeon.

CARE OF PROCEDURE SITE
Your voice box has been removed. The hole in your neck is your 
only airway, and therefore should be treated with great care
Be sure to clean the crusts around the hole in your neck (the 
stoma), as often as needed. Keep the humidified air around the 
stoma as often as possible to prevent crusting.
You may find you need to suction deep into the stoma to get 
rid of this mucous. Some saline may be dropped into the stoma to 
break up some of the mucous if you find it is too thick.
Some swelling of the neck incision is expected
Apply antibiotic ointment to your incisions twice a day.
Keep incisions dry for 3 days. You may be able to take a bath 
from your shoulders down as long as the incision stays dry. If 
there is tape on your incision apply ointment over the tape. 
This tape will start falling off on its own.
If there are any crusts/clots on your wound you may gently 
clean them with a ___ and Half strength  hydrogen peroxide 
(10cc water + 10cc peroxide) as needed. Do not be too vigorous 
or your stitches or staples may break
The staples/stitches will be removed on your first 
___ visit

WHEN TO CALL YOUR DOCTOR
Excessive redness of your incision site
Fever greater than 101 degrees Fahrenheit
Sudden excessive swelling of incision site

*You should have a family member or friend call your local 
police and fire station to alert them you have had a 
laryngectomy and are limited in the ability to verbally 
communicate. This way, if they receive a call from your 
residence, they will send help immediately.

For questions or problems, please call ___ to speak 
to the clinic nurse during clinic hours.

After hours, or on weekends, dial ___ and ask the 
operator to page the Otolaryngology resident ___.

Instructions for ___:
-Please check vitals and do a home safety evaluation. Please 
check blood glucose as patient has diabetes and medications were 
recently changed due to NPO status.
-Please check on nutritional feeding status via ___. Pt is 
strict NPO.
-Please check on stoma care.
-Please check neck incision healing.
-Change ___ dressing daily. Gently cleanse around the skin 
entry site of the catheter with povidone iodine or dilute 
hydrogen peroxide. Dry and apply sterile gauze dressing.
-Please check on pain control. As postoperative pain decreases, 
he should schedule an appointment with Dr. ___ for 
further pain management.
-Please make sure that he follows up with ENT as scheduled, 
PCP/cardiologist, Dr. ___, and colorectal if he wants to 
have surgical management of diverticulitis.
-Report to the physician with any concerning findings.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 50-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a history of laryngeal cancer. He presented with hoarseness of his voice and a sore throat, and was diagnosed with stage III SCC of the supraglottic larynx with concurrent left true vocal cord T1 N0 M0 SCC. He underwent chemoradiation treatment, but his symptoms persisted, and a restaging PET/CT scan showed a prominent FDG avid supraglottic mass and interval enlargement of bilateral Level II lymph nodes.

The patient has a significant past medical history, including alcohol abuse, COPD, DM2, HFpEF, HTN, HLD, AFIB, OSA, morbid obesity, rhinitis, osteoarthritis, and tobacco abuse. He also has a family history of lung cancer, diabetes, and CAD.

The patient underwent a total laryngectomy and bilateral neck dissections, and was monitored for a night in the ICU before transferring to the floor. He received parenteral and enteral narcotics as needed for pain control, and was restarted on home medications during his hospital stay.

At discharge, the patient was tolerating bolus feeds through his G-tube, and was instructed to remain NPO and receive all nutrition and medications through the G-tube until otherwise stated by the surgeon. He was also advised to follow up with his surgeon when ready to transition back to suboxone. ||endoftext||

    extradural lesion.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Lumbar Decompression Without Fusion

You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
Without Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

                Activity:You should not lift anything greater 
than 10 lbs for 2 weeks.You will be more comfortable if you do 
not sit or stand more than~45 minutes without moving around.

                Rehabilitation/ Physical ___ times a 
day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your 
recovery.You can walk as much as you can tolerate.Limit any kind 
of lifting.

                Diet:Eat a normal healthy diet.You may have 
some constipation after surgery.You have been given medication 
to help with this issue.

                Brace:You may have been given a brace.If you 
have been given a brace, this brace is to be worn when you are 
walking.You may take it off when sitting in a chair or lying in 
bed.

                Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.If 
the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.If 
it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.Once 
the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower.Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery,do not get the incision wet.Cover it with a sterile 
dressing and call the office.

                You should resume taking your normal home 
medications.

                You have also been given Additional Medications 
to control your pain.Please allow 72 hours for refill of 
narcotic prescriptions,so please plan ahead.You can either have 
them mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located 
on ___.We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions(oxycontin,oxycodone,percocet) to your pharmacy.In 
addition,we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 
90 days from the date of surgery.

                Follow up:            

                Please Call the office and make an appointment 
for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this has not been 
done already.

                At the 2-week visit we will check your incision, 
take baseline X-rays and answer any questions.We may at that 
time start physical therapy.

               We will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of 
the operation and at that time release you to full activity.

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
Physical Therapy:
1)Weight bearing as tolerated.2)Gait,balance training.3)No 
lifting >10 lbs.4)No significant bending/twisting. 
Treatments Frequency:
Remove the dressing in 2 days.If the incision is draining cover 
it with a new sterile dressing.If it is dry then you can leave 
the incision open to the air.Once the incision is completely dry 
(usually ___ days after the operation) you may take a shower.Do 
not soak the incision in a bath or pool.If the incision starts 
draining at anytime after surgery,do not get the incision 
wet.Cover it with a sterile dressing and call the office.

___

She has a history of neurogenic claudication and lumbar stenosis, and has undergone two epidural steroid injections with temporary relief. She has also been diagnosed with COPD, liver disease, anxiety, and thyroid disease.

The patient underwent a surgical procedure, L3-5 Lami, which was performed without complication. She was started on postoperative pain medication and was advanced to a regular diet as tolerated. She was also started on physical therapy and occupational therapy for mobilization and ADL's.

The patient's hospital course was otherwise unremarkable, with the exception of an episode of altered mental status which was thought to be related to narcotics. Her pain is now well-controlled with Tylenol.

The patient's medications at discharge include acetaminophen, diazepam, docusate sodium, senna, albuterol inhaler, amitriptyline, atenolol, atorvastatin, cyanocobalamin, gabapentin, gemfibrozil, levothyroxine sodium, lisinopril, methimazole, pantoprazole, potassium chloride, and rivaroxaban. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have R leg subcutaneous hematoma and was admitted to the 
orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the 
operating room on ___ for R leg I&D, which the patient 
tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from 
the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory 
recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The 
patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, 
and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. 
The patient was given ___ antibiotics and 
anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were 
continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked 
with ___ who determined that discharge to rehab was appropriate. 

His hospital course was complicated by what was deemed an acute 
aspiration/choking event by MICU service, and he was briefly 
admitted to the ICU for care. His MICU course is as follows:

MICU COURSE ___
Patient cardiac arrested on the floor in the setting of choking 
on dinner. Underwent chest compressions for one minute and 
regained spontaneous respirations. PPM was interrogated to rule 
out primary cardiac arrhythmia and was unremarkable.

Patient was subsequently transferred back to the floor in stable 
condition, and he remained so up until day of discharge.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
weight-bearing as tolerated in the right lower extremity, and 
will be discharged on home Coumadin for DVT prophylaxis. Patient 
was explicitly instructed to follow-up as scheduled with his 
Cardiologist for Coumadin management (pt stated he has an 
appointment ___. Instructions were left with the rehab 
facility to draw INR ___ and adjust dose accordingly. The 
patient will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough 
discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and 
expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the 
office or return to the hospital, and all questions were 
answered. The patient was also given written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

Extended Care

R leg subcutaneous hematoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- WBAT RLE

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Warfarin as previously administered (prior to 
inpatient stay). You need to follow-up with your Cardiologist 
___ monitoring and regimen adjustment of this 
medication. You have stated that you have an appointment with 
her on ___, and we recommend that you keep this appointment 
unless unable to do so for rehab reasons. Your next ___ lab 
draw should be on ___, with your Coumadin dose adjusted 
accordingly.

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.
Physical Therapy:
WBAT RLE
Treatments Frequency:
dry sterile dressing + ACE, change as needed
 
Followup Instructions:
___

The patient is a ___ w/ h/o pancreatic cancer s/p whipple and 
currently on gemzar w/ recent ___ admitted to ___ for workup 
of delirium. A full delirium workup was completed. An MRI head 
did not show any acute abnormalities. Urine was clean. 
Electrolytes were within normal limits. Vitamin B12 was 
elevated. TSH was low, but thyroid hormones were WNL. RPR was 
negative. An LP was performed which was clear, and an HSV PCR 
was sent off and came back negative.

Psychiatry was asked to see the patient. They discussed several 
possibilities including opiate induced delirium, benzo 
withdrawal, ___ body dementia. The patient stopped taking 
oxycondone 2 days before admission. Although opiates can stay in 
the system for a time after stopping them, this is not likely 
the cause. The patient had taken oxycodone in the past and 
tolerated the medication well. She is older, and older patients 
are more sensitive to opiates though. She is taking klonopin and 
recently had the dose decreased by her psychiatrist. It seems 
like the decrease was reasonable, and should not have caused 
withdrawal. Another possibility is ___ body dementia. One of 
the presenting symptoms is visual hallucinations, but several 
other symptoms usually coincide including cognitive fluctuations 
and spontaneous extrapyramidal signs. The patient did not 
display any of these other symptoms making the diagnosis less 
likely. This diagnosis is made clinically and in the abscence of 
more presenting symptoms difficult to make for this admission.

The patient was pre-emptively started on acyclovir for presumed 
HSV infection. The patient was well hydrated while receiving 
this medication. Once the HSV PCR came back negative the 
acyclovir was stopped.

and actually did not occur during the hospitalization. Although 
a definitive cause was not determined, the patient is otherwise 
stable and ready to go home with ___.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 58-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for workup of delirium. She has a history of bipolar disorder and metastatic pancreatic cancer to the liver, which was treated with RFA and chemotherapy. She was recently admitted for RFA of a liver lesion and was discharged the day after, but experienced waxing and waning mental status and RUQ pain over the weekend. She was taking Klonopin and oxycodone, but stopped taking the latter two days before admission. On admission, she reported disturbing visual hallucinations, which seemed to come on more at night. She denied phono/photophobia and had mild neck stiffness, but no fevers, chills, or night sweats. Her past medical history includes a Whipple procedure for pancreatic cancer, and she is currently taking Gemzar for disease progression.

The patient's physical examination was normal, with no abnormalities noted. Her laboratory results were also normal, with the exception of elevated liver enzymes and a low TSH level. A full delirium workup was completed, including an MRI head, which did not show any acute abnormalities. A lumbar puncture was also performed, which was clear, and a HSV PCR was sent off and came back negative.

The patient was diagnosed with delirium, and psychiatry was consulted to discuss possible causes, including opiate-induced delirium, benzodiazepine withdrawal, and Lewy body dementia. The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, but the specific medications were not mentioned in the report. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient admitted to the MICU for hypoxia.  He was on 6L NC.  He 
was febrile and a CXR and Chest CT were concerning for 
hemorrhage, infection or fluid.  He was treated boradly with 
antibiotics (vancomycin and cefepime) and cultures were sent.  
He improved dramatically with dialysis and resultant fluid 
removal.  He was weaned down to 2L nasal canula.  A Bronch was 
discussed but as he was improving it was felt that he could have 
a bronch outside the ICU where brushings could be done.  He 
spiked a temp to 101 in the ICU.  His ICU course was complicated 
by a-fib with RVR while on HD.  He was treated with IV and PO 
betablocker.  

On transfer to the floor, he was stable and breathing 
comfortably on 2 L oxygen with continued hemoptysis improved in 
terms of quantity.  He was continued on PO metoprolol 100 mg tid 
for Afib.  Coumadin and aspirin were initially held after 
discussion with PCP and cardiologist Dr. ___.  He was seen by 
pulmonary who decided against a bronch given improving 
hemoptysis and recommended PO levofloxacin  for total ABX of 10 
day duration given likely infectious etiology of hemoptysis. 
They also approved restarting anticoagulation.  During his 
hospital stay, he remained afebrile with normal WBC.  For his 
end stage renal disease, he received dialysis.  He got dialysis 
on ___.

For his Afib, we will discharge on metoprolol succinate 300 mg 
daily  We will ask him to hold amlodipine, to be re-started at 
discretion of PCP/cardiologist.  We will start him on warfarin 
2.5 mg daily, with INR check on ___ and f/u 
appointment with PCP on ___ at which time warfarin 
dosing can be re-adjusted.  His aspirin was also restarted.

We recommend a f/u x-ray as an outpatient in 8 weeks.  We also 
recommend referral by his PCP to ___ pulmonologist for f/u .

||startoftext|| The patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with hypoxia and hemoptysis. He has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is on dialysis three times a week. He also has hypertension, diabetes type II, dyspepsia, gout, carpal tunnel syndrome, hyperparathyroidism, peptic ulcer disease, atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter, and CHF. He presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath and was found to be hypoxic to 84%, which improved to 95% on 4L oxygen. He reported a two-week history of increasing cough with sputum production and had been experiencing subacute symptoms and increasing orthopnea.

The patient was treated with antibiotics and dialysis, and his condition improved dramatically. He was weaned off oxygen and was stable on 2L oxygen at the time of discharge. He was prescribed metoprolol succinate 300 mg daily for his atrial fibrillation, and warfarin 2.5 mg daily with INR check on a certain date. He was also restarted on aspirin.

The patient's medications at admission included allopurinol, amlodipine, calcium acetate, glargine, lansoprazole, metoprolol succinate, paricalcitol, miralax, warfarin, acetaminophen, and aspirin. His discharge medications included calcium acetate, allopurinol, acetaminophen, insulin glargine, humalog, lansoprazole, and miralax. ||endoftext||

age: 62. gender: F.  
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE

Demerol / Morphine Sulfate / Heparin Agents
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
anemia, liver failure
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with cirrhosis ___ UC/PBC 
recently admitted with ulcerative colitis flare and LGIB, now 
transferred from ___ after presenting with collapse 
and decompensation of ESLD (MELD of 28, up from 13).  Of note 
she does endorse persistent bloody stools sicne recent 
discharge, up to ___ times daily(decreased from 20x/day on 
recent admission).  At ___ she was found to have 
worsening anemia, HCT 25.7 (31.5 on ___ as well as 
decompensated liver failure with Tbili up to 16.4 (2.6 on 
___.  Her course was complicated by hypotension, she was 
treated with IVF and 2 units prbc and she had a L subclavian 
line placed for access.  She was treated with Ceftriaxone ___ 
concern for possible cholangitis given leukocytosis.  She 
initially had ARF with creatinine 1.4 at OSH which resolved with 
IVF/PRBC.     
.  

 
Past Medical History:
1. Ulcerative Colitis  
- Followed by Dr. ___  
- Last sigmoidoscopy ___ without dysplasia  
- Recent flares refractory to steroids, currently on Remicade 
(was on steroids last admission and then transferred to 
Remicade) 
2. Primary biliary cirrhosis  
- Diagnosed ___ yrs ago  
- Complicated by ascites, occasional hepatic encephalopathy,  
variceal bleed  
- Last EGD ___ without varices  
3. Hypokalemia  
4. Blood loss anemia secondary to lower GI bleed  
5. Portal vein thrombosis  
6. Portal-hypertension related ascites  
7. HIT positive  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father: UC, alive age ___  
Mother: No IBD, + ovarian Cancer  
 
Physical Exam:
VS T96.5 BP 91/56 - 100/54 RR ___ HR 95-102  97% on 4l NC 
Gen: cachetic frail jaundiced, appears comfortable in no acute 
distress
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, sclerae icteric, MM slightly dry  
Neck: JVD with significant respiratory variation
CV: RRR no m/r/g. left sided subclavain CVL with intact dressing
Resp: Left sideded chest tube in place with clean dressing, 
breath sounds bilaterally, absent at left base
Abd: soft, non-distended, + bowel sounds, diffuse pressure with 
palpation but denies pain, no rebound or guarding 
Extrem: 2+ pitting edema b/l to knees
Skin: occasional ecchymoses, spider angiomas  
Neuro: A&O x3, speech clear, mild asterixis present  

 
Pertinent Results:
Admission Labs:
WBC-9.2 RBC-3.46* Hgb-11.2* Hct-32.8* MCV-95 MCH-32.4* MCHC-34.2 
RDW-18.5* Plt Ct-32*#
Neuts-93.4* Lymphs-3.0* Monos-3.4 Eos-0.2 Baso-0
___ PTT-56.1* ___
Glucose-169* UreaN-32* Creat-1.0 Na-128* K-4.3 Cl-94* HCO3-28 
ALT-98* AST-83* LD(LDH)-377* AlkPhos-314* TotBili-21.3*
Albumin-2.0* Calcium-9.5 Phos-2.9 Mg-2.1
 
___ EKG - Sinus tachycardia, rate of 101. Non-specific T 
wave changes. No other diagnostic abnormality. 
 
___ RUQ ultrasound - IMPRESSION: 
1. New complete thrombosis of the main portal vein. 
2. Unchanged cirrhosis and ascites. 
 
___ CXR PA & LAT - IMPRESSION: Large left pneumothorax.
 
___ CXR - FINDINGS: There has been little change in the 
appearance of the thorax since ___. A left-sided 
chest tube remains in unchanged position with no evidence of 
pneumothorax. There may have been minimal clearing of the left 
lower lobe atelectasis. The contour of the azygos vein is 
prominent, particularly given the upright positioning suggestive 
of volume overload without frank pulmonary edema. The gaseous 
distention of the stomach has resolved since the previous study, 
but now mildly prominent loops of bowel are noted in the upper 
abdomen. 
 
___ Chest CT with contrast - IMPRESSION: 
1. Compared to a ___ study of ___, and the ___ 
study of 
___, there has been progression of this patient's 
splanchnic thrombus, now occluding the left and right portal 
veins. There is also focal thrombus within the dilated SMV at 
the SMV-portal vein confluence. The SMV, however, remains 
patent. Additionally, there has been an increase in ascites. 
2. Signs of portal hypertension including intra-abdominal, 
paraesophageal 
varices and splenomegaly. 
3. Chronic findings including some small bowel thickening 
(likely related to ascites and venous congestion from splanchnic 
thrombus) and uncomplicated cholelithiasis. 
 
___ ECHO - The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Due 
to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality 
cannot be fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic 
function is normal (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular chamber size 
and free wall motion are normal. Tricuspid regurgitation is 
present but cannot be quantified. The pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure could not be determined. There is a trivial/physiologic 
pericardial effusion. 
No vegetation seen (cannot exclude).  
 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ yo F w/cirrhosis ___ UC/PSC, severe LGIB 
___ UC, h/o HIT transferred from OSH with acute decompensated 
hepatic failure and anemia, found to have large left 
pneumothorax with concern for progression to tension PTX 
prompting emergent ICU transfer and CT placement.    
 
On arrival to the medical floor she was noted to be hypoxic 
88%RA, which was new per discharge summary from the OSH.  She 
had a CXR to further evaluate her hypoxia which showed large 
left hydropneumothorax in the setting of recent line placement 
concerning hemopneumothorax, complete collapse of the left lung, 
and new right effusion.  In addition she had abdominal 
ultrasound on admission given her new hepatic decompensation, 
which showed new portal vein thrombosis.  CT surgery was 
consulted for chest tube placement.  She was also started on 
vancomycin for report of ___ blood culture bottle drawn from 
subclavian line with GPC, peripheral blood culture still with no 
growth.  Prior to chest tube placement she was given vitamin K 
10mg po x1, 5 units FFP, 2 units PRBC, 2 bags platelets to 
reverse her coagulopathy.    
  
While on the floor she acutely decompensated with HR up to 150's 
and hypotension.  She was given 1L IVF bolus and transferred to 
ICU for stat chest tube placement ___ concern for possible 
tension pneumothorax.  She did well post chest tube placement 
with post xray showing re-expansion of her left lung.  She did 
have an episode of hypotension following chest tube placement 
likely ___ acute reexpansion of her left lung.  

MICU course:
 
#Acute Hepatic Decompensation/PBC - Most likely secondary to 
portal vein thrombosis seen on RUQ ultrasound on admission.  
Unfortunately given her severe LGIB secondary to ulcerative 
colitis the patient was not a candidate for anticoagulation.  
SBP was also considered in the differential, but paracentesis 
could not be performed because of low platelets so she was 
intially treated empirically with ceftriaxone then switched to 
cefipime (day #1 = ___ for broader coverage.  She is not a 
transplant candidate currently due to UC and sepsis.  Per 
hepatology even if the patient recovers from bactermia and DIC, 
she is unlikely to be a transplant candidate in the future.  
 
She had waxing and waning mental status while in the MICU.  At 
times A&O x3, but usually oriented just to person and place (not 
date).  She continued to receive lactulose, but some doses were 
held due to extensive stooling with lots of blood.  She was 
continued on rifaxamin and ursodiol
 
# Thrombocytopenia/Coagulopathy: Likely secondary to liver 
disease and consistent with DIC/sepsis.  The patient was given a 
single dose of Neupogen.  Hematology was consulted.  Peripheral 
smear with schisocytes and several other types of dysmorphic 
RBCs.  Her platelets dropped to 13 in setting of an acute bleed. 
 She was transfused 1 unit of platelets.  The following day she 
received 1 unit of platelets and 2U of PRBC.  Her platelets 
subsequently dropped again to 16 and she was given FFP x2 units 
and 1 unit of cryoprecipitate given positive DIC labs.  At one 
point she was bleeding from both her foley and chest tube in 
addition to her rectum, but the former resolved and her DIC labs 
improved.  Currently she continues to have melena/BRBPR 
intermittantly, but no other bleeding.  She received her last 
unit of platelets on ___ before family decided the patient 
would receive no further blood products.  Serial hematocrits and 
other labs were also stopped per family wishes.  
 
# MRSA bacteremia - One blood culture bottle from OSH drawn from 
CVL is positive.  Culture here positive for MRSA in ___ bottles. 
 Her line was changed.  Chest CT showed no abcesses, although 
pleural fluid had many WBCs and coag+ Staph. aureus as well. 
Skin exam shows no focus for bacteremia, although the patient 
has a history of MRSA skin infections.  The primary source of 
her bacteremia is unclear.  ECHO did not show any vegetations on 
her heart valves.  She was started on vancomycin on ___ for a 
14 day course.  
 
#Pneumothorax - most likely developed slowly following placement 
of a left subclavian line at the OSH and likely progressed to 
cause hemodynamic compromise resulting in tachycardia and 
hypotension on the floor.  She had a chest tube placed  with 
post procedure x-ray showing reexpansion of her left lung.  
Chest CT showed residual pneumothorax, but chest tube was sealed 
while at CT.  Again, post CT xray showed no pneumothorax. 
 
#Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter - Early on in admission she had 
been going in and out PAF with rate up to 150's, BP stable since 
CT placed.  PAF resolved with IVF.  Initially rate controlling 
agents were held given episodic hypotension and GI bleeding.  
When she became hemodynamically more stable low dose metoprolol 
was added.  
 
#. Ulcerative colitis: She has severe/refractory disease despite 
steroid treatment. She recently finished a course of 
cipro/flagyl as inpt/oupt.  She was recently treated with 
remicaid on ___ followed by prednisone.  She is now on stress 
dose hydrocortisone.  Mesalamine was stopped per hepatology 
recommendations and remicade and ___ were also held.  
 
# FEN: NGT was placed for tube feeds to improve nutrition status 
and she was initially given a regular diet as well.  Eventually 
the patient stopped taking POs and tube feeds were held due to 
high residuals.  Tube feeds were subsequently restarted at 10cc 
per hour and kept at that rate for approximately 24 hours before 
they were held again because of frequent BRBPR. 
 
#Code status: On ___ the patient stated that she no longer 
wished to live and began refusing medical intervention.  The 
patient's husband/HCP was contacted.  After a family meeting, 
the patient was made DNR/DNI early in the morning of ___.  
After further discussion, the patient was made CMO on the 
afternoon of ___ with the exception that antibiotics are still 
to be given.  However, she is to receive no blood products, lab 
draws, or radiology studies.  

Course of care on the ___ service:

On ___, the patient was transferred to the medical floor given 
the change in the goals of her care.  All phlebotomy and 
radiographs were stopped. Antibiotics were continued.  
Stress-dose steroids were tapered.  All other medications were 
stopped.  She initially continued to receive tube-feeds, but 
this was subsequently withdrawn at the family's request.  
Subsequent;y, after discussion with patient's family, 
antibiotics and steroids were discontinued and the patient 
expired on ___ at 1130am. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Mesalamine 1g PO QID (4 times a day).  
Ursodiol 300 mg PO BID  
Cholestyramine-Sucrose 4 gram Packet Sig: One (1) Packet PO  
BID (2 times a day).  
Spironolactone 100 mg PO DAILY  
Prednisone 20 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO DAILY  
Protonix 40 mg Tablet PO once a day.  
Rifaximin 400 mg PO TID  
Lactulose Thirty (30) ML PO TID titrate to 3 bowel movements 
daily  
Lasix 40 mg PO daily: please take if increasing ascites or lower 
ext edema.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis
End Stage Liver Disease
MRSA Bacteremia
Pneumothorax

 
Discharge Condition:
Expired

 
Followup Instructions:
___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 62-year-old female with a chief complaint of anemia and liver failure. She has a history of cirrhosis, ulcerative colitis, and primary biliary cirrhosis. She was recently admitted with a flare of ulcerative colitis and lower gastrointestinal bleeding, and was found to have worsening anemia and decompensated liver failure. She has a history of allergies to Demerol, Morphine Sulfate, and Heparin Agents. She was treated with IV fluids, blood transfusions, and antibiotics, and had a left subclavian line placed for access. She was also started on vancomycin for a blood culture that grew GPC. The patient's diagnosis includes cirrhosis, ulcerative colitis, and portal vein thrombosis. She underwent a chest CT with contrast, which showed progression of the splanchnic thrombus and signs of portal hypertension. She was treated in the ICU for acute hepatic decompensation and was not a candidate for anticoagulation due to her severe LGIB. She was also treated for sepsis and had a waxing and waning mental status while in the ICU. At discharge, she was prescribed medications including lactulose and was advised to follow up with her primary care physician. ||endoftext||

He has also been taking medications for his schizophrenia, including clozapine, aripiprazole, and hydroxyzine.

The patient's past medical history includes squamous cell lung cancer, paranoid schizophrenia, and GERD. He has no family history of cancer. His physical exam is notable for a thin appearance, and his vital signs are stable.

The patient's pertinent lab results include neutropenia, likely caused by chemotherapy, and normocytic anemia, likely caused by malignancy and inflammatory block and chemo effects. His TSH level is 6.9, indicating hypothyroidism.

The patient's discharge medications include ondansetron, aripiprazole, clozapine, levothyroxine, lorazepam, and prochlorperazine. His discharge diagnosis is lung cancer, and his discharge condition is mental status clear and coherent, level of consciousness alert and interactive, and activity status ambulatory-independent. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, he underwent cadaveric kidney transplant performed by 
Dr. ___. A ureteral stent was placed. He received 
induction immunosuppression (ATG, solumedrol and cellcept). 
Postop, urine output declined. The catheter was flushed without 
increased urine output. A renal U/S was done showing a small 
perinephric fluid collection superior to the renal transplan. 
Vasculature was patent and there was no hydronephrosis. 
Creatinine trended up and urine output was minimal. 

Dialysis was done on ___ for delayed graft function. Potassium 
was 6.1 pre-dialysis. He experienced a hct drop to 18.9. This 
was verified with a repeat hct of 18. An abdominal/pelvis CT was 
done revealing a the transplant kidney surrounded by a right 
perinephric hematoma extending superiorly as a right 
retroperitoneal 
hematoma. There was no evidence of hydronephrosis. The epicenter 
of this hematoma did not involve the renal hilum. He was given 2 
units of PRBC in dialysis with hematocrit increase to 26.2. 

A total of 4 doses of ATG (100mg)were given. Steroids were 
tapered per protocol. Prograf was initiated and up titrated to 
8mg bid for trough levels of 2.0. 

He did experience an ileus requiring an NG tube and NPO status. 
On ___, patient kidney with 1300 ml of urine. Dialysis held 
the following day with improving Cr 5.3 from 5.8. Abdomen still 
appeared distended with tenderness over graft area. Prograf 
levels kept at 8mg BID for level 5.9.

Patient continued to clinically improve until day of discharge. 
Continued to ambulate without problems. Physical therapy 
providing assistance. Urine output regained and > 1.5 liters 
daily. Able to pass flatus with normal bowel movements. Cr 
stable at 2.2. Diet advanced as tolerated. Started on nifedipine 
CR 60mg q daily (takes 90 mg at home) and will be discharged on 
clonidine patch of 0.2mg (0.3mg at home). Prograf level reduced 
to 6mg BID for level 12.3. All medications and instructions 
provided. Patient discharged home with ___ on ___.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 66-year-old male who was admitted for a kidney transplant. He has a history of End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus type 2. He has no known allergies to drugs. The patient's chief complaint was ESRD, and he underwent a cadaveric kidney transplant. However, he experienced delayed graft function and a perinephric hematoma, which was managed with dialysis and medication.

The patient's physical exam revealed a well-nourished individual with normal vital signs. His laboratory results showed a creatinine level of 2.2, and his urine output was stable at the time of discharge.

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, nystatin, docusate sodium, metoprolol tartrate, hydrocodone-acetaminophen, clonidine, timolol maleate, prednisone, mycophenolate mofetil, omeprazole, valganciclovir, nifedipine, glucopro, lancets, glucocom blood glucose kit, insulin regular human, and tacrolimus.

The patient was discharged home with good condition and was instructed to follow up with the transplant office if he experienced any symptoms such as fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, or inability to take his medication. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
#. Hepatic Encephalopathy: Patient admitted because he was found 
to be encephalopathic in the setting of medication 
non-compliance. His NGT had clogged about 3 days prior to 
admission and he stopped taking his medications. He was treated 
with lactulose PR on the day of admission and his mental status 
improved. On HD 2 his mental status was back to his baseline and 
he was switched to PO lactulose. He had a diagnostic 
paracentesis performed that ruled out SBP, urine and blood 
cultures were negative for infection. RUQ U/S did not reveal a 
new liver process and the vasculature was found to be patent. 
His NGT was replaced by ___ and he was re-started on tube feeds. 
He had no more episodes of confusion during his hospitalization.

#. Acute renal failure: Patient's Cr was found to be 2.7 
(baseline 1.5-1.7) on admission. This was thought to be due to 
pre-renal azotemia in the setting of the patient being 
dehydrated and not eating appropriately since his NGT clogged 
and he was encephalopathic. He was treated with hydration and 
his renal function rapidly improved. His Cr was 2.0 on the day 
of discharge. 

#. Anemia: Patient was found to be anemic on admission with a 
Hct of 22.7. His baseline Hct runs in the low ___ range but on 
HD 2 his Hct was 17.8. He had no overt bleed and remained 
asymptomatic.  He was transfused 2 units of PRBCs and his Hct 
responded appropriately. His Hct was 22.6 on discharge which is 
around his baseline.

You were admitted because you were found to be confused in the 
setting of your feeding tube being clogged and you not taking 
your medication as prescribed.  We re-started you on your 
lactulose and rifaxamin and your confusion improved.  We also 
replaced your clogged feeding tube so you can continue to 
receive tube feedings and medications while you are at home.  As 
a consecuence of you not taking your medications and not eating 
propertly because your tube was clogged your kidney function 
worsened transiently.  We hydrated you and gave you medications 
and this is now back to your normal state. While in the hospital 
you were found to be anemic, more so than your normal, and you 
were transfused 2 units of red blood cells.  This made your 
blood count go back to your baseline.
If you start feeling sleepy or confused, dizzy, light headed, 
have any fevers, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath or your 
abdomen becomes very tense please call the GI offices or come to 
the emergency room for futher evaluation. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 43-year-old male with a chief complaint of altered mental status. He has a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, diagnosed with portal vein thrombosis, severe portal hypertension, and gastropathy. He has also had seizures from ethanol withdrawal and has completed a liver transplant workup. The patient's wife reports that his mental status has been worsening over the past three days, and he has been somnolent for the past two days. He was recently discharged from the hospital for hepatic encephalopathy but did not follow up with his clinic appointment and stopped taking his medications.

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a clogged nasogastric tube and was found to have altered mental status, ascites, and a low platelet count. He received a transfusion of 2 PRBCs and was diagnosed with encephalopathy. The patient's laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, low albumin levels, and abnormal coagulation studies.

The patient underwent a chest X-ray, which showed a feeding tube ending close to the pylorus, and a liver ultrasound, which showed a shrunken nodular liver appearance consistent with cirrhosis. The patient's medications at discharge included paracentesis every 1-2 weeks and treatment for his encephalopathy.

The patient's allergies and adverse reactions are not specified in the report. ||endoftext||

1. Post-TACE Monitoring: The patient had hepatocellular 
carcinoma (HCC) presumably from a combination of his Hepatitis C 
Virus infection and history of alcohol abuse. After completion 
of the TACE procedure the patient was transferred to the OMED 
service for monitoring. The patient remained pain free 
throughout the admission but did have some nausea that was 
controlled with anti-emetics. The patient's liver enzymes were 
monitored throughout admission. His AST, ALT, total bilirubin 
were within normal limits at time of transfer, became elevated 
on day two of admission but were trending back down at the time 
of discharge. A CT scan of the abdomen the day following the 
procedure demonstrated post-TACE changes but no concerning 
abnormalities. The patient became febrile to 101.2 the night 
following his procedure and Ciprofloxacin was started in 
addition to Unasyn, which is typically given for four doses 
post-TACE. The remainder of the post-TACE protocol was followed 
without event. The patient was discharged home with instructions 
to follow up with his outpatient Oncologist. 
.
2. ESLD: Stable. The patient was maintained on his regular home 
medications which included Lasix. The patient also received 
Nadolol for prophylaxis of variceal bleeding. Lactulose was 
administered and the patient never produced signs of hepatic 
encephalopathy. 
.
3. Hypertension: The patient was normotensive throughout 
admission. His home anti-hypertensives, Lisinopril and 
Amiloride, were continued throughout his stay.

Discharge Instructions:
Instructions After Orthopedic Surgery
 
- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.
 
Medicines
- Per your infectious disease doctors, you are to continue IV 
Cefazolin for 8 weeks after discharge.  
- Resume taking your home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon. Please talk to your primary 
care doctor within the next ___ weeks regarding this 
hospitalization and any changes to your home medications that 
may be necessary.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive, or operate machinery while you 
are taking narcotic pain relievers (oxycodone/dilaudid).
- As your pain lessens, decrease the amount of narcotic pain 
relievers you are taking. Instead, take acetaminophen (also 
called tylenol). Follow all instructions on the medication 
bottle and never take more than 4,000mg of tylenol in a single 
day.
- If you need medication refills, call your surgeon's office 
3-to-4 days before you need the refill. Your prescriptions will 
be mailed to your home.
- Please take Lovenox for 2 weeks after discharge to help 
prevent the formation of blood clots.
 
Constipation
 
- Both surgery and narcotic pain relievers can cause 
constipation. Please follow the advice below to help prevent 
constipation.
- Drink 8 glasses of water and/or other fluids like juice, tea, 
and broth to stay well hydrated.
- Eat foods that are high in fiber like fruits and vegetables.
- Please take a stool softener like docusate (also called 
colace) to help prevent constipation while you are taking 
narcotic pain relievers. 
- You may also take a laxative such as senna (also called 
Senokot) to help promote regular bowel movements. 
- You can buy senna or colace over the counter. Stop taking them 
if your bowel movements become loose. If your bowel movements 
continue to stay loose after stopping these medications, please 
call your doctor.
 
Incision
 
- Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
surgeon if you experience severe pain, increased swelling, 
decreased sensation, more difficulty with movement, increased 
redness or drainage at the incision site.
- No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- You will continue to use the wound vac until follow up with 
vac sponge changes every ___ days.  
- You may put an ice pack on your surgical site, but do not put 
the ice pack directly on your skin (place a towel between your 
skin and the ice pack), and do not leave it in place for more 
than 20 minutes at a time.
 
Activity
 
- Your weight-bearing restrictions are: weight bearing as 
tolerated in the left lower extremity.
- You should wear your wound vac at all times.
 

Physical Therapy:
WBAT LLE, ROMAT. 
Treatments Frequency:
Q2-3 Day vac changes to LLE. 
If wound becomes too small for vac sponge, proceed with WTD dsg 
changed BID
 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 60-year-old male who was admitted to the orthopedics service with a chief complaint of left lower extremity (LLE) wound infection following a left knee washout and irrigation and debridement (I&D) procedure. He has a history of obesity, hypertension, TB, bronchitis, chronic venous stasis, and mild cognitive delay. He also has a history of physical altercation and suffered an open fracture of his left tibia, which was surgically repaired with multiple revisions and vascular repair.

The patient's past medical history includes a history of "clots" in his blood, for which he took full-dose aspirin. He has a family history of hypertension, schizophrenia, and cancer. His physical examination revealed a 2-3 cm x 2 cm wound on his left tibia with a wound vac in place, minimal surrounding erythema, and scant serosanguineous drainage.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated levels of ALT, AST, and alkaline phosphatase, as well as a high CRP level. His wound cultures grew Enterococcus and Candida, but the ID believes these cultures are contaminants. He was managed on Cefazolin per ID, and despite the wound cultures growing resistant organisms, the ID recommended an 8-week course of Cefazolin.

The patient's discharge medications include Acetaminophen, Aspirin, Cefazolin, Atorvastatin, Docusate Sodium, Enoxaparin Sodium, Hydrocodone, Glargine, Lisinopril, Metformin, and Senna. His discharge diagnosis is left lower extremity wound infection, status post incision and drainage. His discharge condition is clear and coherent, with an alert and interactive mental status, and he is ambulatory with assistance or aid. ||endoftext||

age: 79. gender: F.

___ Complaint:
Breast cancer
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Left simple mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy, with 
immediate tissue expander insertion

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old female with history of previous bilateral breast 
cancer, BCT on left, MRM on right. Now with recurrent left 
breast cancer.

 
Past Medical History:
HTN
macular degeneration
breast cancer
Compression fracture T7 ___ s/p fall
Thyroid disease
reflux 
 
Social History:
Non-smoker, occasional ETOH, denies recreational drug use.
 
Physical Exam:
Pre-procedure physical exam as documented in anesthesia record 
___:
pulse: 65/min
BP: 135/71
O2sat: 98% RA
.
General: NAD
Mental/psych: AxOx3
Airway: as documented in detail in anesthesia record
Dental: Other (chipped R, upper incisor, crowns left and right 
lower, perm, bridge left upper)
Head/neck range of motion: limited
Lungs: clear to auscultation
Other: anicteric, no LAD, thyroid not palpable; left breast skin 
no excoriation; breast exam per Dr. ___
 
___ Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had a left mastectomy with tissue expander 
placement and sentinel node lymph biopsy.  The patient tolerated 
the procedure well. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received dilaudid PCA with 
good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. 
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. She was also started on a bowel 
regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were 
closely monitored. 
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin, 
then switched to PO cefadroxil for discharge home. The patient's 
temperature was closely watched for signs of infection. 
.
Prophylaxis: The patient was encouraged to get up and ambulate 
as early as possible. 
.
At the time of discharge on POD#1, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  Her left mastectomy incision was clean and dry, 
flat.  No evidence of hematoma. Her JP drains x 2 with serosang 
fluid.
 
Medications on Admission:
Lisinopril
 
Discharge Medications:
1. lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain: Patient given Rx by Dr. ___ 
previously.  
3. Tylenol ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as 
needed for fever or pain: Max 12/day. Do not exceed 4gms/4000mgs 
of tylenol per day.  
4. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day): Over the counter stool softener.  
5. cefadroxil 500 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day 
for 10 days: Continue while drain remains in place. Refill as 
needed.
Disp:*20 Capsule(s)* Refills:*1*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Breast cancer

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care:  
 1. Any left mastectomy/chest dressing should be left in place x 
48 hours after surgery.  
 2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with soap and water.  
 3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day.  
 4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount.  
 5. You may shower daily. No baths until instructed to do so by 
Dr. ___.  When you shower you should secure your drain to a 
laniard or an old pair of stockings tied around your neck so it 
does not hang down.
 6. You should wear your surgibra at all times, except for 
showering.
 .  
 Activity:  
 1. You may resume your regular diet.  
 2. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity until instructed by Dr. ___.  
 .  
 Medications:  
 1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered.  
 2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Please note that 
Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient so do 
not take these meds with additional Tylenol.  
 4. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol.  
 5. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.  
 6. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish.  
 7.  Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.  
.  
 Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:  
 1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
welling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s).  
 2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
 
 3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF  
 4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.  
 .  
 Return to the ER if:  
 * If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.  
 * If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.  
 * Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.  
 .  
 DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS  
 You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

age: 35. gender: M.

Asymptomatic with Mitral Valve prolpase and moderate to severe 
mitral regurgitation
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Minimal Invasive Mitral Valve Repair
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a pleasant ___ year male, physically active 
___ at ___, who presents today for 
cardiac surgery evaluation regarding moderate to severe mitral 
regurgitation secondary to MVP. Mr. ___ was diagnosed with 
mitral valve prolapse at the age of ___ back in ___ when his 
friend physician listened to his heart. Subsequently he had 
echocardiographic surveillance in absence of significant 
lifestyle limiting cardiovascular symptoms, playing soccer 3 
times a week. He was born as a normal child without known 
congenital abnormalities and had normal development without 
unusual childhood illnesses, actively participating in sports. 
Sometimes, he feels forceful heartbeat without racing heart 
sensation with greasy food - he specifically denies any 
exertional chest pain, shortness of breath, paroxysmal nocturnal 
dyspnea, or syncope/near syncope. He denies a family history of 
premature CAD or sudden cardiac death. His most recent 
echocardiogram demonstrated moderate to severe mitral 
regurgitation secondary to posterior MVP in the presence of 
normal left ventricular size and function but severely dilated 
left atrium, left atrial volumetric index being measured 70 
ml/meter square. Based on the current findings the 
recommendation as per his Cardiologist is MVR in the presence of 
EF 57% and LASVI 70 ml/m2 (severe LAE).
 
Past Medical History:
Mitral valve prolapse and regurgitation
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Denies premature coronary artery disease
 
Physical Exam:
Pulse: 80  Resp: 16  O2 sat: 97% B/P  ___
 
Height: 5'8"    Weight: 140 lbs

General: Well-developed male in no acute distress
Skin: Warm [X] Dry [X] Intact [X]
HEENT: NCAT [X] PERRLA [X] EOMI [X]

Chest: Lungs clear bilaterally [X]

+ [X]

Discharge Exam:
VS: T: 98.5  HR: ___ SR  BP: 90-100/55 Sats: 98% RA
Weight: 62 kg
General: ___ year-old male in no apparent distress
HEENT: normocephalic mucus membranes moist
Neck: supple no lymphadenopathy
Cardiac: RRR normal S1,S2
GI: benign
Extr:warm no edema
Wound: right mid-thoracotomy site clean dry intact no erythema
Neuro: awake, alert oriented
 
Pertinent Results:
Left Ventricle - Diastolic Dimension:  4.7 cm  <= 5.6 cm  
Left Ventricle - Ejection Fraction:  >= 55%  >= 55%  
Aorta - Annulus:  2.0 cm  <= 3.0 cm  
Aorta - Sinus Level:  2.6 cm  <= 3.6 cm  
Aorta - Ascending:  2.2 cm  <= 3.4 cm  
Aortic Valve - Peak Velocity:  0.2 m/sec  <= 2.0 m/sec  
Aortic Valve - Peak Gradient:  4 mm Hg  < 20 mm Hg  
Aortic Valve - Mean Gradient:  2 mm Hg     
Aortic Valve - LVOT diam:  2.1 cm     
 
Findings  
LEFT ATRIUM: No spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus in the 
___ or the RA/RAA. 
RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: A catheter or pacing wire is 
seen in the RA and extending into the RV. Normal interatrial 
septum. No ASD by 2D or color Doppler. 
LEFT VENTRICLE: Overall normal LVEF (>55%). [Intrinsic LV 
systolic function likely depressed given the severity of 
valvular regurgitation.] 
RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV systolic function. 
AORTA: Normal aortic diameter at the sinus level. Normal 
ascending aorta diameter. Simple atheroma in descending aorta. 
No thoracic aortic dissection. 
AORTIC VALVE: Normal aortic valve leaflets (3). No AS. No AR. No 
AS. 
MITRAL VALVE: Mildly thickened mitral valve leaflets. Partial 
mitral leaflet flail. Mild mitral annular calcification. No MS. 
___ MR ___. Moderate to severe (3+) MR. ___ to the 
eccentric MR ___, its severity may be underestimated (Coanda 
effect). 
TRICUSPID VALVE: Tricuspid valve not well visualized. 
Physiologic TR. 
PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: Pulmonic valve not well seen. 
Physiologic (normal) PR. 
PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion. 

Conclusions  
PRE BYPASS No spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus is seen in 
the body of the left atrium/left atrial appendage or the body of 
the right atrium/right atrial appendage. No atrial septal defect 
is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Overall left ventricular 
systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). [Intrinsic left 
ventricular systolic function is likely more depressed given the 
severity of valvular regurgitation.] The right ventricle 
displays normal free wall contractility. There are simple 
atheroma in the descending thoracic aorta. No thoracic aortic 
dissection is seen. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear 
structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic 
stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. There is partial posterior mitral leaflet 
flail - it involves the P2 scallop. An eccentric, anteriorly 
directed jet of at least moderate to severe (3+) mitral 
regurgitation results. ___ to the eccentric nature of the 
regurgitant jet, its severity may be significantly 
underestimated (Coanda effect). There is no pericardial 
effusion. A coronary sinus catheter is seen transversing the 
right atrium from the ___. Dr. ___ was notified in 
person of the results in the operating room at the time of the 
study.

POST-BYPASS The patient is in sinus rhythm. There is normal 
biventricular systolic function. The mitral valve is s/p repair. 
A mitral valve annuloplasty ring is seen in situ. It appears 
well seated. There is trace to mild mitral regurgitation seen. 
There was some anterior mitral leaflet ___ noted on initial 
separation from bypass but it did not result in an outflow tract 
obstruction and had resolved completely after euvolemia was 
established. There is at least trace and likely mild, resultant 
mitral stenosis. The peak gradient across the mitral valve was 
18 mmHg and the mean about 11 mmHg but at a high cardiac output 
of around 10 liters/minute. The rest of valvular function was 
unchanged from the pre-bypass study. The thoracic aorta was 
intact after decannulation.   
   
Echocardiogram: ___
The left atrium is normal in size. The estimated right atrial 
pressure is ___ mmHg. Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity 
size and regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF 
65%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are 
normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal 
with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic 
regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. 
The mitral valve leaflets are myxomatous. A mitral valve 
annuloplasty ring is present. There is systolic anterior motion 
of the mitral valve leaflets but no obvious outflow tract 
obstruction. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The mean 
diastolic pressure gradient (8 mmHg) across the mitral valve is 
higher than normal. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic 
pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion.  

CXR: ___:
There is no pneumothorax.  The small region of opacification at 
the base of the left lung has essentially cleared.  A tiny left 
pleural effusion is 
stable.  Normal postoperative cardiomediastinal silhouette. 
IMPRESSION:  No pneumothorax.  Lungs are clear, with persistent 
tiny left 
pleural effusion. 

Discharge Labs:
___ 08:50AM BLOOD WBC-6.3 RBC-3.46* Hgb-10.5* Hct-30.3* 
MCV-88 MCH-30.5 MCHC-34.8 RDW-13.2 Plt ___
___ 08:50AM BLOOD Glucose-146* UreaN-12 Creat-0.8 Na-135 
K-4.4 Cl-99 HCO3-29 AnGap-11
___ 08:50AM BLOOD Mg-2.2
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ was a same day admit and on ___ he was brought to 
the operating room where he underwent a Minimally-invasive 
mitral valve repair with a #28 mm ___ Future ring. Please see 
operative note for surgical details. Following surgery he was 
transferred to the CVICU for invasive monitoring in stable 
condition. Within several hours he was weaned from sedation, 
awoke neurologically intact and extubated.He briefly required 
pressor support with Neo. He weaned off of Neo and was started 
on low dose Beta-blocker and ASA. Postoperatively he was 
transfused 1 unit of PRBCs for anemia likely secondary to volume 
resuscitation. POD#1 his chest tubes were discontinued. A right 
pneumothorax resulted. The pt then had a pigtail placed and 
there was resolution of the pneumothorax. He transferred to the 
step down unit for further monitoring. The pigtail was placed to 
water seal and a CXR was done. No evidence of pneumothorax. 
POD#3 his pigtail was discontinued without incident. Repeat CXR 
revealed clear lungs. Echocardiogram performed showed no 
pericardial effusion in the setting of hypotension secondary to 
hypovolemia in setting of large diuresis. Physical Therapy was 
consulted for evaluation of strength and mobility. He was 
repeatedly orthostatic while working with physical therapy this 
recovered by the time of discharge on POD 6.By the time of his 
discharge his incisions were healing well and he was ambulating 
without difficulty. He continued to progress and on POD 6 he was 
discharged to home with ___. All follow up appointments were 
advised.

The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.

___

Mitral valve prolapse and regurgitation s/p Minimal invasive

Ambulating with steady gait
Incisional pain managed with oral analgesia
Incisions: 
Sternal - healing well, no erythema or drainage 
Leg Right/Left - healing well, no erythema or drainage.
No Edema

2). Please NO lotions, cream, powder, or ointments to incisions
3). Each morning you should weigh yourself and then in the 
evening take your temperature, these should be written down on 
the chart
4). No driving for approximately one month and while taking 
narcotics, will be discussed at follow up appointment with 
surgeon when you will be able to drive

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
Overnight on POD#0, the patient's blood pressure was low at 
82/38.  She was given a one-liter bolus of fluids.  She was 
given another bolus of 500 mL for continued low blood pressures. 
 Her blood pressure remained stable post-boluses in the systolic 
of 90-100s.

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received lovenox for DVT 
prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The foley was 
removed and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. 
The overlying dressing was removed on POD#2 and the Silverlon 
dressing was found to be clean and dry. The patient was seen 
daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the 
hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity with posterior precautions. 
Walker or two crutches at all times for 6 weeks.

Mrs. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable 
condition.

Right hip pain

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking anticoagulation 
medication.  ___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your Silverlon dressing clean and 
dry. Remove one week after surgery. It is okay to shower five 
days after surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging 
your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. You may 
place a dry sterile dressing on the wound after the Silverlon 
dressing is removed, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound 
regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow 
drainage. Staples will be removed by the visiting nurse or rehab 
facility in two (2) weeks.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after 
surgery.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated with walker or 2 
crutches at all times for six weeks.  Posterior precautions. No 
strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. 
 Mobilize frequently.

Mobilize frequently

daily dressing changes as needed for drainage
wound checks daily
ice

___ with hips)
remove silverlon on ___

Dr. ___

your incision wet day 3 after surgery.  You may shower before 
this time using a shower cap to cover your head.
**Your wound was closed with staples or non-dissolvable 
sutures then you must wait until after they are removed to wash 
your hair. You may shower before this time using a shower cap to 
cover your head.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) & 
Senna while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc.

not require blood work monitoring.

you are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, 
Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach 
irritation.  Make sure to take your steroid medication with 
meals, or a glass of milk. 
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.

at home.

This is a ___ year old woman with no known past medical history 
who presented to the ___ ED with inebriation and vomiting. In 
the ED, given continued emesis, she was intubated for airway 
protection and was transferred to the ICU for further 
management. Per patient history, drank a total of ___ alcoholic

at the bar/after party she attended prior to admission. She did 
not have any overnight events in the ICU and was extubated 
without complication the following day. She was not started on 
any medications. She was encouraged to see her primary care 
physician to continue discussing how she can better manage her 
alcohol use. 

# RESPIRATORY FAILURE, secondary to 
# INABILITY TO PROTECT AIRWAY: patient intubated in ED, after 
observed to have low GCS and emesis, with concern for ability to 
protect airway. Was initially sedated with fentanyl & midazolam 
gtt in the ED. The following morning, Ms. ___ was weaned off 
the ventilator without complications and extubated on ___. 
She maintained SO2 on room air without incident.  

# ALCOHOL INTOXICATION: no other significant lab abnormalities. 
Serum etOH 193. Urine toxicology screen negative for other 
substances, and urine HCG negative. Intubated for airway 
protection in setting of low GCS secondary to severe etOH 
intoxication. Patient does not have a history of chronic alcohol 
use and is not at risk for while draw. Vomited twice after 
extubation but then resolved by afternoon and eating/drinking 
well. Patient was treated with thiamine 500 mg, folate, 
rehydrated with IVF. Discussed risk of binge drinking and 
protecting drinks from potential contamination with other drugs.

placed in the ED, then not blood output upon arrival to the

hemodyranmically stable without pain. Patient received

patient vomited twice, clear vomit without blood or bile.

suspicion for infection. Aspiration pneumonitis possible, given

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 26-year-old female who presented to the emergency department with inebriation and vomiting. She had no known past medical history and was accompanied by a friend who noted they were out at a bar drinking. In the emergency department, she was intubated for airway protection due to her low Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) and emesis. She was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management. Her laboratory results showed normal complete blood count and chemistry, with a serum ethanol level of 193. She was treated with fentanyl and midazolam in the emergency department and was weaned off the ventilator without complications. She was extubated on the following day and maintained oxygen saturation on room air without incident. The patient was diagnosed with alcohol intoxication and was discharged home with no medications. ||endoftext||
