Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- WBAT RLE

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovenox daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

Physical Therapy:
weight bearing as tolerated 
ROMAT 
Treatments Frequency:
dressing changes as needed.

Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service on ___ 
following a diagnostic laparoscopy and pelvic washout after 
presenting with abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. The 
surgery was uncomplicated. Please see the operative report for 
full details. On post-operative day 0, she was noted to have a 
blood pressure in the ___. She received a fluid bolus, which 
helped improved her blood pressure. Her hematocrit was stable 
and her clinical exam was not concerning for bleeding. She 
started on broad spectrum IV antibiotics, 
gentamicin/clindamycin.

antibiotics and had remained afebrile while in the hospital. She 
was transition to oral antibiotics, levofloxacin and flagyl. She 
was tolerating a regular diet, voiding, ambulating and her pain 
was well-controlled on oral medications. She was discharged in 
stable condition with appropriate outpatient follow-up.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You presented with symptoms of fever and right sided abdominal 
pain, and found to have signs of a tubo-ovarian abscess (pelvic 
infection of ovary and fallopian tube) during your procedure. 
You were admitted to the gynecology service after your procedure 
for IV antibiotics for your infection. You have recovered well, 
did not have any further fevers, and the team believes you are 
ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office 
with any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions 
below.

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incisions; no 
scrubbing of incisions. No tub baths for 6 weeks.
* Since you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off 
on their own or be removed during your followup visit.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

Constipation:
* Drink ___ liters of water every day.
* Incorporate 20 to 35 grams of fiber into your daily diet to 
maintain normal bowel function. Examples of high fiber foods 
include:
Whole grain breads, Bran cereal, Prune juice, Fresh fruits and 
vegetables, Dried fruits such as dried apricots and prunes, 
Legumes, Nuts/seeds. 
* Take Colace stool softener ___ times daily.
* Use Dulcolax suppository daily as needed.
* Take Miralax laxative powder daily as needed. 
* Stop constipation medications if you are having loose stools 
or diarrhea.

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

She underwent a diagnostic laparoscopy and pelvic washout, which revealed a tuboovarian abscess and severe endometriosis. She was treated with IV antibiotics and later transitioned to oral antibiotics. The patient's condition improved, and she was discharged home with instructions to take her medications as prescribed, including acetaminophen, docusate sodium, levofloxacin, metronidazole, and oxycodone. She was advised to follow a regular diet, avoid strenuous activity, and not drive while taking narcotics. The patient was also instructed to take a stool softener and to follow up with her doctor as needed. ||endoftext||

IMPRESSION:
1.  There is cirrhosis complicated by portal hypertension as 
evidenced by splenomegaly, multiple esophageal and gastric 
varices and a small to moderate amount of ascites.  There are no 
concerning hepatic lesions.

the previous exam.  Progressive enhancement along the biliary 
trees is likely related to combination of fibrosis and chronic 
cholangitis. 3.  Sludge/choledocholithiasis in the distal common 
bile duct.

5.  Marrow edema in the ascending colon is nonspecific and may 
be related to portal colopathy or inflammation.  Clinical 
correlation is recommended.

been advanced, now terminating within the proximal right atrium.

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 53-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and fever. She has a history of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), cirrhosis, ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, varices, and possibly Crohn's disease and celiac disease. She was diagnosed with cholangitis during a previous hospitalization and was treated with IV antibiotics. She has also had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and liver biopsy, which showed bile ductular proliferation and early, incomplete nodule formation.

The patient's allergies include Bactrim, Ampicillin, Sulfa, cefuroxime, Gadolinium-Containing Contrast Media, gluten, nadolol, and Pneumovax 23. She has a history of hypertension, GERD, hypothyroidism, and OSA.

During her hospitalization, the patient's symptoms included abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. She was treated with ertapenem and Zofran, and her nausea improved with the latter. Her laboratory results showed slightly elevated liver enzymes, but her chemistry panel and urinalysis were normal.

The patient underwent an ERCP procedure, which showed no dominant stricture in the CBD or CHD, but did show marked narrowing of the right and left common hepatic ducts consistent with known PSC. She also underwent an MRCP procedure, which showed cirrhosis complicated by portal hypertension, splenomegaly, and multiple esophageal and gastric varices.

At discharge, the patient was prescribed medications including ertapenem and Zofran, and was advised to follow up with her primary care physician. ||endoftext||

Mr. ___ is a ___ right-handed man with past medical

with

full body radiation in ___ and a bone marrow transplant in ___
followed by another round of radiation.  He then developed
squamous cell carcinoma of the left mandible requiring modified
radical neck dissection with resection of the left posterior
mandible followed by a third radiation treatment.  He presented
to neurology clinic last week after CT earlier this year showed
evidence of a frontal stroke.  

Earlier today, Mr ___ called the clinic to report several
concerning episodes over the weekend. On ___, around noon 
he
had 30- 60min of right hand numbness. He has had this sensation
before (maybe ~6x in his life). Occasionally, it has been
associated with weakness where he is unable to keep the hand
lifted up. This time, it was associated with numbness of all the
fingers as well as the palm but no weakness. He also reports a
frontal headache around this time that he treated with Tylenol.
At 3pm, he developed dysarthric speech. He knew what he wanted 
to
say but the words coming out did not sound like the words he was
trying to say. His wife was unable to understand what he was
trying to say until he repeated it several times. This 
completely
resolved within an hour. It was not associated with any other
weakness, numbness, visual problems, or vertigo. Yesterday, he
had a additional episode of right hand numbness (no weakness)
lasting ___ minutes. He reports that he is currently back to
his baseline. He denies any recent illnesses, infections,
intoxications that could explain his symptoms.  He had a full
stoke workup ordered as an outpatient (scheduled to get MRI/MRA
head and neck, carotid ultrasounds next ___, a week from
today) but because of these recent episodes, he was instructed 
to
come to the ED for admission and expedited workup. 

The patient had a long and complicated medical history since his
diagnosis of Hodgkin's when he was ___ most significant for bone
marrow transplant and whole body radiation x 3.   mmediately
after the bone marrow transplant, secondary to immunosuppression
medications, he developed chronic kidney disease. This 
progressed
into fulminant renal failure earlier this year (the exact cause
unknown) requiring the placement of a peritoneal dialysis
catheter in ___.  During the time of his kidney
failure, he developed severe generalized sharp headaches focused
behind his eyes that would last approximately four hours a day
but were relatively well treated with Tylenol and Percocet. 
Those
headaches have since resolved as his metabolic and electrolyte
disturbances have normalized with the use of the PD catheter. 
Earlier this year, in order to workup the severe headaches, he
underwent a CT scan which showed a hypodensity in the left
frontal region. On further questioning, he remembers having a
facial droop in ___ that lasted about a month. In addition, he
and his wife describe an episode of an abnormal heart rhythm
during his hospitalization in ___ as SVT) which was
associated with negative CE and unchanged EKG. During that
hospitalization, he had CT Head which did not show the lesion
leading us to believe that it occurred some time in the last
___ years although we are unable to determine a more exact
date.  He comes to clinic today for recommendations for further
workup of this finding as well as secondary prevention
recommendations.

Review of Systems:  Positive for headaches earlier this year
which have almost entirely resolved, generalized numbness and
weakness which has since resolved; chronic muscle cramps; easy
fatigability; vertigo/nausea with any abrupt changes in his PD
catheter which has since resolved; chronic speaking and
swallowing difficulties related to his radical neck dissection;
chronic insomnia; difficulty with maintaining his weight since
his initial diagnosis.  He denies loss of vision, blurred 
vision,
diplopia, hearing difficulty.  He reports difficulty of gait
secondary to his gout. 

On general review of systems, he denies recent fever or chills. 
No night sweats.  Denies cough, shortness of breath, chest pain,
tightness, palpitations.  Had intermittent nausea and vomiting
with his headaches and when his PD catheter malfunctions, but
otherwise this seems to have resolved.  Chronic myalgias since
his bone marrow transplant.

Discharge Diagnosis:
 ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

You were hospitalized due to symptoms of right hand numbness, 
difficulty speaking, and headache resulting from an ACUTE 
ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition where a blood vessel providing 
oxygen and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. The 
brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all the 
other parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being 
deprived of its blood supply can result in a variety of 
symptoms. 

We incidentally found aneurysms in your MCAs which should be 
evaluated by Neurosurgery in outpatient clinic. Please call 
tomorrow to make an appointment in their clinic.
 
Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:  
History of Radiation and Cancer 
High Cholesterol 
High Blood pressure 

We are changing your medications as follows:  
1. START Aspirin 81mg daily 
2. START Atorvastatin 10mg at bedtime  
3. START Amlodipine 5 mg daily 

Please take your other medications as prescribed.  
Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below.  

If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  
- sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
- sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
- sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
- sudden weakness of one side of the body  
- sudden drooping of one side of the face  
- sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body  

Sincerely, 
Your ___ Neurology Team 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

# Nausea
# NB-NB Vomiting
# NB Diarrhea
Patient reported acute onset nausea, vomiting, diarrhea 
concerning for viral gastroenteritis. He was thought to be high 
risk of norovirus given immunosuppressed state and time of year. 
His abdominal examination was nonsurgical and his emesis was 
nonbloody which was reassuring. Patient reported that he was 
currently tolerating sips on admission but exam and lab findings 
showed evidence of dehydration and the patient received 3 L of 
IV fluid. His lipase was found to be normal. Several stool 
studies including C. difficile, neurovirus, stool culture, CMV, 
and CMV viral load were sent given patient's immunocompromised 
state and history of CMV colitis in the past. He was given 
ondansetron as needed for nausea. A right upper quadrant 
ultrasound was reassuring and did not show any new abnormal 
findings. Nutrition was consulted to help provide appropriate 
recommendations. The patient was placed on contact and GI 
precautions and his labs are monitored closely. His home 
medications were continued except his loperamide and tincture of 
opium were held due to concern of infection with plans to 
restart if his cultures were negative. Overall, his diarrhea 
returned to baseline ___ bowel movements daily and he was able 
to tolerate PO intake.

# ___ on CKD
On admission, patients Cr was 1.5, above reported baseline in 
recent hepatology notes at 1.1. However, all creatinine values 
in OMR from the last year ranged between 1.52. His kidney 
function was closely monitored with daily labs.

# Influenza B positive
Patient was noted to be influenza B positive in the emergency 
department. He reported no respiratory symptoms. Given his 
immunosuppressed state, he was started on treatment with a 10 
day course of Tamiflu (___), at a renally dosed 30mg BID 
with plans to escalate dose if renal function improved.

# H/o EtOH cirrhosis s/p OLT ___
On presentation, patient's LFTs were found to be at baseline. He 
also reported being compliant with medications. He was continued 
on mycophenolate mofetil 500 mg twice daily and prednisone 5 mg 
daily.

# Chronic diarrhea
On presentation, the patient patient reported approximately 10 
bowel movements daily daily for the past 2 days, above his 
preadmission baseline. An infection workup was undertaken as 
described above and his home loperamide and opium tincture were 
held due to concern of infection until cultures were negative.

# Chronic back pain
He was continued on home lidocaine patch, oxycontin, and 
hydromorphone.

# Malnutrition
The patient was followed by transplant nutrition on an 
outpatient basis. He was currently G-tube dependent for 
supplemental food. On admission, and nutrition was consulted to 
provide further recommendations while the patient was admitted. 
Initially, tube feeds were not started through his G-tube as the 
patient is very nauseous and was thought to not tolerate any 
type of supplemental feeding. He was started as an sips with 
instructions to advance diet as tolerated. His nutrition needs 
were reassessed daily.

peripheral edema, and dyspnea on exertion concerning for volume 
overload. Dry weight: 144lbs, up to 158lbs on admission. This 
was likely precipitated by dietary indiscretion, but cannot 
exclude valvular heart disease, tachyarrythmia, or MI given

and hydralazine, which was increased to 20 mg TID. No ACE

torsemide 10 mg daily. EP was consulted for up grade to CRT 
given ___ class III symptoms, conduction delay on EKG, and 
multiple HF admissions. CRT upgrade was done on ___.

(Keflex TID on discharge) on ___.

chest pain to suggest ischemic etiology due to heart failure

setting of acute HF exacerbation. Continued on ASA 81 and 
atorvastatin 80.

Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ because you were gaining 
weight and having shortness of breath. This was most likely from 
your heart failure, which can cause fluid to back up into your 
lungs and legs.

While you were here, we gave you IV Lasix to help remove the 
fluid in your lungs and legs. You also had an upgrade to your 
pacemaker to help your heart chambers pump at the same time.

When you go home, please weigh yourself every morning, and call 
your doctor if weight goes up more than 3 lbs. Your medications 
and appointments are below.

health.

He has a history of dilated non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 15%, single-vessel coronary artery disease, severe functional mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, insulin-dependent diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and peripheral artery disease. He has allergies to oxycodone and has had previous admissions for symptomatic hypotension and diarrhea. During his current admission, he underwent a cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) upgrade from a dual chamber to BiV ICD. He was prescribed medications at discharge, including torsemide and imdur. ||endoftext||

Mucosa:Normal mucosa was noted throughout the rectum and

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with a history of HCV/EtOH 
cirrhosis (decompensated by HE, varices (grade 1 varices x 2 on 
EGD ___, who presents with abdominal pain and CTA abdomen 
showing colitis.  MELD 14, DF 29. 

ACUTE ISSUES
============
# Abdominal Pain: Patient presented with right upper quadrant 
abdominal pain.  CTA abdomen did not show any obstruction or 
mesenteric ischemia. Concern for infectious colitis given 
location in R colon, nausea and vomiting however she denied any 
diarrhea. Initially started on ciprofloxacin and flagyl however 
these were discontinued.  Her  abdominal ultrasound does not 
show any ascites, biliary obstruction, or hepatic clots. No 
signs of acute abdomen on physical exam. Alcoholic hepatitis was 
possible given elevated AST>ALT and elevated bilirubin compared 
to prior admission. Her discriminate function 29 as of ___. 
Patient reports drinking recently as of ___. However no 
other signs of alcoholic hepatitis. Steroids were not needed 
given her discriminate function. The patient also has a history 
of marijuana use and cyclical vomiting syndrome was also on the 
differential. No antibiotics were given. The patient started to 
have nausea, vomiting and loose stools during her hospital stay. 
Stool cultures were sent. The patient underwent flex 
sigmoidoscopy   for concern of guaiac positive stool with 
history of hemorrhoids and polyps. However there was no evidence 
of colitis on the sigmoidoscopy. Her pain improved during the 
hospital stay with morphine and nausea controlled with zofran. 
She went a full infectious work up that showed no other cause. 
She started to tolerate PO well. It is likely that she was 
likely suffering from gastroenteritis. 

# Somnolence: Patient was found to be somnolent on admission to 
the floor. This was likely a combination to the IV morphine and 
her acute illness. She was responsive when woken up and did 
answer questions. Her pain medications were held and continued 
on home lactulose and rifaximin. Her mental status improved 
during her hospital stay and was back to baseline on discharge. 

# Sinus tachycardia: Patient was tachycardic into the 100s on 
admission and continued to remain tachycardic during her 
hospital stay. It was likely secondary to dehydration in setting 
of several episodes of vomiting and no oral intake. Patient has 
no other signs of alcohol withdrawal at this point. However she 
was started on a CIWA protocol which she scored for and then 
resolved prior to discharge.  Her pain was well controlled 
throughout the hospital stay. 
 
# History  of alcohol abuse: patient states her last alcoholic 
beverage was on ___. See above for CIWA. She was 
continued on  folate, thiamine, multivitamin and given ativan 
PRN withdrawal symptoms.  

# Alcoholic/HCV cirrhosis: complicated by ascites, 
encephalopathy (multiple admissions this year for confusion), 2 
grade 1 varices on EGD ___ and portal hypertensive 
gastropathy. HCV genotype 1, reports last drink to be ___. MELD 
16 on admission which is stable from prior admission. Last 
colonoscopy ___ with adenomatous polyps on biopsy, no 
stigmata of bleeding, otherwise normal.  However patient had 
guiac positive stool in setting of polyps so she underwent a 
sigmoidoscopy which showed hemorrhoids. She was continued on 
lactulose and rifaxamin. Her spironolactone was held due to 
hypovolemia during hospital stay and restarted prior to 
discharge. 
 
CHRONIC ISSUES
==============
#Thrombocytopenia: At baseline. Likely related to liver disease 
and alcohol use. No overt signs/symptoms of bleeding at this 
time.  

# Leukopenia: has chronic leukopenia from bone marrow 
suppression from alcohol abuse, WBC on this admission lower than 
previous which may be secondary to infectious process or thought 
to be dilutional .  

# Type 2 diabetes: not on home insulin, started on sliding 
scale, not discharged on insulin. 

# Depression: continued on home medications as per PACT team 
recs

TRANSLATIONAL ISSUES:
- follow up CBC as patient had pancytopenia that was likely 
dilutional

Mr. ___, 

WHY WERE YOU IN THE HOSPITAL?
- You were admitted to the hospital because you were having 
trouble breathing and were found to have pneumonia.
- Your labs showed that your creatinine, a number we look at to 
measure kidney function, was high. This means that your kidneys 
were damaged. 
- Your labs showed that your hemoglobin, a number we look at to 
measure your blood count, was low.
- We found that you had blood in your stool, which worried us 
about a source of bleeding in your intestines.  

WHAT WAS DONE FOR YOU WHILE YOU WERE HERE?
- We treated your pneumonia with antibiotics given through your 
vein
- We treated your kidney damage with fluids given through your 
vein
- We consulted the GI doctors, who used a camera to look into 
your stomach to try and find the source of your bleeding. There 
was no bleeding in your esophagus or stomach. The GI doctors 
believed the source of your bleeding was probably in your colon. 

- We gave you a dose of your water pill through your vein to 
help improve the swelling in your legs

- You should follow up with the GI doctors for ___

repeat chest X-ray in the next ___ weeks. 

It was a pleasure taking care of you.

Your ___ Team

The patient's diagnosis includes pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and anemia. He underwent an EGD procedure and was found to have inflammatory colonic polyps, which were believed to be the source of his bleeding.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, including vancomycin, cefepime, and azithromycin for a 7-day course, as well as apixaban for anticoagulation therapy.

The patient's vital signs were stable at discharge, with a temperature of 98.4°F, blood pressure of 138/79 mmHg, heart rate of 189 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%. His physical examination was notable for mild decreased airflow in bilateral bases, and trace pitting edema in his legs. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 41-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with dyspnea, hemoptysis, and abdominal pain. She has a history of morbid obesity, lymphedema, asthma, hypertension, chronic lymphedema, and a prior ectopic pregnancy. She was recently hospitalized for LLE cellulitis and pneumonia and was taking iron supplements. On admission, her vital signs were notable for a temperature of 97.4°F, blood pressure of 169/81 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100% on 4L NC. Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 9.6, hemoglobin of 7.4, and D-dimer of 1838. Chest X-ray showed worsening right middle lobe and right lower lobe infiltrate, left pleural effusion, and concern for Wegener's granulomatosis. She underwent a PICC placement, endotracheal intubation, and arterial line placement. She was treated with duonebs, lasix, vanc/cefepme/azithro, and received antibiotics for a pseudomonas aeruginosa infection. At discharge, her vital signs were stable, and she was prescribed medications including lasix, vanc/cefepme/azithro, and antibiotics for her infection. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 56-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with suspected NASH cirrhosis decompensated by ascites and EV, recent episode of gallstone pancreatitis, and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and cirrhosis of unknown etiology. She was referred to the emergency department from the liver clinic after her labs returned with creatinine 1.5 and was deemed not to be in need of a liver transplant due to a low MELD score. She was treated with IV ceftriaxone for SBP and IV albumin to improve abdominal distention. Her peritoneal and blood cultures were without growth to date. At discharge, she was prescribed ciprofloxacin for SBP prophylaxis and will follow up in liver clinic at the end of the month. ||endoftext||

He was readmitted due to a likely recurrence of his colon cancer and was found to have diffuse cancer in the abdomen. The surgery was aborted due to the extent of the cancer.

The patient's past medical history includes rosacea, hypertension, and colon cancer. He has no known allergies or adverse reactions.

The patient's diagnosis is unresectable metastatic colon cancer. He underwent exploratory laparotomy, but the surgery was aborted due to the extent of the cancer.

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, doxycycline, magnesium oxide, oxycodone, scopolamine, and Zofran. He was also advised to follow up with his primary care physician and surgeon.

The patient was discharged home in a stable condition, with clear and coherent mental status, alert and interactive level of consciousness, and ambulatory status. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
On evening of admission, prior fem-fem cutdown site was probed 
by Fellow, who was easily able to palpate the graft. The 
following day, a wound vac was placed on this site. Pt's ray 
incision was packed with iodoform. A LLE ultrasound was obtained 
to evaluate pt's asymmetrical edema and was negative for DVT.   
Pt was seen by her outpt Cardiologist, who recommended a family 
meeting and palliative care consult should pt require a major 
operation. 
On HD 4, a CTA was obtained and demonstrated decreased fluid 
around the graft and an open bypass graft with flow to the foot. 
That night, she tripped on her vac and began to complain of L 
leg pain. 
The following day, pt continued to complain of L leg pain as 
well as SOB. She spiked another fever. Bcx was again sent and a 
CXR demonstrated diffuse interstital edema and small pleural 
effusions. The next day, pt's SOB resolved but her L leg pain 
persisted. Another LLE US found no DVT and a knee x-ray did not 
demonstrate any acute findings. During a vac change, fluid was 
sent and grew E.coli. 
The next day, HD 7, pt's leg pain persisted. Pain meds were 
increased. X-rays from the pelvis down were obtained; they 
showed osteopenia but no fractures or dislocations. A blister 
was noted of the dorsum of her left foot and her antibiotics 
were changed to vancomycin and zosyn (from vanc/cipro/flagyl) to 
better cover streptococcus. The following day the pt's leg pain 
was somewhat improved but the blister on her foot had enlarged. 
A CT scan was obtained and showed edema but no air or abscesses. 

On HD 9, pt's LUE AV graft was unable to be accessed at HD. The 
following day, Interventional Radiology performed a successful 
thrombectomy and venoplasty. On HD 10, a foot XRay was taken, 
which demonstrate a non-displaced ___ metatarsal fracture. 
Podiatry was consulted and recommended no intervention and 
heel-touch only weight bearing status in the left side. The do 
not believe the left foot blister and residual wound is related. 
On HD ___, antibiotic coverage was adjusted to allow for dosing 
only with dialysis, for ease of administration outside the 
hospital. On HD ___ arrangements were made for the patient to be 
discharged to rehab. At the time of discharge, her pain was 
controlled, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding and 
moving her bowels spontaneously. She was sitting up in a chair 
for the large part of the day, but was not yet moving around on 
her own. She should continue physical therapy in rehab to work 
on regaining her mobility.

IMPRESSION:

contrast is seen in the ascending colon and there is air and 
stool in the colon more distally, more suggestive of mild ileus 
rather than bowel obstruction. 
2. Lack of wall to wall filling with oral contrast of the distal 
small bowel and resultant apparent wall thickening is likely due 
to mixing artifact.

of cholelithiasis or choledocholithiasis.  Pneumobilia and mild 
intrahepatic biliary dilation are again seen, consistent with 
prior sphincterotomy.

5. 1.1 cm right renal hypodensity is unchanged.  Continued 
attention is recommended on future exams.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old male with past medical history of diabetes 
type 2 uncontrolled complicated by neuropathy, Crohn's disease 
s/p ileocecectomy and multiple laparotomies for SBO, chronic 
diarrhea and recurrent pseudo-obstructions prompting venting 
G-Jtube, admitted ___ w diarrhea and abdominal distention 
thought to represent partial small bowel obstruction, with long 
hospital course course notable for intermittent intolerance of 
tube feeds, subsequently requiring initiation of TPN after long 
discussions with patient and GI service, now tolerating well, 
having regular bowel movements without signs of obstruction or 
diarrhea, discharged home with TPN; 

ACTIVE ISSUES
# Intermittent Small Bowel Obstructions / Diarrhea / Abdominal 
pain / Crohn's Disease / Small Intestine Bacterial Overgrowth - 
On presentation, the patient had acutely worsened diffuse 
chronic abdominal pain on presentation. Subsequent workup 
supported multifactorial causes including likely intermittent 
partial small bowel obstructions, osmotic diarrhea from dietary 
indiscretions (eating lots of starburst candies) and Crohn's 
disease.  Initial concern was for SBO. He had a CT with PO and 
IV contrast that showed mild ileus. However, there was some 
thickening of the bowel wall that initially raised concern for 
Crohn's flare (on subsequent revised read, the thickening was 
deemed artifact). Subsequently, he had a colonoscopy that showed 
ulceration at his colonic-colonic anastomosis with biopsies 
showing terminal ileum inflammation. Given that the results were 
suggestive of Crohn's, the patient was started on budesonide 9mg 
PO daily. Furthermore, in working up his diarrhea, which 
improved with no oral intake, he was found to have a stool Osm 
gap of 357-2*(70+24.3) = 168, which suggested an osmotic 
diarrhea. When tube feed was initiated (see below), his diarrhea 
worsened to over 10 times overnight. Eventually, given that he 
had a borderline SIBO breath test in the past, he was started on 
rifaximin empirically for SIBO treatment. When he started TPN 
(see below), his diarrhea improved to 4 BMs per day.

# Acute Protein Calorie Malnutrition - Patient with > 20lb weigh 
loss over last 6 months.  He had intermittent symptoms as above, 
but failed trials of starting on tube feed on 4 separate 
attempts due to abdominal pain, distension and diarrhea.  He was 
tried on several formulations without improvement. Patient 
educated on risks/benefits of TPN.  Ultimately, he was started 
on TPN via R PICC access. He will eventually need consideration 
for a Port-A-Cath if he is to continue TPN long term--given the 
uncertainty about how long he would require TPN, port not placed 
this admission.  He tolerated TPN well with no electrolyte 
abnormalities and signs of refeeding syndrome. He was giving 
thiamine intermittently throughout his hospitalization with 
tubefeed and TPN. 

# Dysphagia | Esophageal Spasm - The patient reported 
significant swallowing issues during his stay and refused to 
take in POs, including pills. He had a barium swallow study that 
showed findings consistent with diffuse esophageal spasm. GI 
consult team wanted to follow up with manometry testing as 
outpatient before starting therapy. Fortunately, his symptoms 
improved during the course of his stay, and he requested 
trialing PO food and was able to tolerate small amount of POs on 
discharge.

# Chronic Back Pain | Chronic Abdominal Pain - Due to NPO 
status, he was given IV hydromorphone in place of his PO regimen 
at home for the most part of his stay. The patient requested on 
multiple occasions to speak with the Pain specialists here. The 
Pain Consult team saw the patient and recommended uptitration of 
gabapentin to 900mg TID for chronic pain and maintaining his 
home narcotics regimen. The team discussed with the patient that 
his abdominal pain can possibly be attributed to his high 
narcotics requirement leading to narcotics bowel syndrome. The 
patient was very reluctant to the idea of decreasing his pain 
medications, stating that without them, he cannot have a normal 
life and wants to have a life. He was discharged on his home 
regimen, but with the understanding that if abdominal symptoms 
should recur or persist, he may need to consider downtitration 
of opiates. He reported needing more hydromorphone despite 
having filled a recent prescription for a 1 month supply only 2 
weeks prior to admission.

CHRONIC ISSUES
# Hypertension: The patient's BPs had been well controlled 
throughout his admission up until the last part of his stay, 
when he had elevated BPs to 180s at times. His home labetalol 
regimen was uptitrated to 400mg TID from 300mg TID. It's 
possible this is due to switching from IV hydromorphone to PO.

# COPD: No symptoms while hospitalized. He continued home 
inhaler regimen. 

# Diabetes Mellitus: Complicated by neuropathy. Patient endorsed 
neuropathic pain in his feet. He continue home Gabapentin liquid 
as tolerated.

# Coronary Artery Disease: He had no symptoms. He continued ASA 
and labetalol. Lisinopril was DC'ed as outpatient due to labile 
blood pressures.
  
# Anxiety/Depression: The patient's overall mood was stable but 
he became tearful at times when discussing his chronic illness. 
He continue home lorazepam, buproprion, and buspirone.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
- TPN: Will need ongoing evaluation of his nutritional 
requirement.
- Access: Patient currently has a PICC for TPN administration. 
If he will be on TPN for a long time, please consider placing a 
Port for longer term access.
- Antibiotics: Will need to continue taking rafaximin 550mg PO 
TID for 7 days, until ___.
- Pain: Patient has been having ongoing issues with abdominal 
pain. His gabapentin was uptitrated to 900mg TID per the 
recommendations of Pain consult team.
- Hypertension: Patient's BP was low earlier during stay but 
became elevated towards the end (160s), likely due to no longer 
receiving IV pain medication. His labetalol was uptitrated to 
400mg TID. Please consider another antihypertensive agent since 
his heart rate is only ___ at discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ after having increasing difficulty 
with maintaining nutrition at home and increasing abdominal 
pain. We performed a CT scan that ruled out a small bowel 
obstruction. We performed a colonoscopy that showed inflammation 
at your anastamosis site, for which we are treating you with 
budesonide, an oral steroid. Furthermore, for your difficulty 
swallowing, we found some signs of esophageal dysmotility on a 
barium study. Fortunately, your symptoms improved without any 
intervention.

Despite our best attempts to start nutrition with tube feed, we 
were unsuccessful. Therefore, we eventually decided to start 
total parenteral nutrition, which you will need to continue on 
until you are able to better tolerate eating by mouth. Last, we 
tried to optimize your diarrhea by trialing you on an 
antibiotics to treat bacteria overgrowth in the small bowel.

Your blood pressure was elevated towards the end of your 
hospitalization. We increased your home dose of labetalol, and 
you will need to follow up with Dr. ___ further 
titration.

Please check your finger sticks at home so that we can monitor 
your glucose level and determine whether you need insulin in 
your TPN.

It was a pleasure to take care of you. We wish you the best!

Sincerely,

Your ___ Care Team

||startoftext|| The patient is a 58-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of weight loss. He has a history of Crohn's disease, multiple laparotomies, and short gut syndrome, which has led to complications such as intermittent small bowel obstruction and dependence on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). He also has a history of chronic abdominal pain, depression, and anxiety. On admission, his physical examination revealed a diffusely tender abdomen with mild rebound tenderness, and his laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, neutrophil count, and C-reactive protein. He was diagnosed with a possible small bowel obstruction and was treated with nebulizer therapy and oral steroids. At discharge, his vital signs were stable, and his physical examination revealed a mild firmness and diffusely tender abdomen. His laboratory results showed improvement in his white blood cell count and C-reactive protein, but his albumin and calcium levels remained low. He was prescribed medications for his chronic pain and was advised to follow up with his primary care physician.

Note: The patient's allergies and adverse reactions are listed as codeine and penicillins. ||endoftext||

text:
age: 40. gender: F.  
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
latex
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Right renal mass
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Robotic right partial nephrectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
I had the pleasure of seeing your patient, Ms. ___
here at ___ today at the request of my
colleague in urology, Dr. ___ in consultation
regarding her small right renal mass.  As you know, Ms. ___ 
is
a ___ woman who is an active smoker, who had a renal 
mass
that was discovered in ___, at which time it showed a 1.1 x 1.2
x 1 cm lesion in the upper pole of the right kidney that was
endophytic in nature.

A followup MRI in ___ showed that the lesion was 1.3 
cm
in size and had low-grade enhancement and it was consistent with
papillary renal cell carcinoma with a possibility of lipid poor
angiomyolipoma and oncocytoma as well.

Followup renal ultrasound showed that the nodule in the upper
pole seems a little bit larger, so followup MRI was performed 
and
this was done on ___, which showed growth of this
lesion, currently measuring 1.5 x 1.3 x 1.4 cm.  Differential
diagnosis was a papillary renal cell carcinoma, once again, with
lipid-poor AML and oncocytic neoplasms also on the differential
diagnosis.  Also noted was an accessory right renal artery.  She
is asymptomatic.  12-point ROS was completely negative.  

She presents for further discussions regarding this mass that
appears to be growing.  I explained that there is probably a
70-80% chance that this mass is malignant.  However, renal 
masses
that are less than 3 cm are very unlikely to metastasize and
research has shown that it is safe to follow up on using active
surveillance.  However, a few cavities in her case make active
surveillance a little bit less ideal.  First, she is young and
given the gross weight of this mass, I have no doubts that over
the period of her lifetime, it will grow to the size where we
will need to remove it or treat it.  Second, it is completely
endophytic and therefore, further growth may make it more
difficult to treat in the future.  I, therefore, recommended 
that
she consider treatment of the right renal mass.

We discussed options for treatment, first being a right partial
nephrectomy, which has the highest chance of success, more than
98%.  The other options include cryoablation of the mass, which
would be less invasive, but has a lower success rate in the
80-90% range, as well as CyberKnife radiotherapy, which has been
new and promising treatment for these renal masses, but has a
shorter track record, as it is newer.  There appears to be quite
promising and I did offer that option as well.

I explained that the risks of partial nephrectomy were infection
and bleeding as well as possible need for an open procedure
(10%), as well as the possible need for radical nephrectomy
(___).  This should be done through a minimally invasive
robotic technique, which will hopefully minimize her scars, as
well as abdominal pain.  I would expect that she will still need
to take at least three to four weeks off work, however, as our
studies have shown that more than half of patients takes greater
than 30 days off work after this procedure.

She would like to think further about her options and is
definitely considering a more minimally invasive approach to 
this
tumor, even though she understands that the success rate may be
slightly lower.  She will speak to her husband, and I have
encouraged her to also speak to Dr. ___.  If she is
to undergo surgery, she would like to undergo this in ___,
when her work is less busy.  I think this is completely
reasonable and I would like to obtain repeat imaging before that
so that we have more recent imaging and there were no surprises
in the operating room.  She will be in contact with us and/or 
Dr.
___ her decisions going forward, and I am happy to
provide assistance in any way possible.

Thank you very much for allowing me to participate in her care,
please feel free to contact me with any questions or concerns 
you
may have.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: Small bilateral renal stones that passed
with medical management. She also has arrhythmia that she didn't
know the details of but said further workup was negative. 

PSH:  C-section x 2.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No history of GU malignancy.

 
Physical Exam:
NAD
WWP
No respiratory distress
Abdomen soft, appropriately tender, non-distended, incisions 
c/d/i
No focal deficits
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:15AM BLOOD Glucose-92 UreaN-7 Creat-0.6 Na-141 K-4.1 
Cl-109* HCO3-27 AnGap-9
___ 07:40AM BLOOD WBC-13.5* RBC-3.48* Hgb-11.3* Hct-33.0* 
MCV-95 MCH-32.4* MCHC-34.2 RDW-12.7 Plt ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Urology after undergoing laparoscopic 
right partial
nephrectomy. No concerning intraoperative events occurred; 
please see dictated operative note for details. The patient 
received perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis. The patient was 
transferred to the floor from the PACU in stable condition. On 
POD0, pain was well controlled on PCA, hydrated for urine output 
>30cc/hour, and provided with pneumoboots and incentive 
spirometry for prophylaxis. On POD1, the patient ambulated, 
restarted on home medications, basic metabolic panel and 
complete blood count were checked, pain control was transitioned 
from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was advanced to a clears/toast 
and crackers diet. On POD2, foley catheter was removed and 
subsequently JP was removed after the output remained low. Diet 
was advanced as tolerated. The remainder of the hospital course 
was relatively unremarkable. The patient was discharged on POD3 
in stable condition, eating well, ambulating independently, 
voiding without difficulty, and with pain control on oral 
analgesics. On exam, incision was clean, dry, and intact, with 
no evidence of hematoma collection or infection. The patient was 
given explicit instructions to follow-up in clinic in 
approximately four weeks time.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Meclizine 25 mg PO TID 
2. Ibuprofen 400 mg PO ONCE 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ibuprofen 400 mg PO Q8H 
2. Meclizine 25 mg PO TID:PRN dizziness 
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
4. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN pain 


 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right renal mass

 
Discharge Condition:
Alert and oriented
Ambulating
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Please also refer to the provided written instructions on 
post-operative care, instructions and expectations made 
available from Dr. ___.

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications except as noted. 
ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes 
and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor.

-___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision 
sites; remember to log roll onto your side and then use your 
hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the 
momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground.

--There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have 
been applied to reinforce wound closure.  Allow these bandage 
strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY 
REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may 
get the steristrips wet.

-Please AVOID aspirin or aspirin containing products and 
supplements that may have blood-thinning effects (like Fish 
Oil, Vitamin E, etc.) unless you have otherwise been advised.

-IBUPROFEN (the ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be taken 
even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You 
may alternate these medications for pain control.  For pain 
control, try TYLENOL FIRST, then ibuprofen, and then take the 
narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain relief 
is needed.

-Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue 
taking and notify your
doctor should you develop blood in your stool (dark, tarry 
stools)

-Call your Urologist's office to schedule/confirm your follow-up 
appointment in 4 weeks
AND if you have any questions.

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely 
walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a 
couch potato

-Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic 
pain medication has been
prescribed for breakthrough pain ___. REPLACE the Tylenol with 
this narcotic pain medication if additional pain control is 
needed..

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up

-You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or 
bathe

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to
narcotic pain medication. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea 
develops. Colace is a
stool-softener, NOT a laxative

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.

She has a history of small bilateral renal stones and arrhythmia, which was further workup negative. She also has a history of C-sections. The patient is an active smoker and has no history of GU malignancy in her family. 

The patient's presenting symptoms were a right renal mass, which was discovered in the past and has been growing over time. The mass was initially thought to be a papillary renal cell carcinoma, but further imaging showed it to be a possible lipid-poor angiomyolipoma or oncocytoma. The patient was asymptomatic and had a 12-point ROS that was completely negative. 

The patient underwent a robotic right partial nephrectomy, which was successful. She received perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis and was transferred to the floor in stable condition. The patient's hospital course was unremarkable, and she was discharged on POD3 in stable condition. 

The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including ibuprofen, meclizine, docusate sodium, and hydrocodone-acetaminophen. She was instructed to follow up in clinic in approximately four weeks and to resume her pre-admission medications except as noted. ||endoftext||

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 56-year-old male with a chief complaint of peritonitis. He has a history of cirrhosis, thought to be secondary to hepatitis, and has been on the transplant list. He also has a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and thrombocytopenia. He was admitted to the hospital with vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal distension, and was diagnosed with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and treated with ceftriaxone. His hospital course was complicated by refractory ascites and suspected hepatorenal syndrome (HRS). He underwent an exploratory laparotomy and paracentesis, and was continued on ceftriaxone, albumin, midodrine, and octreotide. At discharge, he was afebrile and hemodynamically stable, but with poor renal function.

The patient's allergies include erythromycin base, Bactrim, and lisinopril. His medications at discharge include ceftriaxone, albumin, midodrine, and octreotide.

The patient's physical exam was notable for a distended abdomen, and his laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, hyperglycemia, and anemia. His urinalysis showed proteinuria and hematuria. His ascites fluid culture grew Enterococcus faecium, which was sensitive to daptomycin, linezolid, and caspofungin. His fungal culture grew Candida albicans, which was susceptible to fluconazole and caspofungin. ||endoftext||

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L frontal AVM

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Surgery
 You underwent surgery to remove a L frontal AVM from your 
brain.

You may shower at this time but keep your incision dry.
It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Care of the Puncture Site
You will have a small bandage over the site.
Remove the bandage in 24 hours by soaking it with water and 
gently peeling it off.
Keep the site clean with soap and water and dry it carefully.
You may use a band-aid if you wish.

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
You may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
Feeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
Nausea and/or vomiting
Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
Seizures
Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

 
Followup Instructions:
___

The patient was advised to follow up with his neurosurgeon and to avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise until his follow-up appointment. History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ man with a PMH significant for 
polycystic kidney disease who presents with slurred speech, 
headache, and tingling and loss of sensation in his right leg. 
The following history is obtained from the patient, his 
girlfriend, and younger brother.

Mr. ___ was in his normal state of health until about 4 weeks 
ago when he developed a mild headache and intermittent joint 
pains in his ankles and wrist, worse on the right side. He 
presented to his PCP who prescribed ___ and Naproxen for 
sinusitis/inflammation appreciated on ear exam. He reports 
persistent HA over the subsequent 2 weeks. 

On ___, per reports of his girlfriend, who witnessed the 
event, he was driving and speaking on the phone, when all of a 
sudden he hung up the phone and began "seizing". He was observed 
to be foaming at the mouth and his extremities were at first 
very stiff and completely extended, such that his feet were 
pressed down very hard on the gas pedals, and then he began 
flailing with both his arms and legs. His eyes were rolled back 
into his head and he turned his head to the right, and he was 
not responding to any verbal stimuli. The entire event lasted 
for about 20 minutes. After the seizure ended, he regained 
consciousness and was crying in pain because of trauma to his 
shoulder during the incident. He was somnolent, confused, and 
very lethargic following the seizure. He was unable to express 
clear thoughts and his speech was very slurred and unclear. He 
was taken to ___, where a non-contrast head CT reportedly showed 
nothing significant. He was discharged with outpatient 
follow-up. 

Today, the patient presented to his PCP because of ___ 
leg weakness, headache, slurred speech and had been acutely more 
confused the previous evening. Since his seizure, he endorses 
feeling generally more fatigued and experiencing a persistent, 
stable headache in the same bilateral distribution. His family 
members who accompanied him to the appointment report that he 
was behaving strangely and was overly happy and friendly. He was 
reportedly approaching people in the waiting room insisting that 
he knew them and had gone to school with them, when they were in 
fact strangers. He reportedly did this multiple times and was 
very insistent. When he was walking in to the hospital he 
reported that he had no "feeling in his right leg" and required 
assitence with walking. Although his speech was improved today, 
family reports that he was slurring his speech last night. He 
continues to report a frontal bilateral headache, ___ pain, 
that has been stable for the past several days. He denies 
phonophobia, photophobia, or changes in vision. Brother reports 
recorded temperature as high as 99.0 while at home.

EEG (___): This is an abnormal continuous EEG study due to 
mildly slow background activity with superimposed brief and 
prolonged runs of generalized intermittent rhythmic delta 
activity, at times with frontal predominance suggestive of mild 
to moderate encephalopathy. There are also frequent runs of high 
amplitude sharply contoured generalized rhythmic delta activity 
with embedded blunted sharp waves that often start on the right 
fronto-temporal region and seems to evolve in amplitude and 
distribution with no stereotypical clincal correlate which are 
concerning for electrographic seizures. 

EEG (___): This is an abnormal continuous EEG study due to 
slowed background activity with both brief bursts and runs of 
frontally predominant generalized intermittent rhythmic delta 
activity suggestive of mild to moderate encephalopathy. There is 
also generalized rhythmic delta activity with embedded blunted 
frontal sharp waves that do not clearly evolve into 
electrographic seizures and are without clinical correlate. In 
addition, there are also independent bursts of right frontal 
temporal slowing as well. At times, these are more broadly based 
over right hemispheres and evolve to become briefly more 
generalized. There is, at times, evolution in amplitude and 
embedded sharp waves making these more concerning for brief 
electrographic seizures. There is no clinical correlate seen 
with these on video.

HEAD MRI (___):  The study is limited by motion.  There is

HEAD MRA: (___) This study is significantly limited by 
motion artifacts, which particularly limits evaluation for small

arteries, and their major branches, appear patent without

cerebellar and anterior inferior cerebellar arteries are not

Head MRV: (___) HEAD MRV:  Flow is visualized in the

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ ___ man with PKD, who 
presents with slow speech, confusion, bizarre behavior, reported 
___ weakness, and persistent headache in the setting of 
a recent, first-time seizure two weeks ago. 

# NEURO: patient was admitted to neurology service and work up 
was started for encephalopathy with amnesia, personality 
changes/agitation and seizures. Infectious work up was done and 
CSF was sent for HSV, VZV and enterovirus which were all 
negative. He was treated with acyclovir x7 days while HSV/VZV 
panel were pending, and acyclovir was discontinued when these 
results returned negative. 

MRI of brain showed some changes in his basal ganglia and 
thalamus and possible subtle changes in his L temporal lobe. As 
autoimmune encephalitis was high on the differential diagnosis 
given his presentation, various antibodies including LGI-1, 
VGKC, ___, Anti-Ma/Ta, ___ paraneoplastic panel and 
Anti-NMDA receptor antibodies were sent and all returned 
negative. As the results of these studies were pending for 
couple of weeks, patient was empirically treated with 5 day 
course of high dose steroids and IVIg. 

He was loaded with levetiracetam given history of seizures and 
episodes concerning for complex partial seizures including 
olfactory hallucinations prior to admission. He also had EEG 
done while in house which showed bifrontal delta seizures, so 
phenytoin was added to levetiracetam with improvement in EEG. 
Given the episodes of agitation, he was started on valproate 
instead and levetiracetam was weaned off. He did have some 
perioral twitching, so EEG was replaced to look for more 
seizures but did not show it. His perioral twitching improved 
with therapeutic levels of phenytoin and valproate.

Clinically, patient continued to have encephalopathy with 
amnesia, paranoia and intermittent agitation requiring chemical 
and physical restraints. Psychiatry was consulted for better 
management of his antipsychotics given his paranoia. 
Rheumatology was also consulted for possibility of CNS 
vasculitis. He was found to have elevated ESR/CRP, but negative 
___ anticoagulant antibody, SS-A was 
mildly positive but SS-B was negative.

3. Agitation: multiple purple codes, has received combination of 
haloperidol/lorazepam/benztropine, and leather restraints  
- appreciate psych recs, to balance episodes of intermittent 
severe agitation & aggression against oversedation, further 
decreasing morning doses of risperidone. Continue 1 mg qAM, 1.5 
mg qPM and 1 mg qHS.  
- Psych recommending decreased dose of haloperidol 2.5 mg prn 
for agitation requiring medication. Discussed with parents at 
the family meeting today that we would try to minimize extra 
medications for sedation but it may be required at times for the 
patient and staff's safety.  
- clonidine patch to decrease sympathetic output  
4. Perioral & left hand twitching movements: intermittently 
present, possibly perioral asterixis. Urine/serum copper and 
ceruloplasmin wnl, so ___ less likely.  

# OPHTHO: Patient developed right eye conjunctival 
injection/edema, likely conjuctivitis, ophthamology consulted 
but could only do limited examination due to patient's 
agitation. He was empirically started on ciprofloxacin eye drops 
and erythromycin eye ointment with improvement. 

# ID: 
Given concern for immunocompromise and ?atypical/opportunistic 
infection, HIV antibody and HIV viral load were sent and were 
negative. He also had T-cell subset sent given question of 
isolated T-cell deficiency but that was also wnl. 

He was tested for cryptococcal antigen in serum/CSF which were 
both negative. CSF bacterial/viral cultures were negative from 
the initial CSF, and fungal culture was negative.
Patient had intermittent leukocytosis, then developed fevers 
around ___ and rash. 

# HEME: reported history of sickle cell trait. He had decreasing 
hemoblogin count few days after his IVIg and his labs were 
positive for hemolysis with elevated LDH and decreased 
haptoglobin. His direct coombs test was positive as well, and 
this was thought to be due to side effects from 
IVIg.Hematology/oncology was consulted and recommended daily CBC 
to monitor Hgb level and also recommended 7 days of folic acid 
for supplementation. His HB and HCT remained stable since then

# DERM: trucal/arm rashes with erythematous small papular 
rashes, . DRESS syndrome due to phenytoin:
The patient was seen by dermatology service, started on IV 
solumedrol and topical steroid, then changed to PO prednisone 
equivalant dose.He was improving with decrease in rash and liver 
enzymes.
He was discharged home on 80 mg of prednisone, will be taperred 
in his neuro follow up visit 

# RENAL: history of polycystic kidney disease, urine out put and 
cr level remained stable in this hospitalization  
# FEN: He was on regular diet, replete lytes prn

He is awake, alert and oriented x3, attentive.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure to take care of you at ___ 
___. You were admitted due to headaches, confusion 
and difficulty with your right leg. You had a lumbar puncture 
done and your cerebrospinal fluid showed evidence of 
inflammation but no bacteria. You had an MRI of your head done 
which showed subtle evidence of inflammation.

You were treated with antibiotics and antiviral medications 
while in the hospital for possible bacterial or viral 
meningitis/encephalitis (inflammation of brain or tissue 
covering the brain). Causes of brain inflammation/infection were 
investigated through lumbar punctures which demonstrated no 
Herpes Simplex, Enterovirus, Lyme, HHV6, or other viral disease, 
nor were any bacterial or fungal infections noted.  The 
Para-neoplastic panel was also found to be negative for any 
cause of inflammation.  Based on these findings, we were able to 
stop all of the anti-viral and anti-biotic therapies. We 
continued your steroid management for 

You were also treated for seizures given your episode 2 weeks 
ago and also for possible partial complex seizures (confusion, 
olfactory hallucinations).  You will stay on anti-epileptics 
after your discharge. You should not drive till your next visit 
after  being evaluated.
You developed reaction to dilantin and started on prednisone and 
your symptoms were improved.
Brain inflammation and steroid both can cause behavioral 
changes, to control these symptoms you were started on 
risperidone and need to continue this medication.
You were evaluated by our physical therapist and they recommend 
to have 24 hours supervision for now till you are evaluated in 
your follow up visit.
As you developed seizure, although you are on medication, it is 
possible that you experience another one, please avoid swimming, 
driving and lying in bathtub for now.
It was our pleasure to take care of you.
You should take these medication per instruction:
1. Risperidone 0.5 mg in the morning, 1 mg at 4pm, 1mg at 8pm.
2. Prednisone 80mg daily for now.
3. Divalprox 500 mg in the morning and 750 mg at noon and 750 mg 
at night.
4. Lacosamide 200mg twice a day.
5.please take ranitidine for your stomach protection
-please take calcium and vitamin D for your bone protection 
while you are taking steroid.

She has also had previous surgeries, including a right partial hip replacement and a left hip intertrochanteric hip fracture. The patient's symptoms improved during her previous hospitalization, but worsened again while she was an outpatient. She reports pain in her right hip and leg, which radiates into her right groin and down the back of her leg. She also reports intermittent burning with urination and 4 days of brown/green stool per day.

The patient's physical examination revealed limited range of motion in her right leg due to pain, and tenderness along the lateral hip to palpation. Her laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and liver enzymes. A joint aspiration was performed, and septic arthritis was ruled out based on fluid analysis. A CT scan and x-ray of the hip were negative for fracture, hematoma, or hardware misalignment.

The patient was diagnosed with right hip pain, and her pain management plan included starting low-dose gabapentin for a potential neuropathic element to the pain. She was also seen by physical therapy and had an L-spine MRI, which showed degenerative changes but no acute reason for her pain. The patient's warfarin was held for one day and then restarted due to an initial supratherapeutic INR. She was discharged with a plan for follow-up with her primary care physician and orthopedic surgeon. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with HCV, EtOH cirrhosis complicated by encephalopathy 
and ascites, on liver transplant list (MELD 18), and history of 
pulmonary embolism s/p anticoagulation, who presents with 
vomiting x 2 days and dizziness.  
.  
#. Vomiting: The etiology of the patient's vomiting was unclear, 
but was likely related to viral infection. It was non-bloody. 
There was no further vomiting after admission. Blood and urine 
cultures were negative. CXR showed no evidence of pneumonia. 
Diagnostic paracentesis was negative for spontaneous bacterial 
peritonitis. The patient did have several insect bites, so he 
was started on empiric doxycycline (planned 7-day course). He 
was also treated empirically with ciprofloxacin (planned 7-day 
course).
.
#. Dehydration: The patient became dehydrated in the setting of 
overdiuresis and vomiting. He was treated with 1 L of normal 
saline and 100 grams of albumin. Diuretics were initially held 
but were restarted at a lower dose prior to discharge. The 
patient was instructed to monitor his weight daily and report 
any change to his doctor. He was also instructed to hold his 
diuretics if he developed vomiting.
.
#. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient presented with 
creatinine 1.8, up from baseline 1.3. The etiology was thought 
to be prerenal, related to diuresis and vomiting. The patient 
was treated with 1 L of normal saline and 100 grams of albumin. 
Diuretics initially held then restarted at a lower dose. The 
patient's creatinine trended down and was 1.3 at the time of 
discharge.
.
#. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient developed worsened 
hepatic encephalopathy in the setting of dehydration. This 
improved with lactulose. At the time of discharge, the patient's 
mental status had returned to baseline. 
.
#. Headache: The patient had a headache throughout his 
admission. There was no nuchal rigidity. CT head ___ was 
normal. The headaches improved with low-dose acetaminophen (<2 
grams/day).
.
#. Hepatitis C Cirrhosis: Continued lactulose and rifaximin. 
Held and then restarted diuretics as above. An ultrasound of the 
abdomen was performed prior to discharge and did not show enough 
ascites to drain.
.
#. Microcytic Anemia. Baseline Hct around 30. Iron studies in 
___ suggestive of iron deficiency. The patient will 
need an outpatient colonoscopy if he has not had one.
.  
#. Thrombocytopenia: Baseline around 60-70. On admission, the 
patient's platelet count was near the patient's baseline. At the 
time of discharge, the patient's platelet count was slightly 
below his baseline. The patient's thrombocytopenia was thought 
to be related to his liver disease.
.
#. Sinus tachycardia: The patient remained tachycardic to 100 to 
110 throughout his admission. The etiology of this was unclear. 
The patient remained hemodynamically stable.
.  
#. Chronic back pain: Continued lidocaine patch.
.  
#. Code status: FULL (confirmed)  
.

He has a history of cirrhosis from HCV, encephalopathy, and ascites, and is on the liver transplant list. He has also had a pulmonary embolism and has been treated with anticoagulation. The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, depression, anxiety, migraines, cellulitis, obesity, left ankle fracture, colonic polyps, and L2+L3 compression fractures.

The patient's allergies include Bactrim and Ambien. He has a history of adverse reactions to these medications.

The patient underwent an ultrasound-guided paracentesis and had 3.8 liters of fluid removed. He was also treated with diuretics and albumin to manage his dehydration.

At discharge, the patient was prescribed medications including diuretics, antacids, and antibiotics. He was instructed to monitor his weight daily and report any changes to his doctor. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 64-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of shortness of breath and hypoxia. She has a history of asthma, recent left femoral shaft fracture, and provoked deep vein thromboses. She presented to the emergency department with symptoms of dyspnea, hypoxia, and left leg swelling, which she had been experiencing since her surgery. 

The patient's past medical history is significant for asthma, but she has no other significant medical conditions. She has no known allergies or adverse reactions to medications. 

The patient's diagnosis includes acute pulmonary embolism, aspiration pneumonia, and acute hypoxic respiratory failure. She underwent an EGD, which showed grade C esophagitis in the distal esophagus with no bleeding. 

The patient was treated with albuterol, ipratropium, vancomycin, zosyn, and heparin, and was given blood cultures. She was also prescribed medications at discharge, but the specific medications are not mentioned in the report. 

The patient's physical examination showed a tachycardic and tachypneic patient with clear lungs and no wheezing or rales. Her abdomen was soft and non-distended, and her extremities were warm and well-perfused. 

The patient's laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 16.6, which decreased to 5.2 at discharge. Her blood glucose levels were normal, and her electrolyte levels were within normal range. 

The patient's imaging studies, including a chest X-ray, CT angiogram, and Doppler ultrasound, showed evidence of pulmonary embolism, aspiration pneumonia, and patulous fluid-filled esophagus. 

The patient's hospital course was marked by ongoing shortness of breath and cough, but she was able to tolerate her medications and was discharged from the hospital in stable condition. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| 

The patient is a 41-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a non-healing ulcer on his left great toe. He has a past medical history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, diabetic retinopathy, end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, and peripheral artery disease. He has undergone several endovascular procedures, including left AT balloon angioplasty and balloon angioplasty of the entire left tibial artery.

The patient was admitted to the hospital with acute chest pain and shortness of breath, and was found to have a positive troponin and no EKG changes. He was diagnosed with new onset congestive heart failure and was treated with medications to manage his condition.

The patient underwent a partial left ray amputation due to osteomyelitis and ischemia, and was started on a 14-day course of antibiotics. He was also treated with medications to manage his diabetes, hypertension, and HIV.

At discharge, the patient was prescribed the following medications: abacavir, acetaminophen, amlodipine, aspirin, calcitriol, calcium acetate, clonazePAM, clopidogrel, doxepin, glargine, lopinavir-ritonavir, metoprolol XL, nephrocaps, oxycoDONE, pantoprazole, raltegravir, sertraline, sevelamer, and atorvastatin.

The patient was also advised to continue his scheduled dialysis and to follow up with his primary care physician for further management of his condition. ||endoftext||

1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system 
demonstrated non-obstructive coronary artery disease.  The LMCA 
was free

with no other significant disease. 
2. Resting hemodynamics revealed mildly elevated right-sided 
filling 
pressures with mean RA 10mmHg, and normal left-sided filling 
pressures 
with a PCWP of 11 mmHg.  There was moderate-to-severe pulmonary 
arterial 
hypertension with PA pressures of 65/25, mean 38 mmHg.  The 
systemic 
arterial pressures were normal with a central aortic pressure of 
109/58, 
mean 71 mmHg.  The cardiac output was preserved with a cardiac 
index of 
4.2 L/min/m2 (using an assumed oxygen consumption).

left-sided 
filling pressures. 
3. Moderately severe pulmonary arterial hypertension. 
4. Systemic arterial normotension. 
5. Preserved cardiac output.

moderately dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic 
function (LVEF>55%). The right ventricular cavity is mildly 
dilated with mild global free wall hypokinesis. There is 
abnormal systolic septal motion/position consistent with right 
ventricular pressure overload. The ascending aorta is mildly 
dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally 
normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or 
aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally 
normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral 
regurgitation is seen. There is severe pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. 
IMPRESSION: Severe pulmonary hypertension. Dilated right 
ventricle with mild systolic dysfunction and evidence of 
pressure overload. Mild symmetric LVH with normal global and 
regional systolic function. Mild mitral regurgitation.
Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, 
pulmonary pressures may be higher, although the tricuspid
