decompressed and contains vicariously excreted of contrast. The 
pancreas, adrenal glands, and kidneys are unremarkable. There is 
a wedge-like area of hypoenhancement in the upper pole of the 
spleen, consistent with a splenic infarction. 
  
Intermediate density perihepatic fluid without frank 
hemoperitoneum. No 
retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymphadenopathy. The abdominal 
aorta and major branches are normal. There is a right common 
femoral catheter. No abdominal wall hernia or pneumoperitoneum. 
  
PELVIS: The bladder contains a Foley catheter. The uterus is 
unremarkable. 
There is intermediate density free pelvic fluid. No pelvic 
side-wall or 
inguinal lymphadenopathy. 
  
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: No focal lytic or sclerotic lesion 
concerning for 
malignancy. 
  
IMPRESSION:   
1. Active extravasation of contrast at the level of the 
gastroesophageal 
junction during venous phase imaging. The stomach and esophagus 
are massively dilated with blood. 
  
2. Cirrhosis with evidence of portal hypertension including a 
patent umbilical vein and massive hemorrhoids. Pancolonic edema 
and segmental small bowel edema are consistent with portal 
colopathy and enteropathy. 
  
3. Intermediate density perihepatic and pelvic fluid without 
frank 
hemoperitoneum. 
  
4. Endotracheal tube terminates at the level of the carina. 
  
5. Upper pole splenic infarction. 
  
6. Bilateral lower lobe atelectasis with aspiration or mucous 
plugging in the right lower lobe bronchi. 
  
NOTIFICATION:  The emergent finding of GI bleeding was reviewed 
in person with Dr. ___. The final impression was 
discussed via telephone by Dr. ___ with Dr. ___ on 
___ at 5:29 ___, 20 minutes after discovery of the 
findings. 

EEG ___
CONTINUOUS EEG: The background activity varied between what 
appeared to be a significant encephalopathic EEG to one that 
appeared to be associated with persistent stage N2 to N3 sleep. 
During the encephalopathic portion of this record, there is very 
little posterior background rhythm. There is continuous high 
amplitude polymorphic ___ Hz delta activity seen with frontal 
and central predominance admixed with faster theta frequency 
activity over the central regions. During the sleep portion of 
the record, the background is still suppressed posteriorly; 
however, well-formed vertex waves and evolving stage N2 and 3 
sleep was noted. 
SPIKE DETECTION PROGRAMS: There were numerous automated spike 
detections 
predominantly for the vertex related activity. No clear 
interictal Epileptic discharges were identified. 
SEIZURE DETECTION PROGRAMS: There were no automated seizure 
detections. 
QUANTITATIVE EEG: Trend analysis was performed with Persyst 
Magic Marker 
software. Panels included automated seizure detection, rhythmic 
run detection and display, color spectral density array, 
absolute and relative asymmetry indices, asymmetry spectrogram, 
amplitude integrated EEG, burst suppression ratio, envelope 
trend, and alpha delta ratios. Segments showing abnormal trends 
were reviewed and showed diffuse symmetric encephalopathic 
changes. 
PUSHBUTTON ACTIVATIONS: There were no pushbutton activations. 
SLEEP: See above. 
CARDIAC MONITOR: Showed a generally regular rhythm with an 
average rate of 100-115 bpm. 
IMPRESSION: This is an abnormal continuous ICU monitoring study 
because of a moderately severe diffuse encephalopathy with 
attenuation of background frequencies in the presence of high 
amplitude delta activity. However, during portions of the 
record, a relatively normal sequencing of sleep was seen. This 
can happen and may reflect excessive drowsiness in the presence 
of a more mild to moderate encephalopathy. There were no 
lateralized, localized, or epileptic features to the record. 

___ CXR IMPRESSION:  
IN COMPARISON WITH THE STUDY ___, THERE AGAIN ARE LOW 
LUNG VOLUMES.  MONITORING AND SUPPORT DEVICES ARE WITHIN NORMAL 
LIMITS. THERE IS INCREASING BILATERAL OPACIFICATIONS.  ALTHOUGH 
SOME OF THIS MAY MERELY REFLECT CROWDING OF VESSELS AND 
PULMONARY EDEMA, THE POSSIBILITY OF SUPERIMPOSED PNEUMONIA. 
WOULD HAVE TO BE SERIOUSLY CONSIDERED IN THE APPROPRIATE 
CLINICAL SETTING. 
  
___ CXR
IMPRESSION:  
1. Diffuse bilateral airspace opacities are consistent with 
aspiration in the setting of massive upper GI bleed. 
2. Monitoring and support devices are in the appropriate 
positions. 

ABD DUPLEX U/S
FINDINGS:    
There is a large amount of echogenic ascites with more organized 
thrombus 
around the liver.  Although is difficult to accurately 
quantitate the amount of hemorrhage, the ascites appears 
increased compared to CT of 2 days ago. 
  
The main portal vein is patent with hepatopetal flow. The TIPS 
is patent and demonstrates wall-to-wall flow with velocities of 
83, 120, and 120 cm/sec in the proximal, mid, and distal 
portions respectively. 
  
MPV is patent with velocity of 29 cm/sec.  The left portal vein 
is not 
visualized.  Flow within the right anterior portal vein is 
reversed. 
  
IMPRESSION:  
1.  Hemoperitoneum with more organized thrombus around the 
liver. Although it is difficult to accurately quantitate, the 
amount of ascites appears larger than on the CT of 2 days ago 
2.   Patent TIPS. 

___ CT-A A/P
FINDINGS:  The bases of the lungs demonstrate significant 
atelectasis and 
small bilateral pleural effusions.  Superimposed infectious 
process of the consolidations cannot be excluded. 
  
The patient is status post TIPS with the TIPS stent seen in 
appropriate 
position.  The liver is diffusely heterogeneous with a nodular 
contour and regenerative nodules consistent with cirrhosis.  No 
definite arterially enhancing hepatic lesion is identified.  The 
gallbladder is hyperdense, consistent with excretion of 
contrast.  Redemonstrated is a wedge-shaped area of 
hypoenhancement in the upper pole of the spleen, consistent with 
a splenic infarction, unchanged compared to the prior exam.  The 
pancreas is normal without evidence of focal lesions or 
pancreatic duct dilatation. 
  
The adrenal glands bilaterally are normal.  The kidneys 
bilaterally are normal without evidence of focal solid or cystic 
lesions concerning for malignancy.  
There is no evidence of hydronephrosis. 
  
There is a large amount of hemoperitoneum.  On the arterial 
phase, there is a serpiginous structure anterior to the right 
liver which is likely a 
subcapsular vessel which itself is distended secondary to a 
subcapsular 
hematoma.  The terminus of the vessel is irregular on the portal 
venous 
phases.  Active extravasation in this region cannot be excluded. 
 Hyperdense blood is also seen immediately inferior to the 
liver. 
  
Evaluation of the gastroesophageal junction is limited due to 
the embolization particles; however, the stomach is distended 
with hyperdense material concerning for hemorrhage.  
Intraluminal areas of increased density within the small and 
large bowel are also concerning for hemorrhage.  There is no 
evidence of wall thickening or obstruction. 
  
Areas of irregularity within the liver are likely secondary to 
lacerations from the recent TIPS procedure.  There is no 
intra-abdominal free air.  The right common femoral catheter is 
redemonstrated. 
  
CT PELVIS:  The urinary bladder demonstrates a Foley catheter.  
The uterus appears unremarkable. 
  
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  No lytic or blastic lesions concerning for 
malignancy are identified. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
1.  Massive Hemoperitoneum with irregularity of a distended 
subcapsular vessel in both the arterial and portal venous phases 
is concerning for active extravasation.  High-density blood is 
seen immediately inferior to the liver. 
2.  Although evaluation of the gastroesophageal junction is 
limited by embolic particles from recent embolization, there is 
evidence of hemorrhage within a distended stomach and remainder 
of the small and large bowel loops.  Active extravasation from 
the gastroesophageal junction cannot be excluded. 
3.  Irregularity of the liver with evidence of lacerations is 
likely from 
recent TIPS procedure. 
4.  Small foci of pneumoperitoneum are likely secondary to the 
recent 
intervention. 
5.  Diffuse anasarca throughout the body. 

___ MRA NECK W/CONTRAST
IMPRESSION: 
1.       No acute intracranial abnormality. 
2.       Chronic right cerebellar hemispheric infarction, 
unusual in a patient of this age; correlate with more detailed 
clinical information. 
3.       No evidence of hippocampal sclerosis, focal cortical 
dysplasia, gray matter heterotopia or other anatomic substrate 
for seizure 
4.       Normal cranial MRA. 
5.       Large amount of fluid within the mastoid air cells and 
sphenoid air cells. While likely related to prolonged 
intubation, this process has 
progressed considerably since ___, and should be correlated 
clinically. 

___ ABDOMEN US
FINDINGS:  
Limited abdominal ultrasound again demonstrates ascites with 
echogenic 
material consistent with thrombus.  There is a large amount of 
echogenic, 
apparently organized thrombus in the lower quadrants.  The 
quantity of 
anechoic, drainable appearing fluid, is small, however.  A 
paracentesis could be performed, but large volume fluid removal 
is not expected to be achieved. 
IMPRESSION:  
Findings again consistent with hemoperitoneum and ascites with 
large amount of echogenic clot within the abdomen with smaller 
quantity of drainable-appearing free fluid. 

___ LIVER ABD US
IMPRESSION:  
1.  No intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation.  Ascites and 
hemoperitoneum again seen. 
2.  Patent TIPS with velocities similar to ___.      
3.  Hyperechoic lesion in the liver in segment VIII.  MR can be 
done for 
further evaluation when indicated.  

___ CXR
IMPRESSION:  
Right PICC line tip is deep in the right atrium.  , might be 
pulled back 
approximately 2 cm. TIPS and most likely coils of embolization 
of ___ is are unchanged in appearance. Heart size and 
mediastinum are unchanged as well as bilateral basal 
consolidations.  No definitive evidence of interval development 
of pulmonary edema is present. The right need opacity is 
substantial and might reflect infectious process versus 
atelectasis 

___ CT ABDOMEN
IMPRESSION:  
1.  Slight interval decrease in large volume pneumoperitoneum.  
In the absence of IV contrast, cannot assess for superinfection 
or abscess formation. 
2. TIPS in adequate position. 
3.  Anasarca. 
4.  Gallstones. 

___ CT CHEST
IMPRESSION:  
Moderate cardiomegaly with moderate pulmonary edema and 
bilateral pleural 
effusions.  Multifocal pneumonia. 

___ RENAL US
IMPRESSION: 
1. No hydronephrosis. Unremarkable appearance of the kidneys. 
2. Ascites and hemoperitoneum is again noted. 

___ CXR
The tip of the endotracheal tube is 2.6 cm above the carina.  
There is a 
feeding tube with tip and side port in the stomach.  There is a 
right-sided PICC line with distal lead tip in the right atrium.  
This could be pulled back, 3-4 cm for more optimal placement.  
There are very low lung volumes with atelectasis versus 
developing infiltrates at the lung bases.  There are no 
pneumothoraces. 

DISCHARGE LABS
expired
 
Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE
=======================
Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o lady with history of alcohol 
abuse who initially presented with coagulopathy, anemia, 
thrombocytopenia, muscosal bleeding, new onset seizure, 
hypotension s/p cardiac arrest with associated respiratory 
failure. She was found to have a large GE junction variceal 
bleed which was stopped with emolization of gastric artery, 
subsequent TIPS. TIPS was complicated by subsequent hepatic 
artery bleed, which caused severe abdominal compartment syndrome 
requiring repeat ___ intervention with embolization of 2 branches 
of hepatic artery.  She was ultimately transitioned to the ICU 
requiring intubation for pending respiratory failure in the 
setting of worsening liver failure (MELD 56), hepatorenal 
syndrome, anasarca, sepsis, and ongoing bleeding.  She was 
eventually made CMO by her family and expired shortly after 
terminal extubation.

# Massive variceal bleed complicated by hepatic arterial bleed - 
Pt presented with massive bleeding from all mucosal surfaces on 
presentation.  Her lower and upper GI tracts prompted an upper 
endoscopy which showed a massive esophageal bleed.  A stat CTA 
showed active extravasation from the GE junction, and she then 
proceeded to ___ for embolization of the gastric artery.  After 
the procedure, she continued to have significant bleeding with 
unstable blood counts and hemodynamics.  She was then referred 
for urgent TIPS procedure which proceeded without complication.  
However, over the next ___ hours her abdomen became massively 
distended and was sent down for a repeat CTA which confirmed 
massive hemoperitoneum as well as probable bleed from the liver. 
 She then went to ___ for a third procedure where they embolized 
2 branches of the hepatic artery.  They also attempted 
paracentesis but did not get substantial drainage has she was 
thought to be clotting off.  However, they did place an ostomy 
bag over the area.  Fortunately, after this final procedure, the 
patient stopped bleeding and was able to continue without blood 
products.  During this course, she received over 29 units of 
blood (massive transfusion protocol utilized), multiple units of 
FFP, platelets, and cryoprecipitate.  The family was informed on 
multiple occasions of her poor prognosis.  She was later 
transitioned to CMO with terminal extubation per discussion with 
her family after her liver function worsened and was complicated 
by HRS.  

# Elevated transaminases with direct hyperbilirubinemia: 
Patient's LFTs started climbing on HD 4 after her bleeding 
stopped.  A RUS was obtained which showed TIPS is patent and no 
dilatation.  Transaminitis and elevated hyperbilirubinemia was 
thought to be due to cholestasis of sepsis versus EtOH 
hepatitis. MELD score elevated to the ___.

#Abdominal Compartment Syndrome- Patient's bladder pressure 
rose, peak pressures rose, and O2 sats declined along with 
massive abdominal distention in the setting of her hemorrhagic 
ascites when she bled from her hepatic artery.  She was taken 
for hepatic artery embolization as described above.  Multiple 
attempts at paracentesis did not yield fluid.  She had repeat 
abdominal ultrasounds that confirmed large amounts of clot in 
the peritoneum.  She developed oliguric renal failure not 
responsive to diuresis.

#Acute Hypoxemic and hypercarbic respiratory Failure: Intubated 
in the setting of new seizure for airway protection.  She 
appeared to have aspirated blood given BRB out of ET tube.  Her 
ventilator settings were quite minimal until she developed 
worsening mechanics ___ abdominal compartment syndrome on ___ 
necessitating increasing O2 requirement and hypercarbia.  After 
the compartment syndrome resolved, she was easily extubated.  
However, the patient was again intubated for metabolic acidosis 
and altered mental status (likely hepatic encephalopathy).  Upon 
discussion with her family regarding her poor prognosis, she was 
terminally extubated after being transitioned to CMO.  She 
expired shortly after extubation. 

# Septic and hypovolemic shock s/p PEA arrest. (Resolved). Echo 
did not show cardiogenic component.  She was on pressors for the 
first few days for which she had a trauma line placed in R IJ.  
Most of the shock was likely hypovolemic from massive bleeding, 
although she did grow MSSA from her sputum as above.  Pressors 
were d/c on ___.  She was initially treated with 
vanc/cefepime/acyclovir and also received a dose of doxycycline 
and clindamycin early on (empiric coverage for tick born disease 
and toxic shock syndrome).  She was eventually narrowed down to 
just cefepime when meningitis was thought to be less likely.  
Blood cultures were ngtd. She later developed significant 
diarrhea, and although her C. diff was negative, she was treated 
with PO vanc/flagyl for presumed C. diff infection.   

#Hepatorenal syndrome: Spun urine is mostly bland, few casts, 1 
muddy brown cast c/w ATN.  Improved with hemodynamic 
stabilization initially.  However, patient developed worsening 
renal failure in the setting of her concurrent liver failure, 
consistent with HRS.  Renal function worsened with albumin 
infusions.  Renal was consulted and because of her poor 
prognosis and unlikely irreversible liver and renal function, 
dialysis was not an option.

#New onset Seizures: Head CT x 2 negative for bleed.  Likely 
secondary to either alcohol withdrawal, toxic-metabolic, or 
meningitis.  Her bleeding and hemodynamic issues precluded 
neuro's initial recommendations of MRI/MRA and LP.  24 hour EEG 
showed focal slowing left side but no seizure concerning for 
structural abnormality.  She was initially treated for 
meningitis as above, but therapy de-escalated when clinically 
appeared unlikely.  MRI/MRA obtained which were overall 
unremarkable for cause of seizure.  She was treated with keppra 
1000 mg BID per neuro recommendations. 

# MSSA PNA/VAP: Sputum sample obtained which grew coag pos 
staph.  She was treated with cefepime for an 8 day course.

She had a concerning clinical history for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), unresponsiveness after cardiac arrest with return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), and new onset seizure. The patient's past medical history includes "liver problems" and alcohol abuse. She has no known allergies or adverse drug reactions.

The patient's diagnosis includes DIC, cardiac arrest, and seizure disorder. She underwent an embolization of the gastric artery, guided TIPS procedure, and embolization of the hepatic artery, as well as an EGD. Medications prescribed at discharge include vancomycin, PPI gtt, and levophed.

The patient's physical exam revealed a paucity of breast tissue, overall appears small and underdeveloped for stated age, and hepatomegaly about 2-3 cm below the costal margin. Her laboratory results showed a WBC of 22, Hgb of 3.5, hct of 10.2, plt of 93 with 11% bands, creatinine of 6, INR of 2.2, and lactate of 18 on arrival. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is an 84-year-old female who presented with chest pain and dizziness after a trip to the bathroom. She has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and Crohn's disease. She has undergone previous cardiac interventions, including stenting and coronary artery bypass grafting. Her past medical history also includes chronic anemia, monoclonal gammopathy, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and hyperthyroidism.

The patient underwent off-pump coronary artery bypass grafting and endoscopic harvesting of the long saphenous vein. She was found to have a tight left mainstem stenosis and was transferred for urgent coronary bypass grafting. She tolerated the procedure well and was extubated on postoperative day 1.

The patient's medications at discharge include acetaminophen, furosemide, ipratropium-albuterol, nystatin, oxyCODONE, potassium chloride, aspirin, metoprolol, calcitriol, cholecalciferol, clopidogrel, magnesium oxide, mesalamine, omeprazole, and simvastatin.

The patient's discharge diagnosis includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic anemia. She was discharged in good condition with instructions to shower daily, wash incisions gently with mild soap, and manage incisional pain with oral analgesia. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 73-year-old female with a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, chronic systolic heart failure, and chronic kidney disease (CKD). She was admitted for worsening heart failure symptoms, including shortness of breath, orthopnea, and dyspnea. The patient had a history of breast cancer, chemotherapy, and implantation of a biventricular pacemaker/implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) with cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT). She was also diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and was started on apixaban, amiodarone, and metoprolol.

The patient underwent a thoracentesis for a large left pleural effusion and was treated for a systolic heart failure exacerbation. She became hypotensive and had an elevated lactate briefly after diuresis and thoracentesis, but responded well to IV fluids. The patient was discharged on the following medications: torsemide, lisinopril, metoprolol succinate, and amiodarone. She was also advised to continue her home regimen of apixaban.

The patient's allergies include codeine, thiazides, ondansetron, digoxin, doxepin, desipramine, sulfa, and adhesive tape. Her past medical history includes hyperlipidemia, cardiomyopathy post chemotherapy, primary prevention ICD implant, CRT defibrillator, and CABG. ||endoftext||

He has a history of glioblastoma, deep vein thrombosis, and IVC filter placement. His past medical history includes right occipital glioblastoma, craniotomy, radiation, and chemotherapy. He also has a history of renal cell cancer, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, osteoarthritis, PMR, neuralgia, and deep vein thrombosis.

The patient's physical exam revealed that he was making noises intermittently, not following commands, and had a sacral decubitus ulcer stage 1. His vital signs were stable, and he had no fever or signs of infection. His laboratory results showed normal blood counts, electrolyte levels, and liver function tests.

The patient's diagnosis was not specified in the report, but it is likely related to his underlying glioblastoma and encephalopathy. He underwent no surgical or invasive procedures during his hospital stay. At discharge, he was prescribed medications including IV keppra, dilantin, PO vancomycin, and oxacillin, and was advised to have a PEG placement for long-term nutrition.

The patient's social history was not provided in the report. His family history revealed that his mother died after hip surgery, his father died of heart failure, and his brother died of a heart attack at age 60. He has two sisters, one with arthritis and carpal tunnel syndrome, and one with Alzheimer's disease. He also has two daughters and a son, all of whom are healthy. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
HOSPITAL COURSE: Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with uterine sarcoma who 
presented to the ED with nausea/vomiting and obstipation x 1 
week. A CT of her abdomen showed findings consistent with small 
bowel obstruction, secondary to new pelvic mass from her uterine 
sarcoma, despite recent therapy with gemcitabine/docetaxol, 
which provided temporary symptomatic improvement. She was 
admitted for palliative chemotherapy with adriamycin/ifosfamide, 
and was put on bowel rest with NPO/TPN. She became neutropenic 
after the first round, and responded well to Neupogen. Her 
obstructive symptoms worsened, however, requiring placement of a 
jejunal tube for decompression, leading to relief of nausea and 
vomiting. Repeat abdominal CT showed enlargement of the mass. 
After a family meeting and input from her outpatient oncologist 
Dr. ___ opted for a second cycle of 
adriamycin/ifosfamide. She tolerated it well and was sent home 
on TPN, with ___ services.  

# SMALL BOWEL OBSTRUCTION SECONDARY TO UTERINE SARCOMA: Patient 
presented following vacation in ___ with naueas/vomiting 
and loss of bowel movements. CT abdomen showed a new pelvic 
mass, likely progression of uterine sarcoma. Patient was placed 
on bowel rest and strict NPO until initiated on TPN. A port was 
placed received a surface echo in preparation for chemotherapy. 
Patient was started on adriamycin/iphosphamide  on ___ and 
tolerated the infusions well with negative UAs during treatment. 
Patient was continued on TPN and bowel rest with NGT placed 
following vomiting of feculent material. NGT was pulled 
following nose pain as requested by the patient. She was then 
started on clear liquids with occasional vomiting secondary to 
crampy pain in her abdomen. Gyn oncology was following the 
patient and recommended conservative management. 

After many days of symptom management and persistent nausea, 
vomiting of copious feculent/bloody material, abdominal pain, 
and inability to tolerate clears, a repeat CT was performed 
which showed enlargement of the pelvic mass despite the cycle of 
A/I. A PEJ tube was placed for decompression, which provided 
significant symptom management. Prior to tube placement pt had 
intractable vomiting and had several episodes of tachycardia 
secondary to hypovolemia from poor PO intake, responsive to 
fluid. For this reason her home furosemide was discontinued 
until outpatient follow-up with her PCP.

Gyn/Onc said no surgical options for the mass were available, 
and pt appeared to have failed first cycle of A/I as mass had 
progressed, however the CT was done much earlier than 
anticipated (original plan was to hold off until after second 
round), so it may have been too soon to evaluate effect of 
chemo. Family meeting was held and pt decided, after input from 
Dr. ___ Heme/Onc fellow Dr. ___, as well as inpatient 
oncology team and Palliative Care, that she would like to try 
another round of A/I and hope for better results. Three days of 
treatment were administered, which pt tolerated well other than 
some nausea and vomiting, all UAs were clear. She was discharged 
home on regular diet for comfort, but with TPN and PEJ in place. 
Insulin was added to the nightly TPN the day before discharge 
due to AM blood sugars in the high 100s/low 200s, so pt was sent 
home with glucometer and test strips for ___ self-checks, with 
___ instructions to monitor blood glucose. She got a Neulasta 
shot before discharge. She will be followed as an outpatient by 
Dr. ___.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
- A J tube was placed for decompression, not feeding
- She will f/u with her outpatient oncologist regarding future 
chemo
- No longer on furosemide, a previous home medication. Should 
f/u w/ PCP regarding need for the medicine.
- Pt is on nightly TPN. Insulin was added to TPN on ___ due to 
a BS of 232. The following day her BS improved to 144, so she 
was sent home with TPN+10U Insulin. We advised pt to check her 
BS ___.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted for nausea/vomiting and lack of bowel 
movements. It was found that you had a new tumor that was 
obstructing your small bowel. You were started on nutrition 
through your IV and given bowel rest.  You also received 
chemotherapy while admitted, which you tolerated well.  Your 
blood counts dropped and were supported with neupogen shots.  At 
first, your nausea and vomiting and pain were controlled with IV 
medications.  You eventually tolerated a liquid diet.

Later in your hospital course, your small bowel obstruction 
worsened, an on imaging it appeared as if your tumor had grown, 
which caused a worsening of your symptoms of abdominal pain, 
nausea, and vomiting. We had you go to surgery to get a tube 
placed to relieve these symptoms, and gave you another round of 
chemo to try to shrink the mass enough to give you some relief 
from the obstruction. You tolerated the second round of chemo 
well and your symptoms improved with the chemo and the placement 
of the gastric tube. You will continue getting nutrition through 
your IV at home. 

Your blood sugars have been high occasionally in the hospital 
while on TPN, so insulin was added to your IV nutrition. We will 
send you home with a device you can use to test your blood sugar 
___. Symptoms of low blood sugar are shakiness, nausea, 
sweating, palpitations. If you have any of these symptoms or are 
feeling ill, check your blood sugar, eat something, and call 
your doctor for ___ blood sugar less than 80. For blood sugar 
>250, please also notify your doctor.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 50-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of nausea and vomiting. She has a history of uterine leiomyosarcoma that has metastasized to her lung and has undergone surgery and adjuvant radiation therapy. She has also received chemotherapy with gemcitabine and docetaxel, but had to stop due to toxicity. She presented to the emergency department with sudden onset abdominal pain and new abdominal masses, and was found to have three new masses on CT scan. She has not had a bowel movement in a week and has not passed gas. She has also experienced episodes of non-bloody emesis.

The patient's past medical history is significant for menopausal symptoms, fibroids, and a history of open cholecystectomy. She has no history of asthma, heart disease, diabetes, hypertension, thromboembolic disease, or breast cancer.

The patient's diagnosis is leiomyosarcoma with metastatic disease to the lung and abdomen. She underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and bilateral lymph node sampling, and was found to have lymphovascular invasion and positive for desmin.

The patient was treated with gemcitabine and docetaxel, but had to stop due to an allergic reaction to docetaxel. She was also given fluids and CT scans to monitor her disease progression.

The patient's physical exam was significant for a tender abdomen, particularly in the left lower quadrant, and a superficial mass in the periumbilical area. Her discharge physical exam was similar, with no significant changes.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, neutrophils, and lactate levels, as well as decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit levels. Her electrolyte levels were also abnormal, with elevated sodium and potassium levels.

The patient's relevant studies included a CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast, which showed multiple air and fluid-filled dilated loops of small bowel with necrosis. ||endoftext||

It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber,

maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool

amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed

1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)

walked as you can tolerate

||startoftext|| The patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted for lower extremity ischemia. He has a history of extensive peripheral vascular disease, including a left common femoral to posterior tibial artery bypass graft, and has undergone several debridements of ulcers on his feet, followed by a below-knee amputation on his right side. He has also had balloon angioplasty of his left common femoral to posterior tibial artery vein graft.

The patient's past medical history includes coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, coronary artery bypass grafting, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, chronic renal insufficiency, and anemia.

He has allergies to iodine and iodine-containing substances. His medications at admission included amiodarone, Dubrox, Lunesta, Fluticasone, Gabapentin, Humalin, Vicodin, Imdur, Levoxyl, omeprazole, renegel, sun, zocor, coumadin, Colace, and Senna.

The patient underwent a diagnostic left lower extremity angiogram and was found to have patent left femoral to posterior tibial bypass with mildly elevated velocities at the distal anastomosis, suggesting the possibility of moderate stenosis.

At discharge, the patient's medications included amiodarone, nitroglycerin, Levothyroxine, Gabapentin, Fluticasone, B Complex-Vitamin C-Folic Acid, Carvedilol, Citalopram, Oxycodone-Acetaminophen, Lactulose, Lisinopril, Lorazepam, omeprazole, Sevelamer HCl, Simvastatin, Aspirin, Docusate Sodium, Acetaminophen, insulin, and Coumadin.

The patient was discharged to an extended care facility with instructions to weigh himself daily, take his medications as directed, and follow a diet that includes high fiber, lean meats, vegetables, fruits, low fat, and low cholesterol. He was also advised to elevate his legs above the level of his heart, avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting, and drink plenty of fluids. ||endoftext||

pulmonary nodule with VATS on ___ confirming

receiving 9 of 14 doses week #1 complicated by neutropenia,
and 10 of 14 doses week #2.  Initial follow up CT scan showed
improvement with regrowth noted on subsequent scans.

He was admitted on ___ for cycle #2 week #1 high-dose
IL-2 therapy, receiving 7 of ___omplicated
by mid-week elevated creatine kinase and troponin levels
raising concern for possible myocarditis.  IL-2 was held
until his labs improved and he was restarted with 1 dose
daily without further cardiac issues noted.

His recovery was notable for lower GI bleeding with admission
on ___.  His hemoglobin and hematocrit were stable and
he underwent endoscopy with antral gastritis noted.
Colonoscopy revealed an erythematous lipoma felt to be
consistent with a source of bleeding.  Biopsies revealed
colonic mucosa and a hyperplastic polyp.  He is now recovered
is ready for week #2 of therapy.

radiation followed by brachytherapy boost, and history of GI
bleeding in ___ with recurrent GI bleed in ___.

acute distress.  Performance status is 1.  VITAL SIGNS:

Normocephalic, atraumatic.  Sclerae anicteric.  Moist oral
mucosa without lesions.  LYMPH NODES:  No cervical,
supraclavicular, or bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy.
HEART:  Regular rate and rhythm.  S1, S2.  CHEST:  Clear
bilaterally.  ABDOMEN:  Rounded, soft, nontender.  No HSM or
masses.  EXTREMITIES:  No edema.  SKIN:  Intact.  NEUROLOGIC:
Nonfocal.

ADMISSION LABORATORY DATA:  WBC 7.6, hemoglobin 14.1,
hematocrit 40.6, platelet count 419,000.  INR 0.9.  BUN 12,
creatinine 1.2, sodium 140, potassium 4.9, chloride 103, CO2
24.  ALT 24, AST 25, LDH 189, CK 144, albumin 5.0, alkaline
phosphatase 55, total bilirubin 0.6.  CK-MB 4.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted and underwent
central line placement to begin therapy.  He went to
Interventional Radiology for his line placement.  His
admission weight was 113 kg, and he received interleukin-2
600,000 international units/kg based on adjusted ideal body
weight equalling 54.7 million units IV q.8 hours x14
potential doses.  He was placed on telemetry when IL-2
started due to questionable history of myocarditis in his
week #1 of therapy.

During this week he received 2 doses of IL-2 due to note made
of bradycardia with AV conduction block noted on telemetry
during his ___ admission night.  His underlying rhythm was
___, normal sinus brady to normal sinus rhythm with 1st
degree AV block with an irregular rhythm noted, felt

stable.  Cardiology recommended a stress echo which will be

indication for a pacemaker placement given his asymptomatic

he has a positive stress test or if his symptoms change.
However, given concern for this newly noted AV conduction
delay, IL-2 was not continued given that this is appeared to

He was discharged to home on ___, without further

increase in his levothyroxine to 150 mcg p.o. daily.  He also
developed some hand and forearm pain during admission
attributed to IL-2 therapy, which improved after IV morphine
and was resolved at the time of discharge.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care:
1. You may keep your incisions open to air or covered with a 
clean, sterile gauze that you change daily. IF BLISTERING 
DEVELOPS ON THE SKIN AROUND THE CENTRAL FLAP, YOU CAN START TO 
APPLY THE ANTIBIOTIC OINTMENT YOU WERE PRESCRIBED
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with soap and water. 
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day. 
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount. 
5. DO NOT wear a normal bra for 3 weeks. Wear your surgical bra 
at all times except when in shower
6. You may shower daily with assistance as needed. Be sure to 
secure your upper drains to a lanyard that hangs down from your 
neck so they don't hang down and pull out. You may secure your 
lower drains to a fabric belt tied around your waist.
7. The Dermabond skin glue will begin to flake off in about ___ 
days. 
8. No pressure on your chest or abdomen 
9. Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your 
doctor. 
10. Monitor breast flap site for continued viability including 
pink coloring, and warm temperature.
. 
Activity: 
1. You may resume your regular diet. 
2. Keep hips flexed at all times, and then gradually stand 
upright as tolerated. 
3. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity for 6 weeks following surgery. 
. 
Medications: 
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered . 
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. 
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol. 
4. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 
5. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber. 
. 
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 
. 
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
. 
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS 
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.

 
Followup Instructions:
___
target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 57-year-old female who was admitted to the plastic surgery service for definitive oncologic surgical management and breast reconstruction following a right mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy. She has a history of right breast cancer, DCIS/IDC Grade I ER/PR+ HER2-, and has undergone right lumpectomy and SLNB (negative) followed by radiation therapy. She also has a history of seborrheic keratosis, osteopenia, dermatoheliosis, and herpes.

The patient's presenting symptoms were related to her right breast cancer, and she underwent a major surgical procedure, including a right mastectomy, sentinel lymph node biopsy, and immediate right breast reconstruction.

The patient's medications at discharge included acetaminophen for pain, aspirin for cardiovascular prophylaxis, cefadroxil for infection prophylaxis, docusate sodium for bowel regimen, hydromorphone for pain, mupirocin ointment for blistering prevention, polyethylene glycol for constipation, senna for constipation, and valacyclovir for herpes prophylaxis.

The patient was discharged home with service, with instructions to keep her incisions open to air or covered with a clean, sterile gauze, clean around the drain site, strip drain tubing, and record output. She was also advised to avoid pressure on her chest or abdomen, shower daily with assistance as needed, and monitor her breast flap site for continued viability. ||endoftext||

CT scan ___
IMPRESSION:  
1. Complex multiloculated cystic lesion in the right upper 
quadrant may be 
centered in the abdominal wall musculature and extends into the 
superficial 
soft tissues and has a subcapsular hepatic component. Main 
diagnostic 
considerations includes and abscess or hematoma, with neoplasm 
not 
completely excluded. 
2. Large loculated left pleural fluid collection. 
3. Sequela of chronic pancreatitis.  
.
CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST Study Date of ___  
IMPRESSION:  
1. Considerable interval decompression of left lateral pleural 
fluid empyema, which contains a pigtail catheter, with a smaller 
residual collection. 
2. Considerable interval decompression of extensive fluid 
collection 
extending from the subcutaneous tissues of the abdominal wall 
through the 
intracapsular region of the liver and closely approaching the 
hepatic flexure of the colon. At that point, a small collection 
of enteric contrast is present, perhaps extraluminal or within a 
diverticulum, an appearance of unclear significance.  
3. Mildly hypoattenuating region of the adjacent liver with 
surrounding 
enhancement which may be reactive. Given that the overall 
process is most 
suggestive of an infectious etiology, this hypodense area may 
represent an 
early phlegmon. The liver could be further evaluated with US or 
MR if the 
patient is not improving clinically. On the other hand, if 
short-term imaging evaluation is not felt needed, then follow-up 
examination is recommended in several weeks to ensure that an 
underlying mass is not present. 
3. Atrophy and calcification of the pancreas, consistent with 
known 
pancreatitis. Although not optimally visualized, the upper 
superior 
mesenteric vein appears patent.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the ICU under care of the surgical 
service on ___.  He was transfused 5 units of FFP for an 
INR of >22, started on vanc/zosyn, serial Hct's were obtained, 
he was NPO with IVF and IV pain medication.  Interventional 
pulmonary placed a chest tube into the left pleural effusion.  
The patient was transferred to the surgical floor in the evening 
___.

___ - Transfused 2 units FFP, an incision and drainage of the 
RUQ lesion was performed at the bedside.  Chronic pain started a 
ketamine drip and a dilaudid PCA for pain control.  A heparin 
drip was started for SMV thrombosis.  His diet was advanced to 
regular.

___ - A repeat CT scan demonstrated a decrease in both 
collections.  Antibiotics and heparin drip were continued. ID 
was consulted and they recommended HIV testing and TB cultures.  
The patient was placed on respiratory precautions for rule out 
TB.

___ - Underwent successful VATS/decortication of his left 
pleural space with Dr. ___. 

___ - An MRI was obtained to evaluate for a liver abscess.  
It revealed an area in the liver that was consistent with a 
phlegmonous change and that this appeared to communicate with 
the abdominal wall abscess.  He was taken to the operating room 
on ___ for an abdominal wall wound exploration.  The I&D 
incision was extended and the abscess cavity was debrided and 
irrigated.  It did not communicate with the abdominal cavity or 
liver.  He was transferred to the ___ 
post-operatively.  He underwent dressing changes twice a day for 
the next few days and then a wound vac was applied to the 
abscess cavity.  During this time his left chest tube was taken 
off pleura-vac suction and changed to a pneumostat.

___ - Tolerating a regular diet. Pain well controlled with 
oral medication. Left Pneumostat chest tube was removed by 
Thoracic surgery. Post-chest tube removal chest XRAY revealed no 
pneumothorax. A wound vac was placed on the right upper quadrant 
abscess site. ID recommends 4 weeks of IV Penicillin G, and 2 
more weeks of PO Flagyl for treatment of CDIFF.

___ - INR remained subtherapeutic at 1.4 on coumadin so 
Lovenonx SC injections were started to bridge him until his INR 
is therapeutic. He was discharged home with Visiting Nurses for 
___ of his wound vacuum dressing. Vacuum dressing was 
removed prior to discharge and a Wet to dry packing was 
inserted. ___ will deliver the vacuum pump tomorrow, and ___ 
will apply it in the patient's home. Infusion therapy was 
arranged for IV antibiotics via PICC at home.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 43-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of a RUQ mass and pain, as well as a L pleural loculated fluid collection. He has a history of EtOH-induced chronic pancreatitis, SMV thrombosis, and is on Coumadin indefinitely. He also has chronic abdominal pain and is taking Oxycontin and Percocet. The patient's past medical history includes IDDM, chronic abdominal pain, chronic pancreatitis, SMV thrombosis, insomnia, and h/o alcoholism.

The patient's diagnosis includes a complex multiloculated cystic lesion in the right upper quadrant, possibly an abscess or hematoma, and a large loculated left pleural fluid collection. He also has sequela of chronic pancreatitis.

The patient underwent a tube thoracostomy (pigtail) and incision and drainage of the RUQ mass. He was prescribed medications at discharge, including antibiotics and pain medication.

The patient's physical exam revealed a thin male with a firm, extremely tender, erythematous mass deep to the RUQ scar. He had moderate TTP to palpation in the L hemi-abdomen, though he reported this was baseline. His vital signs were stable, and he was afebrile.

The patient's laboratory results showed an elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and liver enzymes, consistent with an inflammatory process. His imaging studies, including CT and MRI, showed a complex multiloculated cystic lesion in the right upper quadrant, a large loculated left pleural fluid collection, and atrophy and calcification of the pancreas.

Overall, the patient's hospital course was marked by a complex and challenging presentation, requiring multiple procedures and a multidisciplinary approach to management. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 27-year-old female who was admitted with oral bleeding and a history of Evans syndrome, a condition characterized by hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). She had recently undergone splenectomy and was hospitalized this month with painful oral ulcers that bled and clotted. She also experienced syncopal events and was found to have scattered petechaie on her chest. Laboratory results showed a low platelet count, and she received IVIG and dexamethasone treatment. Her platelets rebounded to 65 on discharge, and she was prescribed oral dexamethasone for two more days. She was also prescribed trazodone for insomnia and was advised to follow up with her doctor to discuss starting rituximab again. ||endoftext||

The patient's diagnosis is not explicitly stated in the report, but it appears that she has a chronic condition related to her ESRD and C. diff infection.

The patient underwent no major surgical or invasive procedures during her hospital stay. She was prescribed PO vancomycin 125 mg q6 hours at discharge.

The patient's physical exam showed no acute signs of distress, with the exception of some fatigue and decreased lung sounds. Her vital signs were stable throughout her hospital stay.

The patient's laboratory results showed some abnormalities, including elevated WBC and lactate levels, but these were not explicitly related to a specific diagnosis.

Overall, the patient's condition appears to be stable, and she was discharged with a plan for continued treatment and follow-up. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ gentleman with IgA nephropathy, with ESRD 
recently started on HD, who was admitted due to fever at HD and 
was found to have MSSA HD line infection complicated by MSSA 
pneumonia.  He was treated with IV antibiotics and was 
discharged home.
.
# Fever: MSSA bacteremia from HD line infection.
Positive blood cultures grew MSSA.  Line was pulled immediately 
and tip grew MSSA as well.  Infectious Disease was consulted and 
followed throughout admission; TTE and TEE ruled out valve 
vegetation.  When sensitivities returned he was changed from 
Vancomycin to Cefazolin given at HD.  His only positive blood 
cultures here are from when he first came to the ED and 
subsequent ones were negative.  Fever however persisted for much 
of the admission (could have been a drug fever as well) but by 
the time of discharge, he had been fever-free for >24H.  Plan 
for total of 4 weeks of Cefazolin (treating for complicated 
Staph infection given that he is an HD patient: day 1 of 
antibiotics was ___, day 1 of negative blood cultures was 
___. Four week course would end ___.  He will follow up 
___ I.D. ___ clinic.

# Multifocal Pneumonia: with cough that is resolving.
Patient had persistent dry cough, with eventual pleuritic rib 
cage pain.  No shortness of breath or hypoxia.  Found to have 
multifocal pneumonia on CTA. Sputum culture with GPCs ___ 
clusters and pairs; the Cefazolin he was on for bacteremia would 
treat this MSSA pneumonia as well.  Prior to discharge, his 
chest was re-imaged to ensure that no complication had developed 
(e.g. empyema or abscess).  His cough was treated with 
Guaifenisin/Codeine and Benzonatate.  He will be followed by 
I.D. ___ clinic and will likely need follow-up imaging to 
ensure resolution of his lung infiltrates.
.    
# ESRD on HD: due to IgA Nephropathy.
He has been receiving HD at ___.  On presentation 
was compensated with regards to volume and potassium.  Phos was 
elevated and he was started on extra doses of Sevelamer with 
snacks.  Continued Nephrocaps.  New tunneled right IJ HD line 
placed on the day of discharge.  Will return to usual HD 
schedule (___).  He will follow up with Nephrology 
after discharge, and also has follow-up with Transplant Surgery 
for planning of more permanent access (fistula).  
.
# Anemia: likely from CRI, required transfusions.
He has required multiple transfusions ___ the past, most likely 
due to CRI. He gets Epogen with dialysis but did not receive 
this ___ the hospital.  His Hct was near 20 (goal ___ theory is 
>21) - no lightheadedness or shortness of breath.  CT 
abdomen/pelvis ruled out r-p bleed.  He was guaiac negative.  
Not hemolyzing.  His anemia was felt to be due to CKD and he was 
transfused a total of 4 units pRBCs during HD.  He will receive 
Epogen again as an outpatient.  Hct was 27 at the time of 
discharge.
.  
# HTN: SBP at goal while on medication.
When his Lisinopril was held for concern that he may be having 
an ACE-inhibitor related cough, his SBP was out of control (up 
to 190) but when he was started back on his home regimen, SBP 
was better controlled.  He was continued on Lisinopril and 
Labetalol.
.  
# Transitional Issues:
-Code Status: Full Code
-Emergency Contact: Father ___
-Barriers to care: Patient frequently DNK's appointments; the 
importance of coming to outpatient appointments was emphasized 
throughout admission
-Follow-up:
--Primary Care ___: to f/u blood 
pressure, ensure cough resolution, and ensure no recurrent 
fever)
--___ clinic
--Transplant Surgery clinic (for fistula plans)
--I.D. ___ clinic

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:

1. Pulmonary embolism - POD2 Patient was experinecing increased 
O2 requirement. Poor air flow through lungs, gave Lasix with 
minimal effect. CXR unremarkable. CTA showed small subsegmental 
PE. Started on Lovenox ___ BID -> Coumadin.

2. Geriatrics consult for co-management ___ PE.

Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by 
a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1.  The patient 
received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of 
POD#1.  The foley was removed on POD#2 and the patient was 
voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was 
changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean 
and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient 
was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout 
the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).
 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.

6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five 
(5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at 
least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues 
to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be 
removed will be taken out at your follow-up visit in three (3) 
weeks after your surgery.

7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.

8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).

9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox TWICE daily 
until your INR is > 2.0 x 24hrs. Continue warfain (Coumadin) 
daily for a goal INR ___. If you were taking aspirin prior to 
your surgery, it is OK to continue at your previous dose while 
taking this medication.  ___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.

10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up 
visit in three (3) weeks.

11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.

12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize. CPM/ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise 
or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
Physical Therapy:

ROM unrestricted
CPM ___ for 2hr sessions at maximum flexion
Mobilize
Treatment Frequency:
Dry sterile dressing daily as needed for drainage
Wound checks
Ice and elevation
TEDs

 - Goal INR ___
 - Check INR daily
 - Lovenox ___ BID until INR > 2.0 x 24hrs
*Staples will be removed at followup visit in 3 weeks*

IMAGING
=======
___ CXRAY 

Midline sternotomy wires and mediastinal clips are new from 
prior.  The lungs
are clear and hyperinflated.  No focal consolidation, large 
effusion or
pneumothorax.  No signs of congestion or edema.  The 
cardiomediastinal
silhouette is stable with top-normal heart size.  Bony 
structures are intact. 
No free air below the right hemidiaphragm.

___ Cath Report  

Coronary Anatomy

Dominance: Right
 LIMA-LAD: There was a suggestion of a calcified ledge at the 
origin of the left subclavian artery (whichsubsequently impeded 
advancement of the 4 ___ MP catheter). A careful hemodynamic 
pullback across the origin of the left subclavian artery was not 
performed. The initial left subclavian SBP was about 10-20 mm Hg 
lower than the subsequent LVSP, but change in sympathetic tone 
from agitation and pain
could not be excluded as the cause of the higher SBP later. The 
LIMA was of modest caliber and appeared to attach to a mildly 
diffusely diseased native LAD. It could not be engaged 
selectively due to
an unusually oriented origin.

 LMCA: There was an ostial 40% LMCA stenosis and a distal 30% 
stenosis.

 LAD: There was a 20% near-ostial LAD plaque. The mid LAD 
tapered to 40% after S1. There was a
calcified 75% stenosis after D1 followed by another mid LAD 50% 
stenosis. Competitive flow was seen in
the distal LAD. The distal LAD wrapped around the apex.

 LCX: There was a retroflexed 50% ostial stenosis followed by a 
calcified 75% angulated stenosis.
OM1 was of only modest caliber. OM2 had an origin 50% stenosis 
and a proximal 60% stenosis. The
terminal AV groove CX had a 50% stenosis and supplied 
collaterals to the RPLs and terminal AV groove
RCA. No competitive flow was seen in the native CX system.

 SVG-OM: The SVG-OM was stump occluded.

 At this point, the patient became more uncooperative, giggled 
inappropriately, continued her attempts to sit up, moved both of 
her arms (with backing of the radial sheath out of her wrist). 
She complained repeatedly of left arm pain, especially with 
attempts at catheter manipulation (even after IA TNG and 
verapamil and switching to 4 ___ catheters; the 4 ___ JR4 
kinked outside the body, and the 4
___ MP could not advance out of the left subclavian artery 
into the aortic arch without resistance and pain). The patient 
repeatedly requested termination of the procedure. After 
difficulty advancing the 4 ___ MP, the procedure was aborted, 
and a TR Band was applied to the LRA with good hemostasis. 

Intra-procedural Complications: None

Impressions:
1. Known native three vessel coronary artery disease.
2. Mild left ventricular diastolic dysfunction assessed after 
LIMA angiography.
3. Patent LIMA onto a mildly diffusely diseased LAD.
4. Occluded SVG-OM.
5. Native RCA and SVG-RCA not evaluated due to difficulty 
engaging these vessels, patient discomfort
and repeated requests to terminate the procedure. Given the 
severity of the native RCA disease, it
would not be surprising if the SVG-RCA was also occluded.

You continued to have some abdominal pain on discharge but you

She has a history of ulcerative colitis (UC) with a total colectomy and creation of a j-pouch, and has experienced episodes of pouchitis in the past. She has also been diagnosed with hypothyroidism, anxiety, depression, nicotine dependence, endometriosis, and myofascial pain syndrome.

The patient's allergies include NSAIDs, Remicade, and Gabapentin. She has a history of adverse reactions to these medications.

The patient's diagnosis is unclear, but based on her history and biopsy results, it is suggestive of pouchitis. She was started on ciprofloxacin and flagyl, which helped to decrease her symptoms.

The patient underwent a flexible scope of the pouch and small bowel, which showed normal mucosa in the visualized pouch and small bowel. Biopsies showed focal active pouchitis and focal mild active inflammation in the small bowel.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, including oxycodone, ciprofloxacin, and flagyl. She was also advised to follow up with her gastroenterologist and primary care physician for further evaluation and management of her symptoms.

The patient's vital signs were stable throughout her hospital stay, with a temperature of 97.7°F, pulse of 60, and blood pressure of 106/70. She was also noted to have mild scleral injection and mild to moderate tenderness in the suprapubic region. ||endoftext||

Pertinent Results:
Please see ___ Record for relevant laboratory and 
imaging results.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old male with a right sided subdural hematoma.

#Right Sided Subdural Hematoma
The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for 
right burr holes for subdural hematoma evacuation. The procedure 
was uncomplicated. Please see ___ Record for further 
intraoperative details. The patient was extubated in the 
operating room and recovered in the Post Anesthesia Care Unit. 
Postoperative CT of the head showed an improvement in the 
midline shift. The patient was transferred to the step down unit 
postoperatively for close neurologic monitoring. A surgical 
drain was left in place postoperatively, which was subsequently 
removed on ___ without complications. Post pull CT of the 
head was stable without any evidence of acute intracranial 
hemorrhage. Additional imaging continued to be stable. The 
patient remained neurologically stable. On ___, the patient 
continued to be neurologically stable. He was afebrile with 
stable vital signs, ambulating with assistance, tolerating a 
diet, voiding and stooling without difficulty, and his pain was 
well controlled with oral pain medications. He was discharged to 
a skilled nursing facility on ___ in stable condition.

#Atrial Fibrillation With Rapid Ventricular Rate
The patient has known atrial fibrillation. The patient developed 
tachycardia postoperatively, and the Medicine Service was 
consulted for recommendations. The patient's home metoprolol was 
increased and diltiazem was added for rate control. A 
transthoracic echocardiogram was done, which revealed aortic 
stenosis. Cardiology was consulted and recommended that the 
patient follow-up as an outpatient with his regular 
cardiologist.

#Thyroid Function
TSH and T4 levels were drawn as part of a work-up for 
tachycardia as requested by the Medicine Service. The patient 
was found to have an elevated TSH. The Medicine Service did not 
believe that the elevated TSH was contributing to his atrial 
fibrillation and recommended outpatient follow-up with his 
primary care provider for further evaluation and management of 
his thyroid function.

#Agitation 
The patient became agitated postoperatively. Psychiatry was 
consulted and recommended ramelteon as well as Haldol as needed. 
The patient was started on these medications, and his agitation 
improved.

#Disposition
The patient was evaluated by both Physical Therapy and 
Occupational Therapy, both of whom recommended rehabilitation. 
The patient's health insurance company denied acute 
rehabilitation despite our discussion with their healthcare 
providers. The patient was discharged to a skilled nursing 
facility on ___ in stable condition.

7.  Metoprolol Succinate XL 200 mg PO DAILY  
8.  Ramelteon 8 mg PO QHS insomnia   
9.  Senna 17.2 mg PO QHS:PRN Constipation - First Line  
10.  Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO QHS

Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right sided subdural hematoma
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory with assistance.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Surgery:
- You underwent a surgery to remove blood from your brain. 
- Please keep your staples along your surgical incision dry 
until they are removed.
- It is best to keep your surgical incision open to air, but it 
is okay to cover it when outside. 
- Call your neurosurgeon if there are any signs of infection 
like fever, redness, or drainage.

Activity:
- We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up.
- You may take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity 
at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. ___ try to 
do too much all at once.
- No driving while taking narcotics or any other sedating 
medications.
- If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law.

Medications
- Please do NOT take any blood thinning medications (aspirin, 
Coumadin, ibuprofen, Plavix, etc.) until cleared by your 
neurosurgeon. 
- You may use acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
- You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and 
remembering new information.
- Emotional and behavioral difficulties are common. 
- Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
swings are also common.
- You may also experience some postoperative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third days after surgery. You may 
apply ice or a cool or warm washcloth to help with the swelling. 
The swelling will be its worst in the morning after laying flat 
from sleeping, but should decrease when up.
- You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
- Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics, try an over 
the counter stool softener.

Headaches:
- Headache is one of the most common symptoms after a brain 
bleed. 
Most headaches are not dangerous, but you should call your 
neurosurgeon if the headache gets worse or if you develop 
increased sleepiness, nausea or vomiting, or arm or leg weakness 
with a headache.
- Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches, but 
avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed
- There are other things that can be done to help with your 
headaches including avoiding caffeine, daily exercise, getting 
enough sleep, ice or heat packs, relaxation, meditation, 
massage, and acupuncture.

When To Call Your Neurosurgeon At ___:
- Severe pain, redness, swelling, or drainage from the surgical 
incision. 
- Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit.
- Nausea or vomiting.
- Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake.
- Severe headaches not relieved with pain medications.
- Seizures.
- Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak.
- Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or legs.

Call ___ And Go To The Nearest Emergency Department If You 
Experience Any Of The Following:
- Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arms, or legs.
- Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding.
- Sudden dizziness, trouble walking, or loss of balance or 
coordination.
- Sudden severe headaches with no known reason.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Mrs. ___ is a ___ woman who recently gagged on a 
chicken above and underwent an upper endoscopy, which

in the distal stomach, which appeared to be a gastrointestinal 
stromal tumor.  Fine-needle aspirates of the lesion were 
nondiagnostic.  However, endoscopic ultrasound demonstrated 
typical findings of a submucosal mass in the distal body and

curvature.  There was no overlying ulcer, and the lesion was 
tattooed. Plans were made for a minimally invasive robotic

Stomach segment, laparoscopic partial gastrectomy - 
     - Schwannoma (benign peripheral nerve sheath tumor), 4.5

hyperplasia, confirmed with immunoreactivity for S-100 and 
negativity for c-kit and desmin.
     - Resection margin is narrowly free of neoplasm.
     - Overlying mucosa with focal intestinal metaplasia, but 
minimal inflammatory infiltrates.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the ___ Surgical Service for 
evaluation and treatment.  On ___, the patient underwent 
minimally invasive robotic assisted partial gastrectomy, which 
went well without complication (reader referred to the Operative 
Note for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, 
the patient arrived on the floor NPO, on IV fluids, with a foley 
catheter, NG tube, and PCA for pain control. The patient was 
hemodynamically stable.

On POD#1 the patient had good pain control with her PCA. In the 
evening, her NGT was removed and she was given sips of liquids. 
Her foley was removed on this day and she voided independently. 
She was restarted on her home medications. She ambulated with 
nursing assistance.

On POD#2, the patient was advanced to clear liquids, and 
transitioned to oral pain medications, which she tolerated well. 
She ambulated frequently.

On POD#3, the patient was advanced to full liquids, 
post-gastrectomy diet. Her CVL was discontinued. She ambulated 
frequently. Her pain was well-controlled. She was passing gas, 
and had a bowel movement with the assistance of milk of 
magnesia. 

On POD#4, the patient felt well, with good pain control and 
regular ambulation, and felt ready to be discharged. She was 
stressed the importance of remaining on a full liquid diet until 
her follow-up appointment with Dr. ___ on ___. 

The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, 
early ambulation and incentive spirometry were encouraged 
throughout hospitalization. Electrolytes were routinely 
followed, and repleted when necessary. The patient's white blood 
count and fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection. Wound care was performed regularly and thoroughly. 
The patient's blood sugar was monitored throughout his stay; 
insulin dosing was adjusted accordingly. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay; was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Januvia 100mg'
Metformin 850 mg BID
Trazodone 50 mg 3 tabs at bedtime
trihexyphenidyl ___ QHS

3. Senna 1 TAB PO BID:PRN constip 
RX *senna 8.6 mg 1 tablet by mouth twice per day Disp #*60 
Tablet Refills:*0
4. traZODONE 150 mg PO HS:PRN insomnia 
5. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Schwannoma (benign peripheral nerve sheath tumor) of the 
stomach, measuring 4.5 cm

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the surgery service at ___ for surgical 
resection of your stomach lesion. You have done well in the post 
operative period and are now safe to return home to complete 
your recovery with the following instructions:

Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon, who will instruct you further regarding activity 
restrictions.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Please follow-up with your surgeon and Primary Care Provider 
(PCP) as advised.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water.  Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own.  
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you experience 
the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Overall the patient tolerated the procedure well and 
post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable 
condition for recovery and invasive monitoring.  
POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and 
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact 
and hemodynamically stable. Low dose Beta blocker was initiated 
but not titrated up due to first degree AV block with PR 
interval 0.34a. The patient was gently diuresed toward the 
preoperative weight. Hydralazine was added for additional blood 
pressure control. The patient was transferred to the telemetry 
floor for further recovery. Chest tubes and pacing wires were 
discontinued without complication. The patient was evaluated by 
the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and 
mobility. Hematocrit had decreased slightly on day of discharge 
(27.2->25.8) and this is to be rechecked by ___ in 2 days with 
results to be called to the cardiac surgery office. He was free 
water restricted for Na 130 and this had increased to 133 on the 
day of discharge. By the time of discharge on POD 4 the patient 
was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain was 
controlled with oral analgesics. The patient was discharged home 
with visiting nurse services in good condition with appropriate 
follow up instructions.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of shortness of breath. He has a history of severe mitral regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse, pulmonary hypertension, and other medical conditions. He underwent a radical reconstruction of his mitral valve with NeoChords and a Physio II ring.

The patient's past medical history includes severe mitral regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse, pulmonary hypertension, cataracts, erectile dysfunction, rotator cuff tear, hyperlipidemia, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and plantar fasciitis.

The patient's physical examination revealed a pulse of 71 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. His blood pressure was 135/60 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results showed normal kidney function, mild anemia, and mild hyperglycemia. His electrocardiogram showed a normal sinus rhythm with a first-degree atrioventricular block.

The patient underwent a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) which showed severe mitral regurgitation, mild tricuspid regurgitation, and normal left ventricular systolic function.

The patient's hospital course was uneventful, and he was discharged home on post-operative day 4 with instructions to follow up with his cardiologist and to take his medications as prescribed.

The patient's medications at discharge included acetaminophen, aspirin, docusate sodium, hydralazine, metoprolol tartrate, and oxyCODONE. ||endoftext||

Patient has been diagnosed with cholangiocarcinoma in ___ when she presented on ___ with RUQ pain, nausea and 
vomiting, elevated LFTs and multimodality imaging showing 9cm

obstruction/cholangitis that have been treated with ERCP. 

She was most recently admitted the prior week for pain control. 
During that admission she underwent CT that showed mild decrease

Given this finding she deeemed appropriate for a trial of 
resection. Thus she presented to clinic for bowel prep and

Patient reported that since discharge she had been doing well. 
Her pain was much better then given that she was no longer 
nauseous. She denied any infectious symptoms. Her pain was 
chronic and localized to the RUQ. She denied any jaundice, 
fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath or chest pain. She 
denied any blood per rectum, hematuria, or dysuria. She 
continued to be constipated.
