US INTRA-OP ___ MINS Study Date of ___ 7:04 AM 
IMPRESSION:  
Large central liver mass involving both the left and right lobes 
as described. The with close proximity to the origin of the main 
right hepatic vein from the IVC. 

DUPLEX DOPP ABD/PEL PORT Study Date of ___ 8:27 AM 
IMPRESSION:  
1.   Patent hepatic vasculature. 
2.  8 x 2.7 cm hematoma at the surgical bed. 
3.  Small right pleural effusion. 

LIVER OR GALLBLADDER US (SINGLE ORGAN) PORT Study Date of 
___ 9:16 AM 
IMPRESSION:  
1.   Patent hepatic vasculature. 
2.  Unchanged organizing hematoma in the surgical bed. 

CTA ABD W&W/O C & RECONS Study Date of ___ 4:37 AM 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Status post left liver trisegmentectomy with the Roux-en-Y 
hepaticojejunostomy.  No portal venous or hepatic arterial flow 
into the residual liver, with heterogeneous enhancement of 
segment 7 and homogeneous hypoenhancement of segments 6, is 
concerning for ischemia or infarction. Hepatic veins are patent. 

2. Extensive wall thickening and edema of the stomach, ascending 
colon, and to a lesser degree the jejunum. 
3. Rim enhancing fluid collections in the pelvis, with some 
loculated fluid collections in the pericolic gutters 
bilaterally, consistent with 
intra-abdominal abscesses. 
4. 2 small wedge-shaped areas of hypoenhancement in the right 
lower lobe of the lung.  These could reflect pulmonary infarcts, 
although no filling defect within the pulmonary arteries is 
identified. 
5. Right greater than left pleural effusions, with a possible 
hemorrhagic component. 

CT ABD W&W/O C Study Date of ___ 8:11 ___ 
IMPRESSION:   
1. Status post left hepatic trisegmentectomy, with infarction 
and necrosis of segment VI and the periphery of segment VII.  
Abrupt cutoff of an anterior right portal branch into segment VI 
is suspicious for underlying thrombosis.  The residual enhancing 
viable hepatic tissue is predominantly within segment VII, 
approximately 300 cc in volume. 
2. Abnormal perfusion and wall edema in the stomach, small 
bowel, and colon and hyperenhancement of the adrenal glands is 
compatible with shock bowel physiology; correlate with recent 
operative course and hemodynamics. 
3. Intra-abdominal free gas and fluid, with gas tracking along 
the anterior abdominal fascia, related to recent laparotomy. 
4. Moderate anasarca. 
5. Moderate right pleural effusion.  Bibasilar atelectasis. 

CT ABD W&W/O C Study Date of ___ 9:39 AM 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Status post left hepatic trisegmentectomy, multiple 
debridement of remaining segment, and abdominal washout.  The 
remaining the liver, approximately 442.3 cc, is inhomogeneously 
enhancing, most likely due to hypoperfusion. 
2. Portal vein and its branches are attenuated but patent.  
Right hepatic vein is patent. 
3. New splenic infarcts and areas of hypoperfusion. 
4. Improved appearance of the bowel. 
5. Decreased fluid collection now measuring 3.75 x 10.4 cm. 
6. New retroperitoneal and mesenteric lymphadenopathy. 
7. Diffuse anasarca. 
8. Decreased right pleural effusion.  Bilateral atelectasis. 
  

CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST Study Date of ___ 9:39 ___ 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Large pelvic collection measuring 10.8 x 8.6 cm lying between 
the rectum and uterus. 
2. Newly visualized clot within the left external iliac vein. 
3. Slight decrease in size in the perisplenic collections as 
detailed above. 
4. Stable appearance of the multiple splenic infarcts. 
5. Residual heterogenous enhancement of the residual liver, with 
hepatic and portal venous supply patent.  The hepatic arterial 
supply is not visualized.  Findings overall indicate an element 
of hepatic necrosis. 
6. Nonocclusive left common femoral vein thrombus 
7. Slight increase in size of right-sided pleural effusion and 
associated 
lower lobe collapse 

CT CHEST W/CONTRAST Study Date of ___ 10:21 ___ 
IMPRESSION:  
- Moderate layering right pleural effusion, present since at 
least ___, partially hemorrhagic. 
- Multiple discrete lung lesions, new since chest CT in ___ 
and chest radiograph on ___, therefore most likely 
infectious. 
- Possible lingular pneumonia. 
- New anasarca, most severe below the diaphragm. 

BILAT LOWER EXT VEINS Study Date of ___ 4:53 ___ 
IMPRESSION:  
1.  The previously described left common femoral vein thrombus 
is not identified on the current study.  No evidence of deep 
vein thrombosis in the bilateral lower extremities. 
2.  Due to the patient's body habitus and overlying bowel gas, 
iliac veins were not visualized, even with the curved probe. 

CTA ABD W&W/O C & RECONS Study Date of ___ 4:51 ___ 
IMPRESSION: 
1. The portal and hepatic vein supplying the remnant liver are 
patent.  The hepatic artery is only seen proximally similar in 
appearance to prior 
examination. 
2. Splenic infarcts appear similar to prior examination. 
3. Note that the pelvis was not imaged on this examination 
secondary to Liver CTA protocol.  A pelvic ultrasound could be 
obtained further evaluation of previously seen fluid collection. 
 Alternately patient could return for pelvic CT. 
4. Please see chest CT report for chest findings. 

CT CHEST W/CONTRAST Study Date of ___ 4:51 ___ 
IMPRESSION:  
1.  New diffuse ground-glass and more complex opacities seen 
throughout the lungs concerning for pulmonary edema/ARDS.  
Bibasilar atelectasis also noted. 
2.  New small right pneumothorax. 
3.  Please see abdomen CT report for further evaluation of these 
findings. 

CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST Study Date of ___ 9:41 AM 
IMPRESSION:  
1. No drainable collection identified.  Interval decrease in 
size in the recto uterine collection which is being drained via 
transvaginal pigtail catheter as detailed above. 
2. Wall thickening of the distal sigmoid and rectum, perhaps 
secondary to the underlying pelvic collection.  Superimposed 
infection is not excluded, for clinical correlation. 

US ABD LIMIT, SINGLE ORGAN PORT Study Date of ___ 10:13 
AM 
IMPRESSION:  
1.  The hepatic artery is again not visualized in or near the 
remaining liver, as seen on CTA. 
2.  The remaining portal and hepatic veins appear patent with 
proper direction of flow. 
3.  No biliary dilatation. 
4. Free fluid is noted in the mid abdomen 

___ INS ENDOVAS VENA CAVA FILTER Study Date of ___ 6:26 
___ 
FINDINGS: 
1. Patent normal sized, non-duplicated IVC with single bilateral 
renal veins and no evidence of a clot. 
2. Successful deployment of an infra-renal Bard Denali IVC 
filter. 

CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST Study Date of ___ 1:16 AM 
IMPRESSION: 
1. Loss of gray-white matter differentiation globally with 
sulcal effacement suggestive of anoxic brain injury.  Consider 
MR for confirmation. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the ___ under 
Dr. ___ for preparation for the OR on ___. She 
received a bowel prep and was then taken to the OR on ___ 
and underwent the following procedure:  

1. Intraoperative ultrasound with first laparoscopic diagnostic 
review of the peritoneal cavity.
2. Cholecystectomy with use of ultrasound and distal common bile 
duct  sent for margins.
3. Left liver trisegmentectomy with resection of segments 1, 2, 
3, 4A, 4B, 5, and 8.
4. Total extra hepatic bile duct resection down to the pancreas 
including all soft tissue and lymph nodes from the periportal 
dissection.  Frozen section margins were free of cancer.
5. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, intrahepatic, with a single 
bile duct draining segment 6 and 7 was performed with placement 
of fiducial's  by the right hepatic vein and the biliary plate 
next to the single bile duct left for reconstruction.
6. Fibrin glue was applied to the cut surface of the liver and 
an intrahepatic bile duct cannula was placed for the Roux-en-Y 
reconstruction.
7.  Placement of 250 cc On Q device with 1/8% marcaine for 
perioperative pain control. 

Surgeon was Dr. ___ assisted by Dr. ___. 
Please refer to all operative notes for complete details. 

Postoperatively, Ms. ___ was taken to the SICU intubated for 
management. She was extubated the following day, ___. LFTs 
initially increased. She required blood products for initial hct 
drop to 20.9. Epidural was stopped and IV methadone was started 
with a basal rate of dilaudid for pain control given h/o 
Oxycontin use (80mg bid). She continued to be intermittently 
tachycardic into the 150s. She was started on Vancomycin and 
Zosyn ___. JP drain fluid was sent for culture isolating ( 
Vanco sensitive enterococcus and fairly resistant E.coli) Liver 
u/s showed patent vasculature. LFTs continued to increase. Blood 
cultures isolated Ecoli (multi-drug resistant) and antibiotics 
were appropriately tailored. 

On ___, LFTs were worse. A stat CT showed an infected 
collection and areas of necrotic liver. THe patient taken to OR 
and found to have staple line dehiscence requiring a washout, 
oversewing of bowel, and portal venous thrombectomy. Her abdomen 
was left open with vac in place for potential re-exploration on 
___. EBL was 350ccs and she received 3u PRBCs and 1u 
platelets; additional albumin boluses as well as additional 
blood products were required.  Despite these, the patient had 
worsening blood gasses and rising LFTs. Ultrasound could not 
visualize vasculature and so a CTA was ordered; this 
demonstrated improved flow within the main portal vein.  

On ___, the patient remained stable. LFTs were at the time 
downtrending and lactate was improving. Patient was given 1 U 
PRBC, 1 u plts. INR was elevated to 4.2 and so on ___ she 
received 2 units FFP in AM, 1 Cryo, 3gIV Vitamin K. INR goal was 
decided to be ___. She received additional blood products and 
labs were monitored closely.  An ultrasound of the 
liver/gallbladder was ordered and showed minimal portal venous 
flow, although it was a poor-quality study.  

On ___, INR was 2.9 in the early AM; patient received vitamin 
K, and in light of imaging, labs, and clinical picture, patient 
was taken to the OR in ___ for wash-out, liver debridement; there 
was good portal flow and acceptable hepatic artery flow. Seg VII 
was determined to be viable. Abdomen was left open with Apthera 
vac. As for previous and subsequent surgical procedures, for 
full details, please see the dictated operative report.  

On ___ patient continued to receive FFP as needed to keep INR 
<2.5; she was also receiving fat-soluble vitamins given the 
decrease in liver function to secrete bile to absorb Vitamins 
A,D,E,K. Further FFP was required on ___, as well as 1u PRBC 
and 1u Cryo. Repeat CT of the head was within normal limits. 

Patient returned to the OR for repeat washout and completion 
segment VI segmentectomy on ___ with 1u FFP en route to 
OR. TEG was normal intraop, epidural and left femoral cordis 
discontinued in setting of normal coagulation. Previously-drawn 
daily blood cultures were discontinued. After washout, patient 
returned on pressors and continued to require blood products; 
for brevity, patient required frequent intermittent 
administration of blood products including FFP, packed red blood 
cells, and platelets, for the rest of her admission.  

On ___, patient went to ___ for Dobhoff tube advancement and was 
started on tube feeds. She also underwent ultrasound-guided 
thoracentesis with a liter of transudative fluid drained.  

A repeat CT was performed ___ revealing attenuation of the 
portal vein and its branches but patency thereof. Tube feeds 
were held at midnight and patient went to the OR on ___ where 
she underwent revision of the hepaticojejunostomy anastomosis, 
placement of an internal stent in the hepaticojejunostomy, and 
fascial closure with SurgiMend biologic material; no further 
resection of the liver was performed.  2 drains were placed, the 
superior above the anastamosis and the inferior in the liver 
bed. 

On ___, Palliative Care was involved with possibility of 
discussing plan/goals of care. Discussion of tracheostomy was 
also initiated.  Hemodynamic management with occasional pressors 
and blood products and respiratory management with the vent were 
continued.  

On ___, patient desaturated to the ___ with CXR demonstrating 
right pleural effusion; a lasix drip was initiated and tube 
feeds were resumed; TID albumin was also initiated.  The lasix 
drip was continued into ___ with excellent diuresis of -3 
liters.  The wound vac dressing was also changed.  

A repeat CT scan of the chest/abdomen/pelvis was performed ___ 
due to fevers of 101; this scan demonstrated right pleural 
effusion with hemorrhagic component and a 10.8 x 8.6 cm fluid 
collection between the rectum and the uterus as well as a 
newly-visualized left external iliac vein clot and a 
non-occlusive thrombus within the left CFV.  The following day, 
___, ___ placed a pigtail catheter into the pleural effusion 
(850cc immediate output) and a trans-vaginal drain into the 
pelvic collection (400cc murky fluid produced).  The lasix drip 
was continued, but in late evening, the patient was 
intermittently hypotensive to ___ - lasix gtt decreased.  

Patient ultimately underwent percutaneous tracheostomy on ___.  
Ms. ___ mental status was improved as well that morning 
when she was intermittently following commands.  She 
unfortunately did not maintain this improved mental status and 
was non-communicative from that afternoon until the end of her 
course; she also intermittently required neo overnight, although 
the lasix drip was continued.  

On ___, Vascular Surgery was consulted for placement of IVC 
filter and requested LENIs of the bilateral lower extremities to 
assess the left common femoral vein thrombus and external iliac 
vein clot seen on the CT scan ___.  The ultrasound study 
demonstrated no evidence of deep vein thrombosis in the 
bilateral lower extremities and so IVC filter placement was 
deferred.  

Over that weekend, the patient's conditioned worsened.  She 
required 3uFFP and a left IJ triple lumen was placed on ___, and 
diffuse oozing from trach and peripheral IV sites was noted on 
___ she received 2u FFP, 1u platelets, and 4 units PRBCs. CT 
chest/torso that day showed evidence of ARDS and small R 
pneumothorax, stable splenic infarcts, portal and hepatic vein 
patent, hepatic artery seen proximally patent; she spiked to 
101.9 and was pan cultured. Pt self d'ced right radial a line; 
left ulnar a-line was placed under ultrasound.  

Repeat CT of the pelvis on ___ for continued fevers showed no 
drainable collection. ID was consulted for sputum cultures 
growing carbapenem-resistant e. coli. Meropenem was switched to 
extended release 1000mg Q8H. Respiratory status worsened, 
possibly secondary to diffuse micro PEs as evidenced by 
apparently absence on ultrasound of the previously seen ___ 
clots, and so ___ was consulted for IVC filter placement, which 
was performed on ___.  Her right chest pigtail catheter was 
also removed.  

Throughout this course, bilirubin had been slowly uptrending.  
Ms. ___ underwent ultrasound on ___ which demonstrated no 
evidence of biliary dilation.  The patient was stated on 
phenobarbital 40 BID for hyperbilirubinemia.  She was febrile to 
101.9 and cultures were sent on ___.  No cultures were 
positive; her last positive cultures were were the sputum 
cultures with e. coli ___. 

Diuresis with lasix drip was continued and she was alkylotic to 
7.50 although only intermittently on pressors. Total bilirubin 
continued to rise despite the phenobarb. and was in the ___ on 
___.  SHe was again febrile to 102 @ 4AM on ___ a family 
meeting that afternoon confirmed the family's understanding of 
the patient's poor prognosis. Phenobarbital was discontinued.  

Over the weekend, the patient was not following commands and had 
persistent tachycardia.  She also was noted on labs to have 
persistant respiratory and metabolic alkalosis and so a hydrogen 
chloride drit was started with lasix held.  On ___, right 
facial ticking consistent with seizures was noted. Patient 
received 6 mg lorazepam and 2 mg midazolam without effect and so 
was bolused 2 g keppra and started 1 g BID. EEG monitoring 
ordered. Patient discussed with ___. and was 
phenobarbital-loaded.  A propofol drip was started and MAPs 
down-trended; Ms. ___ was placed on neo gtt again. 

A head CT on ___ AM showed loss of gray-white matter 
differentiation globally with sulcal effacement, suggestive of 
anoxic brain injury; pupils were noted to be fixed after the 
head CT. Patient was started on a midazolam drip and then was 
started on on a pentabarbital drip. Total bilirubin that evening 
was over 50 with a rising white blood cell count and rising 
creatinine.  A family meeting took place and it was decided that 
there would be no escalation of care, and the patient was made 
DNR. Overnight, she began to require two pressors and so levo 
was added to the already-running neo.  

On the morning of ___, the patient's condition was 
worsening and she required neo, levo, and vaso for blood 
pressure support with systolic blood pressures principally in 
the ___.  The Transplant Surgery and ICU teams discussed the 
possibility of comfort measures only with the family, and Ms. 
___ family, after discussion, elected to enact comfort 
measures only for the patient.  

Pressors and the vent were discontinued and Ms. ___ passed 
away at 14:52 with family at the bedside.  The office of the 
Medical Examiner was contacted and the case was declined.  Ms. 
___ family declined the offer of an autopsy.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 34-year-old female who was admitted for a left hepatic trisegmentectomy with roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy due to cholangiocarcinoma involving and invading the left lobe of the liver with multiple satellites. The patient had a history of stage T2bN2Mx perihilar cholangiocarcinoma, which was diagnosed 7 months prior to admission. She had undergone 7 cycles of gemcitabine and cisplatin chemotherapy and CyberKnife radiation therapy prior to surgery.

The patient's past medical history includes asthma, obesity, vitamin D deficiency, sickle cell trait, depression, and chronic back pain. She has also had several hospitalizations for abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, as well as cholangitis, and has undergone ERCP and stent placement.

The patient's diagnosis was confirmed by a liver biopsy, and she underwent a left hepatic trisegmentectomy with roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, as well as other procedures including washout, oversewing bowel, PV thrombectomy, open abdomen, and tracheostomy. At discharge, the patient was prescribed medications including antibiotics and pain medication.

 ||endoftext||

You were admitted to the hospital follow placement of your two 
right sided biliary drains. After your procedure, you developed 
a blood stream infection that requires intravenous antibiotics. 
You were placed on the correct antibiotic regimen and you are 
now ready for your discharge home. Please follow the below 
instructions:
.
Please call the transplant clinic at ___ for fever of 
101 or greater, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, 
constipation, inability to tolerate food, fluids or medications, 
worsening yellowing of skin or eyes, increased abdominal pain, 
drain site redness, drainage or bleeding, dizziness or weakness, 
decreased urine output or dark, cloudy urine, swelling of 
abdomen or ankles, weight gain of 3 pounds in a day or any other 
concerning symptoms.
.
You are being sent home with bile drain bags in the event you 
have fevers and are instructed to uncap the drains. Only do this 
if instructed by the transplant clinic
.
Bring your pill box and list of current medications to every 
clinic visit.
.
You will need to have labs drawn on ___ and ___ 
___ then labwork drawn twice weekly for your antibiotic 
therapy. OK to be done at ___ on ___.
.
Follow your medication card, keep it updated with any dosage 
changes, and always bring your card with you to any clinic or 
hospital visits.
.
You may shower. Allow the water to run over your incision and 
pat area dry. No rubbing, no lotions or powder near the 
incision. You may leave the incision open to the air. 
.
No tub baths or swimming
.
No driving if taking narcotic pain medications
.
Avoid direct sun exposure. Wear protective clothing and a hat, 
and always wear sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher when you go 
outdoors.
.
Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light in color. Your 
appetite will return with time. Eat small frequent meals, and 
you may supplement with things like carnation instant breakfast 
or Ensure.
.
Check your blood pressure at home. Report consistently elevated 
values above 160 systolic to the transplant clinic
.
Do not increase, decrease, stop or start medications without 
consultation with the transplant clinic at ___. There 
are significant drug interactions with anti-rejection 
medications which must be considered in medication management 
following transplant.
.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 60-year-old male who was admitted for a re-do craniectomy and Medpore cranioplasty procedure due to a meningioma recurrence. He had a history of meningioma, atrial fibrillation, right shoulder separation, hyperlipidemia, and left ear conduction hearing loss. He also had a past history of craniotomy, vasectomy, and tonsillectomy. The patient had allergies to environmental allergens.

During his hospital stay, the patient underwent a re-do craniectomy and Medpore cranioplasty procedure, as well as a revisional anastomosis of the left superficial temporal vein and irrigation. He was also treated with antibiotics and pain medications.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. He was prescribed several medications, including aspirin, docusate sodium, oxyCODONE, rifampin, and vancomycin. The patient was discharged home with service and was advised to follow up with his healthcare provider as instructed. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was admitted on ___ for closure of an ileostomy. The 
patient tolerated the procedure well without complications. On 
POD1, the patient complained of considerable pain. She was 
continued on a Dilaudid PCA.  Of note, the patient has had a 
history of drug abuse in the past and there was some concern 
about the use of a Dilaudid PCA for pain management. On POD1, 
the patient was started on Ativan, Toradol and Tramadol in 
addition to the Dilaudid PCA for better pain control. The pain 
service was consulted on POD2 to provide suggestions for pain 
management. We consulted the Acute Pain Service for 
recommendations for pain control. They recommended dilaudid 
intravenously for breakthrough pain. On POD2, the patient had a 
bowel movement and was tolerating clears. Psychiatry was 
consulted because the patient had been acting out and was being 
disrespectful to members of the staff. Psychiatry evaluated the 
patient and recommended sqitchign her to her anti-anxiety and 
sleep regimen. On POD3, the patient passed gas and was producing 
greater than 1L in stool. There was concern for possible C. 
difficile infection. Her stool was negative for C. diff. She was 
started on imodium and metamucil wafers on POD4 and the patient 
had decreased stool output. The patient was discharged on POD6 
with instructions to continue the imodium and metamucil wafers. 
She was sent home on ultram and tylenol for pain control.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent a left ___ toe amputation. You have now recovered from 
surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please follow the 
instructions below to continue your recovery:

ACTIVITY: 
 On the side of your amputation (left) you are heel-weight 
bearing for ___ weeks. 
 You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever 
possible. 
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots.
 No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. 

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
 You may shower when you get home
 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery 

WOUND CARE:
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal. 
 When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place 
pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.

CAUTIONS:
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.  
DIET:
 Low fat, low cholesterol / if you are diabetic  follow your 
dietary restrictions as before 
CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
 Bleeding, redness of, or drainage from your foot wound
 New pain, numbness or discoloration of the skin on the 
effected foot
 Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or 
pus draining from the incision site. 

Sincerely,
___ Vascular Surgery

___
target: ||startoftext|| The patient is an 87-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for left toe gangrene. She has a past medical history of peripheral vascular disease, coronary artery disease, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and left lower extremity ischemic disease. She was previously treated with revascularization and had a two-week outpatient course of Augmentin before being admitted for amputation of the left toe. The patient underwent a left toe amputation and tolerated the procedure well without complications. She was discharged one week after surgery and was prescribed medications including digoxin, NPH, isosorbide mononitrate, ketoconazole, levothyroxine, metoprolol, omeprazole, prednisone, simvastatin, acetaminophen, docusate sodium, lisinopril, nitroglycerin, warfarin, and clindamycin. The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician and to contact the office if she experiences any bleeding, redness, or drainage from the foot wound, new pain, numbness, or discoloration of the skin on the affected foot, or fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus draining from the incision site. ||endoftext||

She has a history of depression, anorexia nervosa, and gastritis. Her past medical history includes a psychiatric admission for weight loss and a previous diagnosis of gastritis with H. pylori positivity. She has also had a 1mm non-obstructing right renal stone seen on CT scan 4 months ago.

She underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) which revealed a small hiatal hernia and erythema in the antrum compatible with gastritis. 

The patient's medications at discharge include a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and a standing GI cocktail. Her diagnosis includes gastritis and possibly a tiny renal stone. ||endoftext||

Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Endovascular Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) Discharge 
Instructions

Medications:
Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily 
Do not stop Aspirin unless your Vascular Surgeon instructs you 
to do so. 
Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort

What to expect when you go home:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
appetite will return with time 
Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs
You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate
No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications
Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in ___ weeks for 
post procedure check and CTA 

What to report to office:
Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
Bleeding from groin puncture site

SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site or 
incision)
Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm 
pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call 
vascular office. If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for 
transfer to closest Emergency Room. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

||startoftext|| The patient is a 66-year-old male who was admitted for an enlarging infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. He has a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, coronary angioplasty and stenting, hypertension, and cholecystectomy. He has no known allergies to drugs. The patient underwent a successful endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure and was discharged in good condition.

The patient's medications at discharge include lisinopril, pravastatin, metoprolol succinate, clopidogrel, and oxycodone-acetaminophen. He is advised to take aspirin 325mg once daily and to continue all other medications unless otherwise directed. The patient is also instructed to follow a regular diet, drink plenty of fluids, and avoid heavy lifting, pushing, or pulling for one week.

The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment in one month with a computed tomography angiogram (CTA). He is advised to report any numbness, coldness, or pain in his lower extremities, temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours, new or increased drainage from the incision, or bleeding from the groin puncture site. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 61-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of s/p DDLT, elevated LFTs, and hyponatremia. He has a history of HCV cirrhosis and HCC, and has undergone a deceased donor liver transplant with Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. He has also had complications such as biliary stricture, hepatic artery thrombosis, sepsis, VRE bacteremia, malnutrition, biloma, and multiple intraabdominal collections.

The patient's allergies include NSAIDs. He has a history of insulin-dependent diabetes, HCV cirrhosis, HCC, and other medical conditions.

The patient's diagnosis is not explicitly stated in the report, but it appears that he has a biliary stricture and hyponatremia.

The patient underwent a cholangiogram and manipulation of his drain, and was found to have occlusion of the distal portion of his PTBD. He was exchanged for a new internal-external PTBD, which was attached to a bag for external drainage.

The patient's medications at discharge include acetaminophen, aspirin, benzonatate, cefepime, clopidogrel, daptomycin, docusate sodium, enoxaparin sodium, fluconazole, gabapentin, hydrocodone, insulin, olanzapine, pantoprazole, polyethylene glycol, prednisone, psyllium powder, sulfameth/trimethoprim, and tacrolimus.

The patient's physical exam on admission showed him to be well appearing, with no scleral icterus, midline trachea, and neck supple. His vital signs were normal, and his abdomen was soft, nontender, and nondistended. His drains were producing scant turbid bilious drainage.

The patient's labs on admission showed elevated LFTs and hyponatremia, but his labs at discharge showed improvement in these values. His blood culture was negative.

The patient's plan for continued drain management is to exchange his PTBD and abscess drain in 4 weeks. He will continue to receive IV antibiotics and will be discharged home on the same regimen of daptomycin and cefepime via his existing PICC line. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with metastatic squamous cell lung carcinoma, COPD, and 
paranoid schizophrenia, who presented with acute on chronic 
respiratory failure, hypotension, and febrile neutropenia.

The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure was felt to be 
multifactorial, in the setting o baseline severe COPD, recurrent 
aspirations, pneumonia, chronic pleural effusions, and post 
radiation injury. He required intubation in the ED on arrival 
and had to be reintubated later in his ICU course.  His care was 
further complicated by severe agitation and progression of 
hypoxic respiratory failure.

The patient's outpatient oncologist was involved in his care 
while admitted. Given the clinical decline and overall poor 
prognosis, numerous lengthy discussions were had with the 
patient's court appointed guardian and the care teams involved. 
The decision was made to transition comfort focused care. The 
patient was palliatively extubated. He passed away peacefully 
with family at bedside.

He presented to the emergency department after an unwitnessed fall and was found to be febrile, tachycardic, and desaturated. ||startoftext|| The patient is a 58-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for surgical correction of an underling deformity in her right foot. She has a history of diabetes, depression, and hypertension. She is allergic to penicillins and bee pollens. Her chief complaint was a foot ulcer and hammer toes in her right foot. She underwent flexor tenotomies and metatarsal head resection.

The patient's physical examination revealed afebrile and stable vital signs, with palpable pedal pulses and normal sensation and proprioception in her extremities. Her ulceration was described as a partial thickness sub-metatarsal head ulcer with a granular base and regular margins.

The patient's discharge medications included bisacodyl, vitamin E, multivitamin, citalopram, byetta, albuterol, lisinopril, oxybutynin, simvastatin, spironolactone, fluticasone, metformin, clonazepam, trazodone, linezolid, acetaminophen, and docusate sodium. She was also prescribed a wheelchair with removable arm rests and elevating leg lifts.

The patient was discharged in good condition with instructions to resume all pre-admission medications, keep her dressing clean and dry, and remain non-weight bearing on her right foot in a surgical shoe with crutches at all times. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 79-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital after a motor vehicle accident (MVA). She has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and COPD. She was involved in a MVC, but does not remember the event. She complained of right-sided chest pain and diffuse back pain, and was found to have normal vital signs and laboratory results. She was diagnosed with a mild back strain and was prescribed pain medication. She also has a history of asthma/COPD, GERD, and a pacemaker for tachy/brady arrhythmia. She has no known allergies or adverse reactions. The patient's physical examination was normal, with the exception of some minor abrasions on her knees. She was discharged with a diagnosis of a mild back strain and was prescribed pain medication. ||endoftext||

The patient's presenting symptoms were chest pain and dyspnea on exertion, which worsened over a week. He also experienced right-sided chest pain that radiated to his left neck. 

The patient underwent cardiac catheterization and percutaneous coronary revascularization, which revealed 80% proximal LAD stenosis. The procedure was successful, and the patient was discharged with a diagnosis of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction.

Abdominal colectomy, ileostomy.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with medically-refractory ulcerative colitis, who presented 
this admission for total abdominal colectomy with ileoanal pouch 
or end ileostomy.

___ Pathology 
DIAGNOSIS:  
1. Abdominal colon, colectomy (A-L): 
Chronic active colitis. Unremarkable ileum. 
2. Sigmoid colon, colectomy (M-X): 
Chronic active colitis.  
3. Omentum, resection (Y-AA): 
Unremarkable omentum. 
Note: Mucosal granulomas are present focally related to injured 
crypts. This finding is not specific and may be related to crypt 
rupture in any inflammatory condition, including ulcerative 
colitis. No fissures or transmural inflammation are seen. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was brought to the pre-operative area, evaluated by 
anesthesia, and taken to the OR on ___ and underwent a 
total abdominal colectomy and end ileostomy as the small bowel 
was unable to be brought down for J-pouch (please refer to 
operative note for complete detail). Patient tolerated to the 
procedure well and was brought to the PACU for a short recovery 
before being brought to the floor.  

Neuro: Post operatively the patient received an epidural with 
good effect and adequate pain control of operative sight but had 
reports of shoulder pain and was started on IV tylenol.  Patient 
continued to report pain and was started on toradol on POD 1 for 
a 3 day coarse with good effect.  On POD1 patient reported some 
right leg motor weakness when attempting to ambulate and 
epidural was turned down by the Acute Pain Service with 
improvement of function, with full restoration after epidural 
was discontinued.  On POD 2 when tolerating oral intake, the 
patient was transitioned to PO oxycodone and tylenol with good 
effect.

CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.  Patient 
reported shoulder pain post-operatively that radiated into his 
chest and an EKG was obtained which was sinus rhythm without 
evidence of ischemia, with a few PVCs.  Electrolytes were 
normal.  Pain was noted to be sharp in character and unrelated 
to exertion.

Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization.

GI/GU/FEN: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO with IV 
fluids. Diet was advanced to sips on POD1, and to full liquids 
on POD2, which was well tolerated.  Patient began to have stool 
and gas in ostomy and diet was advanced to POD2 to a regular 
diet.  Ostomy continued to put out gas and stool throughout this 
admission but was not putting out large volumes.  Patient was 
kept until POD 5 to continue ostomy teaching and to monitor 
ostomy output.  Patient's intake and output were closely 
monitored, and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary.  
Electrolytes were routinely followed, and repleted when 
necessary.  Patient retained a foley with his epidural, and 
foley was discontinued on POD2 after epidural was pulled and 
patient voided without incident.

ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were 
closely watched for signs of infection, of which there were 
none.  The incision remained clean, dry, and intact throughout 
this admission. 

Endocrine: The patient's blood sugar was monitored throughout 
his stay; insulin dosing was adjusted accordingly.

Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined 
routinely; no transfusions were required.

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding well, and pain was well controlled.  
The patient received discharge teaching and ___ 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.  Patient was set up with a visiting nurse 
and stated ___ continue to follow up with the ostomy team 
for his continued care. 
 
Medications on Admission:
MVI, probiotics
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as 
needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Chronic ulcerative colitis, medically refractory.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
___ were admitted to the inpatient general surgery unit. ___ 
have adequate pain control and have a tolerated a regular diet 
and may go home to continue your recovery.  

Please continue to monitor your ileostomy output. The most 
common complication from a new ileostomy placement is 
dehydration. The output from the stoma is stool from the small 
intestine and the water content is very high. The stool is no 
longer passing through the large intestine which is where the 
water from the stool is reabsorbed into the body and the stool 
becomes formed. ___ must measure your ileostomy output for the 
next few weeks. The output from the stoma should not be more 
than 1200 cc or less than 500 cc. If ___ find that your output 
has become too much or too little, please call the office for 
advice. The office nurse can recommend medications to increase 
or slow the ileostomy output. Keep yourself well hydrated, if 
___ notice your ileostomy output increasing, take in more 
electrolyte drink such as gatoraide. Please monitor yourself for 
signs and symptoms of dehydration including: dizziness 
(especially upon standing), weakness, dry mouth, headache, or 
fatigue. If ___ notice these symptoms please call the office or 
return to the emergency room for evaluation if these symptoms 
are severe. ___ may eat a modified regular diet with your new 
ileostomy.  

Please monitor the appearance of the ostomy and stoma and care 
for it as instructed by the wound/ostomy nurses. ___ stoma 
(intestine that protrudes outside of your abdomen) should be 
beefy red or pink, it may ooze small amounts of blood at times 
when touched and this should subside with time. The skin around 
the ostomy site should be kept clean and intact. Monitor the 
skin around the stoma for buldging or signs of infection listed 
above. Please care for the ostomy as ___ have been instructed by 
the wound/ostomy nurses. ___ will be able to make an appointment 
with the ostomy nurse in the clinic. A visiting nurse ___ who 
will help ___ monitor your ostomy until ___ are comfortable 
caring for it on your own. ___ have a long vertical incision on 
your abdomen that is closed with staples. This incision can be 
left open to air or covered with a dry sterile gauze dressing if 
the staples become irritated from clothing. The staples will 
stay in place until your first post-operative visit at which 
time they can be removed in the clinic, most likely by the 
office nurse. Please monitor the incision for signs and symptoms 
of infection including: increasing redness at the incision, 
opening of the incision, increased pain at the incision line, 
draining of white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, or if ___ 
develop a fever. 

Please call the office if ___ develop these symptoms or go to 
the emergency room if the symptoms are severe.  ___ may shower, 
let the warm water run over the incision line and pat the area 
dry with a towel, do not rub. 

No heavy lifting for at least 6 weeks after surgery unless 
instructed otherwise by your surgeon.  

___ will be prescribed a small amount of the pain medication. 
___ may take Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take 
more than 4000 mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while 
taking narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive 
a car while taking narcotic pain medication. 

Thank ___ for allowing us to participate in your care. Our hope 
is that ___ will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Best wishes.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

He has a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, diabetes, and end-stage renal disease. He is on immunosuppression and has a history of pericarditis. On admission, his vital signs were normal, and his physical exam was notable for mild cardiomegaly and no signs of edema. His laboratory results showed mild anemia, elevated creatinine, and abnormal liver function tests.

The patient was treated with diltiazem and was asymptomatic on the floor. His discharge medications included diltiazem, metoprolol, warfarin, and immunosuppressive therapy. His discharge physical exam was normal, with no signs of cardiac or respiratory distress.

The patient has a significant family history of cardiovascular disease, including hypertension, diabetes, and cardiomyopathy. He also has a history of depression, allergic rhinitis, and gastrointestinal ulcers.

The patient's allergies include iron, adhesive tape, and shellfish-derived products. His past medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic kidney disease, and depression.

The patient's diagnosis is atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and his treatment plan includes anticoagulation therapy and rate control with diltiazem. ||endoftext||

was then cannulated with a JR 4 guide. The distal lesion was

___ yo woman with H/O hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus 
who presented with 2 hours of sharp left sided chest pain with 
elevated troponin indicative of an NSTEMI, now s/p drug eluting 
stents to the RCA and LCX.

NSTEMI: Patient presented with chest pain and elevated troponin. 
Peak CK-MB 17, peak troponin-T 0.37. Cardiac catheterization 
revealed LVEDP 12. LMCA was normal, LAD had diffuse 
irregularities with <50% proximal disease. LCx had a long 
segment of mid disease to 90%, RCA was diffusely calcified with 
<50% irregularities and a focal 90% lesion proximal to the 
distal bifurcation. Drug eluting stents were placed in the left 
circumflex and right coronary artery. Patient was chest pain 
free post procedure (radial access) without any complications. 
Echocardiogram identified mild symmetric LVH with preserved 
regional and global biventricular systolic function, 
mild-moderate mitral regurgitation, and mild pulmonary artery 
systolic hypertension

Her atorvastatin dose was increased to 80 mg for secondary

along with lifelong aspirin. Nebivolol was changed to metoprolol 
while inpatient but switched back on discharge. Nitroglycerin 
was prescribed in case of future symptoms. Physical therapy saw 
the patient after her procedure and recommended cardiac 
rehabilitation.

orthostatic and was given gentle IV fluid hydration but 
orthostasis persisted. Lack of HR response was suggestive of 
autonomic dysfunction possibly due to longstanding diabetes 
mellitus. She was stable and chest pain free on discharge. She 
was cleared for discharge by physical therapy.

Asymptomatic Bactiuria: Of note, routine urine culture grew 
>100,000 E coli. However, the patient was completely 
asymptomatic and without pyuria so was not treated with 
antibiotics. Should she develop symptoms as an outpatient, she 
should be treated.

checked as outpatient and regimen adjusted accordingly.

becomes symptomatic in the future.

||startoftext|| The patient is an 84-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of chest pain. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and mild aortic stenosis. She presented with 2 hours of sharp left-sided chest pain, which improved after being given aspirin and nitroglycerin. Her past medical history includes pernicious anemia, osteoporosis, and cataract.

The patient's diagnosis was non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), and she underwent cardiac catheterization with drug-eluting stent placement in the right coronary artery (RCA) and left circumflex (LCX) arteries. Her medications at discharge included atorvastatin 80 mg, clopidogrel 75 mg daily, and aspirin lifelong, as well as metoprolol and nitroglycerin as needed.

The patient's physical examination was notable for a regular rhythm, normal s1 and s2, and a II/VI systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. Her laboratory results showed elevated troponin-T levels, with a peak value of 0.37. Her echocardiogram revealed mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved regional and global biventricular systolic function, mild-moderate mitral regurgitation, and mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

The patient's urine culture grew Escherichia coli and Corynebacterium species, and her electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm with LVH and new T wave inversion in aVL. Her chest X-ray showed mild cardiomegaly with no congestion or edema. ||endoftext||

since ___ CT.  Additional bilateral 5mm pulmonary nodules 
are too small for PET characterization. 
2.  FDG avid central lymphadenopathy.  A precarinal lymph node 
has increased in size since ___. 
3.  Diffuse osseous metastatic disease, as described above.   
4.  Focal FDG uptake in the left adrenal gland, compatible with 
metastatic disease. 
5.  Subtle increased FDG activity in the left hepatic lobe, 
likely correspond to hypodense hepatic lesions seen on ___ 
CT, suggestive of metastatic disease. 
6.  Known intracranial metastatic lesion, both in supra and 
infratentorial locations, are better assess on dedicated CT head 
of ___. 
7.  FDG avid pelvic and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy. 
8.  Large left retropsoas mass is FDG avid. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with squamous cell carcinoma metastatic to the posterior 
fossa (s/p prophylactic VPS and XRT to mets) who presents with 
worsening of a 3-week headache and acute onset of nausea.

# Headache/Nausea (resolved): 
When the patient initially presented with severe headache and 
nausea ___ morning, CT was obtained showing progression of 
disease within the brain (increase in both size and number of 
lesions). However, since the patient had undergone three WBRT 
treatments by this point, it was unclear whether the patient's 
symptoms were being caused by progression of metastatic disease 
vs. side effect from radiation (edema, possibly necrosis). The 
patient then resumed his whole brain radiation therapy, as well 
as being started on high-dose dexamethasone 6 mg IV every 6 
hours.  These steroids improved his symptoms dramatically - 
helping him ambulate with a walker, eat well, and lose his 
headache.  His blood glucose was monitored BID and remained in 
the low 100s. He will have ___ services to check his blood sugar 
every other day, and will be continued on pantoprazole given his 
steroid dose. Consideration of duration of therapy of steroids 
to be decided in follow-up. 

# Metastatic Squamous Cell Carcinoma: 
According to a recent PET scan, the patient's SCC was seen to be 
metastatic to many locations in addition to the brain: the 
precarinal lymph node, bone, left adrenal gland, left hepatic 
lobe, supra and infratentorial locations, pelvic and 
retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, and left retropsoas mass. Given 
the extensive disease burden in the patient's body (outside the 
head), no therapeutics were given to offer local control.  For 
the disease in his head, however, it was decided the patient 
ought to continue his remaining 7 out of 10 WBRT doses, and be 
watched closely for radiation necrosis/edema by his radiation 
oncologist.

You finished your fourth dose of radiation yesterday, are

your ten doses as per schedule. As of this morning, on

Please continue your Radiation Oncology appointments, as well as

||startoftext|| The patient is a 64-year-old man who presents with a 3-week history of worsening headache and acute onset of nausea. He has a history of squamous cell carcinoma, diagnosed 5 years ago, which has metastasized to the posterior fossa. He has undergone prophylactic VP shunt placement and XRT to the metastases. The patient's past medical history includes prostate cancer, BPH, cervical disc herniation, L ulnar nerve injury, and DJD.

The patient's physical exam on admission showed a normal vital sign, with no fever, chills, confusion, cough, or shortness of breath. His neurological exam revealed weakness in his left leg and arm, transient trouble seeing, and imbalance. He was also experiencing constipation, which he attributed to his Oxycodone medication.

The patient's laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 12.7, hemoglobin of 15.7, and platelet count of 5.22. His blood glucose level was 119, and his lactate level was 2.8.

The patient's diagnosis is metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, with lesions in the brain, mediastinum, right hilar, right paratracheal lymph nodes, liver, left psoas muscle, and left external iliac and common iliac chain lymph nodes. He has undergone whole brain radiation therapy and has been prescribed high-dose dexamethasone to manage his symptoms.

The patient's medications at discharge include pantoprazole and Oxycodone. He will continue to receive whole brain radiation therapy and will be monitored for radiation necrosis/edema. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ y.o. male with PMH of HCV cirrhosis 
SVR s/p Solvadi (___), previously c/b Grade II-III varices s/p 
TIPS (___), HTN who presents after being found down with 
shock, AMS requiring intubation, and ARF, found to be in 
refractory convulsive status epiliepticus possibly due to 
infective encephalitis. MRI eventually revealed diffuse anoxic 
brain injury with poor prognosis for recovery. In light of this, 
his HCP and family elected to transition him to ___ focused 
care. He terminally extubated and died peacefully ___ 01:34 
with family at his bedside. 

For posterity, his hospital course is as follows:

# Encephalopathy:
# Refractory convulsive status epilepticus: 
# Suspected meningitis vs encephalitis
Likely multifactorial with contributions from seizures, 
toxic/metabolic (uremia, HE), infection, possible hypoxemic 
injury. Seizures suppressed on Keppra, VPA, midazolam, Propofol; 
this was changed to keppra, lacosamide (VPA d/c'd given hepatic 
clearance).  Propofol discontinued. Midazolam slowly weaned. 
Treated TME with aggressive lactulose w/rifaximin, although 
lactulose discontinued in setting of lower GIB as below. 
Maintained on vanc / cefepime / ampicillin / acyclovir at 
meningitic dosing. LP not performed due to coagulopathy.

# Shock / Lactic Acidosis: There was concern for septic, most 
likely of CNS origin given substrate and CSE. Empiric Cefepime, 
Vanc, Ampicillin, & Acyclovir all renally-adjusted for suspected 
meningitis vs encephalitis. Was also on doxycycline from 
___ but discontinued once lyme felt to be less likely. 
CDiff neg. Urine cx +ve for enterococcus.  No ascites to tap as 
of u/s ___. He was briefly on norepinephrine and vasopressin 
but was able to be weaned.  Received thiamine 500mg IV Q8H x 2 
days then 250mg IV QD x 5 days for lactic acidosis. 

# Non-Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: felt to be due to sepsis and 
prerenal etiology vs ATN. Resolved with fluids and improved 
perfusion.

# Acute Respiratory Failure: Intubated initially for airway 
protection in setting of encephalopathy. P:F > 200, likely due 
to encephalopathy c/b aspiration. He was placed on low tidal 
volume ventilation and required paralysis for vent compliance; 
paralytics discontinued ___. He was terminally extubated 
___

# Coagulopathy: likely due to cirrhosis; received IV Vit K x 3 
days and FFP PRN INR > 1.5 for procedures. RUQUS showed patent 
TIPS flow and no other acute changes.

# Acute blood loss anemia: Bright red blood per rectum on ___ 
in flexiseal. s/p 2u FFP, DDAVP, and 1u Platelets. Gastric 
lavage ___ without e/o UGIB. GI consulted, likely LGIB from 
rectal ulcer w flexiseal. He was placed on octreotide gtt and IV 
PPI BID although UGIB felt to be less likely

||startoftext|| The patient is a 64-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital after being found down. He has a history of chronic hepatitis C, cirrhosis, and previous treatment with Solvadi, which resulted in SVR. He also has a history of hypertension, asthma, diabetes mellitus, lumbar radiculopathy, and seizure disorder. The patient was intubated and sedated due to his altered mental status and was found to have a possible clot in the superior mesenteric vein. He was treated with Lovenox and was planned for transfer to a different hospital due to his medical complexity. However, he was admitted briefly to the ICU due to delayed timing in the emergency department. The patient's laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, kidney function abnormalities, and anemia. He was diagnosed with septic shock and presumed right lower lobe pneumonia, and was treated with antibiotics and vasopressors. The patient's condition deteriorated, and he was eventually discharged deceased.

Note: The patient's discharge medications are not specified in the report. ||endoftext||

___ 03:10AM BLOOD Calcium-9.6 Phos-4.4 Mg-2.0
.
MICROBIOLOGY: none
.
IMAGING: 
___ CXR: No acute intrathoracic process.
.
___ ECHO: The left atrium is elongated. No atrial septal 
defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall 
thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is 
normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic 
dysfunction with focal distal septal/apical hypokinesis. No 
masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. There is no 
ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and 
free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the 
sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve 
leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet 
excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The 
mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral 
regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The estimated 
pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no 
pericardial effusion.
.
___ Cardiac MRI:
1. Normal left ventricular cavity size. Hypokinesis of the mid 
and distal septum and the apex with preserved systolic function. 
The LVEF was normal at 60%. The effective forward LVEF was 
normal at 61%. CMR evidence of recent myocardial 
scarring/infarction with increased T2 signal and transmural late 
gadolinium enhancement of the mid and distal septum and the 
apex.
2. Normal right ventricular cavity size and systolic function. 
The RVEF was normal at 67%.  
.
PROCEDURES:
___ Left Heart Cath: 
1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system 
demonstrated no obstructive coronary artery disease. The LMCA 
was normal. The LAD had long 30% lesion from the mid to distal 
portion of the vessel. The LCx and RCx were normal.
2. Limited resting hemodynamics demonstrated hight normal left 
sided filling pressures with an LVEDP of 13mm Hg.
3. Left ventriculography demonstrated normal ejection fraction 
of 60% with no apparent mitral regurgitation.  
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
1. No significant coronary artery disease.
2. Normal ventricular function. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with HTN and asthma transferred from an OSH 
for chest pain, ST depressions, and elevated troponin consistent 
with NSTEMI.
.
# Chest pain: Patient presented with chest pain, elevated 
troponin, and STE in V2 and TWI in V3, V4 concerning for an LAD 
lesion. The patient was continued on a heparin gtt, ASA, and 
Plavix. ECHO revealed mild regional left ventricular systolic 
dysfunction with focal distal septal/apical hypokinesis, 
concerning for infarct. Cardiac catheterization revealed a 30% 
distal LAD lesion, however no obstructive lesions. It was 
unclear whether this was a resolved thrombis vs myocarditis, 
therefore cardiac MRI was obtained which showed evidence of 
recent myocardial scarring/infarction with increased T2 signal 
and transmural late gadolinium enhancement of the mid and distal 
septum and the apex. Therefore, her chest pain was felt to be 
due to an NSTEMI with resolved thrombus. The patient was 
discharged on aspirin 325mg, Plavix 75mg, atorvastatin 80mg, 
metoprolol 12.5mg, and SL nitroglycerin prn. She has outpatient 
cardiology follow up. 
.
# Hypertension: Well-controlled. Continued home, lisinopril and 
started metoprolol.
.
# Asthma: Asymptomatic. Prednisone taper and theophylline were 
stopped. We continued Advair and albuterol inhaler prn.

You were admitted to the hospital for chest pain and were found

.
We made the following changes to your medications:

She initially presented to an outside hospital with chest pain and was given aspirin, Plavix, and metoprolol, but her pain persisted. She was transferred to the current hospital for further management. In the emergency department, she was found to have ST depression on her EKG and an elevated troponin level. She was started on a nitroglycerin drip, but her blood pressure dropped, and the drip was stopped. She was transferred to the floor, where she continued to experience intermittent episodes of mild chest pain.

The patient's diagnosis is not explicitly stated in the report, but it appears that she may have had a myocardial infarction or recent myocardial scarring/infarction based on the cardiac MRI findings. She underwent a left heart catheterization, which showed no obstructive coronary disease.

The patient was prescribed the following medications at discharge: aspirin, Plavix, metoprolol, and nitroglycerin. She has an allergy to erythromycin base.

The patient's physical examination was normal, with no abnormalities noted in her cardiovascular, respiratory, or abdominal systems. Her laboratory results showed elevated troponin and CK-MB levels, but her cardiac enzymes returned to normal levels over time. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
#Brain Lesion
Ms. ___ presented to the emergency department as a 
transfer from outside hospital, with a head CT notable for large 
area of hypodensity suggestive of vasogenic edema causing mass 
effect and shift of midline structures. She was admitted to the 
___ for treatment and surgical planning. She was started on 
dexamethasone and keppra. MRI was performed which demonstrated 
5.2 x 4.5 x 4.6 cm heterogeneously enhancing right 
temporoparietal mass, with moderate surrounding vasogenic edema 
and mass effect with 12 mm leftward midline shift and uncal 
herniation. Patient was taken to the OR on ___ for right 
craniotomy tumor resection. She tolerated the procedure well. 
Please see formal op report in OMR for further intra-operative 
details. She was transferred to the PACU post operatively where 
she remained stable and was later transferred to the floor. MRI 
was done on POD1 and showed normal post operative changes. On 
___ patient was noted to have anisicoria R>L, which was not 
noted the day prior. Her exam was otherwise stable. A NCHCT was 
obtained and showed no acute hemorrhages, and stable post op 
changes. Patient exam remained stable and she was changed to 
floor status.

#HTN
Patient had sustained hypertension post operatively requiring 
nicardipine drip. She was later weaned off the nicardipine drip 
and blood pressure was managed with prn hydral. Patient 
continued to require prn hydral daily for systolic blood 
pressures greater than 160. Therefore she was started on 
amlodipine 5mg daily. 

#Elevated INR & Low platelets 
Patient was noted to have uptrending INR. She received vitamin K 
prior to surgery with adequate response. INR downtrended and 
continued to be monitored closely and remained stable for 
remainder of admission. 

#Anxiety/Paranoia 
Patient had high anxiety during her admission with paranoia, 
stating she felt like the room was closing in on  her. Patient 
has history of anxiety, yet this was likely exacerbated by high 
doses of steroids. Patient steroid taper was accelerated to over 
1 week. She was written for her home Xanax prn and psychiatry 
was consulted for further management. Patient was stating that 
she wants to leave AMA. Psych evaluated the patient and patient 
agreed to stay until rehab placement. 

At the time of discharge she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating without difficulty, afebrile with stable vital signs.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Right temporoparietal brain mass
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory with assistance.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Surgery:
- You underwent surgery to remove a brain mass from your brain.
- You may shower at this time, but please keep your surgical 
incision dry until your sutures are removed. 
- It is best to keep your surgical incision open to air, but it 
is okay to cover it while outside. 
- Please call your neurosurgeon if there are any signs of 
infection, such as fever, redness, swelling, or drainage from 
the surgical incision.

Activity:
- You may take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity 
at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
- We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up.
- No driving while taking narcotics or any other sedating 
medications.
- If you have experienced a seizure, you are not allowed to 
drive by law.
- No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon.

Medications:
- You may use acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
- Please do not take any blood thinning medications, such as 
aspirin, clopidogrel (Plavix), ibuprofen, warfarin (Coumadin), 
etc. until cleared by your neurosurgeon.
- You have been discharged on levetiracetam (Keppra). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication as indicated. It is important that you take this 
medication consistently and on time.

What You ___ Experience:
- You may experience pain at the surgical incision and 
headaches.
- Feeling more tired or restless is common.
- You may also experience some postoperative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the ___ and ___ days after surgery. You may apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to help with this. It will be 
its worst in the morning after laying flat from sleeping, but 
should decrease once up.
- You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
- Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high fiber diet. You may also try and over-the-counter 
stool softener if needed.

Please Call Your Neurosurgeon At ___ If You Experience:
- Severe pain, redness, swelling, or drainage from the surgical 
incision.
- Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit.
- Severe headaches not relieved with prescribed pain 
medications.
- Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake.
- Nausea or vomiting.
- Seizures.
- Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or legs.
- Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak.

Call ___ And Go To The Nearest Emergency Department If You 
Experience Any Of The Following: 
- Sudden severe headaches with no known reason.
- Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding.
- Sudden weakness or numbness in the face, arms, or legs.
- Sudden dizziness, trouble walking, or loss of balance or 
coordination.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

age: 48. gender: F.  
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal Pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ s/p ERCP with Sx on ___ for CBD stone.  Now
presents with epigastric pain that started last night.  Seen at
OSH and U/S demonstrated PCF and large impacted gallstone and
transferred here for further eval. 
 
Past Medical History:
___
NKDA

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
no history of cancer
 
Physical Exam:
99.7 99.7 84 103/67 18 97RA
NAD/A&Ox3
CTAB
RRR
Abd Soft, Appropriately Tender, Nondistended
Wounds clean/dry/intact
 
Pertinent Results:
RUQ U/S (OSH): impacted 2-3cm stone in neck of the GB with wall
thickening, 4mm CBD
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was seen in the ED and admitted to the surgical 
service for management of acute cholecystitis. She was started 
on Unasyn perioperatively and taken to the OR for a laparoscopic 
cholecystectomy. This was performed without complication and the 
patient recovered from anesthesia without difficulty in the 
PACU. She was taken to the floor where the remainder of her 
recovery was uneventful. At the time of discharge her pain was 
well controlled, she was afebrile and tolerating a general diet 
without difficulty. The patient was discharged home with plan to 
follow up in the ___ clinic in 2 weeks, or earlier if she had 
any of the above listed symptoms or other new concerns. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Metrogel
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO TID (3 times 
a day).
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as 
needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute Cholecystitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain. This was 
determined to be from your gallbladder, and as a result, you had 
your gallbladder removed laparoscopically. 

General Discharge Instructions:
You have had an abdominal operation. This sheet goes over some 
questions and concerns you or your family may have. If you have 
additional questions, or ___ understand something about your 
operation, please call your surgeon.

ACTIVITY:
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs.
You may go outside. But avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
___ lift more than ___ pounds for 6 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. 
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common 
sense and go slowly at first. 
You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told you 
otherwise.
HOW YOU MAY FEEL:
You may feel weak or washed out for 6 weeks. You might want to 
nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. 
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You 
might feel somewhat depressed.
You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All these feelings and reactions are normal and should go away 
in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon.

YOUR INCISION:
Your incision may be slightly red around the stitches or 
staples. This is normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are the thin 
paper strips that might be on your incision.) But if they fall 
off before that, its OK.
It is normal to feel a firm ridge along the incision. This will 
go away.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming. 
Over the next ___ months, your incision will fade and become 
less prominent.
YOUR BOWELS:

Constipation is a common side effect of medicine such as 
Percocet or codeine. If needed, you may take a stool softener 
(such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as Milk 
of Magnesia, 1 tablespoon) twice a day. You can get both of 
these medicines without a prescription.

If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon.

After some operations, diarrhea can occur. If you get diarrhea, 
___ take anti-diarrhea medicines. Drink plenty of fluids and 
see if it goes away. If it does not go away, or is severe and 
you feel ill, please call your surgeon.
PAIN MANAGEMENT:

It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as soreness.
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription from your surgeon for pain 
medicine to take by mouth. It is important you take this 
medicine as directed. Do not take it more frequently than 
prescribed. Do not take more medicine at one time than 
prescribed.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please ___ take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said it is OK.  
If you are experiencing no pain, it is OK to skip a dose of pain 
medicine. 
To reduce pain, remember to exhale with any exertion or when you 
change positions. 
Remember to use your cough pillow for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
pain that is getting worse over time
pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain

MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently. 
In some cases, you will have a prescription for antibiotics or 
other medication.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
Worsening abdominal pain
Sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
Temperature of 101 degrees or higher 
___ My doctor:
Name:___________________________
Phone number:                                     _
Severe diarrhea
Vomiting
Redness around the incision that is spreading
Increased swelling around the incision
Excessive bruising around the incision
Cloudy fluid coming from the wound
Bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
An increase in drainage from the wound

 
Followup Instructions:
___

She had previously undergone ERCP with symptoms of CBD stone and was transferred to the hospital for further evaluation. The patient was diagnosed with acute cholecystitis and underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy without complications. She was started on Unasyn perioperatively and was discharged home with a plan to follow up in two weeks.

The patient's past medical history is notable for no known allergies to drugs. She has no history of cancer in her family. Her physical exam was normal, with soft and tender abdomen. Pertinent results include an RUQ US showing an impacted 2-3cm stone in the neck of the gallbladder with wall thickening and 4mm CBD.

The patient was prescribed acetaminophen 500mg tablet three times a day and oxycodone 5mg tablet as needed for pain. She was advised to avoid heavy exercise, lifting more than 10 pounds for six weeks, and to follow up with her surgeon in two weeks. The patient was also advised to take stool softeners or gentle laxatives if needed, and to contact her surgeon if she experiences worsening abdominal pain, sharp or severe pain, temperature of 101 degrees or higher, or severe diarrhea. ||endoftext||
