age: 63. gender: M.  
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Nonhealing right leg wound
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Right lower extremity angiography with Dr. ___
___: ___ Femoral to posterior tibial artery bypass with 
PTFE

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old gentleman with a history of 
bilateral lower extremity bypass grafts who presents with a 1 
week history of cellulitis of his right ___ toe. The patient has 
been followed by Dr. ___ as an outpatient regularly, and was 
being treated for a nonhealing ulcer on his third toe. He has
been taking levofloxacin and bactrim and has noticed some 
improvement. He has been afebrile and otherwise asymptomatic. Of 
note, he has been experiencing vertigo recently and has had a 
fall while getting out of bed approximately 2 days ago when he 
sustained a small laceration around his right eye. 

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: IDDM, HTN, GERD, CVA ___, CAD, CHF  

PSH: R fem-AK pop with PTFE, R BK ___ bpg with rev ___ cephalic 
vein 07, L fem-pt bypass w cephalic vein 03, CABG ___

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/C
 
Physical Exam:
PE on admission:
VS: Temp: 98.8 RR: 18 Pulse: 73 BP: 170/90  
Gen: Oriented x3, Affect Normal, NAD. 
Neck: No masses, Trachea midline. 
Nodes: No clavicular/cervical adenopathy. 
Skin: No atypical lesions. 
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. 
Lungs: Clear, Normal respiratory effort. 
Gastrointestinal: Non distended. 
Rectal: Not Examined. 
Extremities: No RLE edema, No LLE Edema. 
 
Pulse Exam (P=Palpation, D=Dopplerable, N=None)
LUE Radial: P. 
RLE Femoral: P. DP: N. ___: D. 
LLE Femoral: P. DP: D. ___: P. 

PE on discharge:
Gen: AAOx4, conversant, NAD
___: RRR, no M/R/G
Pulm: clear bilaterally
Abd: soft, nontender, nondistended
Ext: warm, well perfused, no cyanosis or edema. R leg incision 
clean, dry, and intact with staples.  No erythema, no drainage.
Neuro: CN II-XII grossly intact.  Gait baseline.
Pulses: R: Fem P, ___ D; L: Fem P, DP D, ___ P
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted on ___ for planned right lower 
extremity angiography in evaluation of his right foot nonhealing 
wound.  After appropriate preparation, bicarb administration, 
and informed consent, he underwent angiography of his right leg 
on ___.  The study revealed occlusion distal to the existing 
right bypass, and he was scheduled for revision of his bypass 
graft on ___.

On ___, neurology consultation was obtained, due to the 
patient's complaint of unsteady gait, subjective vertigo, and 
related nausea.  It was felt by the consultant, that his gait 
disturbance was a combination of possible vertigo, peripheral 
neuropathy, and retinopathy.  Meclizine was recommended on an as 
needed basis for treatment of nausea related to his vertigo.  No 
additional work up was necessary, and the team recommended 
neurology follow up on an as needed basis.

On ___, after appropriate preparation and informed consent, Mr. 
___ underwent right ___ femoral to posterior tibial 
artery bypass w PTFE without complication.  After intial 
recovery in the PACU, he was transferred to the vascular surgery 
floor for post-operative monitoring and recovery.  His pulse 
exam remained stable throughout the remainder of his hospital 
stay.  He was initially quite hypertensive through the first two 
post-operative days, requiring multiple doses of IV lopressor 
and hydralazine, and finally, a nitroglycerin drip.  On ___, he 
was weaned successfully from the IV drip, and his blood pressure 
normalized.  He was maintained on the distal lower extremity 
bypass pathway, and a heparin drip.  Coumadin was started on ___ 
and daily INRs were followed until therapeutic.  The heparin 
drip was then discontinued.  Mr. ___ was out of bed to a 
chair beginning on POD#2 and ambulating by ___.  On ___, he 
was cleared by physical therapy to go home with daily physical 
therapy and visiting nurse care.  He was tolerating a regular 
diet, and reported his pain controlled with oral pain 
medication.  He was deemed stable for discharge on ___ with 
follow-up in Dr. ___ in 2 weeks for wound check 
and staple removal.  His coumadin was held on the day of 
discharge, as his INR was 4.8.  He will follow up on ___ with 
his PCP, ___, in clinic for INR check, and coumadin 
dosing.  He will also need to address his hypertension for 
optimal long-term management as an outpatient.  Mr. ___ 
understood these recommendations and agreed with the plan.  He 
was discharged to home with the above services.
 
Medications on Admission:
Insulin , ASA 81', Bactrim DS'', Levaquin 500'

 
Discharge Medications:
1. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. meclizine 12.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for vertigo/nausea.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for Pain for 5 days.
Disp:*24 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Bactrim DS 800-160 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 14 days.
Disp:*28 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. NPH insulin human recomb 100 unit/mL Suspension Sig: 60 units 
qAM, 40 units qPM  Subcutaneous once a day.  
6. Coumadin 2.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day: 
*Please follow up on ___ with Dr. ___ for INR check 
and coumadin dose adjustment*.
Disp:*10 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
7. insulin regular human 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: per sliding 
scale  Injection per sliding scale: Per sliding scale.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
___:
Peripheral vascular disease
Non-healing right toe ulcer

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions

What to expect when you go home:
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!

2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on:
Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
        You may use a light ACE wrap for slight compression of 
your leg.  Be careful not to apply this tightly.

3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
Eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

You should get up every day, get dressed and walk
You should gradually increase your activity
You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed
Take all the medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
Take one full strength (325mg) enteric coated aspirin daily, 
unless otherwise directed 
Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in 2 weeks for 
staple/suture removal

What to report to office:
Redness that extends away from your incision
A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

*Take coumadin daily as instructed by your PCP.  You will need 
to have daily INR checks with the visiting nurse or the 
outpatient lab until you are stabilized on a regimen.*
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 63-year-old male who was admitted for a planned right lower extremity angiography to evaluate his nonhealing right foot wound. He has a history of bilateral lower extremity bypass grafts, IDDM, HTN, GERD, CVA, CAD, and CHF. He has no known allergies or adverse drug reactions. His presenting symptoms included a 1-week history of cellulitis of his right toe, and he was being treated for a nonhealing ulcer on his third toe. He also experienced vertigo and had a fall while getting out of bed, resulting in a small laceration around his right eye.

The patient underwent right lower extremity angiography, which revealed occlusion distal to the existing right bypass, and he was scheduled for revision of his bypass graft. He also underwent right femoral to posterior tibial artery bypass with PTFE without complication. He was treated with medications including aspirin, meclizine, oxycodone, Bactrim DS, NPH insulin, and Coumadin.

At discharge, the patient was cleared to go home with daily physical therapy and visiting nurse care. He was advised to follow up with his PCP in 2 weeks for INR check and Coumadin dosing, and to address his hypertension for optimal long-term management. ||endoftext||

text:
age: 53. gender: F. Name:  ___           ___ No:  ___

Admission Date: ___        Discharge Date: ___

Date of Birth:  ___        Sex:  F

Service:  OME


HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  Ms. ___ is a ___
female with metastatic renal cell carcinoma admitted to begin
cycle II week 1 high-dose IL-2 therapy on the IL-2 select
trial. Her oncologic history began in ___ when she
developed an E. coli UTI treated with antibiotics. She later
developed hematuria with a CT scan showing a right kidney
mass. Staging workup revealed pulmonary nodules. She
underwent right nephrectomy on ___, with a 12-
cm tumor of clear cell histology with renal vein involvement
and lymphovascular invasion, confirming grade III noted.
Followup torso CT revealed growth in lung nodules. Prior to
five start of IL-2, she underwent electrophysiology
evaluation due to SVT/PAT history with recommendation
obtaining low-dose diltiazem during therapy for arrhythmia
control. She began cycle I week 1 high-dose IL-2 therapy on
___, receiving ___omplicated by toxic encephalopathy and GI side effects. She
was maintained on telemetry without arrhythmia noted. Week #7
follow-up CT scans revealed 30% reduction in the lung nodules
with continued stability at week #11. She is now being
admitted to begin cycle II of IL-2 therapy.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  SVT/PAT controlled on Cartia, right
breast lumpectomy in ___ for benign lesions. Status
post left knee operation in ___. C-section in ___, cervical
laser treatment ___ years ago, history of depression and
anxiety.

ALLERGIES:  Penicillin causes tongue bumps, erythromycin
causes hives, Lasix causes hives.

MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION:  Celexa 40 mg p.o. daily, Ativan 1
mg b.i.d. p.r.n. anxiety, ibuprofen p.r.n., Cartia XT 240 mg
daily on hold now taking diltiazem 30 mg p.o. q.i.d.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  General: Well-appearing female in no
acute distress. Performance status 0. Vital signs: 97, 69,
18, 114/57, O2 sat 100% on room air. HEENT: Normocephalic,
atraumatic. Sclerae anicteric. Moist oral mucosa without
lesions. Neck: Supple without masses. Heart: Regular rate and
rhythm, S1-S2. Chest: Resonant to percussion, clear to
auscultation bilaterally. Abdomen: Rounded, positive bowel
sounds, soft, nontender, no HSM or masses. Extremities: No
lower extremity edema. Skin: Dry. Neurologic exam nonfocal.

ADMISSION LABS:  WBC 6.2, hemoglobin 12.1, hematocrit 37.7;
INR 1.1; BUN 19, creatinine 1, sodium 138, potassium 4.2,
chloride 102, CO2 28, glucose 84; ALT 10, AST 18, LDH 135, CK
31, alk phos 46, amylase 41, total bili 0.5, albumin 4.2,
calcium 9.4, phosphorus 2.9, magnesium 2.2.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted and underwent
central line placement to begin therapy. Her admission weight
was 74.8 kg and she received interleukin-2 600,000
international units per kilo equaling 44.9 million units IV
q.8h. x 14 potential doses. During this week she received
___ doses with 1 dose held related to development of shock,
1 dose held related to flu-like symptoms and 1 dose held at
patient request due to accumulative side effects on treatment
day #5. On treatment day number #2, she developed shock and
hypotension related to capillary leak syndrome requiring
fluid boluses without response and later reinitiation of Neo-
Synephrine vasopressor blood pressure support. She required
only ___ hours of blood pressure support before being
weaned from pressors and dosed with IL-2. Continuous blood
pressure bedside and central telemetry monitoring were
instituted. No cardiac arrhythmias were noted while on Neo-
Synephrine blood pressure support. She developed recurrent
hypotension requiring fluid boluses but did not require
vasopressor therapy again during this week. Other side
effects during this week included nausea and vomiting
improved with antiemetic therapy; development of an
erythematous pruritic skin rash; and fatigue. Mucositis.

During this week she developed acute renal failure with a
peak creatinine of 2.4 with associated oliguria. Metabolic
acidosis was noted with a minimum bicarb of 19 improved with
bicarbonate replacement intravenously. Serum bicarb,
electrolytes, and creatinine were monitored. Electrolytes
were repleted per protocol. Strict I/Os were follows.
Maintenance IV fluids were continued.

She developed hyperbilirubinemia with a peak bilirubin of 2.2
but no transaminitis. She was anemic without need for packed
red blood cell transfusion. She developed thrombocytopenia
with a platelet count low of 29,000 without evidence of
bleeding. She had no coagulopathy or myocarditis noted. She
was maintained on telemetry with occasional PVCs noted. By
___, she had recovered from side effects to
allow for discharge to home.

CONDITION ON DISCHARGE:  Stable.

DISCHARGE STATUS:  To home.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:  Metastatic renal cell carcinoma status
post cycle II week 1 high-dose IL-2 therapy complicated by
shock and acute renal failure.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:  Tylenol ___ tablets q.6h. p.r.n.
pain, Zantac 150 mg p.o. b.i.d. p.r.n. indigestion, lorazepam
1 mg q.6h. p.r.n. nausea/vomiting, Benadryl ___ mg q.6h.
p.r.n. pruritus, Compazine 10 mg q.6h. p.r.n.
nausea/vomiting, ciprofloxacin 250 mg p.o. b.i.d. x 5 days,
Lomotil ___ tablets q.i.d. p.r.n. diarrhea, Eucerin cream
topically, Sarna lotion topically, diltiazem 30 mg p.o.
q.i.d., Celexa 40 mg p.o. daily. Gelclair 1 packet q.i.d.
p.r.n. mucositis.

FOLLOW-UP PLANS:  The patient will return in 1 week for week
#2 of therapy.



                        ___, ___

Dictated By:  ___, NP

MEDQUIST36
D:  ___ 16:07:47
T:  ___ 10:51:34
___:  ___

cc: ___

The patient is a 53-year-old female with metastatic renal cell carcinoma. She was admitted to begin cycle II of high-dose IL-2 therapy, which was complicated by shock, acute renal failure, and other side effects. Her past medical history includes SVT/PAT, right breast lumpectomy, left knee operation, C-section, cervical laser treatment, and depression and anxiety. She has allergies to penicillin, erythromycin, and Lasix. Her medications on admission included Celexa, Ativan, ibuprofen, and Cartia XT. During her hospital stay, she developed an erythematous pruritic skin rash, fatigue, and mucositis. She was treated with various medications, including Tylenol, Zantac, lorazepam, Benadryl, and Compazine. She was discharged with a stable condition and prescribed medications including Tylenol, Zantac, lorazepam, Benadryl, Compazine, ciprofloxacin, Lomotil, Eucerin cream, Sarna lotion, diltiazem, and Celexa. ||endoftext||

age: 75. gender: F.

___ ___

___ female with HTN, HLD, Hypothyroidism, Depression, and prior

Pertinent Results:

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented as a same day admission for surgery. The 
patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for open 
reduction percutaneous pinning/metatarsal head resections of 
Left foot metatarsal fractures with Dr. ___ on ___, 
which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the 
procedure please see the separately dictated operative report. 
The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable 
condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was 
transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV 
fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet 
and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given 
___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The 
patient's home medications were continued throughout this 
hospitalization. The ___ hospital course was otherwise 
unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding spontaneously. The patient is 
heelweightbearing in the left lower extremity with bilateral 
upper extremity assist, and will be discharged on Aspirin 325mg 
x 2 weeks for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with 
Dr. ___ routine. The patient was given written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

 
Medications on Admission:
1. Albuterol Inhaler 2 PUFF IH Q4H:PRN wheezing, shortness of 
breath 
2. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO DAILY 
3. Cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg PO DAILY 
4. FLUoxetine 60 mg PO DAILY 
5. Levothyroxine Sodium 112 mcg PO DAILY 
6. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 
7. Pravastatin 10 mg PO QPM 
8. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
9. Meclizine 12.5 mg PO DAILY:PRN vertigo 
10. Oxybutynin 10 mg PO BID 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 500 mg PO Q4H 
Take for baseline pain control. 
2.  Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
Take for 2 weeks post-operatively to prevent blood clots. 
3.  Ondansetron 4 mg PO Q8H:PRN Nausea/Vomiting - First Line 
4.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 2.5-5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Severe 
5.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID 
Take to prevent constipation. Hold for diarrhea or loose stools. 

6.  Albuterol Inhaler 2 PUFF IH Q4H:PRN wheezing, shortness of 
breath  
7.  Cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg PO DAILY  
8.  FLUoxetine 60 mg PO DAILY  
9.  Levothyroxine Sodium 112 mcg PO DAILY  
10.  Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY  
11.  Meclizine 12.5 mg PO DAILY:PRN vertigo  
12.  Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY  
13.  Oxybutynin 10 mg PO BID  
14.  Pravastatin 10 mg PO QPM  
15.  Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left foot metatarsal neck fractures

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Heelweightbearing of Right lower extremity in short air cast 
boot or post-op shoe with bilateral upper extremity assist

MEDICATIONS:
  1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 4 hours around the clock. This is 
an over the counter medication.
  2)  Add  Oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean 
off this medication in 1 week or sooner.  This is an example on 
how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
  3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.
  4)  Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 
  5)  Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you 
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue 
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication 
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over 
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
  6)  Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
___ while taking narcotic pain relievers.
  7)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
  8)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.
      
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Aspirin 325mg daily for 2 weeks.

WOUND CARE:
- You may bathe, but keep your dressing dry.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
-Keep your surgical dressing in place. If it falls off, replace 
with dry sterile dressing and an ACE wrap. 

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with your Orthopaedic Surgeon, Dr. ___, 
in 2 weeks post-operatively. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

age: 63. gender: M.  
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Allergies/ADRs on File
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Liver failure
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo M with HBV/HCV cirrhosis, previously Child A with low 
MELD. On entecavir with negative VL being transferred to ___ 
for expedited transplant workup.

At baseline, he lives independently with compensated cirrhosis. 
He was seen in ___ for biopsy of a liver lesion that was 
concerning for HCC. Biopsy was negative for malignancy and 
showed mild chronic inflammation c/w cirrhosis. Had been doing 
well up until one month prior to presentation on ___ when he 
developed headaches and abdominal pain refractory to 
peptobismol. On ___ he came to outpatient GI with headaches, 
abdominal pain, nausea and confusion. His cirrhosis was 
compensated prior to this visit. Labs at clinic showed elevated 
AST/ALT/INR/Cr 1->1.8 so he was admitted for worsening hepatic 
failure with encephalopathy.

On the floor, US was negative for PV thrombosis, CT showed known 
cirrhosis and liver lesion without biliary or ductal or 
pathology. He was given ceftriaxone and flagyl as well as 
lactulose for HE. Transaminitis, coagulopathy and mental status 
worsened and a rapid response was called on morning of ___ for 
FSBG 29. Glucagon and juice brought sugar up to 150s. He was 
given IM haldol, placed in 4pt restraints and was transferred to 
the ICU for better access.

In the unit, he was sedated and intuibated. Femoral line and 
a-line were placed. He was noted to have WBC 18.87, Hct 28.8 
from 38.6 earlier in the AM. VBG showed lactate 19.9, 9,96/42. 
INR rose to 16. He was started on a bicarb gtt. At this time he 
developed significant bleeding from ETT and had PIPs in the ___. 
Bronchoscopy showed a blood/mucus plug in the right mainstem and 
in the ETT. In the setting of dyssynchrony and elevated 
pressures, he was paralyzed. He was bronched x3 overnight during 
which a large red cast was removed from the airway. PIPs 
decreased to ___ following extraction. He was also 
hypotensive requiring levophed at 15mcg as well as vasopressin. 
He was trasfused 8U FFP, 3 units of plts and albumin at SBP 
dosing as well as 500cc NS. Despite fluid challege, UOP 
decreased to 25cc/hr. Due to concern for untreated infection, 
abx were broadened to vanc/zosyn/levaquin.

Morning of transfer Pt's sats dropped, increased PEEP to 10 and 
FiO2 70%, restarted levo, rebronched this AM ___ bronch, huge 
clot came out with ___ bronch)without finding explanation for 
Sats dropping.

At this point it was decided that patient would be best served 
by transfer to ___ for urgent transplant evaluation. Transfer 
was held until the morning given concern for inability to 
ventilate in the setting of ongoing bleeding into the 
respiratory tract.

  
On transfer, vitals were:

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with HBV/HCV cirrhosis, previously Child A with low 
MELD. On entecavir with negative VL being transferred to ___ 
for fulminant liver failure now with worsening coagulopathy and 
bleeding.

# Fulminant Liver Failure: MELD of 48 (based on INR 16, Bili 3.0 
Cr 2.0). Intial decompensation likey due to hepatitis B flare, 
with subsequent multiorgan failure likely due to sepsis. Blood 
cultures never confirmed bacteremia, but the patient was treated 
empirically w/ vanc/zosyn/levo. The patient was transferred from 
___ to liver transplant evaluation. Evaluation was begun, but 
the patient's clinical status never improved to the point where 
transplantation would have been feasible. With increasing 
pressor requirements and multiorgan failure, a family meeting 
was held and it was decided to transition the patient to CMO. 
Paralysis was discontinued and his pressors were turned off. The 
patient expired rapidly with family, son and daughter, at 
bedside.

# Shock: Likely hypovolemic from blood loss. NG lavage was 
bloody. Hb dropped to 5.2. Transfused 2 units, bumpted to 6, 
transfused 2 additional units.  Treated empirically w/ 
vanc/zosyn/levo. On levophed. CT abd/pelvis neg for source of 
infection or overt bleeding. Vasopressin was added on ___.

AMS. Course complicated by hemoptysis and bloody mucous plug 
obstructing right main stem and ETT resulting in PIPs to ___, 
now s/p 3 bronchoscopies w/ plug removal and PIP decreased to 
___. Got paralysis overnight for vent synchrony in setting of 
PIPs ___ w/ plateau 28. Esophageal balloon showed acceptable 
transpulmonary pressures. Paralysis was continued until just 
before the patient expired.

# Anuric renal failure - Likely secondary to hypovolemia from 
shock. Cr 2 at ___, unknown baseline. Developed oliguria 
overnight on ___. Pt was empirically treated for HRS w/ 
albumin, midodrine and octreotide, without improvement.

failure with ?component of DIC. S/p 2U pRBCs AM of ___, also 8U 
FFP and 3 platelets. Blood loss likely secondary to hemoptysis, 
oozing from lines. Possible GI source, though EGD ___ without

||startoftext|| The patient is a 63-year-old male with a chief complaint of liver failure. He has a history of HBV/HCV cirrhosis, previously Child A with low MELD, and has been taking entecavir with negative VL. He was admitted for worsening hepatic failure with encephalopathy and was found to have elevated AST/ALT/INR/Cr levels. He developed bleeding from the ETT and had a blood/mucus plug in the right mainstem and ETT, which was removed through bronchoscopy. He was also found to have anemia, coagulopathy, and anuric renal failure, likely secondary to fulminant liver failure. He was treated empirically with antibiotics and vasopressors, but his condition did not improve and he expired.

The patient's past medical history includes HBV/HCV infection, cirrhosis, and a liver mass that was biopsied and found to be negative for malignancy. He also has a history of gastritis, OSA, and a family history of breast cancer.

The patient's medications on admission included entecavir, clotrimazole cream, docusate sodium, methadone, polyethylene glycol, multivitamins, omeprazole, and triamcinolone acetonide cream. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the general surgery service after 
presenting with complaint of epigastric and RUQ pain x several 
weeks. His initial labwork was notable for a leukocytosis of 
11.5, lipase of 129, TBR 1.1, and mild transaminitis. He 
underwent RUQ ultrasound which demonstrated gallbladder sludge 
but no evidence of cholelithiasis or cholecystitis. At this 
point, he was admitted to the medicine service due to concern 
for pancreatitis or potential choledocholithiasis given his lab 
abnormalites. He was started on bowel rest, IVF hydration, and 
IV ciprofloxacin/flagyl therapy. On HD2, he subsequently 
underwent MRCP which demonstrated mild pancreatitis, CBD 
dilation to 1.1cm, and gallbladder wall thickening concerning 
for acute cholecystitis.  He was transferred to the surgical 
service on HD2 in anticipation of cholecystectomy given these 
findings of cholecystitis in the absence of choledocholithiasis. 
At this point, his lipase had returned to normal and his 
abdominal pain had largely resolved. He was taken to the 
operating room on HD3 for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which 
was uncomplicated and tolerated well. He did well 
post-operatively. His diet was gradually advanced from clears to 
regular, which he tolerated well. He voided appropriately and 
ambulated. His pain was well controlled on an oral regimen prior 
to discharge home. He is being discharged home on POD1 in stable 
condition to follow up in general surgery clinic in ___ weeks. 

Also of note, the patient complained of some pain in his right 
great toe, likely secondary to gout. He was continued on his 
home allopurinol and started on colchicine as needed, with 
improvement in his symptoms. 

 
Medications on Admission:
1. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
2. BuPROPion (Sustained Release) 200 mg PO QAM 
3. Divalproex (DELayed Release) 1000 mg PO BID 
4. Allopurinol ___ mg PO BID

Do not exceed 3500mg per day.   
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
hold for loose stools  
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - Severe 
Do not take while drinking or driving.

Disp #*15 Tablet Refills:*0

Hold for loose stools

6.  BuPROPion (Sustained Release) 200 mg PO QAM  
7.  Divalproex (DELayed Release) 1000 mg PO BID  
8.  Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
cholecystitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 
You were admitted to the general surgery service for treatment 
of your gallbladder infection. You were taken to the operating 
room for removal of your gallbladder, which you tolerated well. 
You did well post-operatively and are being discharged home in 
stable condition. You should follow up in general surgery clinic 
in one to two weeks. 
 
Please follow the post-operative directions below:

ACTIVITY:
- Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
- You may climb stairs. You should continue to walk several 
times a day. 
- You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit. 
- You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. 
Slowly increase your activity back to your baseline as 
tolerated.
- Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common 
sense and go slowly at first. 
- No heavy lifting (10 pounds or more) until cleared by your 
surgeon, usually about 6 weeks. 

HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
- You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
- You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during the surgery.

DIET:
You may have a regular diet as tolerated without restrictions. 

YOUR BOWELS:
-It is common to have some diarrhea after having your 
gallbladder removed. This should improve on it's own gradually. 
You can use immodium as needed if you have significant diarrhea 
until you are seen in clinic in ___ weeks. 
- Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain medicine 
such as oxycodone. If needed, you may take a stool softener 
(such as Colace) or gentle laxative (such as senna or miralax) 
twice a day. You can get any of these medicines without a 
prescription.
- If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon.

PAIN MANAGEMENT:
- You are being discharged with a prescription for oxycodone for 
pain control. You may take Tylenol as directed, not to exceed 
3500mg in 24 hours. Take regularly for a few days after surgery 
but you may skip a dose or increase time between doses if you 
are not having pain until you no longer need it. You may take 
the oxycodone for moderate and severe pain not controlled by the 
Tylenol. You may take a stool softener while on narcotics to 
help prevent the constipation that they may cause. Slowly wean 
off these medications as tolerated. 
- Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.

If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon: 
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- chest pain, pressure, squeezing, or tightness
- cough, shortness of breath, wheezing
- pain that is getting worse over time or pain with fever
- shaking chills, fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
- nausea and vomiting, inability to tolerate fluids, food, or 
your medications
- if you are getting dehydrated (dry mouth, rapid heart beat, 
feeling dizzy or faint especially while standing)
-any change in your symptoms or any symptoms that concern you

MEDICATIONS:
- Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just 
as you did before, unless you have been told differently.
- If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not 
to take, please call your surgeon. 

WOUND CARE: 
- dressing removal: Remove the outer dressing 48 hours after 
your surgery.
-You may shower starting tonight. Once you remove your outer 
dressing tomorrow, you can continue to shower with any bandage 
strips that may be covering your wound. Do not scrub and do not 
soak or swim, and pat the incision dry. If you have steri 
strips, they will fall off by themselves in ___ weeks. If any 
are still on in two weeks and the edges are curling up, you may 
carefully peel them off.  
-Do not take baths, soak, or swim for 6 weeks after surgery 
unless told otherwise by your surgical team. 
-Notify your surgeon is you notice abnormal (foul smelling, 
bloody, pus, etc) or increased drainage from your incision site, 
opening of your incision, or increased pain or bruising. Watch 
for signs of infection such as redness, streaking of your skin, 
swelling, increased pain, or increased drainage. 

Please call with any questions or concerns. Thank you for 
allowing us to participate in your care. We hope you have a 
quick return to your usual life and activities. 

-- Your ___ Care Team

 
                             ___ MD ___
 
Completed by: ___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a patient known to cardiac surgery service that 
was seen in ___ after MI for surgical evaluation. She 
completed her workup and was admitted on ___ for Heparin 
bridging (Afib) prior to surgery.  She was taken to the 
operating room on ___ and underwent coronary artery 
bypass grafting see op note for full details. In summary she 
had: Coronary artery bypass grafting x4 with
left internal mammary artery graft to left anterior descending, 
reverse saphenous vein graft to posterior descending artery, 
diagonal branch, marginal branch. Her bypass time was 77 minutes 
with a crossclamp time of 62 minutes.
She tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was 
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and 
invasive monitoring. She remained hemodynamically stable and 
later that day weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact 
and was extubated.  On POD1 she was weaned from vasopressor 
support, Beta blocker was initiated and she was diuresed toward 
her preoperative weight.  Additionally she was transferred to 
the telemetry floor for further recovery. All chest tubes, and 
lines were discontinued per cardiac surgery protocol without 
complication. Coumadin was resumed for history of paroxysmal 
AFib.  She developed rapid AFib on POD 2 and converted to SR 
with Amiodarone and titration of beta blockade.  Once on the 
floor she worked with nursing and physical therapy service for 
assistance with strength and mobility. Her INR became 
supratherapeutic  and coumadin had to be held before pacing 
wires could be removed. They were finally removed on POD 9.  She 
also had an inflammatory reaction with elevated WBC into the 30 
range.  Hematology was consulted.  She was pan cultured several

She has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, acute myocardial infarction, coronary artery disease, COPD, diverticulosis, kidney cyst, and chronic kidney disease. She is allergic to sulfa and codeine. 

The patient underwent cardiac catheterization, which revealed significant stenosis in the left main coronary artery, left anterior descending coronary artery, and right coronary artery. She also had an echocardiogram, which showed global hypokinesis of the left ventricle with an estimated ejection fraction of 40-45%. 

The patient underwent coronary artery bypass grafting, which was successful. She was discharged with medications including coumadin for her history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. ||endoftext||

Mrs. ___ you were admitted on ___ and underwent an 
uncomplicated left sided below the knee amputation. However, 
given the nature of the procedure, you will be discharged to 
rehab and will rehabilitate. 

Here are your discharge instructions:

ACTIVITY:
 On the side of your amputation you are non-weight bearing on 
left side for ___ weeks
 You should keep this amputation site elevated whenever 
possible
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots
 No driving until cleared by your surgeon
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks
 
BATHING/SHOWERING:
 You may shower when you get home
 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery
 
WOUND CARE:
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal.
 When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place 
pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.
 
CAUTIONS:
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.
 
DIET:
 Low fat, low cholesterol / if you are diabetic  follow your 
dietary restrictions as before
 
CALL THE OFFICE at ___  FOR:
 Bleeding, redness of, or drainage from your foot wound
 New pain, numbness or discoloration of the skin on the 
effected foot
 Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or 
pus draining from the incision site.

___

She has a past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, fibromyalgia, spinal stenosis, chronic pain syndrome, depression, and bilateral cataracts. She has a family history of premature coronary artery disease in her father, who died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. 

The patient's allergies include penicillins and ibuprofen. She was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of chest pain and was found to have an 80% stenosis at the bifurcation of the LAD and OM, which was too difficult to stent due to concern for jailing the artery. She also had a 90% lesion to the mid RCA, which was stented with a DES. 

The patient's medications at discharge include ASA, morphine, lopressor, heparin, plavix, and integrallin. Her physical examination was normal, with no signs of chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations. Her laboratory results showed normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, with elevated troponin and creatine kinase levels. 

The patient's diagnosis is two-vessel coronary artery disease, with successful stenting of the mid-RCA with a Cypher DES. Her echocardiogram showed normal left atrial size, left ventricular wall thickness, and regional/global systolic function, with mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and a surgical repair of a subcostal hernia with mesh.  
The patient tolerated the procedure well. Overnight, patient 
noted left eye pain, injection and periorbital redness.  
Artificial tears were given for comfort and an Ophthalmology 
consult was obtained.  A left corneal abrasion was diagnosed and 
patient was commenced on erythromycin ointment, artificial 
tears, and a left eye patch was applied for comfort.  On POD#2, 
patient developed nausea and abdominal distention and 
discomfort.  She was made NPO and started on IV fluids.  Patient 
was given antiemetics and a KUB was obtained.  Patient was noted 
be tachycardic to 120's and oxygen saturations were 91-94% yet 
denied feeling shortness of breath or chest pain.  EKG was 
normal. Labs revealed WBC count of 17.7.  Patient was sent for a 
V/Q scan which revealed low probability of pulmonary embolism.  
A CT of the abdomen, without IV contrast due to allergy, 
revealed concern for pneumatosis of the cecum, but with no 
clinical correlation to symptoms and is likely a benign finding. 
The patient was switched from oral to IV metoprolol and her 
tachycardia improved. She was encouraged to use her incentive 
spirometer and her O2sats improved. On POD#4, the patient was 
tolerating a regular diet, her pain was well controlled, and she 
was transitioned back to her home dose of PO metoprolol. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received IV pain medication 
with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. 
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. His/Her diet was advanced when 
appropriate, which was tolerated well. She was also started on a 
bowel regimen to encourage bowel movement. Foley was removed on 
POD#2. Intake and output were closely monitored. 
MRI revealed a L renal cyst that should be evaluated again by 
MRI in the outpatient setting to monitor for increase in size. 
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin. 
The patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of 
infection. 
.
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during 
this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible. 
.
At the time of discharge on POD#4, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.

1) subcostal hernia 
2) Left corneal abrasion
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care: 
1. Leave your abdominal incision open without a dressing.
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with soap and water. 
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day. 
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. Your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount. 
5. You may shower daily. No baths until instructed to do so by 
Dr. ___. 
6. Wear your abdominal binder.
. 
Activity: 
1. You may resume your regular diet. 
2. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity until instructed by Dr. ___. 
. 
Medications: 
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered. 
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol 
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. 
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol.  
4. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 
5. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber. 
. 
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
3. Separation of the incision.
4. Severe nausea and vomiting and lack of bowel movement or gas 
for several days.
5. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
6. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 
. 
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
. 
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS 
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction. 

CORNEAL ABRASION:
- Do not rub or scratch your eye. Continue to wear the eye patch 
as needed.
- Apply the erythromycin ointment to the eye twice a day on ___ 
and ___. On ___ and ___, apply the ointment once daily. 
- Continue to use artificial tears in the left eye five times a 
day
- Please follow up with your Ophthalmologist next week
 
Followup Instructions:
___

She is allergic to sulfa, iodine, lisinopril, Diovan, and CT dye.

She was prescribed several medications, including acetaminophen, artificial tears, docusate sodium, cloniDINE, metoprolol, and tramadol, among others. She was also instructed to follow up with her doctor and to take certain precautions, such as not lifting anything heavier than 5 pounds or engaging in strenuous activity until instructed to do so. ||endoftext||

irregularity of the left V3 and V4 segments with mild to 
moderately V3 and moderate V4 segment narrowing. 
4. Intracranial atherosclerotic disease causing moderate 
narrowing of the left petrous internal carotid artery, and 
mild-to-moderate narrowing of the bilateral supra clinoid 
internal carotid arteries, and mild narrowing of the left distal 
M1 segment appears 
5. Multinodular goiter with a 4.5 cm dominant nodule extending 
from the left lobe and isthmus substernally into the superior 
mediastinum.

compared to CT chest from ___. 
1. Thyroid ultrasound is recommended according to the ACR 
guidelines, if not previously performed elsewhere. 
2. Chest CT is recommended for comprehensive evaluation of the 
lungs. 

Head CT ___
  
1. No evidence of hemorrhage or infarction. 
2. Age-related involutional changes and nonspecific white matter 
hypodensities suggesting moderate chronic small vessel ischemic 
disease. 

___ Echo
The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. No 
left atrial mass/thrombus seen (best excluded by transesophageal 
echocardiography). No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or 
color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy with normal cavity size and global systolic function 
(LVEF>60%). Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall 
motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. No masses or 
thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. Tissue Doppler imaging 
suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure 
(PCWP>18mmHg). There is no ventricular septal defect. Right 
ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The 
ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened (?#). There is no aortic valve stenosis. No 
aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears 
structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is 
no mitral valve prolapse. There is mild pulmonary artery 
systolic hypertension. There is a trivial/physiologic 
pericardial effusion. 

 IMPRESSION: Mild left ventricular hypertrophy with normal 
biventricular cavity sizes and systolic function. Mild pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. Mildly dilated ascending aorta. 
Findings c/w hypertensive heart disease. No cardiac source of 
embolism identified. 

 Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, 
there is no significant change.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the stroke service given mild 
dysarthria. This improved during admission. Given defibrillator, 
MRI was not obtained for further analysis of a possible infarct, 
and CT did not reveal evidence of acute infarct. CTA was notable 
for intracranial atherosclerosis affecting in the intracranial

During admission, new HD catheter was placed by ___ as her

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Possible stroke

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
  
 
Dear Ms. ___,  
 
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of difficulty speaking 
resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition where a 
blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is 
blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your body that 
controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage 
to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result 
in a variety of symptoms.  
 
Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:  
- High blood pressure
- High cholesterol
 
We are changing your medications as follows:  
- Stop taking aspirin and start Plavix 75mg daily. 
 
Please take your other medications as prescribed.  
 
Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician.  

 
If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:  
- sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
- sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
- sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
- sudden weakness of one side of the body  
- sudden drooping of one side of the face  
- sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body  
 
Sincerely,
Your ___ Neurology Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

She has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hypertension, diabetes, and a lifetime of smoking. She also has a history of long QT syndrome, which was complicated by a ventricular tachycardia (VT) arrest after receiving azithromycin. 

The patient's past medical history includes type 2 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, renal tubular acidosis, peripheral vascular disease, sciatica, cataract, and unspecified sensorineural hearing loss. 

On physical examination, the patient was awake, cooperative, and oriented to her name, location, and date. Her language was fluent, but she had mild dysarthria. Her cranial nerves were intact, and her motor strength was full throughout. 

The patient's laboratory results showed a hemoglobin A1c level of 7.9%, triglycerides of 107, and a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level of 1.0. 

The patient's imaging studies showed approximately 25% stenosis of the left proximal internal carotid artery, severe stenosis of the origin of the left vertebral artery, and intracranial atherosclerotic disease. 

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of mild dysarthria and recommendations for further evaluation and management. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 61-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital after falling down 10 stairs and presenting with a cervical spine fracture and disc herniation. He has a history of diabetes, cardiac bypass surgery 20 years ago, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He has no known allergies or adverse reactions. The patient underwent a C3-C4 anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF) procedure and was intubated due to a difficult airway. He was also treated for a gastrointestinal bleed and was started on insulin for hyperglycemia. At discharge, the patient was awake, alert, and oriented, with full motor function in his lower extremities and some motor function in his upper extremities. He was prescribed a range of medications, including pain medication, anticoagulation therapy, and medications for his underlying medical conditions. The patient was discharged to extended care with instructions to wear a hard cervical collar at all times, avoid heavy lifting and strenuous exercise, and follow up with his neurosurgeon for further care. ||endoftext||

Facility:

Right carotid stenosis

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

  It was a pleasure treating you at ___.  You were admitted 
after having a right carotid endarterectomy due to your 
stenosis. Please, follow the instructions below:

WHAT TO EXPECT:

1. Surgical Incision:
It is normal to have some swelling and feel a firm ridge along 
the incision
Your incision may be slightly red and raised, it may feel 
irritated from the staples
2. You may have a sore throat and/or mild hoarseness
Try warm tea, throat lozenges or cool/cold beverages 
3. You may have a mild headache, especially on the side of your 
surgery
Try ibuprofen, acetaminophen, or your discharge pain 
medication
If headache worsens, is associated with visual changes or 
lasts longer than 2 hours- call vascular surgeons office
4. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
You may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
5. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
Eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

MEDICATION:
Take all of your medications as prescribed in your discharge 
ACTIVITIES:

No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
No excessive head turning, lifting, pushing or pulling 
(greater than 5 lbs) until your post op visit
You may shower (no direct spray on incision, let the soapy 
water run over incision, rinse and pat dry)
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area

 
Followup Instructions:
___

vasopressor support.  Beta blocker was initiated and the patient 
was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight.  Plavix was 
resumed for drug eluting stents.  Pacing wires were discontinued 
and the patient immediately had a large amount of bloody chest 
tube output.  He did remain hemodynamically stable.  He had a

packed red blood cells.  He developed hypotension with fever and 
was worked up for transfusion reaction.  Pathology determined 
that this was not an actual transfusion reaction.  He was 
treated with Benadryl and steroids.  Echo did not reveal 
tamponade.  He remained hemodynamically stable.  Chest tubes 
were discontinued without complication.  The patient was 
transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery.

hypertension.  The patient was evaluated by the physical therapy 
service for assistance with strength and mobility.  By the time

Brief Hospital Course:
___ YO F with a history of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma s/p BMT (___), 
Aortic valve replacement (biological), atrial fibrillation not 
previously on coumadin, prior report of cardiomyopathy (EF 45%) 
who was transferred to ___ on ___ for management of left 
parietal mass found to have a parietal Strep ___ abscess c/b 
subdural empyema s/p craniotomy with evacuation.

1. Brain Abscesses (Seizures): The patient initially presented 
to an OSH on ___ after nearly a week of left frontal headaches, 
right sided arm and leg weakness and progressive aphasia. At the 
OSH neuroimaging revealed a ring enhancing left parietal mass 
with extensive surrounding edema.  On ___ morning rounds, 
patient was witnessed to have ongoing seizures characterized 
with right arm tremor despite Keppra loading.  Respiratory 
status was marginal with acute tachypnea and so she was 
transferred to the ICU at this time. MRI read came back 
indicating a intracranial abscess with a subdural empyema.  The 
patient was taken emergently to the OR for drainage.  She was 
left intubated post operatively and maintained on a midazolam 
gtt, which was slowly weaned and the patient was transitioned to 
Keppra and dilantin. An MRI from ___ showed interval decrease 
in size of the left parietal abscess status post surgical 
evacuation. There was also a small new multiloculated subdural 
collection in the left parieto-occipital region which worsened 
and repeat craniotomy was performed on ___.  She has been 
without seizure activity since ___.  Her motor exam improved 
slightly in UE and significantly in ___ on the Right. 

On transfer to the internal medicine service, the patient left 
sided strength continued to improve.  She is to continue 
Pencillin, Cipro and Flagyl for at least 3 more weeks as 
directed by Infectious disease.  Her recent repeat head MRI 
showed significant interval improvement.  The patient has 
Neurology & Neurosurgical follow-up in the next several weeks 
with a repeat MRI scheduled.  She will continue on Keppra, 
Phenytoin taper and Divalproex with levels followed by 
Neurology.

The patient continues to have head pain which is currently 
controlled on a Fentanyl Patch and Dilaudid PO prn.  It is 
expected that her need for these medicines will diminish over 
the coming weeks.

2. Anastamotic Leak/Splenic Abscess: Patient was noted to have 
multiple abscesses on head imaging.  Ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV 
Q12H, MetRONIDAZOLE 500 mg IV Q8H and Fluconazole 400 mg IV Q24H 
were started empirically as was vancomycin.  The cultures from 
burhole surgical site on ___ grew STREPTOCOCCUS ANGINOSUS 
(___) for which she was desensitized and started on 
Penicillin G on ___, vancomycin was discontinued as was 
fluconazole.  She has remained afebrile since ___.  She 
underwent infectious work up which revealed negative UCx, CXR, 
___ TEE showed no vegetations.  Her CT abdomen showed a 
small air-fluid collection at the splenic hilum, tracking 
through the spleen in a wedge-shaped configuration, w/ small 
pleural effusion and left lower lobe atelectasis as well as a 
possible ulceration at the old roux en y site. She was also 
noted to have opacities in her sinuses (maxillary, sphenoid, but 
not frontal). It was felt that the source for the infection was 
either splenic abscess, a possible ulceration vs. extension from 
the sinuses (unlikely based on ENT evaluation).  Given difficult 
approach, it was felt that she could not undergo drainage by ___. 
 The obturator abscess was ruled a hematoma and the splenic 
abscess was ruled a remant of the leak.  The patient will 
continue Cipro/Flagyl for 3 more weeks under the guidance of 
Infectious Disease.

Surgery was consulted for a thorough evaluation of her 
anastamotic leak.  After a period of NPO with repeat studies by 
CT and X-ray, as well as consultation with bariatric surgery, it 
was decided that this leak was likely chronic, and although 
possibly the source of the abscesses, did not pose an active 
risk with regards to nutrition.  The patient was maintained on 
TPN while this was under evaluation, but ultimately was able to 
be discharged on a regular diet without issue. 

3. R Iliac Deep Vein Thrombosis:  The patient developed a DVT 
discovered on CT and confirmed with ultrasound.  Given her 
recent brain surgery and history of GI bleeds, the pros and cons 
of anticoagulation were weighed with her neuro- and general 
surgeons.  Based on obtained old records and a discussion with 
the above parties, it was determined that the benefits of 
anticoagulation outweighed the risks.  The patient has been 
briefed on concerning signs of GI Bleed and pulmonary embolism.  
Her PCP agreed to manage her coumadin as an outpatient.  The 
patient tolerated 48 hours of a heparin drip and was 
transitioned to Lovenox/Coumadin which she will continue until 
therapeutic at ___.

4. Atrial fibrillation s/p cardioversion:  The patient was 
admitted on Sotalol but converted to metoprolol on this 
hospitalization.  She was rate controlled in the ___ and 
will continue 12.5mg PO BID on discharge.  Anticoagulation per 
problem DVT above.

5. Leukopenia/Anemia: The patient developed a stable and 
non-hemodynamically significant leukopenia and anemia while 
admitted.  These problems have been variously attributed to 
Dilantin, Penicillin and her underlying history of lymphoma s/p 
BMT.  She was repleted with Vitamin B while admitted.  We have 
left the patient instructions to follow up with her PCP & 
Oncologist to monitor these values.  Infectious disease will 
also monitor her blood counts weekly.

6. Hypertension: The patient had no signs of hypertension and 
will continue on Metoprolol.

7. CAD, s/p MI, CABG. The patient was not continued on Aspirin 
due to risk of GI bleed and anticoagulation.  She will follow 
with her PCP on this issue.

8. Anxiety: The patient was continued on Ativan.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnoses:
1. Brain Abscess
2. s/p Roux-en-y Bypass with anastamotic leak
3. R femoral deep vein thrombosis
4. Simple partial seizures

Secondary Diagnoses:

Aortic Stenosis s/p Aortic valve replacement

Discharge Condition:
Hemodynamically stable with normal vital signs. Ambulating 
without difficulty.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have been admitted to the hospital for evaluation of a brain 
abscess.  While you were here, our Neurosurgical team was 
successful in draining these abscesses.  Our Infectious Disease 
and Surgical teams evaluated you for a source of infection and 
found that your old bypass surgery had a small but stable leak, 
and this was likely the cause of your infection.  Unfortunately 
while you were here you also developed a blood clot which 
obligates you to 6 months of anticoagulation therapy. 

It has been a long and difficult hospital course and I commend 
you on your continued positive spirits.  It has been a true 
pleasure caring for you during this difficult time.

There have been many changes to your medications including 
antibiotics.  Please ask the nurse for ___ full print out of your 
medications as the most accurate and up to date list.
Of note:

time
Please take your Cipro & Flagyl (antibiotics) every day as 
directed
Please take your Warfarin (Coumadin, blood thinner) as directed 
and follow with Dr. ___ to guide you on dose. Please continue 
enoxaparin until Dr. ___ you otherwise.
Please take valproate, levatiracetem, and fosphenytoin at the 
currently prescribed doses until you are told otherwise by your 
seizure doctor. While on these medications, you should have your 
liver function, platelet count and drug levels drawn and 
monitored by either Dr ___ your seizure doctor.  

Please make all appointments as directed.  For many of our 
specialists, we have made appointments for you but you can find 
a specialist closer to home.

Please make all appointments as scheduled and recommended:
1. Primary Care: ___ ___, ___ @ 
11am
Please tell your Primary care doctor that you need a pelvic 
ultrasound 6 weeks post discharge to evaluate an adnexal cyst

2. Infectious Disease: ___ @ 10:00a  with Dr. 
___ at the:  ___ (___), BASEMENT 
ID WEST (SB) 

3. Neurology (Epileptology): ___  01:00p   ___. 
  ___ CTR, ___ FLOOR   
  NEUROLOGY UNIT CC8 (SB) (This appointment can be made with 
your own neurologist/epileptologist)

4. Neurosurgery: On ___ at 1:40pm you are scheduled for a 
brain MRI, at 2:30pm on the same day you will see Dr ___. The 
MRI is located on the ___ basement of the ___ 
___. Dr ___ is located on the ___ ___ of the ___ 
building behind the ___ on ___. Dr 
___ can be reached at ___.

We recommend the following appointments:
1. Hematologist/Oncologist: Your blood counts were low on this 
admission and this should be followed.

2. Gastroenterologist/Bariatric Surgeon: Our surgeons have no 
operative recommendations regarding your bypass leak, but your 
surgeons may care to re-evaluate you.

Please call your doctor or 911 if you experience worsening or 
uncontrolled head pain, confusion, chest pain, difficulty 
breathing, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, black or bloody 
stools or any other concerning medical symptom.

Neurosurgical Instructions:
Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING
New onset of tremors or seizures.
Any confusion or change in mental status. 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, or drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.

target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 54-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a left parietal mass. She has a history of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, status post bone marrow transplant, atrial fibrillation, cardiomyopathy, and gastric bypass surgery. She is allergic to penicillins, codeine, and Keflex. 

The patient initially presented with left frontal headaches, right-sided arm and leg weakness, and progressive aphasia. Imaging revealed a ring-enhancing left parietal mass with surrounding edema, suggestive of an abscess with subdural empyema. She underwent stereotactic evacuation of the abscess and burr hole drainage of the subdural empyema. 

The patient was started on vancomycin for strep coverage and cipro/flagyl for concern of infection. She also had refractory seizure activity on continuous EEG monitoring. 

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and her physical exam was normal except for a healing surgical wound. Her laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 2.5, hemoglobin of 9.8, and platelet count of 277. 

The patient's imaging studies showed a small air-fluid collection in the splenic hilum, which was likely a chronic collection. She also had a new multiloculated subdural collection in the left parieto-occipital region. 

The patient was prescribed valproate for seizure control and was advised to follow up with her primary care physician for further management. ||endoftext||

Followed for latent TB infection by Dr. ___ been treated 
with INH, but while being treated was exposed to his son so

going to start CTX/Azithro after HD the next morning. Around

and worse on HD days), and so at that time moving all his 
extremities, no focal deficits, then had bedside HD after exam, 
and nurse noted that he was moving his extremities, then came in

weakness, but is moving it, still has nasolabial fold flattening 
on the left. They did see a R carotid stenosis. No a fib on EKG.
  
In Neuro ICU, patient started to speak slowly, so hopefully more

# ___ EKG:
Normal sinus rhythm at a rate of 80. Right bundle-branch block. 
Mild 
prolongation of the Q-T interval. Left ventricular hypertrophy. 
There are 
diffuse non-specific ST-T wave changes throughout. Clinical 
correlation is 
suggested.  
  
# ___ CXR:
IMPRESSION: Mild pulmonary edema with bilateral small pleural 
effusions and atelectasis. 
  
# ___ EKG:
Normal sinus rhythm. Right bundle-branch block. Non-specific 
ST-T wave 
changes, all of which are unchanged compared with the previous 
tracing. 
  
# ___ CT Brain Perfusion
IMPRESSION: 
1. No acute intra- or extra-axial hemorrhage. 
2. Relatively small geographic region of abnormally increased 
mean transit 
time, without definite corresponding decreased relative cerebral 
blood volume, 
in the superior right frontal lobe, representing acute ischemic 
(penumbra) in 
the superior division, right MCA territory; there is no similar 
region 
elsewhere. 
3. Unremarkable intracranial circulation; specifically, no 
stenosis or 
occlusion of the right MCA and its branches or the right ICA 
terminus. 
4. Atherosclerotic disease, involving particularly the left 
carotid bulb and 
proximal ICA with at least 65% diameter stenosis at its origin. 
5. Evidence of CHF with bilateral pleural effusions. 
  
# ___ TTE
Conclusion:
The left atrium is moderately dilated. There is mild symmetric 
left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and 
regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Doppler parameters 
are indeterminate for left ventricular diastolic function. There 
is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size 
and free wall motion are normal. The aortic root is mildly 
dilated at the sinus level. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are 
mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The tricuspid 
valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is borderline 
pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is a very small 
pericardial effusion. 
  
IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
preserved global and regional biventricular systolic function. 
Indeterminate indices to assess diastolic dysfunction. No 
pathologic valvular abnormality seen.
  
# ___ CXR:
FINDINGS: In comparison with the study of ___, there is 
increasing 
opacification at both bases with poor definition of the 
hemidiaphragms 
consistent with pleural effusions and compressive atelectasis. 
The degree of pulmonary vascular congestion is more prominent, 
though some of this could reflect the AP supine rather than PA 
technique. 
  
# ___ Non Con Head CT
IMPRESSION: 
Residual IV contrast limits optimal evaluation for subtle 
hemorrhage.  
1. New focal hypodense area with loss of gray-white 
differentiation in the 
right frontal lobe corresponding to the previously seen 
perfusion abnormality representing either evolving ischemia or 
infarction.  
2. No large area of hemorrhage in this area or elsewhere within 
limitation of this study. No new edema, mass effect, or shift in

# ___ TTE Bubble Study
Findings:
No evidence suggestive of an atrial septal defect or patent

with maneuvers.  
   
# ___ MRI Head
IMPRESSION: 
  
1. Acute infarct in the right posterior frontal lobe involving 
the precentral gyrus which is unchanged. 
   
2. No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage or new infarct. 
   
3. Changes of chronic small vessel ischemic disease. 
   
4. Arachnoid cyst versus a prominent cisterna magna in the 
posterior fossa.  
  

  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT:  ___ yo ___ RHM with h/o ESRD, CAD s/p 
drug-eluting stent placed ___, DM2, HTN, HL, and latent TB 
initially presented on ___ with c/o CP, productive cough and 
night sweats, admitted for MI rule out hospital course c/b 
right-sided acute cerebral infarct s/p tPA on ___, initially 
with motor weakness, left sided facial droop and expressive 
aphasia, now with symmetric strength and no facial droop but 
persistent expressive aphasia. 
  
# Acute Cerebral Infarct: While in dialysis on ___ pt was 
found around 09:20 to have new speech difficulty and LUE flaccid 
weakness. A Code Stroke was called and CTA showed small 
frontoparietal increased MTT/perfusion deficit. He was 
administered tPA starting at approximately 11:15 on ___. He was 
then transfered to the TICU for frequent neuro checks given risk 
of bleed post-tPA. Passed speech and swallow on ___. 
Continued to improve on the medical floor, with equal strength 
and sensation distally. TTE showed no ASD or PFO. Cardiology had 
low suspicion for any left atrial thrombus or appendage 
abnormality, so TEE was recommended for outpatient. Neuro aware 
of left ICA. LDL is 95, so started a statin to obtain less than 
70. Followed daily by neurology. Antihypertensives were 
uptitrated as necessary to bring BP within goal SBP 140-180.  
Patient was placed on Aspirin 325 mg per neuro recs because they 
felt plavix was not a good medication for him.
Treatment Course:
- Captopril 12.5 mg PO TID x1 day
- Captopril 37.5 mg PO TID x3 days
- Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY x2 days
- Metoprolol tartrate 25 mg PO BID x3 days
- Carvedilol 25 mg PO BID x3 days
- Hydralazine ___ mg IV Q6H PRN SBP>180
- Atorvastatin 80 mg daily x6 days
- Aspirin 325 mg PO/NG DAILY x7 days 
- Frequent neuro checks with monitoring for headache as 
indication of possible hemorrhagic conversion or cerebral edema
- Continuous monitoring by telemetry   
- Maintained normothermia  
- Risk Factor Assessment with Lipid panel 
  
# Headache: pt has h/o chronic HA with HD along with dizziness 
and ear ache. ___ have h/o migraine but due to language barrier 
it is described simply as HA. Associated with nausea and 
vomiting. Varies from ___ to ___ in severity.
- Acetaminophen dose to 1000 mg PO Q6H prn pain
- Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q8H prn pain
- Odansetron 4 mg IV Q8H:PRN nausea/vomiting 
- Elevated HOB to 30 degrees
- Monitored closely for concurrent neurological findings 
- Pt sent with a prescription for Tramadol for break through 
headache pain
  
# No TB infection, ruled out after neg AFBx3 and neg 
concentrated smear. Has been followed for latent TB infection by 
Dr. ___ previously treated with INH. Resolved.
  
# ESRD: has a LUE fistula, after TPA did have more swelling of 
his LUE ?less mobile, non pitting edema, so don't believe there 
is a clot but something to monitor as an outpatient.  Dialysis 
on T, Tr, ___. 
- Monitored by daily Cr, urine output, electrolytes  
  
# No current chest pain on discharge, ruled out for MI with flat 
CK-MB and TpnT.  Resolved.
  
# Pulmonary Edema: Likely ___ fluid overload on admission CXR, 
now resolved.  Sats stable, lung sounds clear.
  
# DM 2: 
- Pt placed on Insulin SS with goal <150.  BG very well 
controlled during this admission.
  
# Anxiety: Pt has increased anxiety following stroke, especially 
around HD, now resolved.
- Pt given Lorazepam 0.5 mg IV PRN anxiety pre-HD.
     
# Consults:
- ___ evaluations for walking stairs, showering without assitance
- Nutrition evaluations for poor PO intake, treated with 
appetite stimulant Megace
- Social work consults for discharge home with services
  
Transitional Issues:
1. Pt still needs a TEE for a better look at possible atrial 
pathology which may have caused this stroke.  Cardiology did not 
feel that this procedure had to be done in house and that he was 
very low risk for having anything that would change our 
management.  For this reason he was set up with cardiology as an 
outpatient to get this TEE.
2. Pt will need close neurology follow up to follow neuro 
deficits and continue to reduce his risk of further stroke.
3. Pt will need close PCP follow up to follow up on new 
medications, medication refills, ongoing neuro deficits, stroke 
risk reduction etc.
