Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute Cerebral Infarct
Headache
End Stage Renal Disease
Pulmonary Edema
Type II Diabetes Mellitus
Anxiety
Anemia
Hypertensive urgency

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
  
You were admitted to the hospital with chest pain which has 
resolved.  Unfortunately, while you were here you had a stroke 
that affected the right side of your brain (and consequently the 
left side of your body). You were given a medication that helps 
to dissolve clots and helps people improve following a stroke.  
Over the few days following the stroke you improved dramatically 
and your motor muscle function appears to be back to baseline.  
As we discussed, the reason for the stroke was secondary to 
years of high cholesterol, diabetes, high blood pressure, and 
dialysis that lead to hardening of the arteries, leading to a 
blockage. The key to your recovery lies in your new medications 
including aspirin, atorvastatin, and new blood pressure agents. 
Further, you will benefit from outpatient physical therapy, 
occupational therapy, and speech therapy. We have set you up 
with primary care, cardiology and neurology appointments below. 
    
Additionally, while you were here we tested you for tuberculosis 
and all of our tests were negative, indicating that you do not 
have this infection.
  
The following changes were made to your medications:
STOP Metoprolol
STOP Fluticasone
CHANGE Vitamin B complex vitamins to B complex with Vitamin C 
and Folic Acid, 1 capsule by mouth daily
CHANGE Aspirin from 81 mg daily to 325 mg daily
START Atorvastatin 80 mg by mouth once daily
START Carvedilol 25 mg by mouth twice daily
START Lisinopril 20 mg by mouth twice daily
START Megace 600 mg by mouth once daily
START Tramadol 50 mg by mouth every 6 hours as needed for 
headache
  
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.  We wish 
you a speedy recovery.
 
Followup Instructions:
___
target:
||startoftext|| The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of End Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, Type II Diabetes Mellitus, Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) with a drug-eluting stent, Hyperlipidemia, Hypertension, and Anemia. He was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of chest pain, tuberculosis rule-out, acute cerebral infarct, headache, and pulmonary edema. 

The patient's past medical history includes latent tuberculosis treated with INH, chronic hypertension, and chronic hemodialysis. His social history is significant for a sister who died from diabetes complications and multiple living children with various health problems. 

During his hospital stay, the patient was diagnosed with a right MCA perfusion defect with "penumbra" and was treated with tPA. He was also found to have a R carotid stenosis. The patient remains aphasic and has left upper extremity weakness, but is able to move his extremities and ambulate to the bathroom without assistance. 

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, and he was prescribed medications for his conditions. His laboratory results showed normal blood chemistry values, except for slightly elevated glucose levels. ||endoftext||

the pericardial effusion is now larger and there is now right

appears circumferential. No right ventricular diastolic collapse 
is seen. There is brief right atrial diastolic collapse 
suggestive of elevated intrapericardial pressure without overt 
tamponade. Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of 
___, no change.

for abnormal LFTs.  2. Trace perihepatic ascites. 3. Right

4. Moderate pericardial effusion.

Moderate-to-severe enlargement of the cardiac silhouette which 
enlarged 
between ___ and ___ is unchanged subsequently. 
Mediastinal and 
pulmonary vascular engorgement are essentially unchanged since 
___, and edema is minimal, if any, difficult to 
distinguish from relatively symmetric infrahilar opacification 
which could also be due to mild-to-moderate atelectasis. There 
is no pulmonary edema or consolidation in the upper lungs. 
___ Echo: Normal LV size with low-normal systolic function. 
Normal right ventricular chamber size and systolic function. 
Moderate sized circumferential pericardial effusion with 
evidence of early hemodynamic effect in inversion of the right 
atrium, consistent with increased intrapericardial pressure. No 
definitive signs of pericardial tamponade. In the setting of 
elevated right sided pressures, echocardiographic evidence of 
tamponade may be absent. Mild-moderate mitral regurgitation and 
mild-moderate tricuspid regurgitation.
Compared with the findings of the prior study (images reviewed) 
of ___, the effusion is slightly larger and there is 
slightly more pronounced diastolic inversion of the right 
atrium.

continued substantial enlargement of the cardiac silhouette with 
less prominent vascular congestion that may reflect the PA 
rather than supine AP technique. Opacification at the left base 
in the retrocardiac region could merely reflect atelectasis, 
though in the appropriate clinical setting supervening pneumonia 
would have to be seriously considered. There is left and 
possibly also right pleural effusion. Scattered streaks of 
atelectasis are seen especially at the left base.

___ left shin biopsy: The sections shows patchy superficial 
and mid-dermal hemorrhage. No primary vasculitis/microthrombotic 
vasculitis are seen. There is no evidence of malignancy in this

superficial dermis, compatible with relative chronicity of this 
hemorrhagic episode. The PAS, GMS, and tissue Gram stains are

___ Bone marrow biopsy: Immunophenotypic findings 
consistent with involvement by persistent involvement by 
patient's known acute leukemia.

(CD117, CD13) along with B-marker CD19, as well as CD7.

Mr. ___ is a ___ yo M with refractory biphenotypic leukemia 
and history of disseminated fusarium infection, on Ambisome and

(pulled ___.

His day 14 marrow showed persistent disease and his regimen was 
changed to 7+3. Two subsequent marrows all continued to show

of decitabine (C1D41, ___. Continued home neupogen to

neutropenia after induction chemotherapy. Voriconazole held

and galactomannan are negative.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 62-year-old male with a chief complaint of disseminated fusarium, VRE bacteremia. He has a past medical history of biphenotypic leukemia, which was initially treated with steroids and IVIG, and later with hyperCVAD and 7+3 chemotherapy. He was also diagnosed with disseminated fusarium infection and treated with Ambisome and voriconazole. The patient has no known allergies or adverse drug reactions.

The patient was admitted to the hospital for a new lesion on his congenital oral mass, which is concerning for persistent and worsening fungal infection. He has been experiencing pain in his mouth, but has not taken pain medication. He also developed painless, nonpruritic erythematous blanching patches on his shins bilaterally.

The patient's physical examination revealed a pleasant elderly male in no acute distress, with a normal chest and abdominal examination. He had petechiae on his lower abdomen, legs, and feet, as well as erythematous, blanching patches on his anterior shins with superficial ulcerations bilaterally.

The patient's laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 0.3, with 28% blasts, and a platelet count of 10%. His liver function tests were abnormal, with elevated levels of ALT, AST, and LDH. His blood cultures were positive for VRE.

The patient underwent a bone marrow biopsy and skin biopsy, and was treated with decitabine and Ambisome. He was also prescribed medications at discharge, including voriconazole and Lamivudine.

Overall, the patient's diagnosis is disseminated fusarium infection, VRE bacteremia, and biphenotypic leukemia. He is being treated with antifungal and antibacterial medications, and will require ongoing monitoring and management of his condition. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is an 82-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of dyspnea on exertion. She has a history of metastatic breast cancer and is currently taking everolimus and exemestane. She was found to have worsening shortness of breath over the past five days, which was initially attributed to worsening of her metastatic breast cancer. However, further evaluation revealed a 2:1 AV block on ECG, which was likely due to AV node disease. She was admitted to the EP service for placement of a permanent pacemaker.

The patient's past medical history is significant for metastatic ER+ breast cancer, bilateral mastectomy, Adriamycin, tamoxifen, Arimidex, exemestane, Faslodex, XRT to left axillary nodes and subpectoralis nodes, Xeloda, glaucoma, bladder suspension, and cholecystectomy.

The patient has no known allergies, but is allergic to morphine. She has no significant social or family history.

On admission, the patient's physical exam revealed a bradycardic rhythm, bibasilar crackles in the lungs, and no pedal edema. Her discharge physical exam showed a regular rhythm, no pedal edema, and a soft, non-distended abdomen.

The patient's laboratory results showed a lactate level of 1.9, troponin T < 0.01, and proBNP of 4769. Her chest CT scan showed increased left perihilar and lower lung opacities concerning for pneumonia.

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of AV node disease and was prescribed medications for her condition. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 72-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with new onset heart failure and atrial fibrillation. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea, hypercholesterolemia, benign prostatic hypertrophy, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. The patient developed a retroperitoneal bleed and acute renal failure, which responded well to fluids and blood administration. He was also diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, which was likely related to atrial stretch. The patient was started on digoxin, Lasix, Spironolactone, and enalapril, and was later transferred to Warfarin. He was also prescribed medications for his COPD, including Spiriva and Advair.

At discharge, the patient was prescribed medications including Terazosin, Simvastatin, Omeprazole, Cholestyramine, Aspirin, Spiriva, Advair, Toprol XL, Enalapril, and Multivitamin. He was advised to follow up with a pulmonary doctor for pulmonary function tests and with a cardiologist to determine a long-term medication regimen for his congestive heart failure. The patient was also instructed to maintain a less than 2gm of salt diet daily, weigh himself daily, and call his primary care physician if he gains more than 3 pounds. ||endoftext||

___: 
    CLOSTRIDIUM DIFFICILE. 
         Positive for toxigenic C difficile by the Cepheid 
nucleic
         amplification assay.  

=======================
IMAGING: 
=======================

KUB ___ 
Gaseous distention of the large and small bowel which tapers at 
the level of the descending and sigmoid colon. Decreased 
haustral markings are noted in the descending colon. There is no 
gross pneumoperitoneum, however evaluation for free 
intraperitoneal air is limited on supine radiographs. 

SECOND OPINION CT TORSO: CT from outside hospital dated ___.
Extensive colitis from the splenic flexure to the mid portion of 
the 
descending colon with extension to the transverse colon without 
signs of 
perforation.  Small bowel and terminal ileum are intact. 

====================
PATHOLOGY 
====================
PATHOLOGY (from colonoscopy ___
Intestinal mucosal biopsies, seven:
1. Terminal ileum:
Small intestinal mucosa, within normal limits.
2. Cecum:
Colonic mucosa, within normal limits.
3. Ascending:
Colonic mucosa within normal limits.
4. Transverse:
Colonic mucosa, within normal limits.
5. Descending:
Chronic severely active colitis with ulceration.
6. Sigmoid:
Paneth cell metaplasia consistent with chronic inactive colitis.
7. Rectum:
Focal Paneth cell metaplasia consistent with chronic inactive 
colitis.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
==================
BRIEF SUMMARY 
==================
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with history of Crohn's 
disease previously well controlled on mesalamine, CAD s/p stent 
___ years ago, and polymyalgia rheumatica who presented with 2 
weeks of abdominal pain, diarrhea and poor PO, found to have a 
Crohn's flare as well as concurrent c diff infection. He was 
treated with IV methylprednisolone without marked improvement, 
so he was started on infliximab on ___, to good effect, and 
transitioned to PO prednisone for discharge. He is receiving PO 
Vancomycin for the c diff infection. 

=====================
PROBLEM-BASED SUMMARY 
=====================

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS: 

# Crohn's disease 
Patient has a long history of Crohn's disease, previously well 
controlled on mesalamine with the last flare ___ years ago. CT 
A/P performed on ___ at ___, and reviewed 
by ___ radiology, showed colitis from the transverse to the 
descending colon. Colonoscopy this admission showed deep 
circumferential ulcerations from the transverse colon through to 
the sigmoid colon, with pathology revealing chronic severely 
active colitis with ulceration in the descending colon. 
Presentation felt to be most consistent with Crohn's flare. He 
received IV methylprednisolone without appropriate improvement, 
so was started on infliximab (first infusion ___, 10 mg/kg), 
which he tolerated well. He was evaluated by colorectal surgery; 
no need for acute intervention. He improved symptomatically 
after the infliximab and was transitioned to PO prednisone for 
discharge. He is planned for a repeat infusion of infliximab at 
1 week (10mg/kg), for an escalated induction dosing, arranged 
with his outpatient GI, Dr. ___ ___. He will be 
discharged on prednisone PO 40mg daily. 

# C Diff 
Patient presented with abdominal pain and diarrhea, WBC 14.5 on 
admission, positive c diff. He was treated with PO Vancomycin, 
for a planned 14-day course (day ___, last day will be on 
___. To our knowledge, this is his first episode of c diff 
infection. 

# Hematochezia 
Patient had one episode of hematochezia in the ED, with no other 
events. Possible source may be related to colitis. There was no 
concern for active GI bleeding during admission. 

# Malnutrition
Patient was followed by nutrition while inpatient. By discharge, 
he was tolerating improved PO and eating well. 

CHRONIC PROBLEMS: 

# Anemia 
Patient reports a history of chronic anemia on home B12. 
Discharge hemoglobin was 10.3. 

# CAD 
Home clopidogrel was held this admission, as his last stent was 
placed ___ years ago. He was continued on home atorvastatin and 
aspirin. Attempt was made to reach out to outpatient 
cardiologist Dr. ___ by email regarding the clopidogrel. 
Please readdress clopidogrel at his outpatient cardiology 
appointment. 

# PMR: Stable. 

====================
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
====================

- Please evaluate for depression and consider starting an 
antidepressant as an outpatient. Wife notes that patient seems 
to have depressed mood at home, does not leave the house. 
- Follow up with cardiology, to readdress clopidogrel 
(clopidogrel was held this admission, as his last stent was ___ 
years ago). 
- Patient is to complete 14-day course of PO Vancomycin for c 
diff (day ___, last day on ___. 
- He will need HBV/HAV vaccines, pneumovax, prevnar and flu 
vaccines as an outpatient. 
- He will need regular skin check with either dermatology or PCP 
as an outpatient. 

New medications: PO Vancomycin, Remicade
Stopped medications: Clopidogrel, mesalamine 
Changed medications: Prednisone 40 daily

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure to care for you at the ___ 
___. Please find detailed discharge instructions 
below: 

WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL? 
- You were admitted because you had abdominal pain and diarrhea. 


WHAT HAPPENED TO YOU IN THE HOSPITAL? 
- Your symptoms were thought to be primarily from a flare of 
your Crohn's disease.
- You were also found to have a GI infection, called "c diff", 
that can also cause diarrhea and abdominal pain.   
- You received a colonoscopy, which showed inflammation in parts 
of your large intestine.  
- You required IV steroids for your Crohn's flare. 
- You required an additional therapy to suppress inflammation 
called Remicade (infliximab) to treat your Crohn's flare. 
- You did well after receiving the Remicade, so you were 
transitioned to oral steroids for discharge. 
- You were treated with oral antibiotics (vancomycin) for your c 
diff infection. 

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL? 
- Please go to all your appointments as scheduled. 
- Please take all your medications as prescribed. 
- You will need another infusion of the Remicade 1 week after 
the first one, so please make sure to follow up at your GI 
doctor appointment. 

We wish you the best! 
- Your ___ treatment team

||startoftext|| The patient is a 69-year-old male who presents with a chief complaint of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and inability to tolerate food. He has a history of Crohn's disease, coronary artery disease, and polymyalgia rheumatica. His symptoms began two weeks ago and have been worsening, with a recent increase in abdominal pain after eating. He has not had any recent travel, ill contacts, or new food consumption.

The patient's physical examination revealed tachycardia, tenderness in the periumbilical area, epigastrium, right upper quadrant, and left upper quadrant, with rebound tenderness in the epigastrium and periumbilical area. His laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and lactate levels.

The patient underwent a colonoscopy, which showed multiple areas of scarred mucosa consistent with worsening Crohn's colitis. He was given IV fluids, Tylenol, and solumedrol, and was recommended to be prepped for colonoscopy and hold further steroids and mesalamine.

The patient's discharge medications included IV fluids, Tylenol, and solumedrol. His discharge physical examination revealed a soft, non-distended abdomen with no tenderness or guarding. ||endoftext||

||startoftext|| The patient is a 91-year-old female who was admitted with a non-healing left lower extremity ulcer. She has a history of pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) and has been treated with various medications, including Levaquin and corticosteroids. The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, spinal stenosis, right thigh squamous cell carcinoma, bilateral hearing loss, and diverticulosis. She has also had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and has undergone several surgical procedures, including a rotator cuff repair.

The patient's allergies include dapsone and Levaquin. She has been diagnosed with osteomyelitis and has undergone treatment with antibiotics, including Cefepime. The patient's wound has been treated with intralesional corticosteroid injections and topical steroids, and she has been prescribed oral dapsone.

The patient's vital signs on admission were normal, with the exception of a slightly elevated blood pressure. Her physical examination revealed a wound on her left shin with no surrounding erythema or granulation tissue. She had a 10cm by 5cm ovoid lesion on her left shin with no bone involvement.

The patient's laboratory results showed an elevated white blood cell count and a slightly elevated creatinine level. Her blood cultures were pending, and she had a negative hepatitis panel and ANCA test.

The patient's hospital course was marked by significant nausea and vomiting, which was managed with anti-nausea medication. She was also treated for a DVT and had a moderate scoliosis with asymmetry of the rib cage.

The patient was discharged with a plan for further management and continuity of care at another facility. ||endoftext||

acute blood loss anemia. His home dose coumadin was resumed on

vital signs were routinely monitored.

on a bowel regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and 
output were closely monitored. The patient required 
self-catherizations (his baseline).
ID: The patient received perioperative antibiotics.  The 
patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of

was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. - Resume your 
regular activities as tolerated, but please follow your weight 
bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- WBAT RLE

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take lovenox 40mg daily for 2 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

Physical Therapy:
___ - weight bearing as tolerated right lower extremity. 
Treatments Frequency:
Dry sterile dressing changes daily or as needed. 
Wound evaluation at follow up appointment. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
Opacity at the right lung base likely in part due to effusion 
with possible loculation laterally with adjacent parenchymal 
opacity, potentially in part atelectasis noting that infection 
or mass are entirely possible.  Suspected left pleural effusion 
and atelectasis. Leftward deviation of the upper thoracic 
trachea. Correlation with cross-sectional imaging may help 
further characterize these findings unless prior exam is 
available for comparison.

Overall unchanged cardiopulmonary findings. New patchy opacities 
within the left midlung could possibly have been obscured by the 
overlying left chest wall battery pack on the prior radiograph, 
but nonetheless are concerning for pneumonia given the provided 
clinical history.

___ Transthoracic Echo Report
The left atrial volume index is SEVERELY increased. The right 
atrium is moderately enlarged. A prominent Eustachian valve is 
present (normal variant). There is no evidence for an atrial 
septal defect by 2D/color Doppler. The estimated right atrial 
pressure is ___ mmHg. There is normal left ventricular wall 
thickness with a mildly increased/dilated cavity. There is 
SEVERE regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with 
akinesis of the inferior and inferolateral walls (see schematic) 
and severe global hypokinesis of the remaining segments. There 
is beat-to-beat variability in the left ventricular 
contractility due to the irregular rhythm. Quantitative biplane 
left ventricular ejection fraction is 13 %. There is no resting 
left ventricular outflow tract gradient. No ventricular septal 
defect is seen. Normal right ventricular cavity size with mild 
global free wall hypokinesis. The aortic sinus diameter is 
normal for gender with mildly dilated ascending aorta. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. There is no 
aortic valve stenosis. There is trace aortic regurgitation. The 
mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened with no mitral valve 
prolapse. The transmitral E-wave deceleration time is short 
(consistent with restrictive left ventricular filling). There is 
mild [1+] mitral regurgitation. The tricuspid valve leaflets 
appear structurally normal. There is mild to moderate [___] 
tricuspid regurgitation. Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity 
of tricuspid regurgitation may be UNDERestimated. The estimated 
pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal but may be 
underestimated due to shadowing. The estimated pulmonary artery 
ejection time is 86 consistent with mildly elevated pulmonary 
artery systolic pressures. There is no pericardial effusion. 
Bilateral pleural effusions are present.
IMPRESSION: Normal left ventricular wall thickness with mild to 
moderate cavity dilation and severe regional and global systolic 
dysfunction c/w a mixed ischemic (in an RCA distribution) and 
nonischemic cardiomyopathy with beat to beat variabiltiy in 
systolic function. Restrictive left ventricuar filling. At least 
mild to moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Mild mitral 
regurgitation.

There is no spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus in the body of 
the left atrium/left atrial appendage.The left atrial appendage 
ejection velocity is mildly depressed. No spontaneous echo 
contrast or thrombus is seen in the body of the right 
atrium/right atrial appendage. The right atrial appendage 
ejection velocity is normal. There is no evidence for an atrial 
septal defect by 2D/color Doppler. Overall left ventricular 
systolic function is depressed. The right ventricle has 
depressed free wall motion. There are simple atheroma in the 
aortic arch with simple atheroma in the descending aorta. The 
aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. No masses or

seen. There is no aortic valve stenosis. There is no aortic

with no mitral valve prolapse. No masses or vegetations are seen

be estimated.

3.  Small right pleural effusion

10.1 x 5.7 x 11.9 cm, causing obstruction of the right bronchus 
intermedius, is concerning for malignancy.  There is extensive 
mediastinal and right hilar 
lymphadenopathy, as well as axillary and supraclavicular 
lymphadenopathy.  
Findings are suggestive of small cell lung cancer versus poorly 
differentiated carcinoma of the lung. 
2. Please see separate report of CT abdomen and pelvis performed 
same day for description of subdiaphragmatic findings. 

___ Barium Study
Very limited evaluation secondary to patient's limited mobility. 
 There was no obstruction noted within the esophagus. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
PATIENT SUMMARY STATEMENT: 
==========================
MR. ___ is a ___ with PMH of HTN, HLD, CAD (s/p DES x2 to ___ 
in ___, HFrEF (EF 10%),
Afib on Coumadin, and prior treated lung CA who initially 
presented with dyspnea and chest pain, found to have cardiogenic 
shock, possibly in the setting of a pneumonia, complicated by 
Type II NSTEMI. Course further complicated by imaging that 
showed metastatic cancer, and patient ultimately discharged with 
hospice. 

ACTIVE ISSUES:
===============
# Goals of care
# Metastatic cancer
Noted to have significant weight loss with concern for 
malignancy. CT torso obtained and showed a soft tissue mass in 
the RLL of the lung and multiple liver lesions, concerning for 
metastatic small cell lung cancer vs. poorly differentiated 
carcinoma of the lung. Goals of care meeting held with patient 
and family, and ultimately, decision was made to pursue hospice 
care. Pain was controlled with oxycodone and tylenol. 

# Cardiogenic shock ___ HFrEF exacerbation 
On arrival to CCU, hypotensive requiring support with 
vasopressors. Diuresed with IV Lasix gtt and treated with broad 
spectrum antibiotics for presumed PNA, which was felt to be the 
trigger of his heart failure exacerbation. Ultimately improved 
and was weaned off pressor support. Patient underwent RHC on 
___ that showed low biventricular filling pressures, so 
diuresis was subsequently held. Continued on isordil for 
afterload reduction, and unable to tolerate re-addition of beta 
blocker. Discontinued isordil and bblocker on discharge. 
Continued aspirin. 

# Chest pain 
# Type II NSTEMI
Likely in the setting of pneumonia and HFrEF exacerbation. ECG 
with atrial fibrillation, RBBB, intermittent VPCs, and 
non-specific ST-TW changes. Troponins peaked at 0.56. Continued 
to have intermittent chest pain, and on re-check, ECG unchanged 
and troponins elevated to peak of 1.46. Chest pain improved with 
Tums and magic mouth wash, suggesting possible GERD/esophageal 
dysmotility, but persisted despite treatment. Likely has 
component of CAD, so nitrates were uptitrated. Continued on 
asprin and stopped atorvastatin due to potential side effects. 
Chest pain likely in the setting of metastatic cancer (see 
above). 

# Pneumonia
CXR with concern for RLL pneumonia, also with leukocytosis and 
cough. Treated with 7d course of cefepime. 

# Atrial Fibrillation
# Frequent PVCs
# Supertherapeutic INR

Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because you were feeling short 
of breath and having chest pain. 

In the hospital, you were treated for an exacerbation of your 
heart failure with medications to help remove extra fluid from 
your body. You were also treated with antibiotics for pneumonia. 
You continued having chest pain, and imaging showed that you 
have cancer, which we believe is causing your pain. We had a 
discussion with you and your family, and ultimately, you decided 
to pursue hospice care. 

When you leave the hospital, you should continue taking the 
medications that help you feel comfortable. You should follow up 
with your primary care doctor as needed.

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 75-year-old male who was admitted with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a significant past medical history, including hypertension, dyslipidemia, cardiomyopathy with an ejection fraction of 10%, atrial fibrillation, and a recent lung cancer diagnosis. He was recently treated with Lasix and was switched to Entresto due to a chronic cough. On admission, his vital signs were notable for a temperature of 97.3, heart rate of 50, and blood pressure of 102/70. His physical exam revealed mild crackles at the bases of his lungs and a wide QRS complex on his EKG. Laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels and a lactate level of 2.8. He was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, and cardiology recommended diuresis with IV Lasix, obtaining a TTE, and trending cardiac biomarkers. He was prescribed aspirin, cefepime, vancomycin, and furosemide at discharge. ||endoftext||

She has a history of glomerulonephritis, kidney transplants, and a double kidney and pancreas transplant. She has also had a history of diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia, but no COPD. Her mother has been diagnosed with lung cancer, but is now in remission.

The patient's past medical history includes a stereotaxic brain biopsy, induction cycles of high-dose methotrexate, and maintenance therapy. She has also had a history of meningoencephalitis and was treated with ganciclovir. Her neurological problems began when her mother noted psychomotor slowing, short-term memory problems, and inability to tolerate stress.

The patient's allergies include Ampicillin, Penicillins, and Morphine Hcl. She has no known adverse reactions.

The patient's diagnosis is recurrent EBV-driven CNS lymphoma, which is being treated with HD-MTX. She has undergone several cycles of HD-MTX and has had a stable brain MRI.

The patient's procedures performed include a stereotaxic brain biopsy and CyberKnife radiosurgery.

The patient's medications prescribed at discharge include leucovorin, anti-emetics, and mycophenolate. ||endoftext||

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 43-year-old male with a chief complaint of confusion and obtundation. He has a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, seizures from ethanol withdrawal, and has undergone liver transplant workup. He was admitted to the hospital with a blood ammonia level of 217 and was treated with therapeutic paracentesis and oral lactulose. He also received a single dose of Cipro/Flagyl in the emergency department. The patient's physical exam revealed an obtunded mental status, anicteric sclera, and a soft, distended abdomen. Laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, low albumin, and abnormal blood chemistry. The patient's urine culture grew Klebsiella pneumoniae, an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) producer, which is resistant to many antibiotics. The patient underwent a duplex Doppler ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis, which showed a coarse echotexture of the liver and significant ascites. ||endoftext||

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Weight bearing as tolerated on left lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
  1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is 
an over the counter medication.
  2)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
  3)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.
      
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please continue home dabigatran 75mg twice a day

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If 
draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper 
tape.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

THIS PATIENT IS EXPECTED TO REQUIRE <30 DAYS OF REHAB
Physical Therapy:
Weight bearing as tolerated, left lower extremity
Treatments Frequency:
Any staples or superficial sutures you have are to remain in 
place for at least 2 weeks postoperatively.  Incision may be 
left open to air unless actively draining.  If draining, you may 
apply a gauze dressing secured with paper tape.  You may shower 
and allow water to run over the wound, but please refrain from 
bathing for at least 4 weeks postoperatively.

Call your surgeon's office with any questions.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a left femoral neck fracture after being struck by a train. He has a history of coronary artery disease, atrial flutter, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and other medical conditions. He was found to have a low hematocrit in the post-anesthesia care unit and was transfused with 2 units of packed red blood cells. He was also noted to have orthostatic hypotension and was given IV and oral hydration. A Foley catheter was placed due to urinary retention.

The patient underwent a left hip short TFN placement procedure and was discharged with a diagnosis of left femoral neck fracture. He was prescribed several medications, including acetaminophen, bisacodyl, calcium carbonate, dabigatran, docusate sodium, finasteride, metoprolol, pantoprazole, rosuvastatin, senna, and vitamin D.

The patient was advised to follow up with his surgeon and to take his medications as prescribed. He was also instructed to avoid baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks and to keep his incision clean and dry. ||endoftext||

Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking part in your care. You had a rigid 
bronchoscopy (procedure to look in your lungs) with cryptherapy 
and electrocautery to help open your airways and improve your 
breathing. After the procedure you had shortness of breath and 
likely had a blockage of your airway from a mucous plug or blood 
clot. You were admitted to the ICU for non-invasive ventilation 
(breathing mask) and respiratory monitoring. Your breathing 
improved tremendously overnight and your x-ray showed 
improvement. You also received steroids after the procedure, 
which were subsequently stopped.

care, and felt that your breathing was greatly improved and you 
were safe for discharge, with follow-up in clinic in one month 
with a CT scan of your airways.

He has a history of meningioma, astrocytoma, and CVA, which has resulted in limited verbal ability. He was recently discharged from the hospital after an extended course of treatment for sepsis, GI bleed, cholecystitis, and C. diff. He was readmitted due to a fever and possible recurrent C. diff.

The patient's past medical history includes a temporal lobe astrocytoma, multiple meningiomas, a seizure disorder, PE, hypertension, and a left thyroid nodule. He has also had a G tube placement and has a history of GI bleed and cholecystitis.

The patient's diagnosis was HAP and possible recurrent C. diff. He underwent a CT abdomen, which showed a decompressed gallbladder with a cholecystostomy tube and bibasilar atelectasis. He was treated with broad-spectrum antimicrobials, including flagyl, zosyn, and vancomycin, and was eventually discharged on levofloxacin and flagyl.

The patient's medications at discharge included levofloxacin, flagyl, and warfarin. He was also prescribed a lovenox bridge and was instructed to continue aggressive pulmonary toilet management, including out-of-bed-to-chair exercises and chest physiotherapy. ||endoftext||

age: 80. gender: M.  
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___

Chief Complaint:
hypoxic respiratory failure, septic shock 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Central line placement on ___ and ___. Failed 
thoracentesis on ___.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o male with complicated past medical history of COPD, 
atrial fibrillation, ileus, abdominal abscess status post 
drainage, and C-difficile infection, who was initially admitted 
to ___ on ___ for hyponatremia. Per discussion with the 
hospitalist there, patient had a PEG tube placed for FTT. He was 
on ciprofloxacin and tigacycline and required ICU transfer for 
hypotension and septic shock, and was on levophed and dopamine. 
A CVL was placed, and antibiotics were changed to imipenem and 
vancomycin. A urine culture was positive for ESBL Ecoli on 
___. Patient's code status was changed from DNR/DNI to 
full code after discussing goals of care with patient's wife.

Patient remained with a clinical picture of septic shock, 
improved for one day, but then developed hypoxic respiratory 
failure. X-ray was felt to be consistent with multifocal 
pneumonia and CHF/volume overload, for which lasix x 2 was 
attempted. Patient was reportedly agitated and pulled out his 
PICC line and femoral CVL line. A PIV x 1 was placed.

For his shortness of breath, lasix, morphine, and solumedrol 
were initiated. Patient's wife reports that goals of care are 
still full code. An ABG was 7.21/39/77/92% on 100% NRB. Bipap 
was attempted, but patient was still with labored breathing, and 
intubation was performed. ETT position was checked prior to 
transfer and was in adequate position. Patient's ventilator 
settings are AC 440 x 16 x 88% FIO2 x 5 PEEP on transfer. 
  
On transfer, VS: BP 160/100, HR 107, 96% for oxygenation. 
Propofol was initiated. Access is only 1 PIV. Per report, 
further attempt at access was not successful. The patient was 
intubated and sedated on arrival.
 
Past Medical History:
- COPD, on home O2
- atrial fibrillation 
- congestive heart failure 
- history of recurrent urinary tract infections 
- Pseudomonas and Proteus sepsis abdominal abscess
- C. Diff colitis
- failure to thrive s/p PEG placement

___

not-relevant to the current admission

General: Intubated, sedated
HEENT: PERLL, Sclera anicteric  
Neck: supple, JVP 6-8 cm, no LAD  
Lungs: coarse breath sounds bilaterally, rhonchi with occasional 
crackles at bases 
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops  
Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, 
no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly  
Ext: warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or 
edema 
 
Pertinent Results:
Discharge laboratory studies:
 - ___    
 - ___ 04:00AM BLOOD WBC-10.8 RBC-2.75* Hgb-8.7* Hct-26.2* 
MCV-95 MCH-31.6 MCHC-33.1 RDW-16.4* Plt ___

Na-136 K-4.1 Cl-99 HCO3-31 AnGap-10

 - ___ Blood Culture: no growth
 - multiple negative C diff studies

Imaging:
 - ___ Chest Xray: The endotracheal tube now terminates 4.5 
cm from the carina. An enteric tube terminates in the stomach. A 
right internal jugular catheter terminates in the mid SVC. There 
has been interval improvement in aeration bilaterally, right 
greater than left, but alveolar and interstitial opacities 
compatible with edema persist. Lung bases remain hyperinflated, 
with small bilateral pleural effusions. The cardiomediastinal 
silhouette is unchanged. IMPRESSION: 1. Supporting devices as 
described. 2. Interval improvement in pulmonary edema, now 
moderate. 3. Unchanged small-to-moderate bilateral pleural 
effusions. 
 - ___ TTE: The left atrium is normal in size. Left 
ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There 
is moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with 
near akinesis of the anterior septum and anterior wall. The 
lateral wall is mildly hypokinetic. There is no ventricular 
septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly 
thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial mitral 
regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. 
There is no pericardial effusion. 
IMPRESSION: Moderate regional LV systolic dysfunction consistent 
with LAD ischemia/infarction. Calcified aortic valve without 
significant stenosis.  

___ CT Chest notable findings: 1. Bilateral upper lobe 
bronchovascular ground-glass infiltrates, this is most likely 
due to bilateral upper lobe pneumonia or aspiration, hemorrhage 
and pulmonary edema are considered less likely.  2. A renal 
ultrasound is suggested to evaluate possible left hydroureter. 

___ Renal Ultrasound notable findings: No evidence of 
hydronephrosis, hydroureter, or stones.  Previously seen left 
hydroureter has now resolved, possibly secondary to Foley 
placement in the bladder. 

___ CT Chest notable findings: 1. No intra-abdominal 
abscess. 2. Interval near-complete resolution of right pleural 
effusion. Interval increase of small-to-moderate on the left. 3. 
Normal aeration of the right lung without focal consolidations. 
4. Subtotal collapse of the left lower lobe with loculated 
pleural effusion.  Superimposed infectious process cannot be 
excluded. 5. Bilateral severe hydronephrosis extending to the 
UVJs but without definite obstructive mass. Could represent 
chronic reflux from a full bladder. 6. Tiny pockets of 
intravesicular air in the anti-dependent portion of the bladder. 
If the patient has no recent instrumentation, differential 
diagnosis of emphysematous cystitis must be considered. 7. A 1.3 
cm right hyperdense renal cyst, better characterized in the 
previous ultrasound study. 8. Tiny urinary bladder stones. 

___ Renal Ultrasound notable findings:Interval development 
of bilateral symmetric moderate hydronephrosis involving both 
kidneys. Foley catheter in the bladder outlet and likely not 
functioning properly. 

___ Portable chest X-ray: Cardiac size is normal. Collapse 
of the left lower lobe is stable. Mild left pleural effusion has 
minimally increased in amount. The right lung is clear with no 
pneumothorax. Small right pleural effusion is unchanged.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is an ___ M with a medical history notable for COPD, 
congestive heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, recent 
G-tube placement for failure to thrive, and recurrent urinary 
tract infections who was transferred from an outside hospital to 
the ___ ICU for urosepsis.

He initially was intubated and on pressors. He required 
treatment for urosepsis (OSH cultures grew ESBL E coli), COPD, 
health-care associated pneumonia (culture negative), and CHF 
with reduced LVEF. He eventually improved and was extubated on 
___. However, he required transfer back to the ICU for flash 
pulmonary edema a few days later.

He was eventually transferred back to the floor and treated for 
the above conditions. He continued to have episodes of 
hypotension and respiratory distress and was found to have a 
leukocytosis and suspected empyema. This was unable to be 
drained by thoracentesis and the patient declined additional 
invasive procedures. He stabilized but did not improve on 
broad-spectrum antibiotics. Other active issues during this time 
included frequent episodes of flash pulmonary edema, delirium, 
and anxiety. 

A family meeting was held and the patient and his wife expressed 
strong desires for him to return home. He decided to pursue 
hospice care for his many chronic medical conditions. Of note, 
the patient had recently been admitted to a SNF and had a G-tube 
placed for failure to thrive thought to be from mild dementia; 
at that time he was DNR/DNI per his wishes but his goals of care 
changed immediately prior to admission to ___.

Management of active issues at discharge are outlined below:
1. Respiratory distress
 - thought to be from both COPD and CHF
- patient unable to tolerate treatments for CHF as outlined 
below
 - COPD treated with Spiriva, Advair, prednisone 5mg, 
guaifenesin, and oxygen
 - as mentioned above, he was treated for a healthcare 
associated pneumonia and may have developed an empyema that 
could not be drained without aggressive treatment; he stabilized 
with long courses of meropenam and ciprofloxacin during the 
hospital stay and these were discontinued at discharge
 - despite aggressive treatment Mr. ___ still complained of 
air hunger at rest and was started on morphine for symptom 
control at discharge

2. Anxiety
 - Mr. ___ reported a history of anxiety and benefited from 
PRN Ativan during his hospital stay

3. Diarrhea and malnutrition
 - he had frequent, loose stools while on tube feeds; these did 
not improve with fiber
 - he had multiple negative C diff studies including a PCR study
 - he was discharged on prophylactic oral Vancomycin given his 
recent antibiotics

4. Congestive heart failure with reduced LVEF
 - patient unable to tolerate beta-blocker,  Ace-In, or 
diuretics due to hypotension; this was likely related to the 
suspected ongoing infection as outlined above

5. BPH with obstruction
 - relieved with a Foley and could not tolerate BPH therapies 
due to hypotension as mentioned above

6. Atrial fibrillation, paroxysmal: 
 - continued on amiodarone at discharge; no anticoagulation as 
not consistent with goals of care

 Your infection was treated with antibiotics. In addition to the

Discharge Condition:

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you this visit. You were 
admitted to the hospital with complaints of chest pain and were 
having a heart attack. You were immediately taken to the cardiac 
catheterization lab where they identifified a blockage 
consistnet with the changes on your EKG which they thought to be 
the cause of your acute heart attack. This vessel is called the 
right coroanry artery. This artery was stented with a drug 
coated stent. At that time it was also confirmed by visualizing 
all of the arteries that feed the heart muscle that you have 
blockages in the other arteries of your heart. 

You have also been identified as having a blcokage in your right 
carotid artery.

Given these issues we are sending you home with tight medication 
control as detailed below and with a plan to discuss the most 
appropriate interventions for your coronary artery disease as 
well as your carotid blockage. 

You will start the following medications:
Aspirin 325mg daily
Plavix 75mg daily: this prevents clot from forming in the new 
area the stent was placed, DO NOT stop this medication unless 
specifically spoken to by Dr. ___.
Rosouvastatin 20mg daily: this is replacing the pravastatin for 
cholesterol management
Metorpolol 75mg XL daily: This is to decrease your heart rate 
and thereby the workload of the heart.
Nitroglycerin tablets: placed under the tongue and dissolve if 
you experience chest pain or shortness of breath this medicaiton 
acutely dilates the arteries that feed the heart muscle. You can 
take one every five minutes for a total of three and shoudl call 
___ if you do not experience relief. 

Additionally while you were in the hospital you received two 
large doses of contrast which can effect your kidneys. You 
should have started a drug called an ACE inhibitor as part of 
your recovery after your heart attack, but this can also cause 
some damage to vulnerable kidneys so we are holding this drug 
for now. This should be reconsidered once your labs are back to 
baseline and we know your kidney function is back to baseline.

___

The patient underwent a left heart cardiac catheterization with a drug-coated stent placed in the right coronary artery. He was also noted to have severe 3-vessel disease.

The patient's diagnosis is high-grade stenosis of the right internal carotid artery at its origin, and regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction suggestive of multivessel ischemia.

The patient underwent the following procedures: left heart cardiac catheterization with a drug-coated stent placed in the right coronary artery.

The patient was prescribed the following medications at discharge: aspirin 325 daily, Plavix 75mg daily, metoprolol 37.5 BID, captopril 6.25mg BID, and rosuvastatin 20mg daily.

The patient will require both CABG and CEA in the coming weeks, and the cardiac surgery and vascular surgery teams will discuss the approach in terms of performing interval vs. simultaneous procedures. ||endoftext||

following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.

with the surgeon.
*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered.

-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 47-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She had a history of colon adenocarcinoma and had undergone a low anterior resection 7 months prior. She presented with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, which was similar to a previous small bowel obstruction (SBO) she experienced after her colectomy. 

The patient's past medical history includes breast cancer, cervical DDD, and depression. She has no known family history of breast or ovarian cancer, but her maternal grandmother had colon cancer. 

The patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy and lysis of adhesions, and was found to have a strangulating small bowel obstruction. She was managed with IV fluids, medications, and a nasogastric tube, and was eventually able to tolerate a regular diet. 

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of strangulating small bowel obstruction, and was prescribed medications including venlafaxine, famotidine, docusate sodium, and hydromorphone. She was advised to follow up with her doctor in 6 weeks and to avoid lifting heavy objects, driving, or operating heavy machinery while taking pain medications. ||endoftext||

for any acute processes.  He was placed on telemetry and IV 
metoprolol,  was found to be overall fluid positive, and 
responded well to gentle diuresis and minimalizing fluid intake.

advanced on POD 4.  He received one dose of unasyn, and his

consistent with serous fluid, and removed without difficulty.

||startoftext|| The patient, a 91-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) in the right hemisphere. He was found unresponsive on the floor by his grandson and was taken to the hospital where a head CT scan revealed a large hemorrhage with intraventricular spread. The patient was intubated and started on a propofol drip. He was previously well, living alone and fully independent, with a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and benign prostatic hypertrophy.

The patient's physical examination revealed a critically ill patient with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 3, with no response to voice or deep noxious stimuli. His neurologic examination showed anisocoria, with a right pupil that was minimally reactive to light, and a left pupil that was also minimally reactive. He had no movement to noxious stimuli on the left arm and was internally rotating his left leg to nailbed pressure.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated levels of creatine kinase (CK), troponin T, and lactate, as well as an anion gap and hyperosmolality. His urine analysis showed proteinuria and hematuria.

The patient's hospital course was complicated by respiratory arrest, which led to his death. He was diagnosed with subarachnoid hemorrhage following injury, pneumonia, and other amyloidosis. He was prescribed several medications, including diltiazem, metoprolol, and vancomycin, but expired before discharge.

Note: The patient's medications on admission were aspirin, diltiazem, finasteride, digoxin, metoprolol, and lasix, but he was not prescribed any medications at discharge since he expired. ||endoftext||

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a Right Sided Colectomy 
and hernia repair for surgical management of your colon polyp 
and incisional hernia. You have recovered from this procedure 
well and you are now ready to return home. Samples from your 
colon were taken and this tissue has been sent to the pathology 
department for analysis. You will receive these pathology 
results at your follow-up appointment. If there is an urgent 
need for the surgeon to contact you regarding these results they 
will contact you before this time. You have tolerated a regular 
diet, passing gas and your pain is controlled with pain 
medications by mouth. You may return home to finish your 
recovery.  
You will be discharged home on Lovenox injections to prevent 
blood clots after surgery. You will take this for 30 days after 
your surgery date. This will be given once daily. Please follow 
all nursing teaching instruction given by the nursing staff. 
Please monitor for any signs of bleeding: fast heart rate, 
bloody bowel movements, abdominal pain, bruising, feeling faint 
or weak. If you have any of these symptoms please call our 
office for advice or seek medical attention if there is an 
emergency. Avoid any contact activity while taking Lovenox. 
Please take extra caution to avoid falling.

 Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not 
have had a bowel movement prior to your discharge which is 
acceptable, however it is important that you have a bowel 
movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not 
uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function 
but you should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool 
and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are 
expected. However, if you notice that you are passing bright red 
blood with bowel movements or having loose stool without 
improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room 
if the symptoms are severe. If you are taking narcotic pain 
medications there is a risk that you will have some 
constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener 
such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the 
office.  
 If you have any of the following symptoms please call the 
office for advice ___:  
 fever greater than 101.5  
 increasing abdominal distension  
 increasing abdominal pain  
 nausea/vomiting  
 inability to tolerate food or liquids  
 prolonged loose stool  
 extended constipation  
 inability to urinate  
 Incisions:  
 You have a long vertical surgical incisions on your abdomen 
closed with staples. This is healing well however it is 
important that you monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of 
infection including: increasing redness of the incision lines, 
white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the 
incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or 
swelling of the area.  
 You may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. 
The small incisions may be left open to the air. If closed with 
steri-strips (little white adhesive strips), these will fall off 
over time, please do not remove them. Please no baths or 
swimming until cleared by the surgical team.  
 Pain  
 It is expected that you will have pain after surgery and this 
pain will gradually improved over the first week or so you are 
home. You will especially have pain when changing positions and 
with movement. You should continue to take 2 Extra Strength 
Tylenol (___) for pain every 8 hours around the clock and you 
may also take Advil (Ibuprofen) 600mg every 6 hours for 7 days. 
Please do not take more than 3000mg of Tylenol in 24 hours or 
any other medications that contain Tylenol such as cold 
medication. Do not drink alcohol while or Tylenol. Please take 
Advil with food. If these medications are not controlling your 
pain to a point where you can ambulate and preform minor tasks, 
you should take a dose of the narcotic pain medication 
oxycodone. Please take this only if needed for pain. Do not take 
with any other sedating medications or alcohol. Do not drive a 
car if taking narcotic pain medications.  
 Activity  
 You may feel weak or "washed out" for up to 6 weeks after 
surgery. No heavy lifting greater than a gallon of milk for 3 
weeks. You may climb stairs. You may go outside and walk, but 
avoid traveling long distances until you speak with your 
surgical team at your first follow-up visit. Your surgical team 
will clear you for heavier exercise and activity as the observe 
your progress at your follow-up appointment. You should only 
drive a car on your own if you are off narcotic pain medications 
and feel as if your reaction time is back to normal so you can 
react appropriately while driving. You will have a physical 
therapist visit you at home to work on your strength and 
mobility.  
 Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

# Upper GI bleed: Pt has a hx of a gastric cancer s/p resection 
and now has had recurrent bleeds over last week at her 
anastomsis site and is s/p a clipping of a gastroduodenal 
branch. She was initially admitted to the MICU where she 
received one unit pRBC, however as NG lavage was negative and 
she remained hemodynamically stable she was quickly transferred 
to the general medical floor. GI, surgery and ___ were consulted. 
 followed the patient while in-house and given negative repeat 
nasogastric lavage, patient was transferred to the floor. Prior 
to EGD/Colonoscopy, patient was continued on Sucralfate, 
protonix BID IV with every ___ hour hematocrits. Patient had 
EGD/colonoscopy on ___. On ___ patient felt lightheaded and saw 
double vision, in the setting of hemodynamic stability, and Hct 
had dropped ___ points. 2 units blood transfused, and hct bumped 
appropriately. The next morning, repeat EGD performed that 
showed evidence of old bleed, but no active bleed. That same 
day, tagged RBC scan performed to attempt to localize source of 
bleeding, but did not show any definite GI bleed.  Patient next 
had a repeat EGD on ___ in which further clipping was done (see 
results section). 
After that final procedure, patient's Hct was serially checked 
and remained stable. Her diet was advanced and well tolerated. 
PPI changed to PO. Sucralfate continued. Patient was ambulating 
and was notably pain-free throughout her entire time on the 
hospital floor. Serology was positive for H.pylori and the 
patient was started on quadruple therapy for ___elieve the anastamosis site s/p gastric cancer resection was 
vulnerable to ulceration/bleed, and in the setting of H.pylori 
infection resulted in further ulceration and hence the bleed. 
Follow up with GI was arranged prior to discharge.
.
# Fever: UA was positive therefore she was treated with 
Ciprofloxacin.  Urine culture did then grow two species 
infection. Treated for e.coli and beta strep in her urine 
(asymptomatic), with an antibiotic course. Afebrile afterwards, 
without leukocytosis, without dysuria.
.
# Renal failure: Creatinine on admission to OSH was 1.6 --> 1.3 
on admission to ___ but responded to 4 liters total of normal 
saline and one unit pRBC to 1.2. Continued hydration, in setting 
of NPO and bleed, again brought Cr down lower. On discharge, Cr 
was stable and patient was without dysuria and was hydrating on 
her own through PO.
.
# HTN: Blood pressures were mildly elevated in the setting of 
holding her home amlodipine and lisinopril given the recent GI 
bleed. These were continued to be held in the setting of bleed. 
Beta-blocker started to help reduce patient's pre-op risk, in 
case had to urgently go to surgery. Once GI bleed issue resolved 
and Hct's were stable, stopped beta-blocker and restarted 
patient's home anti-hypertensive regimen.
.
# Memory impariment / Presumed dementia: Patient is a very poor 
historian and has little short term memmory. Unclear if she 
officially has a dx of dementia, but appears to on exam. Patient 
was monitored closely for delirium, re-oriented frequently and 
tubes/drains were minimized when possible. Without issues during 
this hospitalization.  Requires outpatient follow up. 
. 
# Communication: Son ___ is HCP; he was updated throughout the 
___ hospital course.
.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hosptial with blood in your stool. Your 
blood levels were monitored and you were rehydrated. You 
continued to have blood in your stool, the gastrointestinal team 
and the surgical team were consulted regarding your care. With 
multiple imaging studies by the gastrointestinal team to looks 
at your esophagus, stomach, and intestines, they saw evidence of 
bleeding at the stomach, near the site of your prior surgery 
where there was bleeding & an ulcer. You were transfused blood 
and IV fluids, and you had clips placed at the bleeding site. 
After the clips were appropriately placed, your blood counts 
were closely monitored and they remained stable for multiple 
days. We believe the bleeding had to do with a bacteria in your 
stomach as well as it being a complication at your prior 
surgical site where there was a bleeding ulcer. Your diet was 
advanced to regular and you were tolerating that well; you were 
also feeling well and walking well. You had stopped bleeding, 
and on discharge your blood levels were stable.
.
You had a fever that resolved. You were found to have a urinary 
tract infection, and were treated with a course of antibiotics.
.
You spent a night in the ICU and then were on the regular 
hospital floor.
.
Changes to your medications include:
- START Metonidazole four times a day for 2 weeks
- START Bismuth four times a day for 2 weeks
- START Tetracycline four times a day for 2 weeks
- START Pantoprazole twice a day
- START Sucralfate four times a day
- START Senna daily, as needed for constipation
- CONTINUE your other home medications
.

check your blood level to make sure that it is stable. On 
discharge from the hospital today (___), your Hematocrit 
level was 34.1).
.
Please call your doctor or return to the hospial if you develop 
vomiting with blood, bloody stool, lightheadedness, shortness of 
breath, chest pain, or other symptoms that concern you or your 
family.

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is an 88-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital due to hematochezia. She has a history of gastric cancer, hypertension, and dementia. She was previously treated for a bleeding vessel at an anastomosis site and underwent clipping of the gastroduodenal artery. On admission, she had a hemoglobin level of 33 and was given a blood transfusion. She underwent endoscopy and colonoscopy, which showed a large amount of clot in the stomach and an ulceration at the anastomotic site. The patient was given medications including Pantoprazole, Acetaminophen, Lidocaine Jelly, Ondansetron, and Metronidazole. She was also given 2 liters of normal saline and had a nasogastric tube placed. The patient's vital signs were stable, and she was able to ambulate without difficulty. The patient's urine culture showed the presence of beta streptococcus group B and Escherichia coli. The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of upper gastrointestinal bleed and was advised to follow her hematocrit levels closely and continue taking proton pump inhibitors and carafate slurry. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ presented with a complex history of fistulizing 
ileocolonic Crohn's disease since ___ and now a colocutaneous 
fistula/abscess. At this of her admission it was clear that her 
penetrating Crohn's disease had not been responding to Stelara 
and her steroid dependence was potentially predisposing to 
fistula/abscess formation. 

In this current setting both Gastroenterology and Colorectal 
surgery determined that there were limited medical options to 
attempt to induce remission of her disease. It was recommended 
that she receive total parenteral nutrition or enteral feeding- 
although she initially declined, she eventually consented to a 
PICC being placed so that she could receive TPN. TPN was 
continued throughout this admission and by the time of 
discharge, it was being cycled over 12hours and this was 
tolerated well. 

CT taken on ___ was indicative of an active Crohn's flare; MRE 
was also obtained and demnstrated extensive acute on chronic 
inflammation involving multiple loops of small bowel and large 
bowel. Of particular note, on CT there was an area surrounding 
the eleventh rib concerning for osteomyelitis. She underwent MRI 
of chest to further characterise this. It demonstrated a 
10x1.7x6.8cm abscess centered at the left thoracolumbar junction 
tracking along the left chest wall and extending inferiorly to 
the level of iliac bone in the setting of a colocutaneous 
fistula.As a result infectious disease recommended daily 
ertapenem infusions (1g daily for 7 days until surgery).  She is 
planned for an OR procedure on ___ for multiple resections to 
get control of her fistulizing disease and possible ostomy 
creation; the area surround the 11th rib will also be cultured.

  

 
Medications on Admission:
(Stelara) 
Prednisone 20mg Daily

Dear Ms. ___, 

You were admitted to the hospital with drainage from your 
previous incision. Imaging was obtained and confirmed a fistula 
(connection) from your colon to your skin. You were started on 
antibiotics, IV nutrition, and given bowel rest. You are now 
ready to be discharged on antibiotics, IV nutrition, and 
continued sips of the clear ensure.   
 
If you have any of the following symptoms, please call the 
office or go to the emergency room (if severe): increasing 
abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, nausea, 
vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, prolonged loose 
stool, or extended constipation.
 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care, we wish 
you all the best!

target: ||startoftext|| The patient is a 56-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with right lower extremity pain and maceration. He has a history of diabetes, Charcot foot, osteomyelitis, and tibiocalcaneal fusion. He was previously treated for C. difficile and has a history of atrial fibrillation. The patient has allergies to erythromycin base and has had adverse reactions to it. His diagnosis was mixed flora with MRSA, and he was treated with vancomycin and ertapenem. He underwent debridement with podiatry and PICC placement. At discharge, he was prescribed medications including vancomycin and ertapenem. ||endoftext||

___:  chest x-ray:

No previous images.  The cardiac silhouette is mildly enlarged 
and there is opacification centrally consistent with elevated 
pulmonary venous pressure.  Left subclavian PICC line extends to 
the upper right atrium.  It could be pulled back approximately 2 
cm if the desired position is at or above the cavo-atrial 
junction. 

___:  chest x-ray:

Lung volumes remain exceedingly low.  Left basal consolidation 
has improved, right basal consolidation has worsened, suggesting 
pneumonia.  Heart size normal.  Pulmonary vasculature engorged, 
no definite edema or appreciable pleural effusion 

___:  CT of the chest:

The nondependent multifocal consolidations in the right and left 
lung show a distribution and contrast enhancement pattern highly 
suggestive of multifocal pneumonia.  The distribution and 
location of the lesions is not typical for septic emboli.  Small 
bilateral pleural effusions, right more than left, extensive 
bilateral dependent areas of atelectasis. 

___:  cat scan of abdomen and pelvis:

1. Large debridement with packing in the anterior abdominal wall 
and perineum with small locule of gas posterior to the area of 
debridement in the perineum adjacent to the left gluteal cleft. 
Unclear if this reflects postsurgical change or infection. 
2. Very distended bladder despite a Foley catheter. 
3. For details regarding the chest including bilateral 
consolidations, please see dedicated chest CT report

Moderate pulmonary edema has increased, and bibasilar 
consolidation, 
particularly on the right, has worsened since ___, 
pneumonia until 
proved otherwise.  Bilateral pleural effusions are presumed, not 
large but 
still possibly considerable in size. 
  
ET tube, feeding tube, left PIC line, esophageal drainage tube, 
are all in 
standard placements

right 
clinical context

and/or pneumonia.

RECOMMENDATION(S):  Multi focal pneumonia has worsened since 
___, not appreciably changed since ___.  Patient was 
in mild pulmonary edema on ___ which improved by ___ 
and is probably recurred.  Heart is mildly enlarged but 
unchanged.  Pleural effusions are presumed but not large. 
With the chin down, the tip of the endotracheal tube less than 3 
cm from the carina is acceptable.  Left PIC line and right 
jugular line both end low in the SVC close to the superior 
cavoatrial junction.  Feeding tube ends in the stomach.  
Esophageal drainage tube can be traced only as far as the low 
esophagus.  The tip is obscured. 
There is no pneumothorax. 

___:  chest x-ray:

Large areas of consolidation in both lungs due to multi focal 
pneumonia have probably improved on the right, but worsened in 
the left lower lobe over the past 48 hr. The disseminated 
infiltrative abnormality in the left lung is less heterogeneous 
on this radiograph, but I cannot tell whether that means its 
improving or obscured by concurrent edema.  Heart is borderline 
enlarged but unchanged.  Paragraph ET tube and right internal 
jugular line are in standard placements.  Left PIC line ends 
close to the superior cavo-atrial junction.  Feeding tube and 
esophageal drainage tube both into the stomach.  No 
pneumothorax.  Substantial pleural effusions are presumed and 
may be increasing on the left. 
  

  

  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with PMH of poorly controlled 
diabetes transferred from OSH with necrotizing soft tissue 
infection of the perineum/abdominal wall. She underwent multiple 
washout and debridements. Please see the operative reports for 
details. Her hospital course has also been complicated by 
aspiration event ___ w/ mild ARDS, now much improved from a 
respiratory standpoint, extubated. Plastic Surgery has been 
consulted for reconstructive planning. Infectious disease also 
followed the patient and provided recommendations throughout the 
ICU stay.

ICU Course:
Neurologic: Pain control initially with fentanyl gtt, and 
sedation required while intubated. Pain control with Tylenol and 
dilaudid PRN prior to transfer to floor. 
 
Cardiovascular: Initially required multiple pressors for blood 
pressure support. As necrotizing soft tissue infection under 
more control, pressor requirement decreased to the point of no 
longer being required. Patient received IVF crystalloid in 
initial sepsis fluid resuscitation. Albumin boluses were given 
on later in ICU course PRN. 

Pulmonary: Patient developed ARDS and was placed on ARDS 
protocol. She was extubated on ___ (intubated ___. By the 
time of floor transfer, her oxygen requirement continued to 
decrease on NC. ABGs were obtained routinely while intubated for 
assessment. Once extubated, the patient used incentive 
spirometry and got OOB to chair. 
  
GI/Abdomen: The patient was initially NPO with OGT while 
intubated. TF were given via dobhoff (replaced ___. Famotidine 
ppx was given and restarted for heartburn. She was maintained on 
a bowel regimen. She had a rectal tube to keep stool away from 
perineal wound. 

Nutrition: NPO with Glucerna TF via dobhoff.

Renal: Baseline renal function: Cr 0.6 on admission. Patient was 
initially fluid resuscitated. Required IVF for large amounts of 
insensible losses from abdominal drainage, now better quantified 
with make shift wound vac (ioban, moist to dry kerlex, 2x tubes 
to continueous wall suction). By time of transfer to floor, 
fluid balance goal even-negative. Patient received daily 
weights. After initial volume resuscitation, patient was given 
PRN 5% albumin boluses.

Infectious Disease:  
Immunoglobulin levels: IgG 1254; IgA 419 (both near 
normal/high); no IVIG. Infectious disease team following and 
made recommendations throughout hospitalization. Positive 
culture data includes ___ tissue: GBS, ___ miniBAL: ___ 
ALBICANS; ___ urine: ___ ALBICANS, ___ ___ 
BAL: ___ ALBICANS; ___ Urine: YEAST; ___ tissue: ___, 
___ ALBICANS (rare), yeast; ___ urine: YEAST; ___ tissue: 
___ ALBICANS(rare); ___ tissue: Enterococcus. Abx 
history includes Vanc ___ - ___, Cefepime ___ - 
___, Flagyl (___), Clinda ___ - 
___ - ___, fluc (___), Linezolid ___ - ). 
 
Hematology: Hct was trended. Patient required pRBC transfusion 
when Hct <21. For DVT PPx, patient had SQH and pneumoboots.
  
MSK: Abdominal wound packing, serial debridement, dressing 
changes wet to dry.

Endocrine: Uncontrolled diabetes at home. ___ following and 
making recommendations. Insulin lantus 20u qAM + RISS. Goal 
___, Q2 fingersticks.

The patient was transferred to the surgical floor on ___ and 
continued to have frequent visits to the OR for wound 
debridement. During this time, she had marked increases in her 
WBC. ID was consulted and the patient was started on a course of 
meropenum and the cefepime was discontinued.  Hematology was 
consulted for consultation regarding leukocytosis.  No pheresis 
was indicated.  As reported above, the patient reportedly grew 
___ from the tissue culture and was stared on linezolid on ___, 
vancomycin and clindamycin were discontinued. On ___, the 
patient returned to the operating room for wound debridement.  
After the surgery, she went to the intensive care unit for blood 
sugar monitoring and an insulin drip. After the patient came off 
the insulin drip, she was transferred to the surgical floor.  
___ was involved in her care, providing 
recommendations for management of her blood sugar. Her blood 
sugar ranged for 101-306. She continues on lantus and Humalog.  
On ___, the wound vac was placed on her wound and the Plastic 
surgery service was consulted for possible skin grafting. She 
returned to the operating on ___ where she underwent placement 
of split-thickness skin graft on
the right abdominal region and placement of large 
vacuum-assisted closure for abdomen
She also underwent a local tissue rearrangement and advancement 
and closure
of perineal area.  Harvesting was taken from the upper thighs 
and xerform gauze was applied.  

Over the course of the hospitalization, the patient has made 
significant improvement.  Her vital signs have been stable and 
she has been afebrile.  She has been tolerating her diet.  Her 
wound appear clean and dry.  The VAC dressing was replaced on 
___ on left side of abdomen.  She continues to have the foley 
catheter and flexicel in place to prevent wound contamination, 
although, she continues to have leakage from around the flexicel 
and needs frequent cleansing to the area.  Her mother has 
remained at her bedside and has provided support to the patient. 
The patient was discharged to rehab on ___.  

The patient is due to return to the ___ on ___ 
for surgical procedure by the Plastic surgery service, Dr. ___.

___, # ___, for confirmation of time and place of
