||startoftext|| The patient is a 42-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a necrotizing soft tissue infection of the perineum. She has a history of poorly controlled diabetes and was transferred from another hospital. The patient underwent multiple debridements and wound care procedures, including vacuum-assisted closure and packing of the wound. She was treated with antibiotics, including Vancomycin, Imipenem, and Clindamycin, and was started on an insulin drip due to hyperglycemia.

The patient's past medical history includes diabetes and depression. She has allergies to penicillins and shellfish-derived products. Her physical examination revealed a surgical wound over the left perineum and lower abdominal wall, with trace edema in her lower extremities.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated blood sugar levels, anion gap acidosis, and ketonuria. Her complete blood count (CBC) showed a white blood cell count of 23.7, with a hemoglobin level of 6.7 and a platelet count of 240. Her electrolyte levels were within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's chest x-rays showed mild pulmonary edema and bilateral consolidations, consistent with pneumonia. Her CT scan of the chest and abdomen showed multifocal consolidations in the lungs, suggestive of multifocal pneumonia. Her CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed a large debridement with packing in the anterior abdominal wall and perineum.

At discharge, the patient's vital signs were stable, with a temperature of 99.9°F, heart rate of 101 beats per minute, and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Her physical examination revealed a warm and dry skin, with no pedal edema or calf tenderness. ||endoftext||

Cardiomegaly is severe. Heterogeneous opacification throughout

accompanied by right pleural effusion is most easily explained 
by pulmonary edema, but other possibilities abound such as drug 
reaction, hemorrhage, or multifocal pneumonia. 
  
The transvenous right atrial pacer lead terminates more medial 
than the 
expected location of the normal right atrial appendage. It could 
be in a 
gigantic right atrium or running through the tricuspid valve 
toward the 
pulmonary outflow tract of the right ventricle. No pneumothorax.

transvenous pacemaker leads are in standard position. Pulmonary 
edema has improved, now is mild.

new lung 
abnormalities. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted on ___ under the Acute Care Surgery 
Service for management of his RLE hematoma. He was taken to the 
operating room overnight and underwent incision and drainage of 
hematoma with debridement of skin, muscle, and fascia. He 
tolerated the procedure well and was extubated upon completion 
and taken to the PACU for recovery.

Postoperatively, he was transferred to the surgical floor. His 
vital signs were routinely monitored. He remained afebrile with 
a stable heart rate and BP. However, in the evening of POD 0 his 
oxygen saturation was noted to drop into the high 70's on room 
air and he had objective increased work of breathing. A chest 
xray was obtained which showed pulmonary edema and small 
bilateral pleural effusions. The patient was restarted on his 
home dose of Lasix, which had been held initially 
postoperatively for a borderline systolic BP in the 90's. His 
systolic BP remained stable in the 90's-100's with the Lasix. On 
POD1 he continued to have increased work of breathing with 
audible wheezing and inability to wean off supplemental O2 with 
O2 sats in the mid 80's on room air. A repeat chest xray was 
obtained at that time which showed improvement in pulmonary 
edema and stable small bilateral pleural effusions. At the time 
of discharge his O2 sats remained stable in the high 90's on 1.5 
L NC with decreased evidence of pulmonary edema. His oxygen was 
successfully weaned off prior to discharge.

Plastic surgery was consulted for the RLE wound postoperatively, 
who recommended wet to dry dressing changes BID, elevation of 
the RLE, and discussed the possibility of performing a skin 
graft. He will follow up as an outpatient in Plastics clinic for 
further discussions regarding skin grafting.

Physical therapy was consulted as it was noted that the patients 
mobility status had declined since being admitted to the 
hospital. He is being recommended for rehab after his acute 
hospital stay.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted for the above mentioned procedures.  These 
were performed as planned and tolerated well by the patient.

Post-operatively, pain was controlled with IV medications.  The 
chest tube for thoracotomy was managed by CT surgery.  ___ was 
consulted for assistance with patient's care.  After discussing 
with hematology, subQ heparin was initiated on post-op day 2 
after the ___ procedure and daily coumadin with daily INR 
monitoring was initiated.

Post-operatively, patient had increasing problems with pain 
control and with respiratory function.  Diagnosis of mucus plug 
was made, and patient was transferred to the ICU for more 
aggressive pain control and for management of the respiratory 
insufficiency.  Intubation was required.  Patient's respiratory 
status rapidly improved and she was successfully extubated.

throughout hospitalization.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 33-year-old female with a chief complaint of toe pain. She has a history of type 1 diabetes, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on peritoneal dialysis (PD), hypertension, and iron deficiency anemia. She was admitted with a fever of 104 and a left toe ulcer, which had been worsening over two weeks. Imaging studies showed vascular calcifications and minimal loss of cortical detail at the level of the terminal tuft of the third toe, which may reflect a component of osteomyelitis. The patient underwent toe amputation and was diagnosed with osteomyelitis. She was treated with antibiotics and discharged on a 6-week course of oral antibiotics.

The patient has allergies to lisinopril and has a history of poorly controlled type 1 diabetes, with an A1C level of 11. She also has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage III. Her social history is significant for a family history of diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.

The patient's physical examination revealed a regular pulse and rhythm, normal S1 and S2 heart sounds, and clear lungs. Her abdomen was soft, non-tender, and non-distended, and her extremities showed no edema. Her neurological examination was normal.

The patient was discharged on a regimen of antibiotics, vitamin D supplements, and sevelamer to control her hyperphosphatemia. She was also advised to follow up with her primary care physician and to monitor her laboratory results. ||endoftext||

CT OF THE CHEST: There are numerous pathologically enlarged

extensive lymphadenopathy and possibly an adjacent mass. There 
is substantial volume loss due to post obstructive changes 
involving the right lower and middle lobes. A central hypodense 
component with cavitations is noted within the collapsed lung 
region (3:34), which may represent a cavitating mass or 
infection in post obstrutive lung. There is a moderate pleural 
effusion, measuring 30 Hounsfield units on pre-contrast images, 
suggestive of a possible hemorrhagic component. There are 
diffuse bilateral areas of ground-glass opacities involving 
predominantly lower left lung and the right lung, which may be 
infectious, inflammatory nature, or metastasis. The heart is 
mildly enlarged with small pericardial effusion. There are 
extensive coronary vascular calcifications. The intrathoracic 
aorta is notable for calcified atherosclerotic disease without 
aneurysmal changes.  Otherwise, great vessels are unremarkable. 
There are no pathologically enlarged axillary or supraclavicular 
nodes.  
CT OF THE ABDOMEN:  
The liver is of homogeneous attenuation without focal masses. 
There is a 
calcified focus within the right lobe of the liver, which may be 
due to old trauma or related to prior granulomatous disease. 
There is no evidence of intrahepatic or extrahepatic biliary 
ductal dilatation. The hepatic 
vasculature is widely patent. There are multiple gallstones 
within the 
gallbladder without associated inflammatory changes. The spleen 
appears 
unremarkable. The pancreas enhances homogeneously without ductal 
dilatation.  The right adrenal gland appears normal. The left 
adrenal gland is enlarged with attenuation of 35 Hounsfield 
units on pre-contrast images, concerning for a metastatic focus. 
The kidneys enhance and excrete contrast symmetrically without 
evidence of hydronephrosis or renal masses. There are several 
hypodense lesions within the left kidney, which are too small to 
characterize and most likely represent cysts. There are no 
pathologically enlarged mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymph 
nodes. There is no free air or free fluid within the abdomen. 
The 
intra-abdominal aorta and its branches are notable for extensive 
calcified 
atherosclerotic disease without aneurysmal changes.   
The small and large bowel are normal in caliber without evidence 
of 
obstruction. 
  
CT OF THE PELVIS: 
The bladder, distal ureters, prostate, and rectum appear 
unremarkable. The 
Foley catheter is in place. There are scattered diverticula 
within the 
sigmoid colon without associated inflammatory changes. There is 
no inguinal or pelvic lymphadenopathy.   
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: There are numerous destructive lesions 
involving both 
appendicular and axial skeleton. There are multiple destructive 
lesions 
involving bilateral ribs, the largest lesion involves the 
posterior right 11th rib. There are lytic lesions involving the 
right scapula and pelvic bones, easpecially the right acetabulum 
with cortical breakthrough. Vertebrae may also have lucent/lytic 
lesions.   
IMPRESSION:   
1. Extensive mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy. No distinct 
pulmonary 
masses identified. There is near obliteration of the right main 
bronchus with post-obstructive changes involving the right lower 
and middle lobes. There is a central hypodense component and 
cavitation of the right lower lung, which may represent a mass.  
 
2. Diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities, which may be 
infectious, 
inflammatory in nature, and metastasis cannot be excluded.   
3. Moderate right pleural effusion.   
4. Mildly enlarged heart with small pericardial effusion.   
5. Extensive lytic lesions involving both axial and appendicular 
skeleton, 
c/w metastatic lesions.   
6. Enlarged left adrenal gland concerning for metastatic focus.  
 
7. Cholelithiasis without cholecystitis.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with suspected metastitic lung ca presenting with 4 days 
of confusion, s/p fall, found to have SAH and hypercalcemia  
.  
# SAH/AMS: Pt had several days of declining mental status 
leading to a fall. Thus SAH was likely traumatic, there was 
concern for it being ___ mets but intially could not do MRI b/c 
pt could not tolerate during delerium. Neurosurgery consulted in 
ED, and do not feel an acute surgical intervention was 
necessary. Neuro checks were institued.  Because of hx of heavy 
alcholol use there was also concern for possible w/drawal 
symptoms and pt was placed on CIWA but tried to minimize use of 
benzos to avoid exacerbating delerium and eventually able to d/c 
CIWA. Pt was given ativan and zyprexa for agitation. CT of head 
was repeated as pt had a fall from bed but SAH remained 
unchanged. Based on this, neurosurge felt that there still was 
not surgical intevention indicated.  Pt continued to have AMS 
and then spiked a fever, CXR looked like possible PNA/effusion 
and had coarse lung sounds so was started on vanco/zosyn for 
likely obstructive or aspiration PNA. Fever improved as did the 
pt's calcium. Slowly AMS improved. (see below for additional 
details)
.  
# Hypercalcemia/AMS: Hypercalcemia was likely secondary to 
metastatic disease. Was low PTH but PTHrp eventually returned 
positive.  Pt received bisphosphonate at OSH prior to arrive to 
___. Calcitonin and IVF fluids given. Calcium decreased but 
continued to remain elevated. Lasix, steroids and additional 
dose of pamidronate were also given. Renal was consulted for 
help with managment and medications were able to be stopped. 
Eventually combination of interventions resulted in 
normalization of calcium. However, later in hospital course 
___, calcium increased again which was able to be 
controlled w/lasix, fluids; at this point was also due for 
another dose of pamidornate which he received on ___. 
Continued to monitor and give fluids and lasix as needed.  
Calcium began rising again and pt was redosed w/pamidronated on 
___ and Ca improved w/IVF and lasix.
.  
# R basilar and RUL lung opacity, PNA: On initial presentation, 
there was a R basilar and RUL lung opacity and could not rule 
out superimposed PNA on CXR. Pt was reported as having reported 
chills, "shaking" (?rigors), and increased cough at home and had 
recent "head cold." Was afebrile on admission. Received one dose 
of levaquin in the ED. Has remained afebrile but had mild 
leukocytosis however pt was on steriods b/c of aggressive 
attempts to treat hypercalcemia. However, pt spiked overnight on 
___ w/worsening respiratory status so was put on 
vanco+zosyn while cultures pending were pending. There was 
concern for likely obstructive PNA but b/c of delerium there was 
also concern for aspiration PNA. Pt's responded well to abx, 
respiratory status improved and eventually mental status 
improved as well. On ___ switched to PO levoquin w/plan for 
additional 14 days (last day on ___. Sputum and blood 
cultures-->NGTD. Pt completed the course of levo which was then 
stopped; however, several days later pt became 
confused/delerious again on ___ and had fever, coarse lung 
sounds w/worsened CXR so restarted levoquin and flagyl to be 
continued and completed at rehab on ___.
.  
# Hypernatremia: likely related to poor PO intake and 
hypercalcemia. IVF switched prn to ___ to help decrease 
sodium, fix free water defecit. Resolved on ___ but on ___ 
had elevated sodium again.  Gave ___ or D5W prn; lytes 
normalized.  
.  
# Hypokalemia: diuresis related. Pt's K was very sensitive to 
administration of 10mg IV lasix; drop to 2.7 after 1 dose. 
Monitored and repleted IV and PO prn; repeated EKG which was wnl 
and kept pt on tele.
.  
# Metastatic lung cancer: Initially difficult to work up given 
AMS. Could not get MRI of head initially b/c pt wouldn't 
tolerate due to agitation and delerium. CT of head was done to 
assess for brain mets as a ___ best study (did not show any 
brain mets but showed known bony met in orbit). As AMS cleared, 
were able to get biopsy which showed NSC lung cancer (squamous). 
Later MRI of brain was obtained which did not show brain mets. 
Given that pt's AMS and clinical status had improved 
substantially, decision was made to try an attenuated course of 
chemo w/Carboplatin and Taxol. Got first course as inpt which pt 
tolerated well w/only mild nausea; was dosed again on ___ 
___. Outpt followup planned w/Dr. ___. Pt will have 
radiation treatment in ___ at ___ 
___. 
.  
# ETOH abuse: Pt has reported heavy history of daily ETOH use. 
Unclear day of last drink. Did not want to give benzos 
unecessarily in state of mental confusion. Pt placed on CIWA to 
assess scoring, watch vitals closely and institute meds only 
when necessary. Did not score on CIWA but did receive small 
doses of zyprexa and ativan for control of agitation. This 
resolved as mental status cleared. MVI, folate, thiamine, B12 
supplement. Social work consult. Pt also was started on 10mg 
celexa as it appeared that pt was likely self treating 
depression w/EtOH (very sad after his wife's death ___ ago 
per family and pt later mentioned). 
.

Discharge Instructions:
You were transferred to ___ because you were experiencing 
increased confusion and found to have high calcium levels, a 
small head bleed from a prior fall and acute kidney function 
decline which were likely related to your cancer. You were 
transferred here for further management of your acute medical 
issues and work-up of your newly diagnosed cancer. You were 
given medications, IV fluids and other supportive care to help 
reduce your calcium level. Your heart developed an irregular 
beat so you were given medication to help regulate the rate of 
your heart. You were also treated with antibiotics for 
pneumonia. You also had several imaging studies to asses the 
extent of your disease and develop a plan of care.
.

hours.

needed to have roughly 1 bowel movement per day.

compazine
- For pain we have given you lidocaine patches, tylenol and 
iburpofen
- Please continue to take all of your other home medications as 
prescribed
.

||startoftext|| The patient is a 65-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for management of hypercalcemia. He presented with increased confusion, s/p fall with headstrike, and was found to have a serum calcium level of 17. He has a history of presumed metastatic lung cancer, diagnosed approximately two weeks ago based on imaging studies. He has also had a productive cough for the past year, worsening in the past four days, and has been taking Vicodin at home for pain control.

The patient's past medical history includes a presentation to the emergency department two weeks ago with right-sided chest pain, which was found to be a rib fracture, and he was referred to an oncologist. He was told he likely had metastatic lung cancer and was sent for further testing.

The patient's physical exam revealed a cachetic male with altered mental status, diffuse inspiratory crackles, and poor inspiratory effort. His laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, neutrophil count, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, as well as elevated calcium and phosphorus levels.

The patient was given 2L of normal saline and IV Levaquin for possible pneumonia, and was also given zoledronic acid. He was transferred to the hospital's emergency department for further management. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is an ___ year-old male with hypertension, type II 
diabetes mellitus (diet-controlled), and renal carcinoma s/p 
right partial nephrectomy in ___ presenting with new atrial 
fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and cough/dyspnea. 
The patient's symptoms initially were thought to be 
multifactorial with bronchitis (given quality of cough and upper 
airway wheezing without fever or leukocytosis), COPD (given 
extensive smoking history and history of prior cough), and 
diastolic heart failure due to atrial fibrillation with rapid 
ventricular rate. Pneumonia was also considered initially given 
LLL rales. The patient was started on azithromycin/ ceftriaxone/ 
and vancomycin (given + blood culture on day of admission) for 
broad coverage. The patient was also placed on respiratory 
precautions given concern for TB. On ___, the patient was found 
to have acute worsening of respiratory status with tachypnea, 
significant wheezing, and desaturations to 80%'s despite being 
on a non-rebreather. He was transferred to the ICU for further 
evaluation.

Brief MICU course: Upon arrival to the ICU, echo results 
returned showing moderate LV systolic dysfunction with severe 
inferolateral hypokinesis and EF ___ (EF 55% in ___, 4+ 
mitral regurgitation, elevated right-sided pressures, and mild 
LVH. A moderate sized echodense pericardial effusion was noted, 
consistent with blood, inflammation or other cellular elements, 
with no evidence of tamponade. The patient underwent diagnostic 
L thoracentesis, which showed transudative properties with 
cultures and cytology negative. The patient was effectively 
diuresed 3 liters during MICU stay with dramatic improvement in 
SOB. He was then transferred back to the floor. Remainder of 
hospital course is by problem, as follows:

# Cough/ SOB: As above, the patient was initially started on 
antibiotics to cover for a possible bronchitis/ pneumonia. He 
completed a course of ceftriaxone and azithromycin for this. 
(Vancomycin was d/c'd as GPC were felt to be contamination.) He 
completed a course of prednisone x 3 days and was started on 
Advair with prn levalbuterol and ipratropium nebulizers for 
potential COPD component. The patient was screened for 
tuberculosis with negative AFB smears x 3. Bilateral LENIs were 
negative for DVTs. Once echo results returned, SOB and cough 
were felt to be most likely cardiac in origin with acute 
systolic and diastolic dysfunction and decompensated valvular 
disease contributing. The  patient was effectively diuresed 
approximately >6 L over his hospital course with resolution of 
symptoms and no further oxygen requirement. Upon discharge, the 
patient was continued on cardiac medications, as below, as well 
as Advair inhaler.

# CAD: The patient had no known CAD on admission. There was no 
evidence of MI with negative cardiac biomarkers x 3 and no ST-T 
wave changes suggestive of ischemia. On ___ catheterization, 
the patient was found to have evidence of 1 vessel disease in 
the RCA as well as diffuse plaquing. There were no interventions 
done during catheterization, and there were no current 
indications for CABG. The patient was continued on medical 
management with ASA, ACE-I, beta-blocker, and statin therapy.

# Rhythm: The patient presented with newly diagnosed atrial 
fibrillation on this admission. Etiology was felt to be due to 
severe systolic as well as diastolic dysfunction and 
decompensated valvular disease. The patient was started on 
several agents for HR control, which were uptitrated to the 
following regimen with HR in mostly ___: metoprolol XL 300 
mg daily, diltiazem SR 120 mg daily (added for rate control 
despite the severe LV systolic heart failure), and digoxin 
(therapeutic at 0.9 on discharge). He was continued on a heparin 
drip for anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation; however, upon 
discharge decision was made not to pursue Coumadin therapy as 
patient was felt to be a poor candidate due to history of 
medication noncompliance.

# Congestive heart failure, acute, systolic and diastolic, EF 
25%: As mentioned above, the patient was found to have ___ 
mitral regurgitation, pulmonary hypertension, elevated R-sided 
pressures, and systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of 
the basal inferolateral wall and moderate hypokinesis of the 
remaining segments with EF 35% on ___ echo. Cath confirmed 
severe systolic LV dysfunction (global HK), mild diastolic 
biventricular dysfunction, 2+ mitral regurgitation, and LVEF 
25%. The patient was aggressively diuresed, as above, and was 
discharged on standing dose of Lasix. He was continued on 
beta-blocker, ACE-I, and CCB for BP and HR control. He was set 
up with Dr. ___ further ___ of heart failure as an 
outpatient.

# Hypertension: The patient presented with hypertension to 
160s/90s, which improved with diuresis, ACE-I, and uptitration 
of metoprolol and diltiazem. BPs upon discharge were 
100s-120s/50s-60s.

# Decompensated Mitral Valve Disease: ___ echo revealed 4+ 
mitral regurgitation of unclear etiology. The patient was 
treated medically while in house with resolution of symptoms. No 
plan was made for MV repair given that the patient was 
asymptomatic; however, MVR may be an option in the future if 
medical management fails.

# Pericardial effusion: The patient presented with an enlarged 
cardiac silhouette on admission CXR, with ___ echo revealing 
moderate sized effusion with mixed echogenic material. Effusion 
was of unclear etiology - inflmammation vs infection vs 
malignancy vs hemorrhagic. There were no echocardiographic signs 
of tamponade, no pulsus paradoxus on exam, and no evidence of 
tamponade on catheterization. There was no change in effusion 
size on serial echos. Decision was made not to perform 
pericardiocentesis as effusion seemed stable and the patient was 
asymptomatic. Malignant etiology of effusion was considered; 
however, this is less likely as pleural effusion analysis had 
negative cytology.

# Ophthalomology: The patient was blind in left eye (does not 
know etiology of this), and right eye had conjunctival injection 
on admission. Per the patient, injection was secondary to not 
using prednisiolone acetate 1% eye drops. Ophtalmology was 
consulted, and they recommended to use prednisilone acetate 1% 
in R eye QD to prevent rejection of corneal implant.

# Renal Cell Carcinoma: The patient has a history of RCC s/p 
right partial nephrectomy in ___. Creatinine remained stable 
throughout hospital course, near baseline of 1.0-1.2. The 
patient is followed by urology as an outpatient with no acute 
issues. As above, pleural effusion cytology was negative for 
malignant cells.

# Hematuria: The patient had brief episode of hematuria upon 
removal of Foley catheter, likely secondary to Foley trauma. He 
was briefly kept on CBI with subsequent resolution of hematuria.

# DMII: The patient has a history of diet-controlled DM, with 
recent HbA1c of 5.8%. He was continued on an ISS while inhouse, 
but demonstrated good glycemic control on a diabetic diet. He 
was discharged with a glucometer to check finger sticks 
regularly.

# BPH: The patient was continued on outpatient finasteride. 
Doxazosin was held due to low BP.

# Code: FULL (confirmed with patient and HCP - ___.

# COMMUNICATION: ___ (c: ___ is the 
first contact and ___ (c: ___ is second 
contact; daughter ___ ___.  ___ 
___, ___

The patient was discharged to home on ___ in good condition,

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with shortness of breath that, upon further 
workup, was thought to be due to heart failure. You had several 
echocardiograms (ultrasounds of the heart), and a cardiac 
catheterization which confirmed heart valve disease and poor 
pumping function of the heart (EF ~25%). 

You were started on several new medications for your heart 
disease, which you should continue to take DAILY as prescribed. 
These include metoprolol, diltiazem, and digoxin for heart rate 
control. Please take all medications as prescribed. Please 
attend all of your ___ appointments. You should continue 
to weigh yourself daily, if weight increases > 3lbs, you should 
call your PCP or cardiologist. You should adhere to a 2gm sodium

||startoftext|| The patient is an 85-year-old male who was admitted with shortness of breath and cough for several weeks. He has a history of hypertension, diet-controlled type II diabetes mellitus, and renal carcinoma, which was surgically treated with a partial right nephrectomy. He also has a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy, testicular microlithiasis, left eye blindness, and supraventricular tachycardia. The patient has allergies to morphine and has been experiencing worsening symptoms over the past month.

Upon admission, the patient's vital signs were stable, and he was noted to be in atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. He was treated with diltiazem and levoquin, and his symptoms improved. The patient's physical examination revealed coarse breath sounds with crackles at bilateral bases, and his chest X-ray showed severe cardiomegaly with bilateral pleural effusions.

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels, indicating cardiac damage, and his electrocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation with left axis deviation and left anterior fascicular block. His echocardiogram revealed mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy and moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction.

At discharge, the patient was prescribed medications including diltiazem, levoquin, and ASA, and he was advised to continue his medications as directed. ||endoftext||

and site covered with steri-strips and gauze with tegaderm.
Pt voiding without difficulty.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:55AM BLOOD WBC-8.5 RBC-4.29* Hgb-13.1* Hct-39.3* 
MCV-92 MCH-30.6 MCHC-33.3 RDW-12.6 Plt ___
___ 06:55AM BLOOD Glucose-120* UreaN-10 Creat-1.2 Na-140 
K-4.2 Cl-104 HCO3-31 AnGap-9
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Urology after undergoing robot-assisted 
laparoscopic left partial nephrectomy. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details. The patient received perioperative antibiotic 
prophylaxis. The patient was transferred to the floor from the 
PACU in stable condition.  On POD0, pain was well controlled on 
PCA, hydrated for urine output >30cc/hour, and provided with 
pneumoboots and incentive spirometry for prophylaxis. On POD1, 
the patient ambulated, restarted on home medications, basic 
metabolic panel and complete blood count were checked, pain 
control was transitioned from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was 
advanced to a clears/toast and crackers diet.  He did have some 
intermittent nausea but no vomiting on POD#1, which was well 
controlled with IV Zofran. On POD2, JP and urethral catheter 
(foley) were removed without difficulty and diet was advanced as 
tolerated. The remainder of the hospital course was relatively 
unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable condition, 
eating well, ambulating independently, voiding without 
difficulty, and with pain control on oral analgesics. On exam, 
incisions were clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of 
hematoma, collection or infection. The patient was given 
explicit instructions to follow-up in clinic with Dr. ___ in 
3 weeks.

 
Medications on Admission:
Dovonex
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H (every 
4 hours) as needed for fever.  
2. hydrocodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for break through pain only (score 
>4)  for 10 days.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) for 10 days: Stop if you develop diarrhea.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left kidney tumor

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable; Improved

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may shower but do not bathe, swim or immerse your incision.
 
-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up
 
-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.  
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.  Max daily 
Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also 
contains Tylenol (acetaminophen)
 
-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics
 
-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.
 
-Resume all of your home medications, except hold NSAID 
(aspirin,  and ibuprofen containing products such as advil & 
motrin,) until you see your urologist in follow-up
 
-Call your Urologist's office today to schedule/confirm your  
follow-up appointment in 3 weeks AND if you have any questions.
 
-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest ER
 
-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids

 
Followup Instructions:
___

He presented with intense abdominal bloating and pain radiating up into his chest, which was initially thought to be related to gallbladder disease but was later found to be suspicious for renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The patient underwent a robot-assisted laparoscopic left partial nephrectomy and was discharged in stable condition.

The patient has no significant past medical history, allergies, or adverse reactions. His diagnosis is left kidney tumor, and he was prescribed medications for pain management, including acetaminophen and hydrocodone-acetaminophen. He was also given instructions to follow up with his urologist in three weeks and to avoid certain activities, such as lifting or driving, until then.

The patient's discharge condition is stable and improved, and he was given instructions on how to care for his incision and manage his pain. ||endoftext||

She was admitted to the FICU for closer monitoring with improvement in her AGMA, resulting in transfer to medicine service. Ultimately the end of her hospitalization involved adjustments of her insulin and tube feeding regimen in order to obtain adequate glycemic control. # Anion gap metabolic acidosis # Respiratory acidosis # Lactic acidosis Patient presented with elevated lactate and AGMA. The suspect etiology was hypovolemia with improvement in lactate after 4L IVF. There was brief increase in lactate to 5 while in ICU but this was felt to be a spurious value with improvement after 1L of IVF. No evidence of ketones in urine to suggest DKA despite elevated glucose on presentation. Patient remained normotensive in FICU with improvement in AGMA and downtrend in lactate. Given stability, she was transferred to medicine service. She remained stable during her stay. Anion gap closed. # G-tube # Nutrition G-tube dislodged at outside facility. Surrounding erythema and tenderness. Plastic surgery and wound consult evaluated the site and were not concerned by its appearance. ___ was consulted for G-tube replacement and the existing tube was put back in place. Her tube feeds were restarted and advanced to goal. She was able to tolerate a full regular diet before discharge, but not quite at goal in terms of nutrition. As such her tube feeds are currently running continuous, and as a result her insulin regimen, outlined below, needed titration. Initially she was also placed on a pureed solid/thin liquid diet however this was advanced to soft solids/thin liquids before discharge. Once able to take sufficient PO intake, her tube feeds may be changed to Glucerna 1.2 @ 60 mL/hr x12hours w/ Juven TID ___ kcal, 50 g protein, 1590 mL free water), with monitoring of sodium and hydration status; adjust flushes prn. Her insulin will also need titration as her tube feeds are adjusted. # Concern for aspiration Several days ago was found to have food in her mouth. SLP recommending pureed solids with thin liquids, Meds crushed in applesauce via tube, 1:1 feeds. Patient very unhappy with this change, SLP re-evaluated and recommended soft solids with thin liquids. Hopefully this will help with augmentation of her PO intake. # Diabetes with hyperglycemia Glucose in the 500s on presentation. Started on insulin drip in ED, transitioned to SC. No ketones on UA, Beta-OH wnl. She was given her home glargine and sliding scale insulin, but had blood sugar 300s. ___ was consulted and increased her home Lantus and Humalog. Ultimately, likely due to continuous tube feeding rather than cycled, her insulin requirements went up significantly. Anticipate that as her PO feeds pick up and tube feeds become night time only/cycled, she could go back to her home insulin regimen (lantus 50 units BID, Humalog 16 units TIDWM). UA was positive, but urine culture was negative. Empiric ceftriaxone was started and stopped. # Abdominal wound # Abdominal pain Patient presented with abdominal pain. Exam notable for significant erythema surrounding ileostomy site and abdominal wound. CT scan without evidence for abdominal pain. At this point, suspect that her abdominal pain is related to the skin erythema. If/when BP starts to trend up, would resume these. HR around the ___, so could consider Metoprolol first, but might consider starting at lower doses than she had been on before. # h/o CVA w/ residual asphasia and right hemiplegia: patient was continued on her home baclofen, gabapentin, and lidocaine patch # Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease: patient was given duonebs and albuterol prn # Hyperlipidemia: continued atorvastatin # Depression: continued amitriptyline # Transaminitis Mild transaminitis recently. ||startoftext|| The patient is a 62-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for G-tube replacement. She has a complicated past medical history, including a stroke with residual deficits, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, depression, and a total colectomy with ileostomy. She was recently readmitted from another hospital for a small bowel obstruction and underwent an exploratory laparotomy, left ostomy, and reduction of internal hernia, but unfortunately, the abdominal graft failed.

Upon presentation to the emergency department, the patient complained of abdominal pain around her ileostomy site and PEG tube site, as well as burning with urination. She was found to have hyperglycemia, hyperkalemia, hypercalcemia, and lactic acidosis, with concern for intraabdominal infection. She was started on insulin and antibiotics, and a CT abdomen showed nonspecific areas of low attenuation in the liver, which may be due to hepatic infarction or geographic fat.

The patient underwent several procedures, including G-tube placement and replacement, and was prescribed several medications, including insulin, antibiotics, and pain medication. She was also diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and was treated with antibiotics.

The patient's physical exam revealed a soft abdomen with tenderness around the PEG tube site and ileostomy site, as well as a left thigh skin wound. Her neurological exam showed residual deficits from her stroke, including right-sided hemiplegia. ||endoftext||

Brief Hospital Course: The patient is a ___ y.o. M with h/o alcohol abouse, who presented with nausea and vomiting 1 day after his last drink. He was admitted for alcohol withdrawal. . # Alcohol Withdrawl: The patient has been admitted many times in the past for this. He was maintained on a CIWA scale and received 20 mg po Valium the night of admission. He had no hemodynamic instability or vomiting. He was given IV fluids, Zofran for nausea, thiamine, and folate. Both social work and addictions were consulted. He was referred to the ___ ___ clinic by our addiction consult. On ___ his LFTs were in the ___. He will need outpatient follow up of his LFTs. . # Thrombocytopenia: The patient had platelets in the low 100s, with baseline in the 300s-400s. Each time he has been admitted for withdrawl his platelets drop, often to the low 100s. He likely has splenic sequestration, accounting for this transient finding. He will need his CBC checked at follow up. . # Cough: The patient had no evidence of pneumonia clinically or on chest xray. Medications on Admission: Medications at time of d/c in ___ 1. PO three times a day for 1 weeks. Disp:*42 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*0* Discharge Medications: 1. Outpatient Lab Work CBC and AST, ALT, Alk Phos, Bilirubin Discharge Disposition: Home Discharge Diagnosis: Primary: Alcohol withdrawl . Secondary: Liver transaminitis Thrombocytopenia Discharge Condition: stable, no signs of alcohol withdrawl, heart rate in the ___. Discharge Instructions: You were seen for alcohol withdrawl. Brief Hospital Course:
======================
BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE
======================
___ year old psychiatrist with a history of obesity, 
hypertension, chronic right thalamic stroke, and achalasia who 
presented to the ___ ED as a transfer from ___ 
urgent care with dyspnea found to have acute HFrEF.

The patient was noted to have globally reduced systolic function 
with an EF of 34%. He received Lasix for diuresis. The patient 
ultimately went for left and right heart catheterization on 
___ which demonstrated normal filling pressures at a weight 
of 96.4 kg (212.52 lb) and 70% LAD lesion that was not thought 
to be contributory to global systolic dysfunction. No 
intervention was done at this time. Heart failure was ultimately 
thought to be secondary to hypertension with possible 
contribution from sleep disorder or stimulant medications. He 
was discharged to rehab and will follow up with Dr. ___ 
___ in cardiology in the coming weeks. 

========================
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
========================

#MEDICATION CHANGES:
[]New medications: Aspirin 81 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg 
nightly, lisinopril 5 mg daily, metoprolol succinate 25 mg 
daily, torsemide 20 mg daily
[]Changed medications: Amlodipine decreased to 5mg daily
[]Held medications: Sildenafil

#OBJECTIVE MEASURES:
[]Dry weight was determined to be: 96.4 kg (212.52 lb) -- at 
this weight the patient was euvolemic based on right heart 
catheterization filling pressures
[]Discharge Cr: 1.5

#REHAB:
[]Please continue to monitor weights and uptitrate torsemide as 
needed for goal dry weight as above. If patient weight 
increasing, please call outpatient cardiologist Dr. ___ 
___ at ___ to discuss plan for diuresis.
[]Please check renal function and electrolytes 3 days after 
discharge to confirm they are stable on current 
diuresis/medication regimen
[]Please monitor BPs and titrate antihypertensives accordingly

#PCP:
[]Patient was noted to have ___ breathing during his 
hospital stay, likely indicative of underlying sleep disorder. 
He should have a sleep study done as an outpatient for further 
workup, as this may be the potential contributing factor to his 
heart failure.
[]Please try to wean the patient off of stimulants and other 
psychiatric medications as tolerated as this may also be 
contributing to his cardiomyopathy.
[]Please check BPs, lytes, and renal function at next visit and 
titrate medications accordingly
[]Consider GI referral for ongoing management of achalasia 

#CARDIOLOGY:
[]Consider further workup for global hypokinesis and HFrEF
[]Would recommend outpatient CMR to evaluate for myocarditis or 
other etiology of systolic dysfunction
[]Please continue to titrate medications and consider additional 
medications for guideline directed management as blood pressures 
and renal function allows

#CODE: Full (presumed)
#CONTACT:
Name of health care proxy: ___ 
Relationship: wife 
Phone number: ___ 
Alternative: ___, younger brother (h) ___ 
___
Alternative: ___ ___ 

==========================
PROBLEM-BASED SUMMARY 
==========================

#Acute HFrEF
Presented with difficult volume exam, but presumed warm and wet, 
with reduced EF in a global pattern which could be hypertensive 
heart disease in the setting of essential hypertension and 
stimulant use. RHC shows patient euvolemic at weight of 96.4kg 
(212.52 lbs). Coronary cath noted 70% LAD lesion not thought to 
be contributory to global systolic dysfunction with some other 
nonocclusive disease, no intervention. As such, ischemic 
etiology unlikely. Pt denies EtOH use. Underlying sleep disorder 
may be a contributing factor. Treated with ASA 81, atorvastatin 
80 for CAD in addition to h/o stroke as below. Could consider 
outpatient Cardiac MR for further evaluation of systolic 
dysfunction including to evaluate for myocarditis or other 
etiologies.
Preload: torsemide 20 daily
Afterload: lisinopril 5mg daily, amlodipine 5mg daily
NHBK: metoprolol succinate 25mg daily

#Hypertension 
-Amlodipine 10mg daily initially held, but restarted at 5mg at 
discharge given persistent hypertension despite new 
antihypertensives
-Metoprolol and lisinopril as above 

___
No recent hypotension, contrast, or new medications. This may be 
a reflection of cardiorenal syndrome vs. progression to CKD from 
uncontrolled hypertension or obstructive uropathy from BPH. Cr 
downtrended to 1.3 on ___. Cr uptrend to 1.8 on ___, since
